this reverend holy friar, Our whole city is much bound to him.Your guests are coming: Lift up your countenance, as it were the day Of celebration of that nuptial which We two have sworn shall come.Pray, let us go.I stretch it out for that word 'broad;' which added to the goose, proves thee far and wide a broad goose.If thou neglect'st or dost unwillingly What I command, I'll rack thee with old cramps, Fill all thy bones with aches, make thee roar That beasts shall tremble at thy din.My lord, I hear the Marquis Dorset's fled To Richmond, in those parts beyond the sea Where he abides.Set it down.then I defy you, stars!O, what cause have I, Thine being but a moiety of my grief, To overgo thy plaints and drown thy cries!To answer that, I should confess to you.But sup them well and look unto them all: To-morrow I intend to hunt again.All men, I hope, live so.His friends still wrought reprieves for him: and, indeed, his fact, till now in the government of Lord Angelo, came not to an undoubtful proof.O bitter consequence, That Edward still should live!Take up the bastard; Take't up, I say; give't to thy crone.Exton, thy fierce hand Hath with the king's blood stain'd the king's own land.Give us some seats.the one affrights you, The other makes you proud.Sir, the year growing ancient, Not yet on summer's death, nor on the birth Of trembling winter, the fairest flowers o' the season Are our carnations and streak'd gillyvors, Which some call nature's bastards: of that kind Our rustic garden's barren; and I care not To get slips of them.If not, our swords shall plead it in the field.I thought of her, Even in these looks I made.Go, count thy way with sighs; I mine with groans.And take his thanks that yet hath nothing else.A thousand men have broke their fasts to-day, That ne'er shall dine unless thou yield the crown.Doth not rosemary and Romeo begin both with a letter?or shall I say, her uncle?O, be thou Dian, and let her be Kate; And then let Kate be chaste and Dian sportful!More to know Did never meddle with my thoughts.I crave your honour's pardon.I would they were barbarians--as they are, Though in Rome litter'd--not Romans--as they are not, Though calved i' the porch o' the Capitol-- Be gone; Put not your worthy rage into your tongue; One time will owe another.Come, therefore, let's about it speedily.What, art thou afraid?Alas, poor Clarence!Pray you, go to him.This gentleman, the prince's near ally, My very friend, hath got his mortal hurt In my behalf; my reputation stain'd With Tybalt's slander,--Tybalt, that an hour Hath been my kinsman!mocker!Good time of day unto my gracious lord!Thou canst not speak of that thou dost not feel: Wert thou as young as I, Juliet thy love, An hour but married, Tybalt murdered, Doting like me and like me banished, Then mightst thou speak, then mightst thou tear thy hair, And fall upon the ground, as I do now, Taking the measure of an unmade grave.Hath love in thy old blood no living fire?Some say he shall be stoned; but that death is too soft for him, say I draw our throne into a sheep-cote!Thou show'st a noble vessel: what's thy name?For which I do discharge you of your office: Give up your keys.I humbly thank you.Subjects may challenge nothing of their sovereigns; But if an humble prayer may prevail, I then crave pardon of your majesty.Nay!I pray thee, gentle keeper, stay by me; My soul is heavy, and I fain would sleep.To do them good, I would sustain some harm.But, O, poor souls, Come you to seek the lamb here of the fox?Let him alone; He did inform the truth: but for our gentlemen, The common file--a plague!And what makes robbers bold but too much lenity?But yesternight, my lord, she and that friar, I saw them at the prison: a saucy friar, A very scurvy fellow.how mean you that?O the gods!O monstrous fault, to harbour such a thought!Warwick, this is some post to us or thee.If I may be bold, Tell me, I beseech you, which is the readiest way To the house of Signior Baptista Minola?He has our voices, sir.hang not on my garments.Well done, my lord.That's worthily As any ear can hear.Hold, take these keys, and fetch more spices, nurse.news, old news, and such news as you never heard of!He's one honest enough: would all the rest were so!what?The wars for my money.Come on, lay it by: and let's first see moe ballads; we'll buy the other things anon.Happy return be to your royal grace!My lord, I would that Thursday were to-morrow.Too early seen unknown, and known too late!The cockerel.husband!But since correction lieth in those hands Which made the fault that we cannot correct, Put we our quarrel to the will of heaven; Who, when they see the hours ripe on earth, Will rain hot vengeance on offenders' heads.But I bethink me what a weary way From Ravenspurgh to Cotswold will be found In Ross and Willoughby, wanting your company, Which, I protest, hath very much beguiled The tediousness and process of my travel: But theirs is sweetened with the hope to have The present benefit which I possess; And hope to joy is little less in joy Than hope enjoy'd: by this the weary lords Shall make their way seem short, as mine hath done By sight of what I have, your noble company.If it Please your honour, I am the poor duke's constable, and my name is Elbow: I do lean upon justice, sir, and do bring in here before your good honour two notorious benefactors.By what?Your belly's answer?Therefore let him be consul: the gods give him joy, and make him good friend to the people!No, I'll not meddle.No money, on my faith, but the gleek; I will give you the minstrel.My leisure serves me, pensive daughter, now.Consenting to the safeguard of your honour, I thought your marriage fit; else imputation, For that he knew you, might reproach your life And choke your good to come; for his possessions, Although by confiscation they are ours, We do instate and widow you withal, To buy you a better husband.When you have done, repair to Crosby Place.No, indeed.Peace, ho!Ay.Why that's some comfort.Sure, it is no sin, Or of the deadly seven, it is the least.Do you not hear him?How ceremonious, solemn and unearthly It was i' the offering!shall I believe That unsubstantial death is amorous, And that the lean abhorred monster keeps Thee here in dark to be his paramour?But that still use of grief makes wild grief tame, My tongue should to thy ears not name my boys Till that my nails were anchor'd in thine eyes; And I, in such a desperate bay of death, Like a poor bark, of sails and tackling reft, Rush all to pieces on thy rocky bosom.Nothing but bonfires: the oracle is fulfilled; the king's daughter is found: such a deal of wonder is broken out within this hour that ballad-makers cannot be able to express it.Then say at once what thou dost know in this.Ah, Montague, If thou be there, sweet brother, take my hand.let's assist them, For our case is as theirs.Most strange, but yet most truly, will I speak: That Angelo's forsworn; is it not strange?there's none else by: Richard loves Richard; that is, I am I.All the regions Do smilingly revolt; and who resist Are mock'd for valiant ignorance, And perish constant fools.Off with my boots, you rogues!This you may know And so deliver, I am put to sea With her whom here I cannot hold on shore; And most opportune to our need I have A vessel rides fast by, but not prepared For this design.Even he, your wife, this lady, and myself, Are suitors to you.A French crown more.Yet am I arm'd against the worst can happen; And haste is needful in this desperate case.And you shall pay well for 'em.Nay, prithee, dispatch: the gentleman is half flayed already.Come on, I say; and first begin with her.Poor soul, thy face is much abused with tears.He hath songs for man or woman, of all sizes; no milliner can so fit his customers with gloves: he has the prettiest love-songs for maids; so without bawdry, which is strange; with such delicate burthens of dildos and fadings, 'jump her and thump her;' and where some stretch-mouthed rascal would, as it were, mean mischief and break a foul gap into the matter, he makes the maid to answer 'Whoop, do me no harm, good man;' puts him off, slights him, with 'Whoop, do me no harm, good man.'Speak not for him.Farewell.There, Coriolanus.Tybalt is gone, and Romeo banished; Romeo that kill'd him, he is banished.3 KING HENRY VI Great lords, wise men ne'er sit and wail their loss, But cheerly seek how to redress their harms.His is the right, and therefore pardon me.I will tell you If you'll bestow a small--of what you have little-- Patience awhile, you'll hear the belly's answer.Why, 'tis good; it is the right of it; it must be so: ever your fresh whore and your powdered bawd: an unshunned consequence; it must be so.Provost, how came it Claudio was beheaded At an unusual hour?Here comes the lady: O, so light a foot Will ne'er wear out the everlasting flint: A lover may bestride the gossamer That idles in the wanton summer air, And yet not fall; so light is vanity.Be Duke of Lancaster; let him be king.prithee, woman,-- Now the red pestilence strike all trades in Rome, And occupations perish!We have very oft awaked him, as if to carry him to execution, and showed him a seeming warrant for it: it hath not moved him at all.Though this island seem to be desert,-- Ha, ha, ha!Thursday is near; lay hand on heart, advise: An you be mine, I'll give you to my friend; And you be not, hang, beg, starve, die in the streets, For, by my soul, I'll ne'er acknowledge thee, Nor what is mine shall never do thee good: Trust to't, bethink you; I'll not be forsworn.Nay, friar, I am a kind of burr; I shall stick.I promised we would be contributors And bear his charging of wooing, whatsoe'er.this do I beg of God, When I am cold in zeal to yours.But, master mayor, if Henry be your king, Yet Edward at the least is Duke of York.Sir John and Sir Hugh Mortimer, mine uncles, You are come to Sandal in a happy hour; The army of the queen mean to besiege us.for any good That I myself have done unto myself?Happily You something know; yet I believe there comes No countermand; no such example have we: Besides, upon the very siege of justice Lord Angelo hath to the public ear Profess'd the contrary.O, a cherubim Thou wast that did preserve me.Nay, more, Some parcels of their power are forth already, And only hitherward.Welcome, Sir John!O love!'They have press'd a power, but it is not known Whether for east or west: the dearth is great; The people mutinous; and it is rumour'd, Cominius, Marcius your old enemy, Who is of Rome worse hated than of you, And Titus Lartius, a most valiant Roman, These three lead on this preparation Whither 'tis bent: most likely 'tis for you: Consider of it.'Had I not Four or five women once that tended me?Carnally, she says.What, are they dead?Too well, too well thou tell'st a tale so ill.Then, by myself-- Thyself thyself misusest.Villain, thy own hand yields thy death's instrument.We have made inquiry of you; and we hear Such goodness of your justice, that our soul Cannot but yield you forth to public thanks, Forerunning more requital.Now, messenger, what letters or what news From France?I tell thee, I, that thou hast marr'd her gown.Oh, he is young and his minority Is put unto the trust of Richard Gloucester, A man that loves not me, nor none of you.Who, not the duke?The guilt of conscience take thou for thy labour, But neither my good word nor princely favour: With Cain go wander through shades of night, And never show thy head by day nor light.Now am I seated as my soul delights, Having my country's peace and brothers' loves.Force her hence.But, tell me, is young George Stanley living?What, ho!stopping the career Of laughing with a sigh?--a note infallible Of breaking honesty--horsing foot on foot?Come, is the bride ready to go to church?My child, my only life, Revive, look up, or I will die with thee!Come; I would your cambric were sensible as your finger, that you might leave pricking it for pity.Camillo has betray'd me; Whose honour and whose honesty till now Endured all weathers.what then?He was drunk then, my lord: it can be no better.Stand all apart, And show fair duty to his majesty.Your request?Call it so.How well my comfort is revived by this!and more unlikely Than to accomplish twenty golden crowns!Did I forget that by the house of York My father came untimely to his death?By this at Daintry, with a puissant troop.Discharge my followers: let them hence away, From Richard's night to Bolingbroke's fair day.Bear hence this body and attend our will: Mercy but murders, pardoning those that kill.Ay, mistress bride, hath that awaken'd you?Thy fault our law calls death; but the kind prince, Taking thy part, hath rush'd aside the law, And turn'd that black word death to banishment: This is dear mercy, and thou seest it not.We are less afraid to be drowned than thou art.Let me be Duke of Clarence, George of Gloucester; For Gloucester's dukedom is too ominous.Who shall begin?Not according to the prayer of the people, for they love not Marcius.Dove-feather'd raven!It is, my lord.She hangs about his neck: If she pertain to life let her speak too.Marry, and shall.Be confident to speak, Northumberland: We three are but thyself; and, speaking so, Thy words are but as thoughts; therefore, be bold.In troth, I think she would.It shall be done, my sovereign, with all speed.No less!Come, take your flowers: Methinks I play as I have seen them do In Whitsun pastorals: sure this robe of mine Does change my disposition.Art thou his father?Slave, I have set my life upon a cast, And I will stand the hazard of the die: I think there be six Richmonds in the field; Five have I slain to-day instead of him.I'll mountebank their loves, Cog their hearts from them, and come home beloved Of all the trades in Rome.Dazzle mine eyes, or do I see three suns?O cursed wretch, That knew'st this was the prince, and wouldst adventure To mingle faith with him!What is granted them?My gracious sovereign, now in Devonshire, As I by friends am well advertised, Sir Edward Courtney, and the haughty prelate Bishop of Exeter, his brother there, With many more confederates, are in arms.Nothing that I respect, my gracious lord.Now, good Aufidius, Were you in my stead, would you have heard A mother less?3 KING HENRY VI Thus far our fortune keeps an upward course, And we are graced with wreaths of victory.Bid them home: Say their great enemy is gone, and they Stand in their ancient strength.The sense of death is most in apprehension; And the poor beetle, that we tread upon, In corporal sufferance finds a pang as great As when a giant dies.Content you, gentlemen: I will compound this strife: 'Tis deeds must win the prize; and he of both That can assure my daughter greatest dower Shall have my Bianca's love.stay, dog, for thou shalt hear me.How now there!They seek revenge and therefore will not yield.Well, let us to the king: there is that in this fardel will make him scratch his beard.The fringed curtains of thine eye advance And say what thou seest yond.A certain number, Though thanks to all, must I select from all: the rest Shall bear the business in some other fight, As cause will be obey'd.Nor I, nor any But one that's here, and that's himself, for he The sacred honour of himself, his queen's, His hopeful son's, his babe's, betrays to slander, Whose sting is sharper than the sword's; and will not-- For, as the case now stands, it is a curse He cannot be compell'd to't--once remove The root of his opinion, which is rotten As ever oak or stone was sound.It is now apparent?Though Marcius earned them not, and all his faults To Marcius shall be honours, though indeed In aught he merit not.And a half, sir.Here's such ado to make no stain a stain As passes colouring.Those eyes of thine from mine have drawn salt tears, Shamed their aspect with store of childish drops: These eyes that never shed remorseful tear, No, when my father York and Edward wept, To hear the piteous moan that Rutland made When black-faced Clifford shook his sword at him; Nor when thy warlike father, like a child, Told the sad story of my father's death, And twenty times made pause to sob and weep, That all the standers-by had wet their cheeks Like trees bedash'd with rain: in that sad time My manly eyes did scorn an humble tear; And what these sorrows could not thence exhale, Thy beauty hath, and made them blind with weeping.Believe me, this may be: he promised to meet me two hours since, and he was ever precise in promise-keeping.Alas poor York!He cannot choose.I'll pay that doctrine, or else die in debt.My husband is on earth, my faith in heaven; How shall that faith return again to earth, Unless that husband send it me from heaven By leaving earth?Thus we set on, Camillo, to the sea-side.Why, is not this better now than groaning for love?Edward from Belgia, With hasty Germans and blunt Hollanders, Hath pass'd in safety through the narrow seas, And with his troops doth march amain to London; And many giddy people flock to him.What noise is here?It may be right; but you are i' the wrong To speak before your time.Patience is stale, and I am weary of it.I'll be with you at your sheep-shearing too: if I make not this cheat bring out another and the shearers prove sheep, let me be unrolled and my name put in the book of virtue!I do demand, If you submit you to the people's voices, Allow their officers and are content To suffer lawful censure for such faults As shall be proved upon you?Camillo, Preserver of my father, now of me, The medicine of our house, how shall we do?Let's see for means: O mischief, thou art swift To enter in the thoughts of desperate men!I am ashamed: does not the stone rebuke me For being more stone than it?I cannot tell; I fear 'tis choleric.Here.Come, come, thou art as hot a Jack in thy mood as any in Italy, and as soon moved to be moody, and as soon moody to be moved.I prithee go and get me some repast; I care not what, so it be wholesome food.How do you all at Verona?We shall be short in our provision: 'Tis now near night.Not since widow Dido's time.For shame, thou helding of a devilish spirit, Why dost thou wrong her that did ne'er wrong thee?My lord, will't please you to fall to?But thy vile race, Though thou didst learn, had that in't which good natures Could not abide to be with; therefore wast thou Deservedly confined into this rock, Who hadst deserved more than a prison.Was ever king so grieved for subjects' woe?Though I am satisfied and need no more Than what I know, yet shall the oracle Give rest to the minds of others, such as he Whose ignorant credulity will not Come up to the truth.This interchange of love, I here protest, Upon my part shall be unviolable.Do, Paulina; For this affliction has a taste as sweet As any cordial comfort.The hand that hath made you fair hath made you good: the goodness that is cheap in beauty makes beauty brief in goodness; but grace, being the soul of your complexion, shall keep the body of it ever fair.O day!'Tis better using France than trusting France: Let us be back'd with God and with the seas Which He hath given for fence impregnable, And with their helps only defend ourselves; In them and in ourselves our safety lies.Make haste; the hour of death is expiate.Why, sir, what 'cerns it you if I wear pearl and gold?who's at home?Sir, most heedfully.This is unlikely: He and Aufidius can no more atone Than violentest contrariety.He turns away: Down, ladies; let us shame him with our knees.Your right depends not on his life or death.we'll to dinner, thither.I am none, by this good light.would thy best friends did know How it doth grieve me that thy head is here!Choler!Neither the king, nor he that loves him best, The proudest he that holds up Lancaster, Dares stir a wing, if Warwick shake his bells.I know not what to say: but give me your hands; God send you joy, Petruchio!So please you, this friar hath been with him, and advised him for the entertainment of death.Beseech your highness, My women may be with me; for you see My plight requires it.I tell thee, Catesby-- What, my lord?If it?But, soft!You are the fount that makes small brooks to flow: Now stops thy spring; my sea sha$l suck them dry, And swell so much the higher by their ebb.I do assure thee, father, so it is.Bring forth that fatal screech-owl to our house, That nothing sung but death to us and ours: Now death shall stop his dismal threatening sound, And his ill-boding tongue no more shall speak.Give me my long sword, ho!Come, muster men: my counsel is my shield; We must be brief when traitors brave the field.Condemned villain, I do apprehend thee: Obey, and go with me; for thou must die.I do not, sir.Have done!Will you tell me that?Hear me one word; Beseech you, tribunes, hear me but a word.Dighton and Forrest, whom I did suborn To do this ruthless piece of butchery, Although they were flesh'd villains, bloody dogs, Melting with tenderness and kind compassion Wept like two children in their deaths' sad stories.Mine boy?think'st thou that we fear them?Come, sirrah, let's away.O my love!Farewell, farewell!You logger-headed and unpolish'd grooms!Lord Angelo dukes it well in his absence; he puts transgression to 't.And he shall pardon thee these outrages.I told your majesty as much before: This proveth Edward's love and Warwick's honesty.Blood, thou art blood: Let's write good angel on the devil's horn: 'Tis not the devil's crest.But in this troublous time what's to be done?Say that again.And so, proud-hearted Warwick, I defy thee, And to my brother turn my blushing cheeks.Reproach and dissolution hangeth over him.'Faith, some certain dregs of conscience are yet within me.And yet I know not how to get the crown, For many lives stand between me and home: And I,--like one lost in a thorny wood, That rends the thorns and is rent with the thorns, Seeking a way and straying from the way; Not knowing how to find the open air, But toiling desperately to find it out,-- Torment myself to catch the English crown: And from that torment I will free myself, Or hew my way out with a bloody axe.With patience, noble lord, as prisoners must: But I shall live, my lord, to give them thanks That were the cause of my imprisonment.The earth that's nature's mother is her tomb; What is her burying grave that is her womb, And from her womb children of divers kind We sucking on her natural bosom find, Many for many virtues excellent, None but for some and yet all different.As little joy, my lord, as you suppose You should enjoy, were you this country's king, As little joy may you suppose in me.Were I as patient as the midnight sleep, By Jove, 'twould be my mind!Meaning, to court'sy.The son of Clarence have I pent up close; His daughter meanly have I match'd in marriage; The sons of Edward sleep in Abraham's bosom, And Anne my wife hath bid the world good night.Words against me?You are too blunt: go to it orderly.I hear that news, my lord.Come on, brave soldiers: doubt not of the day, And, that once gotten, doubt not of large pay.With child, perhaps?to the gaol with him!A nest of traitors!Where's Richard gone?Yes, I am: Then fly.Fie, fie, fie!Ay, sir; but she will none, she gives you thanks.Let a guard Attend us through the city.Women are soft, mild, pitiful and flexible; Thou stern, obdurate, flinty, rough, remorseless.Was ever father so bemoan'd his son?I am hurt.I' fecks!How now, my headstrong!Some say the lark makes sweet division; This doth not so, for she divideth us: Some say the lark and loathed toad change eyes, O, now I would they had changed voices too!Well, then, imprison him: if imprisonment be the due of a bawd, why, 'tis his right: bawd is he doubtless, and of antiquity too; bawd-born.O heavens!O that I had him, With six Aufidiuses, or more, his tribe, To use my lawful sword!'Faith, my lord.It's supper-time, my lord; It's nine o'clock.Faith, look you, one cannot tell how to say that: for the defence of a town, our general is excellent.Come, let us to our holy task again.in good time: let him that moved you hither Remove you hence: I knew you at the first You were a moveable.Here comes Bohemia.Are you content to stay?My love and fear glued many friends to thee; And, now I fall, thy tough commixture melts.From off the gates of York fetch down the head, Your father's head, which Clifford placed there; Instead whereof let this supply the room: Measure for measure must be answered.Did you see the meeting of the two kings?here, sir!Come, blow thy blast.Then is there here one Master Caper, at the suit of Master Three-pile the mercer, for some four suits of peach-coloured satin, which now peaches him a beggar.You, that are thus so tender o'er his follies, Will never do him good, not one of you.If not, that, I being queen, you bow like subjects, Yet that, by you deposed, you quake like rebels?On pain of death, no person be so bold Or daring-hardy as to touch the lists, Except the marshal and such officers Appointed to direct these fair designs.Thou art a widow, and thou hast some children; And, by God's mother, I, being but a bachelor, Have other some: why, 'tis a happy thing To be the father unto many sons.The bay-trees in our country are all wither'd And meteors fright the fixed stars of heaven; The pale-faced moon looks bloody on the earth And lean-look'd prophets whisper fearful change; Rich men look sad and ruffians dance and leap, The one in fear to lose what they enjoy, The other to enjoy by rage and war: These signs forerun the death or fall of kings.who is there?'Hic ibat,' as I told you before, 'Simois,' I am Lucentio, 'hic est,' son unto Vincentio of Pisa, 'Sigeia tellus,' disguised thus to get your love; 'Hic steterat,' and that Lucentio that comes a-wooing, 'Priami,' is my man Tranio, 'regia,' bearing my port, 'celsa senis,' that we might beguile the old pantaloon.He has it now, and by his looks methink 'Tis warm at 's heart.Be it as your wisdom will.For I ne'er saw true beauty till this night.Then set before my face the Lord Aumerle.Marry, I will, let them play it.My wife comes foremost; then the honour'd mould Wherein this trunk was framed, and in her hand The grandchild to her blood.wherefore?I hate the word, As I hate hell, all Montagues, and thee: Have at thee, coward!is sportful Edward come?What love, think'st thou, I sue so much to get?This is a happier and more comely time Than when these fellows ran about the streets, Crying confusion.O, he is wounded; I thank the gods for't.Especially in pride.I am afeard.Fetch us in fuel; and be quick, thou'rt best, To answer other business.What must the king do now?traitor!My liege, I'll knock once more to summon them.Shall we thither and with our company piece the rejoicing?But what say you to Thursday?I spy comfort; I cry bail.Not in my house, Lucentio; for, you know, Pitchers have ears, and I have many servants: Besides, old Gremio is hearkening still; And happily we might be interrupted.And thus I took the vantage of those few, 'Thanks, gentle citizens and friends,' quoth I; 'This general applause and loving shout Argues your wisdoms and your love to Richard:' And even here brake off, and came away.The shadow of my sorrow!Nurse?They that stabb'd Caesar shed no blood at all, Did not offend, nor were not worthy blame, If this foul deed were by to equal it: He was a man; this, in respect, a child: And men ne'er spend their fury on a child.My Lord of Buckingham, if my weak oratory Can from his mother win the Duke of York, Anon expect him here; but if she be obdurate To mild entreaties, God in heaven forbid We should infringe the holy privilege Of blessed sanctuary!My brave spirit!And 'twas time for him too, I'll warrant him that: an he had stayed by him, I would not have been so fidiused for all the chests in Corioli, and the gold that's in them.What devil art thou, that dost torment me thus?'Twas I that gave the kingdom to thy brother.If therefore you dare trust my honesty, That lies enclosed in this trunk which you Shall bear along impawn'd, away to-night!Fear comes upon me: O, much I fear some ill unlucky thing.'Tis pity of him.But he's deceived; we are in readiness.ah, my tender babes!Sooth, when I was young And handed love as you do, I was wont To load my she with knacks: I would have ransack'd The pedlar's silken treasury and have pour'd it To her acceptance; you have let him go And nothing marted with him.I understand the business, I hear it: to have an open ear, a quick eye, and a nimble hand, is necessary for a cut-purse; a good nose is requisite also, to smell out work for the other senses.Thy sin's not accidental, but a trade.No, never such an oath; nor will not now.come forth!I am Christophero Sly; call not me 'honour' nor 'lordship:' I ne'er drank sack in my life; and if you give me any conserves, give me conserves of beef: ne'er ask me what raiment I'll wear; for I have no more doublets than backs, no more stockings than legs, nor no more shoes than feet; nay, sometimes more feet than shoes, or such shoes as my toes look through the over-leather.It shall be speeded well.Let me pass The same I am, ere ancient'st order was Or what is now received: I witness to The times that brought them in; so shall I do To the freshest things now reigning and make stale The glistering of this present, as my tale Now seems to it.This, and Saint George to boot!Go, then; for 'tis in vain To seek him here that means not to be found.Why looks your grace so heavily today?Judge.What else?No, indeed, will I not, Pompey; it is not the wear.And then with kind embracements, tempting kisses, And with declining head into his bosom, Bid him shed tears, as being overjoy'd To see her noble lord restored to health, Who for this seven years hath esteem'd him No better than a poor and loathsome beggar: And if the boy have not a woman's gift To rain a shower of commanded tears, An onion will do well for such a shift, Which in a napkin being close convey'd Shall in despite enforce a watery eye.He'll never hear him.I'll bring him to you.You are sent for to the Capitol.Catesby, we come.What's this?I'll go along with you.Tranio, be so, because Lucentio loves: And let me be a slave, to achieve that maid Whose sudden sight hath thrall'd my wounded eye.The former agents, if they did complain, What could the belly answer?Condition!Wife, go you to her ere you go to bed; Acquaint her here of my son Paris' love; And bid her, mark you me, on Wednesday next-- But, soft!By this account then Margaret may win him; For she's a woman to be pitied much: Her sighs will make a battery in his breast; Her tears will pierce into a marble heart; The tiger will be mild whiles she doth mourn; And Nero will be tainted with remorse, To hear and see her plaints, her brinish tears.That honourable day shall ne'er be seen.Nay, keep your place.Let us withdraw together, And we may soon our satisfaction have Touching that point.what a head have I!Montague!Chop off his head, man; somewhat we will do: And, look, when I am king, claim thou of me The earldom of Hereford, and the moveables Whereof the king my brother stood possess'd.Wouldst thou withdraw it?See, your guests approach: Address yourself to entertain them sprightly, And let's be red with mirth.Direct not him whose way himself will choose: 'Tis breath thou lack'st, and that breath wilt thou lose.As willingly as e'er I came from school.Sweet rest his soul!'Tribunes!'Sweet Isabel, take my part; Lend me your knees, and all my life to come I'll lend you all my life to do you service.I can add colours to the chameleon, Change shapes with Proteus for advantages, And set the murderous Machiavel to school.Fear me not.Who?Alas, poor soul!My lord, your son was gone before I came.I thank you, good friend Lucio.For what, I pray thee?Masters, lay down your weapons.I should to Plashy too; But time will not permit: all is uneven, And every thing is left at six and seven.Where it seems best unto your royal self.Should I now meet my father, He would not call me son.Who taught you this?Master, it is no time to chide you now; Affection is not rated from the heart: If love have touch'd you, nought remains but so, 'Redime te captum quam queas minimo.'But thou art neither like thy sire nor dam; But like a foul mis-shapen stigmatic, Mark'd by the destinies to be avoided, As venom toads, or lizards' dreadful stings.What train?If it be honest you have spoke, you have courage to maintain it: I am bound to call upon you; and, I pray you, your name?We did observe.Ah, that same pale hard-hearted wench, that Rosaline.Bid my guard watch; leave me.Ay, but thou canst do what I mean to ask.What an exchange had this been without boot!Myself and my good cousin Buckingham Will to your mother, to entreat of her To meet you at the Tower and welcome you.Well, well, sir, well.There's fire ready; and therefore, good Grumio, the news.Accursed, unhappy, wretched, hateful day!How now, old lad?Sirrah, no more!Not within, sir.Thank you, good Pompey; and, in requital of your prophecy, hark you: I advise you, let me not find you before me again upon any complaint whatsoever; no, not for dwelling where you do: if I do, Pompey, I shall beat you to your tent, and prove a shrewd Caesar to you; in plain dealing, Pompey, I shall have you whipt: so, for this time, Pompey, fare you well.The boy gives warning something doth approach.I have trusted thee, Camillo, With all the nearest things to my heart, as well My chamber-councils, wherein, priest-like, thou Hast cleansed my bosom, I from thee departed Thy penitent reform'd: but we have been Deceived in thy integrity, deceived In that which seems so.what, dost thou make us minstrels?Come, bitter conduct, come, unsavoury guide!Ay, fool; is that a shame?You may say it, but not swear it.Why, it contains no king?These are news indeed!Could you not have told him As you were lesson'd, when he had no power, But was a petty servant to the state, He was your enemy, ever spake against Your liberties and the charters that you bear I' the body of the weal; and now, arriving A place of potency and sway o' the state, If he should still malignantly remain Fast foe to the plebeii, your voices might Be curses to yourselves?That gallant spirit hath aspired the clouds, Which too untimely here did scorn the earth.There was a time when all the body's members Rebell'd against the belly, thus accused it: That only like a gulf it did remain I' the midst o' the body, idle and unactive, Still cupboarding the viand, never bearing Like labour with the rest, where the other instruments Did see and hear, devise, instruct, walk, feel, And, mutually participate, did minister Unto the appetite and affection common Of the whole body.Neither, fair saint, if either thee dislike.O, that thou wouldst as well afford a grave As thou canst yield a melancholy seat!'Tis done.The very trick on't.Thou art a traitor and a miscreant, Too good to be so and too bad to live, Since the more fair and crystal is the sky, The uglier seem the clouds that in it fly.Greater he shall not be; if he serve God, We'll serve Him too and be his fellow so: Revolt our subjects?I tell you, sir, she bears me fair in hand.Princes and noble lords, What answer shall I make to this base man?How if it come to thee again?Your own desert!Four lagging winters and four wanton springs End in a word: such is the breath of kings.Why, just, my lord, and that is Angelo, Who thinks he knows that he ne'er knew my body, But knows he thinks that he knows Isabel's.God save your majesty!Pluck up thy spirits; look cheerfully upon me.In God's name and the king's, say who thou art And why thou comest thus knightly clad in arms, Against what man thou comest, and what thy quarrel: Speak truly, on thy knighthood and thy oath; As so defend thee heaven and thy valour!You are looked for and called for, asked for and sought for, in the great chamber.O, stand up blest!Justice, O royal duke!Twenty crowns!But say, I pray, what nobleman is that That with the king here resteth in his tent?ah, what a fault were this!Then be your eyes the witness of this ill: See how I am bewitch'd; behold mine arm Is, like a blasted sapling, wither'd up: And this is Edward's wife, that monstrous witch, Consorted with that harlot strumpet Shore, That by their witchcraft thus have marked me.What brings thee to France?Be patient, gentle queen, and I will stay.Look on the boy; And let his manly face, which promiseth Successful fortune, steel thy melting heart To hold thine own and leave thine own with him.No, pray thee.O gentle Romeo, If thou dost love, pronounce it faithfully: Or if thou think'st I am too quickly won, I'll frown and be perverse an say thee nay, So thou wilt woo; but else, not for the world.Would I had never Married my daughter there!Son, I'll be your half, Bianca comes.Heavy matters!is he not stupid With age and altering rheums?At thy good heart's oppression.for death doth hold us in pursuit.Sir, give him head: I know he'll prove a jade.They say, best men are moulded out of faults; And, for the most, become much more the better For being a little bad: so may my husband.England hath long been mad, and scarr'd herself; The brother blindly shed the brother's blood, The father rashly slaughter'd his own son, The son, compell'd, been butcher to the sire: All this divided York and Lancaster, Divided in their dire division, O, now, let Richmond and Elizabeth, The true succeeders of each royal house, By God's fair ordinance conjoin together!Think you so?I'll be hanged first: thou art deceived in me, friar.Caius Marcius Coriolanus!Northumberland, say thus the king returns: His noble cousin is right welcome hither; And all the number of his fair demands Shall be accomplish'd without contradiction: With all the gracious utterance thou hast Speak to his gentle hearing kind commends.a bawd, a wicked bawd!How now!My lord, I had forgot to tell your lordship, To-day, as I came by, I called there; But I shall grieve you to report the rest.Tend to the master's whistle.Peace, impudent and shameless Warwick, peace, Proud setter up and puller down of kings!I neither know it nor can learn of him.Plain and not honest is too harsh a style.Will you pluck your sword out of his pitcher by the ears?Ay.Tybalt, the kinsman of old Capulet, Hath sent a letter to his father's house.'Do it presently.'The curse my noble father laid on thee, When thou didst crown his warlike brows with paper And with thy scorns drew'st rivers from his eyes, And then, to dry them, gavest the duke a clout Steep'd in the faultless blood of pretty Rutland-- His curses, then from bitterness of soul Denounced against thee, are all fall'n upon thee; And God, not we, hath plagued thy bloody deed.No, no; let carman whip his jade: The valiant heart is not whipt out of his trade.Sirrah, here's a fellow will help you to-morrow in your execution.Why let it strike?Nay, but hear me.Benedicite!Why, may one ask?Your purse is not hot enough to purchase your spice.Let me see: every 'leven wether tods; every tod yields pound and odd shilling; fifteen hundred shorn.Thou villain Capulet,--Hold me not, let me go.Trembled and shook; for why, he stamp'd and swore, As if the vicar meant to cozen him.Foul wrinkled witch, what makest thou in my sight?My Lord!Come, Hastings, help me to my closet.Once more, what news?Not Romeo, prince, he was Mercutio's friend; His fault concludes but what the law should end, The life of Tybalt.What, art thou drawn among these heartless hinds?Ay, and make't manifest where she has lived, Or how stolen from the dead.Still-waking sleep, that is not what it is!the thrush and the jay, Are summer songs for me and my aunts, While we lie tumbling in the hay.My dagger, little cousin?At least two glasses.There let him sink, and be the seas on him!He says he loves my daughter: I think so too; for never gazed the moon Upon the water as he'll stand and read As 'twere my daughter's eyes: and, to be plain.And trust me, love, in my eye so do you: Dry sorrow drinks our blood.What then?No; then he will say 'twas done cowardly, when he wakes.Slain, sir, doubtless.Cousin of Exeter, frowns, words and threats Shall be the war that Henry means to use.Dost thou not laugh?Commend me to thy brother, Edmund York.Why, then the world and all that's in't is nothing; The covering sky is nothing; Bohemia nothing; My wife is nothing; nor nothing have these nothings, If this be nothing.Yes, an't please you, sir.Why who's so gross, That seeth not this palpable device?What news abroad, friar?A grievous burthen was thy birth to me; Tetchy and wayward was thy infancy; Thy school-days frightful, desperate, wild, and furious, Thy prime of manhood daring, bold, and venturous, Thy age confirm'd, proud, subdued, bloody, treacherous, More mild, but yet more harmful, kind in hatred: What comfortable hour canst thou name, That ever graced me in thy company?Thy gown?Thy life answer!Tell me, good grandam, is our father dead?Yes, as I love the woman that wrong'd him.Call forth an officer.Our king, being ready to leap out of himself for joy of his found daughter, as if that joy were now become a loss, cries 'O, thy mother, thy mother!'Yet, for I loved thee, Take this along; I writ it for thy sake And would have rent it.Love is a smoke raised with the fume of sighs; Being purged, a fire sparkling in lovers' eyes; Being vex'd a sea nourish'd with lovers' tears: What is it else?Lords appellants, Your differences shall all rest under gage Till we assign you to your days of trial.Ah, what an unkind hour Is guilty of this lamentable chance!If you refuse it,--as, in love and zeal, Loath to depose the child, Your brother's son; As well we know your tenderness of heart And gentle, kind, effeminate remorse, Which we have noted in you to your kin, And egally indeed to all estates,-- Yet whether you accept our suit or no, Your brother's son shall never reign our king; But we will plant some other in the throne, To the disgrace and downfall of your house: And in this resolution here we leave you.-- Come, citizens: 'zounds!speak, man: what's thy name?Why, then, give way, dull clouds, to my quick curses!A' was a merry man--took up the child: 'Yea,' quoth he, 'dost thou fall upon thy face?She is, When once she is my wife.Is't lawful, pray you, To see her women?can so young a thorn begin to prick?'Tis meet so, daughter: but lest you do repent, As that the sin hath brought you to this shame, Which sorrow is always towards ourselves, not heaven, Showing we would not spare heaven as we love it, But as we stand in fear,-- I do repent me, as it is an evil, And take the shame with joy.Tell him, and spare not: look, what I have said I will avouch in presence of the king: I dare adventure to be sent to the Tower.Let me have open means to come to them, And soon I'll rid you from the fear of them.And do you remember what you said of the duke?I care not: It is an heretic that makes the fire, Not she which burns in't.Pray you now, buy it.I, even I: what think you of it, madam?I'll look to like, if looking liking move: But no more deep will I endart mine eye Than your consent gives strength to make it fly.Follow.No, good madam, pardon me; indeed, I will not forth.Peace, ho, for shame!Sweet saint, for charity, be not so curst.But here it is: prepare To see the life as lively mock'd as ever Still sleep mock'd death: behold, and say 'tis well.Ah, gentle Clifford, kill me with thy sword, And not with such a cruel threatening look.Call forth Bagot.But shall I live in hope?Why, I can smile, and murder whiles I smile, And cry 'Content' to that which grieves my heart, And wet my cheeks with artificial tears, And frame my face to all occasions.Sound drums and trumpets boldly and cheerfully; God and Saint George!Which she shall purchase with still lasting war.thou wouldst be gone to join with Richmond: I will not trust you, sir.Madam, bethink you, like a careful mother, Of the young prince your son: send straight for him Let him be crown'd; in him your comfort lives: Drown desperate sorrow in dead Edward's grave, And plant your joys in living Edward's throne.Good or bad?Being holiday, the beggar's shop is shut.Rather than fool it so, Let the high office and the honour go To one that would do thus.Thanks, good friend Escalus, for thy much goodness: There's more behind that is more gratulate.Prithee now, Go, and be ruled: although I know thou hadst rather Follow thine enemy in a fiery gulf Than flatter him in a bower.I do; and surely It is a sleepy language and thou speak'st Out of thy sleep.Your grace may do your pleasure.satisfy!I take it up; and by that sword I swear Which gently laid my knighthood on my shoulder, I'll answer thee in any fair degree, Or chivalrous design of knightly trial: And when I mount, alive may I not light, If I be traitor or unjustly fight!'Twas a commodity lay fretting by you: 'Twill bring you gain, or perish on the seas.As rich shall Romeo's by his lady's lie; Poor sacrifices of our enmity!'Tis almost morning; I would have thee gone: And yet no further than a wanton's bird; Who lets it hop a little from her hand, Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves, And with a silk thread plucks it back again, So loving-jealous of his liberty.Hence, old goat!Was not a man my father?My naked weapon is out: quarrel, I will back thee.But I do bend my speech To one that can my part in him advertise; Hold therefore, Angelo:-- In our remove be thou at full ourself; Mortality and mercy in Vienna Live in thy tongue and heart: old Escalus, Though first in question, is thy secondary.You need not fear it, sir: This child was prisoner to the womb and is By law and process of great nature thence Freed and enfranchised, not a party to The anger of the king nor guilty of, If any be, the trespass of the queen.The gods be good to us!What title hast thou, traitor, to the crown?Yet who's so blind, but says he sees it not?Canst thou not speak?What, are there no posts dispatch'd for Ireland?As much to him, else is his thanks too much.or granted less, Aufidius?yes, marry, sir: see where he looks out of the window.Yea.Ay, Marcius, Caius Marcius: dost thou think I'll grace thee with that robbery, thy stol'n name Coriolanus in Corioli?what stuff is here 'Twas never merry world since, of two usuries, the merriest was put down, and the worser allowed by order of law a furred gown to keep him warm; and furred with fox and lamb-skins too, to signify, that craft, being richer than innocency, stands for the facing.Beggars, that come unto my father's door, Upon entreaty have a present aims; If not, elsewhere they meet with charity: But I, who never knew how to entreat, Nor never needed that I should entreat, Am starved for meat, giddy for lack of sleep, With oath kept waking and with brawling fed: And that which spites me more than all these wants, He does it under name of perfect love; As who should say, if I should sleep or eat, 'Twere deadly sickness or else present death.Come, strike up!Ay, now my sovereign speaketh like himself; And now will I be Edward's champion.Hear me, my masters, and my common friends,-- He's sentenced; no more hearing.If is, my liege; and all things are in readiness.Yes, my good lord, It doth contain a king; King Richard lies Within the limits of yon lime and stone: And with him are the Lord Aumerle, Lord Salisbury, Sir Stephen Scroop, besides a clergyman Of holy reverence; who, I cannot learn.But that her tender shame Will not proclaim against her maiden loss, How might she tongue me!Tell me in sadness, who is that you love.Where is kind Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey?I have already.Fellows in arms, and my most loving friends, Bruised underneath the yoke of tyranny, Thus far into the bowels of the land Have we march'd on without impediment; And here receive we from our father Stanley Lines of fair comfort and encouragement.ballads?Thy father was a traitor to the crown.Bid them wash their faces And keep their teeth clean.Then was your sin of heavier kind than his.Now, Signior Petruchio, how speed you with my daughter?Therefore, that I may conquer fortune's spite By living low, where fortune cannot hurt me, And that the people of this blessed land May not be punish'd with my thwarting stars, Warwick, although my head still wear the crown, I here resign my government to thee, For thou art fortunate in all thy deeds.Once, if he do require our voices, we ought not to deny him.The silent hours steal on, And flaky darkness breaks within the east.To have no screen between this part he play'd And him he play'd it for, he needs will be Absolute Milan.I prithee, give no limits to my tongue: I am a king, and privileged to speak.On your allegiance, Out of the chamber with her!Business, my lord!Or how Should I, in these my borrow'd flaunts, behold The sternness of his presence?Or shall we beat the stones about thine ears?How fares my Juliet?That Angelo's a murderer; is 't not strange?I would, that I might thank you as you call me.So please you, madam, To put apart these your attendants, I Shall bring Emilia forth.Which is the way?May it please you, lords, to grant the commons' suit.What answer makes King Lewis unto our letters?These tears are my sweet Rutland's obsequies: And every drop cries vengeance for his death, 'Gainst thee, fell Clifford, and thee, false Frenchwoman.And thine, Lord Clifford; and you both have vow'd revenge On him, his sons, his favourites and his friends.That's my noble master!Your brother is a forfeit of the law, And you but waste your words.Yet again!What are you?I aim'd so near, when I supposed you loved.But, in the midst of this bright-shining day, I spy a black, suspicious, threatening cloud, That will encounter with our glorious sun, Ere he attain his easeful western bed: I mean, my lords, those powers that the queen Hath raised in Gallia have arrived our coast And, as we hear, march on to fight with us.how I scorn his worthless threats!we'll none on 't: here has been too much homely foolery already.Is your man secret?If it were so that our request did tend To save the Romans, thereby to destroy The Volsces whom you serve, you might condemn us, As poisonous of your honour: no; our suit Is that you reconcile them: while the Volsces May say 'This mercy we have show'd;' the Romans, 'This we received;' and each in either side Give the all-hail to thee and cry 'Be blest For making up this peace!'ladies that have their toes Unplagued with corns will have a bout with you.leave Henry, and call Edward king.As I guess, Marcius, Their bands i' the vaward are the Antiates, Of their best trust; o'er them Aufidius, Their very heart of hope.I have seen them in the church together: God send 'em good shipping!Madam, he hath not slept tonight; commanded None should come at him.Have you not set them on?what shout is this?There is differency between a grub and a butterfly; yet your butterfly was a grub.I, Daedalus; my poor boy, Icarus; Thy father, Minos, that denied our course; The sun that sear'd the wings of my sweet boy Thy brother Edward, and thyself the sea Whose envious gulf did swallow up his life.We three are married, but you two are sped.I cry you mercy, sir; and well could wish You had not found me here so musical: Let me excuse me, and believe me so, My mirth it much displeased, but pleased my woe.who is it?Thus to have said, As you were fore-advised, had touch'd his spirit And tried his inclination; from him pluck'd Either his gracious promise, which you might, As cause had call'd you up, have held him to Or else it would have gall'd his surly nature, Which easily endures not article Tying him to aught; so putting him to rage, You should have ta'en the advantage of his choler And pass'd him unelected.A deadly groan, like life and death's departing.Tell me of corn!Sitting on a bank, Weeping again the king my father's wreck, This music crept by me upon the waters, Allaying both their fury and my passion With its sweet air: thence I have follow'd it, Or it hath drawn me rather.Then, Angelo, thy fault's thus manifested; Which, though thou wouldst deny, denies thee vantage.We will have vengeance for it, fear thou not: Then weep no more.The man is noble and his fame folds-in This orb o' the earth.What mutter you, or what conspire you, lords?Peace, ho!Why does my blood thus muster to my heart, Making both it unable for itself, And dispossessing all my other parts Of necessary fitness?Cominius, no.Ay, the most peerless piece of earth, I think, That e'er the sun shone bright on.What is his name?O God, I have an ill-divining soul!'He killed my cousin Marcus.'Thus do I leave thee.Pray, be content: Mother, I am going to the market-place; Chide me no more.I did, my lord.For this, be sure, to-night thou shalt have cramps, Side-stitches that shall pen thy breath up; urchins Shall, for that vast of night that they may work, All exercise on thee; thou shalt be pinch'd As thick as honeycomb, each pinch more stinging Than bees that made 'em.Have we no wine here?The time hath been, Would you have been so brief with him, he would Have been so brief with you, to shorten you, For taking so the head, your whole head's length.My gracious lord, I may be negligent, foolish and fearful; In every one of these no man is free, But that his negligence, his folly, fear, Among the infinite doings of the world, Sometime puts forth.If you would seek us, We are yours i' the garden: shall's attend you there?Sir, his stoutness When he did stand for consul, which he lost By lack of stooping,-- That I would have spoke of: Being banish'd for't, he came unto my hearth; Presented to my knife his throat: I took him; Made him joint-servant with me; gave him way In all his own desires; nay, let him choose Out of my files, his projects to accomplish, My best and freshest men; served his designments In mine own person; holp to reap the fame Which he did end all his; and took some pride To do myself this wrong: till, at the last, I seem'd his follower, not partner, and He waged me with his countenance, as if I had been mercenary.My gracious uncle-- Tut, tut!I do desire to learn, sir: and I hope, if you have occasion to use me for your own turn, you shall find me yare; for truly, sir, for your kindness I owe you a good turn.Injurious Margaret!Cold friends to Richard: what do they in the north, When they should serve their sovereign in the west?To-morrow!For fear of that, I still will stay with thee; And never from this palace of dim night Depart again: here, here will I remain With worms that are thy chamber-maids; O, here Will I set up my everlasting rest, And shake the yoke of inauspicious stars From this world-wearied flesh.Here, madam: 'Hic ibat Simois; hic est Sigeia tellus; Hic steterat Priami regia celsa senis.'For what hath broach'd this tumult but thy pride?Right true it is, your son Lucentio here Doth love my daughter and she loveth him, Or both dissemble deeply their affections: And therefore, if you say no more than this, That like a father you will deal with him And pass my daughter a sufficient dower, The match is made, and all is done: Your son shall have my daughter with consent.Wenches, I'll buy for you both.It is 'music with her silver sound,' because musicians have no gold for sounding: 'Then music with her silver sound With speedy help doth lend redress.'Could he not speak 'em fair?A match, sir.Then, good my lords, bear witness to his oath.She should this Angelo have married; was affianced to her by oath, and the nuptial appointed: between which time of the contract and limit of the solemnity, her brother Frederick was wrecked at sea, having in that perished vessel the dowry of his sister.I will omit no opportunity That may convey my greetings, love, to thee.and give no foot of ground!'He is in heaven, where thou shalt never come.When daffodils begin to peer, With heigh!Dear earth, I do salute thee with my hand, Though rebels wound thee with their horses' hoofs: As a long-parted mother with her child Plays fondly with her tears and smiles in meeting, So, weeping, smiling, greet I thee, my earth, And do thee favours with my royal hands.this sight of death is as a bell, That warns my old age to a sepulchre.The day serves well for them now.the gates shall then be open'd.He's not confirm'd; we may deny him yet.O, here comes my nurse, And she brings news; and every tongue that speaks But Romeo's name speaks heavenly eloquence.My lords, look where the sturdy rebel sits, Even in the chair of state: belike he means, Back'd by the power of Warwick, that false peer, To aspire unto the crown and reign as king.Break off thy song, and haste thee quick away: Here comes a man of comfort, whose advice Hath often still'd my brawling discontent.Leave me solely: go, See how he fares.for well using me?Thou speak'st truth.Then he disdains to shine; for by the book He should have braved the east an hour ago A black day will it be to somebody.Do you the office, friar; which consummate, Return him here again.My brother slew no man; his fault was thought, And yet his punishment was cruel death.Ay, but she's come to beg, Warwick to give; She, on his left side, craving aid for Henry, He, on his right, asking a wife for Edward.Among them know you one Vincentio?I'll bury thee in a triumphant grave; A grave?If by your art, my dearest father, you have Put the wild waters in this roar, allay them.Why, and I trust I may go too, may I not?O, no!O, ye're well met: the hoarded plague o' the gods Requite your love!You keep a constant temper.Our prerogative Calls not your counsels, but our natural goodness Imparts this; which if you, or stupefied Or seeming so in skill, cannot or will not Relish a truth like us, inform yourselves We need no more of your advice: the matter, The loss, the gain, the ordering on't, is all Properly ours.Be that you are, That is, a woman; if you be more, you're none; If you be one, as you are well express'd By all external warrants, show it now, By putting on the destined livery.Tybalt, the reason that I have to love thee Doth much excuse the appertaining rage To such a greeting: villain am I none; Therefore farewell; I see thou know'st me not.O woful sympathy!True, Clifford; and that's Richard Duke of York.Then shall we hear their 'larum, and they ours.Now for our Irish wars: We must supplant those rough rug-headed kerns, Which live like venom where no venom else But only they have privilege to live.And so swear I, my lord Now, princely Buckingham, seal thou this league With thy embracements to my wife's allies, And make me happy in your unity.You have a daughter call'd Elizabeth, Virtuous and fair, royal and gracious.Nay, let them go, a couple of quiet ones.And so was I: I'll bear you company.He is coming.Nay, he's a flower; in faith, a very flower.Well, my lord.Be swift like lightning in the execution; And let thy blows, doubly redoubled, Fall like amazing thunder on the casque Of thy adverse pernicious enemy: Rouse up thy youthful blood, be valiant and live.Come on, poor babe: Some powerful spirit instruct the kites and ravens To be thy nurses!Next, it imports no reason That with such vehemency he should pursue Faults proper to himself: if he had so offended, He would have weigh'd thy brother by himself And not have cut him off.All things in common nature should produce Without sweat or endeavour: treason, felony, Sword, pike, knife, gun, or need of any engine, Would I not have; but nature should bring forth, Of its own kind, all foison, all abundance, To feed my innocent people.I am robbed, sir, and beaten; my money and apparel ta'en from me, and these detestable things put upon me.I will kiss thy lips; Haply some poison yet doth hang on them, To make die with a restorative.No, Warwick, no; while life upholds this arm, This arm upholds the house of Lancaster.Go tell the lords o' the city I am here: Deliver them this paper: having read it, Bid them repair to the market place; where I, Even in theirs and in the commons' ears, Will vouch the truth of it.I promised to inquire carefully About a schoolmaster for the fair Bianca: And by good fortune I have lighted well On this young man, for learning and behavior Fit for her turn, well read in poetry And other books, good ones, I warrant ye.Yea, are you so brief?Come, I'll conduct you to the sanctuary.I am the sister of one Claudio, Condemn'd upon the act of fornication To lose his head; condemn'd by Angelo: I, in probation of a sisterhood, Was sent to by my brother; one Lucio As then the messenger,-- That's I, an't like your grace: I came to her from Claudio, and desired her To try her gracious fortune with Lord Angelo For her poor brother's pardon.How say you to a fat tripe finely broil'd?Why art thou patient, man?What a boot is here with this exchange!Confess, confess, hath he not hit you here?The clock struck nine when I did send the nurse; In half an hour she promised to return.I have heard of the lady, and good words went with her name.Would not this ill do well?If thou wilt confess, Or else be impudently negative, To have nor eyes nor ears nor thought, then say My wife's a hobby-horse, deserves a name As rank as any flax-wench that puts to Before her troth-plight: say't and justify't.What one, my lord?That I may call thee something more than man And after that trust to thee.Save you, sir.As for you, Say what you can, my false o'erweighs your true.Methoughts that I had broken from the Tower, And was embark'd to cross to Burgundy; And, in my company, my brother Gloucester; Who from my cabin tempted me to walk Upon the hatches: thence we looked toward England, And cited up a thousand fearful times, During the wars of York and Lancaster That had befall'n us.Well, Petruchio, this has put me in heart.Why, that is nothing: for I tell you, father, I am as peremptory as she proud-minded; And where two raging fires meet together They do consume the thing that feeds their fury: Though little fire grows great with little wind, Yet extreme gusts will blow out fire and all: So I to her and so she yields to me; For I am rough and woo not like a babe.Peace, peace!That he, our hope, might have retired his power, And driven into despair an enemy's hope, Who strongly hath set footing in this land: The banish'd Bolingbroke repeals himself, And with uplifted arms is safe arrived At Ravenspurgh.Even now forsake me, and of all my lands Is nothing left me but my body's length.Nay, good, be patient.Thy pains, Fitzwater, shall not be forgot; Right noble is thy merit, well I wot.I have not deserved it.Flatter my sorrows with report of it; Tell me what state, what dignity, what honour, Canst thou demise to any child of mine?Not to them all.There is none worthy, Respecting her that's gone.Here at the palace I will rest awhile.Spit in the hole, man, and tune again.To Edward, but not to the English king.No, my good lord; therefore be patient.His grace looks cheerfully and smooth to-day; There's some conceit or other likes him well, When he doth bid good morrow with such a spirit.Come hither, Catesby.Still, methinks, There is an air comes from her: what fine chisel Could ever yet cut breath?He hath deserved worthily of his country: and his ascent is not by such easy degrees as those who, having been supple and courteous to the people, bonneted, without any further deed to have them at an into their estimation and report: but he hath so planted his honours in their eyes, and his actions in their hearts, that for their tongues to be silent, and not confess so much, were a kind of ingrateful injury; to report otherwise, were a malice, that, giving itself the lie, would pluck reproof and rebuke from every ear that heard it.Hold you there: farewell.thou hast need of more rags to lay on thee, rather than have these off.God gi' god-den.All sects, all ages smack of this vice; and he To die for't!Send out a pursuivant at arms To Stanley's regiment; bid him bring his power Before sunrising, lest his son George fall Into the blind cave of eternal night.Go to, sir; you weigh equally; a feather will turn the scale.pow, wow.What were more holy Than to rejoice the former queen is well?What are they that fly there?Are they all ready?I shall be reconciled to him again.O, full of danger is the Duke of Gloucester!Come, sir.My liege, the Duke of Buckingham is taken; That is the best news: that the Earl of Richmond Is with a mighty power landed at Milford, Is colder tidings, yet they must be told.'tis cowardly and womanish.A pleasing cordial, princely Buckingham, is this thy vow unto my sickly heart.What with him?Well, Go muster men; but, hear you, leave behind Your son, George Stanley: look your faith be firm.Now, good my lord, Let there be some more test made of my metal, Before so noble and so great a figure Be stamp'd upon it.Do you know, and dare not?Now I fear thee not: Sirrah young gamester, your father were a fool To give thee all, and in his waning age Set foot under thy table: tut, a toy!No longer Earl of March, but Duke of York: The next degree is England's royal throne; For King of England shalt thou be proclaim'd In every borough as we pass along; And he that throws not up his cap for joy Shall for the fault make forfeit of his head.What?The grand conspirator, Abbot of Westminster, With clog of conscience and sour melancholy Hath yielded up his body to the grave; But here is Carlisle living, to abide Thy kingly doom and sentence of his pride.Now are they come.May these same instruments, which you profane, Never sound more!Now, Bagot, freely speak thy mind; What thou dost know of noble Gloucester's death, Who wrought it with the king, and who perform'd The bloody office of his timeless end.How does your little son?No; he doth but mistake the truth totally.And if thy poor devoted suppliant may But beg one favour at thy gracious hand, Thou dost confirm his happiness for ever.Yea, noise?Why, that's my bawcock.I am disgraced, impeach'd and baffled here, Pierced to the soul with slander's venom'd spear, The which no balm can cure but his heart-blood Which breathed this poison.'Tis not a mile; briefly we heard their drums: How couldst thou in a mile confound an hour, And bring thy news so late?Sweet prince, the untainted virtue of your years Hath not yet dived into the world's deceit Nor more can you distinguish of a man Than of his outward show; which, God he knows, Seldom or never jumpeth with the heart.but I would fain die a dry death.Say no more: Howe'er the business goes, you have made fault I' the boldness of your speech.Why, sir, you know no house nor no such maid, Nor no such men as you have reckon'd up, As Stephen Sly and did John Naps of Greece And Peter Turph and Henry Pimpernell And twenty more such names and men as these Which never were nor no man ever saw.I take my leave with many thousand thanks.Nay, come away.Jog on, jog on, the foot-path way, And merrily hent the stile-a: A merry heart goes all the day, Your sad tires in a mile-a.it was thy device By this alliance to make void my suit: Before thy coming Lewis was Henry's friend.Out upon him!But, worthy lords, have you with heed perused What I have written to you?Ay, when the special thing is well obtain'd, That is, her love; for that is all in all.Tapster; a poor widow's tapster.Here cease more questions: Thou art inclined to sleep; 'tis a good dulness, And give it way: I know thou canst not choose.wishing clocks more swift?Canst thou remember A time before we came unto this cell?And tells us, what occasion of import Hath all so long detain'd you from your wife, And sent you hither so unlike yourself?How now!If the man be a bachelor, sir, I can; but if he be a married man, he's his wife's head, and I can never cut off a woman's head.not till King Henry be dead.Farewell, sweet lords: let's meet at Coventry.Thy father!Hie to your chamber: I'll find Romeo To comfort you: I wot well where he is.Darest thou resolve to kill a friend of mine?Now march we hence: discharge the common sort With pay and thanks, and let's away to London And see our gentle queen how well she fares: By this, I hope, she hath a son for me.Whiles we have struck, By interims and conveying gusts we have heard The charges of our friends.Familiarly shall call thy Dorset brother; Again shall you be mother to a king, And all the ruins of distressful times Repair'd with double riches of content.Spakest thou of Juliet?Speak, good Cominius: Leave nothing out for length, and make us think Rather our state's defective for requital Than we to stretch it out.What should she do here?It is not yet near day.Yes, I know thee to be Signior Lucentio.you'll be the man!O, well begg'd!Is it new and old too?Sir, induced by my charity, and hearing how hastily you are to depart, I am come to advise you, comfort you and pray with you.Saving your tale, Petruchio, I pray, Let us, that are poor petitioners, speak too: Baccare!We must not make a scarecrow of the law, Setting it up to fear the birds of prey, And let it keep one shape, till custom make it Their perch and not their terror.But Barnardine must die this afternoon: And how shall we continue Claudio, To save me from the danger that might come If he were known alive?Tarry, Petruchio, I must go with thee, For in Baptista's keep my treasure is: He hath the jewel of my life in hold, His youngest daughter, beautiful Binaca, And her withholds from me and other more, Suitors to her and rivals in my love, Supposing it a thing impossible, For those defects I have before rehearsed, That ever Katharina will be woo'd; Therefore this order hath Baptista ta'en, That none shall have access unto Bianca Till Katharina the curst have got a husband.No: first shall war unpeople this my realm; Ay, and their colours, often borne in France, And now in England to our heart's great sorrow, Shall be my winding-sheet.Then take him up and manage well the jest: Carry him gently to my fairest chamber And hang it round with all my wanton pictures: Balm his foul head in warm distilled waters And burn sweet wood to make the lodging sweet: Procure me music ready when he wakes, To make a dulcet and a heavenly sound; And if he chance to speak, be ready straight And with a low submissive reverence Say 'What is it your honour will command?'Here comes the queen, whose looks bewray her anger: I'll steal away.Then is he more beholding to you than I. He may command me as my sovereign; But you have power in me as in a kinsman.No settled senses of the world can match The pleasure of that madness.I say she's dead; I'll swear't.Tread on the sand; why, there you quickly sink: Bestride the rock; the tide will wash you off, Or else you famish; that's a threefold death.Gentlemen, importune me no farther, For how I firmly am resolved you know; That is, not bestow my youngest daughter Before I have a husband for the elder: If either of you both love Katharina, Because I know you well and love you well, Leave shall you have to court her at your pleasure.'Tis Aufidius, Who, hearing of our Marcius' banishment, Thrusts forth his horns again into the world; Which were inshell'd when Marcius stood for Rome, And durst not once peep out.And stint thou too, I pray thee, nurse, say I.Did not I tell thee yea?Have you thought on A place whereto you'll go?why dost thou not speak, Elbow?I'll be at charges for a looking-glass, And entertain some score or two of tailors, To study fashions to adorn my body: Since I am crept in favour with myself, Will maintain it with some little cost.Give me a bowl of wine: I have not that alacrity of spirit, Nor cheer of mind, that I was wont to have.O Ratcliff, I have dream'd a fearful dream!'Tis time to speak; my pains are quite forgot.Where?Are these your herd?Hark you.what news?What, hast smutch'd thy nose?All unavoided is the doom of destiny.Well, thou hast comforted me marvellous much.Arise, dissembler: though I wish thy death, I will not be the executioner.Happily met, my lady and my wife!And thou shalt still remain the Duke of York.Prithee, no more; cease; thou know'st He dies to me again when talk'd of: sure, When I shall see this gentleman, thy speeches Will bring me to consider that which may Unfurnish me of reason.O, this is it that makes your servants droop!Now, brother of Gloucester, Lord Hastings, and the rest, Stand you thus close, to steal the bishop's deer?the new-deliver'd Hastings?So please your lordship to accept our duty.Tush, man, abodements must not now affright us: By fair or foul means we must enter in, For hither will our friends repair to us.Nay, let them follow: The Volsces have much corn; take these rats thither To gnaw their garners.I twice five hundred and their friends to piece 'em.There was a man-- Nay, come, sit down; then on.To the market-place!It is a kind of history.And if I be, sir, is it any offence?Richard and Hastings: let them go; here is The duke.Father, tear the crown from the usurper's head.I'll not call you tyrant; But this most cruel usage of your queen, Not able to produce more accusation Than your own weak-hinged fancy, something savours Of tyranny and will ignoble make you, Yea, scandalous to the world.beat them down!Let us take the law of our sides; let them begin.To her, Kate!O my brother's child!Therefore, to arms!God bless your grace with health and happy days!Tut, man, one fire burns out another's burning, One pain is lessen'd by another's anguish; Turn giddy, and be holp by backward turning; One desperate grief cures with another's languish: Take thou some new infection to thy eye, And the rank poison of the old will die.Wouldst thou have laugh'd had I come coffin'd home, That weep'st to see me triumph?You live that shall cry woe for this after.Why, then let's home again.So thrive I, as I truly swear the like!I have spirit to do anything that appears not foul in the truth of my spirit.I never heard any soldier dislike it.Say, what art thou that talk'st of kings and queens?'tis a groom indeed, A grumbling groom, and that the girl shall find.What, must our mouths be cold?Some food we had and some fresh water that A noble Neapolitan, Gonzalo, Out of his charity, being then appointed Master of this design, did give us, with Rich garments, linens, stuffs and necessaries, Which since have steaded much; so, of his gentleness, Knowing I loved my books, he furnish'd me From mine own library with volumes that I prize above my dukedom.In one little body Thou counterfeit'st a bark, a sea, a wind; For still thy eyes, which I may call the sea, Do ebb and flow with tears; the bark thy body is, Sailing in this salt flood; the winds, thy sighs; Who, raging with thy tears, and they with them, Without a sudden calm, will overset Thy tempest-tossed body.What's the matter, you dissentious rogues, That, rubbing the poor itch of your opinion, Make yourselves scabs?To save her life, I'll say she is not so.What said my man, when my betossed soul Did not attend him as we rode?Go waken Juliet, go and trim her up; I'll go and chat with Paris: hie, make haste, Make haste; the bridegroom he is come already: Make haste, I say.Ah, wretched man!No.It is a man's voice.Nay, hear you, Kate: in sooth you scape not so.What, will my daughter prove a good musician?I can hardly believe that, since you know not what you speak.How now, noble Pompey!Then be it as you will; for 'tis my right, And Henry but usurps the diadem.quoth he: he spake it twice, And urged it twice together, did he not?Why, then they are not dead: But dead they are, and devilish slave, by thee.Give me the letter; I will look on it.It were as good To pardon him that hath from nature stolen A man already made, as to remit Their saucy sweetness that do coin heaven's image In stamps that are forbid: 'tis all as easy Falsely to take away a life true made As to put metal in restrained means To make a false one.you were used To say extremity was the trier of spirits; That common chances common men could bear; That when the sea was calm all boats alike Show'd mastership in floating; fortune's blows, When most struck home, being gentle wounded, craves A noble cunning: you were used to load me With precepts that would make invincible The heart that conn'd them.Stop there, stop there.If you see this in the map of my microcosm, follows it that I am known well enough too?I pray you, let it stand.plant love among 's!And from my soul too; Or else beshrew them both.Dolour comes to him, indeed: you have spoken truer than you purposed.O ill-dispersing wind of misery!Please you to interpose, fair madam: kneel And pray your mother's blessing.why do I rail on thee, Since thou, created to be awed by man, Wast born to bear?Did Julius Caesar build that place, my lord?O, what pity is it That he had not so trimm'd and dress'd his land As we this garden!Say, you ne'er had done't-- Harp on that still--but by our putting on; And presently, when you have drawn your number, Repair to the Capitol.We do it not alone, sir.You must not speak of that: you must desire them To think upon you.Then all too late comes counsel to be heard, Where will doth mutiny with wit's regard.Have you a catalogue Of all the voices that we have procured Set down by the poll?The keeper of the prison, call to him; let him have knowledge who I am.So, you're paid.My wretchedness unto a row of pins, They'll talk of state; for every one doth so Against a change; woe is forerun with woe.Verona, for a while I take my leave, To see my friends in Padua, but of all My best beloved and approved friend, Hortensio; and I trow this is his house.I'll swear for 'em.This tiger-footed rage, when it shall find The harm of unscann'd swiftness, will too late Tie leaden pounds to's heels.Fortune and victory sit on thy helm!Ay, but the mustard is too hot a little.Have I not in a pitched battle heard Loud 'larums, neighing steeds, and trumpets' clang?Hence!What's open made to justice, That justice seizes: what know the laws That thieves do pass on thieves?Romeo can, Though heaven cannot: O Romeo, Romeo!My master's.3 KING HENRY VI Madam, what makes you in this sudden change?And keep your honours safe!Provost, a word with you!I say again, give out That Anne my wife is sick and like to die: About it; for it stands me much upon, To stop all hopes whose growth may damage me.Marry, as for Clarence, he is well repaid, He is frank'd up to fatting for his pains God pardon them that are the cause of it!This is your son-in-law, And son unto the king, who, heavens directing, Is troth-plight to your daughter.With that, methoughts, a legion of foul fiends Environ'd me about, and howled in mine ears Such hideous cries, that with the very noise I trembling waked, and for a season after Could not believe but that I was in hell, Such terrible impression made the dream.Lo, now my glory smear'd in dust and blood!If guilty dread have left thee so much strength As to take up mine honour's pawn, then stoop: By that and all the rites of knighthood else, Will I make good against thee, arm to arm, What I have spoke, or thou canst worse devise.We know thy charge, Brakenbury, and will obey.I have heard it was ever his manner to do so.Your own is yours, and I am yours, and all.To whom, my lord?Let me see the county; Ay, marry, go, I say, and fetch him hither.Faith, none, but Humphrey Hour, that call'd your grace To breakfast once forth of my company.Who knows not that the noble duke is dead?Sir, he must die.Amen, sir: to my poor unworthy notice, He mock'd us when he begg'd our voices.Nay, look not big, nor stamp, nor stare, nor fret; I will be master of what is mine own: She is my goods, my chattels; she is my house, My household stuff, my field, my barn, My horse, my ox, my ass, my any thing; And here she stands, touch her whoever dare; I'll bring mine action on the proudest he That stops my way in Padua.Ambitious York doth level at thy crown, Thou smiling while he knit his angry brows: He, but a duke, would have his son a king, And raise his issue, like a loving sire; Thou, being a king, blest with a goodly son, Didst yield consent to disinherit him, Which argued thee a
