most unloving father.Who saw the sun to-day?No, but the loss of his own royal person.His nurse!How should they, when that wise men have no eyes?That ever I should live to see thee dead!Where then do you know best We be affied and such assurance ta'en As shall with either part's agreement stand?You, to remove that siege of grief from her, Betroth'd and would have married her perforce To County Paris: then comes she to me, And, with wild looks, bid me devise some mean To rid her from this second marriage, Or in my cell there would she kill herself.This forenamed maid hath yet in her the continuance of her first affection: his unjust unkindness, that in all reason should have quenched her love, hath, like an impediment in the current, made it more violent and unruly.He for his father's sake so loves the prince, That he will not be won to aught against him.Take, then, this your companion by the hand, Who hath a story ready for your ear.Faith, here it is.O,'tis Marcius!Yet, Derby, notwithstanding she's your wife, And loves not me, be you, good lord, assured I hate not you for her proud arrogance.Worthy sir, thou bleed'st; Thy exercise hath been too violent for A second course of fight.Down with that sword!Why, Romeo, art thou mad?Should dying men flatter with those that live?Give me thy hand: I will swear to the prince thou art as honest a true fellow as any is in Bohemia.This is his tent; and see where stand his guard.And see where comes the breeder of my sorrow!Now He that made me knows I see thee ill; Ill in myself to see, and in thee seeing ill.Seek you to seize and gripe into your hands The royalties and rights of banish'd Hereford?Here pitch our battle; hence we will not budge.Not so, not so; his life is parallel'd Even with the stroke and line of his great justice: He doth with holy abstinence subdue That in himself which he spurs on his power To qualify in others: were he meal'd with that Which he corrects, then were he tyrannous; But this being so, he's just.Tut, fear not me.you pluck my foot awry: Take that, and mend the plucking off the other.Is this your speeding?Yet show some pity.What, you will not?This letter doth make good the friar's words, Their course of love, the tidings of her death: And here he writes that he did buy a poison Of a poor 'pothecary, and therewithal Came to this vault to die, and lie with Juliet.Your ships are stay'd at Venice, and the duke, For private quarrel 'twixt your duke and him, Hath publish'd and proclaim'd it openly: 'Tis, marvel, but that you are but newly come, You might have heard it else proclaim'd about.No, I can better play the orator.O, who hath any cause to mourn but I?I beseech thee, youth, Put not another sin upon my head, By urging me to fury: O, be gone!The bloody parliament shall this be call'd, Unless Plantagenet, Duke of York, be king, And bashful Henry deposed, whose cowardice Hath made us by-words to our enemies.The tongue of Isabel.Die, perish!Now is this golden crown like a deep well That owes two buckets, filling one another, The emptier ever dancing in the air, The other down, unseen and full of water: That bucket down and full of tears am I, Drinking my griefs, whilst you mount up on high.So have we thought it good From our free person she should be confined, Lest that the treachery of the two fled hence Be left her to perform.Arise; one knocks; good Romeo, hide thyself.That it would please thee leave these sad designs To him that hath more cause to be a mourner, And presently repair to Crosby Place; Where, after I have solemnly interr'd At Chertsey monastery this noble king, And wet his grave with my repentant tears, I will with all expedient duty see you: For divers unknown reasons.tell me, that I may sack The hateful mansion.That they have let the dangerous enemy Measure our confines with such peaceful steps?When he had done, some followers of mine own, At the lower end of the hall, hurl'd up their caps, And some ten voices cried 'God save King Richard!'Let's along.for the selfsame heaven That frowns on me looks sadly upon him.Sweet York, be patient.I'll keep you company.Thou art sworn as deeply to effect what we intend As closely to conceal what we impart: Thou know'st our reasons urged upon the way; What think'st thou?Had not you come upon your cue, my lord William Lord Hastings had pronounced your part,-- I mean, your voice,--for crowning of the king.why, 'twere perpetual shame.For this reason, if you'll know, That she's the choice love of Signior Gremio.Here, my lord.And give me leave, And do not say 'tis superstition, that I kneel and then implore her blessing.Come, my old son: I pray God make thee new.Prithee, be my present partner in this business, and lay aside the thoughts of Sicilia.The selfsame name, but one of better nature.Fellow Grumio!Marry, I thank your good worship for it.Go, signify as much, while here we march Upon the grassy carpet of this plain.I do beseech you, pardon me; I may not show it.most damned Angelo!Hastings, and Edward's children, Rivers, Grey, Holy King Henry, and thy fair son Edward, Vaughan, and all that have miscarried By underhand corrupted foul injustice, If that your moody discontented souls Do through the clouds behold this present hour, Even for revenge mock my destruction!Ah, Tranio, what a cruel father's he!It is so, sir: truly, I have forgot you.Was ever book containing such vile matter So fairly bound?a velvet hose!Forgot you!Enough, my lord.A boon, my sovereign, for my service done!I will provide thee.Haste still pays haste, and leisure answers leisure; Like doth quit like, and MEASURE still FOR MEASURE.I warrant it is: and thy head stands so tickle on thy shoulders that a milkmaid, if she be in love, may sigh it off.yare, yare!Was ever woman in this humour won?Which, of he or Adrian, for a good wager, first begins to crow?Uncle, even in the glasses of thine eyes I see thy grieved heart: thy sad aspect Hath from the number of his banish'd years Pluck'd four away.O, that once more you knew but what you are!What, in the midst of the street?Hortensio, to what end are all these words?Shame on himself!Come, we burn daylight, ho!Friend hast thou none; For thine own bowels, which do call thee sire, The mere effusion of thy proper loins, Do curse the gout, serpigo, and the rheum, For ending thee no sooner.We cannot be here and there too.This is the place; there, where the torch doth burn.A shy fellow was the duke: and I believe I know the cause of his withdrawing.Nor I; my spirits are nimble.Sister, farewell; I must to Coventry: As much good stay with thee as go with me!When, I beseech you?Now the fair goddess, Fortune, Fall deep in love with thee; and her great charms Misguide thy opposers' swords!Thy thrice noble cousin Harry Bolingbroke doth humbly kiss thy hand; And by the honourable tomb he swears, That stands upon your royal grandsire's bones, And by the royalties of both your bloods, Currents that spring from one most gracious head, And by the buried hand of warlike Gaunt, And by the worth and honour of himself, Comprising all that may be sworn or said, His coming hither hath no further scope Than for his lineal royalties and to beg Enfranchisement immediate on his knees: Which on thy royal party granted once, His glittering arms he will commend to rust, His barbed steeds to stables, and his heart To faithful service of your majesty.But make you ready your stiff bats and clubs: Rome and her rats are at the point of battle; The one side must have bale.She it is.Deceitful Warwick!whence comes this restraint?Thus I conceive by him.Take that, until thou bring me better news.My Lord of Somerset, at my request, See that forthwith Duke Edward be convey'd Unto my brother, Archbishop of York.Thou art a widow; yet thou art a mother, And hast the comfort of thy children left thee: But death hath snatch'd my husband from mine arms, And pluck'd two crutches from my feeble limbs, Edward and Clarence.Indeed, I should have ask'd you that before.And where's that valiant crook-back prodigy, Dicky your boy, that with his grumbling voice Was wont to cheer his dad in mutinies?What!Twice for one step I'll groan, the way being short, And piece the way out with a heavy heart.And your fair princess,--goddess!--O, alas!I hope the king made peace with all of us And the compact is firm and true in me.Call up Lord Stanley, bid him bring his power: I will lead forth my soldiers to the plain, And thus my battle shall be ordered: My foreward shall be drawn out all in length, Consisting equally of horse and foot; Our archers shall be placed in the midst John Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Earl of Surrey, Shall have the leading of this foot and horse.He's to make his requests by particulars; wherein every one of us has a single honour, in giving him our own voices with our own tongues: therefore follow me, and I direct you how you shall go by him.What's that, I pray?What, do I love her, That I desire to hear her speak again, And feast upon her eyes?hast thou forgot her?Some light-foot friend post to the Duke of Norfolk: Ratcliff, thyself, or Catesby; where is he?I grant; as there may between the lists and the velvet.Perhaps you have learned it without book: but, I pray, can you read any thing you see?Can you so stead me As bring me to the sight of Isabella, A novice of this place and the fair sister To her unhappy brother Claudio?Now, had I not the dash of my former life in me, would preferment drop on my head.Indeed, you shall not.What do you think, You, the great toe of this assembly?why 'music with her silver sound'?Away, you three-inch fool!Well, well, thou hast a careful father, child; One who, to put thee from thy heaviness, Hath sorted out a sudden day of joy, That thou expect'st not nor I look'd not for.or any of your faction?Would he were wasted, marrow, bones and all, That from his loins no hopeful branch may spring, To cross me from the golden time I look for!For shame, my liege, make them your precedent!I cannot speak, nor think Nor dare to know that which I know.An if he may, then am I lawful king; For Richard, in the view of many lords, Resign'd the crown to Henry the Fourth, Whose heir my father was, and I am his.For shame, come down: he made thee Duke of York.Is't a verdict?By his command Have I here touch'd Sicilia and from him Give you all greetings that a king, at friend, Can send his brother: and, but infirmity Which waits upon worn times hath something seized His wish'd ability, he had himself The lands and waters 'twixt your throne and his Measured to look upon you; whom he loves-- He bade me say so--more than all the sceptres And those that bear them living.Welcome hither, As is the spring to the earth.Are they not now upon the western shore.O, God defend my soul from such deep sin!None rare, my lord.answer to that; Say either, and I'll stay the circumstance: Let me be satisfied, is't good or bad?On Thursday, sir?What more remains?We will before the walls of Rome tomorrow Set down our host.Say that I did all this for love of her.Peace, both, and hear me speak.Where is Lucentio?Read o'er this paper while the glass doth come.This a consul?I, that now Refused most princely gifts, am bound to beg Of my lord general.To him will I present them: there may be matter in it.Ay, and he'll tame her.My lords, forbear this talk; here comes the king.See, how they kiss and court!For mine own part, I never come into any room in a tap-house, but I am drawn in.Thomas of Norfolk, what say'st thou to this?And let their heirs, God, if thy will be so.Come, go with us; speak fair: you may salve so, Not what is dangerous present, but the loss Of what is past.Up to some scaffold, there to lose their heads?What's your name?O' my word, the father's son: I'll swear,'tis a very pretty boy.Refuse not, mighty lord, this proffer'd love.Therefore fasten your ear on my advisings: to the love I have in doing good a remedy presents itself.Romeo's a dishclout to him: an eagle, madam, Hath not so green, so quick, so fair an eye As Paris hath.And now by law, as well as reverend age, I may entitle thee my loving father: The sister to my wife, this gentlewoman, Thy son by this hath married.Ay, Edward will use women honourably.I am, in this, commanded to deliver The noble Duke of Clarence to your hands: I will not reason what is meant hereby, Because I will be guiltless of the meaning.We'll break our walls, Rather than they shall pound us up: our gates, Which yet seem shut, we, have but pinn'd with rushes; They'll open of themselves.All for our vantage.O miserable thought!I'll teach you how you shall arraign your conscience, And try your penitence, if it be sound, Or hollowly put on.and, swifter than his tongue, His agile arm beats down their fatal points, And 'twixt them rushes; underneath whose arm An envious thrust from Tybalt hit the life Of stout Mercutio, and then Tybalt fled; But by and by comes back to Romeo, Who had but newly entertain'd revenge, And to 't they go like lightning, for, ere I Could draw to part them, was stout Tybalt slain.I have seen two such sights, by sea and by land!No, no: this shall forbid it: lie thou there.I think there's never a man in Christendom That can less hide his love or hate than he; For by his face straight shall you know his heart.3 KING HENRY VI Fair Queen of England, worthy Margaret, Sit down with us: it ill befits thy state And birth, that thou shouldst stand while Lewis doth sit.Why, madam, have I offer'd love for this To be so bouted in this royal presence?One fire drives out one fire; one nail, one nail; Rights by rights falter, strengths by strengths do fail.My partner in this action, You must report to the Volscian lords, how plainly I have borne this business.No, say'st me so, friend?Look, how thou dream'st!Order the trial, marshal, and begin.every wink of an eye some new grace will be born: our absence makes us unthrifty to our knowledge.By your patience, I may not suffer you to visit them; The king hath straitly charged the contrary.Aumerle, thou weep'st, my tender-hearted cousin!For thy conceit is soaking, will draw in More than the common blocks: not noted, is't, But of the finer natures?Why, then thou shalt not have thy husband's lands.O God, she comes!O, thou didst prophesy the time would come That I should wish for thee to help me curse That bottled spider, that foul bunch-back'd toad!Setting your scorns and your mislike aside, Tell me some reason why the Lady Grey Should not become my wife and England's queen.This sudden stag of rancour I misdoubt: Pray God, I say, I prove a needless coward!First, hear me speak.What, will the aspiring blood of Lancaster Sink in the ground?Romeo, come forth; come forth, thou fearful man: Affliction is enamour'd of thy parts, And thou art wedded to calamity.Thou art a traitor: Off with his head!There's no remedy; Unless, by not so doing, our good city Cleave in the midst, and perish.He had, my lord; and that it was which caused Our swifter composition.Come, civil night, Thou sober-suited matron, all in black, And learn me how to lose a winning match, Play'd for a pair of stainless maidenhoods: Hood my unmann'd blood, bating in my cheeks, With thy black mantle; till strange love, grown bold, Think true love acted simple modesty.if you had, The thought of them would have stirr'd up remorse: But if you ever chance to have a child, Look in his youth to have him so cut off As, deathmen, you have rid this sweet young prince!I am afraid, sir, Do what you can, yours will not be entreated.alack, or we must lose The country, our dear nurse, or else thy person, Our comfort in the country.No doubt, no doubt; O, 'tis a parlous boy; Bold, quick, ingenious, forward, capable He is all the mother's, from the top to toe.and my good friend Petruchio!Boy!Give me thy hand: Be pilot to me and thy places shall Still neighbour mine.Here is the head of that ignoble traitor, The dangerous and unsuspected Hastings.You are i' the right, sir: 'tis for my mistress.I saw him in the battle range about; And watch'd him how he singled Clifford forth.They are both in either's powers; but this swift business I must uneasy make, lest too light winning Make the prize light.Whither?This, here before you.That I'll try.Come, sir page, Look on me with your welkin eye: sweet villain!Or do I dream?Come, come, come.To make an act of tragic violence: Edward, my lord, your son, our king, is dead.Thus, what with the war, what with the sweat, what with the gallows and what with poverty, I am custom-shrunk.Now, tell me, I pray, You that durst swear at your mistress Bianca Loved none in the world so well as Lucentio.God's bread!Wilt thou have music?Now, brother king, farewell, and sit you fast, For I will hence to Warwick's other daughter; That, though I want a kingdom, yet in marriage I may not prove inferior to yourself.Then know, it is your fault that you resign The supreme seat, the throne majestical, The scepter'd office of your ancestors, Your state of fortune and your due of birth, The lineal glory of your royal house, To the corruption of a blemished stock: Whilst, in the mildness of your sleepy thoughts, Which here we waken to our country's good, This noble isle doth want her proper limbs; Her face defaced with scars of infamy, Her royal stock graft with ignoble plants, And almost shoulder'd in the swallowing gulf Of blind forgetfulness and dark oblivion.If any in Vienna be of worth To undergo such ample grace and honour, It is Lord Angelo.Nay, good goose, bite not.They shall be satisfied: I'll read enough, When I do see the very book indeed Where all my sins are writ, and that's myself.Thou sing'st sweet music.This is some changeling: open't.what means death in this rude assault?A match!I go.Your children were vexation to your youth, But mine shall be a comfort to your age.If he have power Then vail your ignorance; if none, awake Your dangerous lenity.Why, say, fair queen, whence springs this deep despair?Or, if his mind be writ, give me his letter.O, fie, fie, fie!To be a make-peace shall become my age: Throw down, my son, the Duke of Norfolk's gage.We talk here in the public haunt of men: Either withdraw unto some private place, And reason coldly of your grievances, Or else depart; here all eyes gaze on us.Where is my father, and my mother, nurse?I think, this coming summer, the King of Sicilia means to pay Bohemia the visitation which he justly owes him.So God help Montague as he proves true!You here shall swear upon this sword of justice, That you, Cleomenes and Dion, have Been both at Delphos, and from thence have brought The seal'd-up oracle, by the hand deliver'd Of great Apollo's priest; and that, since then, You have not dared to break the holy seal Nor read the secrets in't.Who's that which calls?Or blessed was't we did?No more, I say!Lay hold on him.Some word there was, worser than Tybalt's death, That murder'd me: I would forget it fain; But, O, it presses to my memory, Like damned guilty deeds to sinners' minds: 'Tybalt is dead, and Romeo--banished;' That 'banished,' that one word 'banished,' Hath slain ten thousand Tybalts.Signior Romeo, bon jour!Bound by my charity and my blest order, I come to visit the afflicted spirits Here in the prison.If sorrow can admit society, Tell o'er your woes again by viewing mine: I had an Edward, till a Richard kill'd him; I had a Harry, till a Richard kill'd him: Thou hadst an Edward, till a Richard kill'd him; Thou hadst a Richard, till a Richard killed him; I had a Richard too, and thou didst kill him; I had a Rutland too, thou holp'st to kill him.You have brought A trembling upon Rome, such as was never So incapable of help.His son was but a ward two years ago.My lord?I do not sleep: I see, I hear, I speak; I smell sweet savours and I feel soft things: Upon my life, I am a lord indeed And not a tinker nor Christophero Sly.These news I must confess are full of grief; Yet, gracious madam, bear it as you may: Warwick may lose, that now hath won the day.Good brother, as thou lovest and honourest arms, Let's fight it out and not stand cavilling thus.No, not these twenty years.Am I like such a fellow?Not he alone shall suffer what wit can make heavy and vengeance bitter; but those that are germane to him, though removed fifty times, shall all come under the hangman: which though it be great pity, yet it is necessary.That's the way; for women are light at midnight.we have many goodly days to see: The liquid drops of tears that you have shed Shall come again, transform'd to orient pearl, Advantaging their loan with interest Of ten times double gain of happiness.Music, awake her; strike!May not one speak?Thou, wretched boy, that didst consort him here, Shalt with him hence.Hidest thou that forehead with a golden crown, Where should be graven, if that right were right, The slaughter of the prince that owed that crown, And the dire death of my two sons and brothers?I will be angry: what hast thou to do?Nurse, will you go with me into my closet, To help me sort such needful ornaments As you think fit to furnish me to-morrow?Provost, my brother Angelo will not be altered; Claudio must die to-morrow: let him be furnished with divines, and have all charitable preparation.It is an honour that I dream not of.It is his highness' pleasure that the queen Appear in person here in court.Yet you must be saying, Marcius is proud; who in a cheap estimation, is worth predecessors since Deucalion, though peradventure some of the best of 'em were hereditary hangmen.Good madam, be not angry with the child.Breathe you, my friends: well fought; we are come off Like Romans, neither foolish in our stands, Nor cowardly in retire: believe me, sirs, We shall be charged again.Gramercies, lad, go forward; this contents: The rest will comfort, for thy counsel's sound.Merely, my lord.What, hath thy fiery heart so parch'd thine entrails That not a tear can fall for Rutland's death?I am no beast.I know not what to do: I would to God, So my untruth had not provoked him to it, The king had cut off my head with my brother's.Is thy news good, or bad?What say'st thou, Henry, wilt thou yield the crown?Come hither, man.How canst thou urge God's dreadful law to us, When thou hast broke it in so dear degree?Did my heart love till now?If we be not, show us the hand of God That hath dismissed us from our stewardship; For well we know, no hand of blood and bone Can gripe the sacred handle of our sceptre, Unless he do profane, steal, or usurp.Or ill-beseeming beast in seeming both!I will, sir, flatter my sworn brother, the people, to earn a dearer estimation of them; 'tis a condition they account gentle: and since the wisdom of their choice is rather to have my hat than my heart, I will practise the insinuating nod and be off to them most counterfeitly; that is, sir, I will counterfeit the bewitchment of some popular man and give it bountiful to the desirers.Upon his place, And with full line of his authority, Governs Lord Angelo; a man whose blood Is very snow-broth; one who never feels The wanton stings and motions of the sense, But doth rebate and blunt his natural edge With profits of the mind, study and fast.One Isabel, a sister, desires access to you.3 KING HENRY VI Brother of Gloucester, at Saint Alban's field This lady's husband, Sir Richard Grey, was slain, His lands then seized on by the conqueror: Her suit is now to repossess those lands; Which we in justice cannot well deny, Because in quarrel of the house of York The worthy gentleman did lose his life.Are you agreed?What is that Barnardine who is to be executed in the afternoon?Marry, they say my uncle grew so fast That he could gnaw a crust at two hours old 'Twas full two years ere I could get a tooth.What subject can give sentence on his king?Ay, why not?Come, let's go: Leave this faint puling and lament as I do, In anger, Juno-like.We can: my royal liege, He is not guilty of her coming hither.I confess the cape.And the new deputy now for the duke-- Whether it be the fault and glimpse of newness, Or whether that the body public be A horse whereon the governor doth ride, Who, newly in the seat, that it may know He can command, lets it straight feel the spur; Whether the tyranny be in his place, Or in his emmence that fills it up, I stagger in:--but this new governor Awakes me all the enrolled penalties Which have, like unscour'd armour, hung by the wall So long that nineteen zodiacs have gone round And none of them been worn; and, for a name, Now puts the drowsy and neglected act Freshly on me: 'tis surely for a name.Uncle, this is a Montague, our foe, A villain that is hither come in spite, To scorn at our solemnity this night.Farewell, dear father!To him, and to his substitutes.Marcius, his name?Nay, do not say, 'stand up;' Say, 'pardon' first, and afterwards 'stand up.'What, all so soon asleep!Good faith, good faith, the saying did not hold In him that did object the same to thee; He was the wretched'st thing when he was young, So long a-growing and so leisurely, That, if this rule were true, he should be gracious.Cry mercy, lords and watchful gentlemen, That you have ta'en a tardy sluggard here.Ha!Canst thou tell if Claudio die to-morrow or no?Hold him in safety, till the prince come hither.Go you to Angelo; answer his requiring with a plausible obedience; agree with his demands to the point; only refer yourself to this advantage, first, that your stay with him may not be long; that the time may have all shadow and silence in it; and the place answer to convenience.Marcius coming home!See, see, King Richard doth himself appear, As doth the blushing discontented sun From out the fiery portal of the east, When he perceives the envious clouds are bent To dim his glory and to stain the track Of his bright passage to the occident.No longer shall you gaze on't, lest your fancy May think anon it moves.I am a villain: yet I lie.O, I have bought the mansion of a love, But not possess'd it, and, though I am sold, Not yet enjoy'd: so tedious is this day As is the night before some festival To an impatient child that hath new robes And may not wear them.A match!In the base court?why have they dared to march So many miles upon her peaceful bosom, Frighting her pale-faced villages with war And ostentation of despised arms?You are gentlemen of brave metal; you would lift the moon out of her sphere, if she would continue in it five weeks without changing.Fiddler, forbear; you grow too forward, sir: Have you so soon forgot the entertainment Her sister Katharina welcomed you withal?Would the duke that is absent have done this?fight it out!'What were I best to say?Cannot a plain man live and think no harm, But thus his simple truth must be abused By silken, sly, insinuating Jacks?Had I been there, which am a silly woman, The soldiers should have toss'd me on their pikes Before I would have granted to that act.'Tis he, that villain Romeo.Sirrah, bring Barnardine hither.Ay, mine own fortune in my misery.Is't not a kind of incest, to take life From thine own sister's shame?O God!--O nurse, how shall this be prevented?If love be rough with you, be rough with love; Prick love for pricking, and you beat love down.why, fool, he shall never wake till the judgment-day.Your voices: for your voices I have fought; Watch'd for your voices; for Your voices bear Of wounds two dozen odd; battles thrice six I have seen and heard of; for your voices have Done many things, some less, some more your voices: Indeed I would be consul.Fare you well.I did so: but thou strikest me Sorely, to say I did; it is as bitter Upon thy tongue as in my thought: now, good now, Say so but seldom.She shall not need; we'll meet her in the field.Talk not, Signior Gremio: I say he shall go to prison.What, Juliet!Thou didst speak but well When most the truth; which I receive much better Than to be pitied of thee.Thus do I hope to shake King Henry's head.First, heaven be the record to my speech!when?I like your silence, it the more shows off Your wonder: but yet speak; first, you, my liege, Comes it not something near?O, was she so?No deeper wrinkles yet?Come hither, goodman baldpate: do you know me?I do not like this news.Hortensio, have you told him all her faults?Spirits are not finely touch'd But to fine issues, nor Nature never lends The smallest scruple of her excellence But, like a thrifty goddess, she determines Herself the glory of a creditor, Both thanks and use.Why, noble lords, Will you be put in mind of his blind fortune, Which was your shame, by this unholy braggart, 'Fore your own eyes and ears?Oh for our father, for our dear lord Clarence!Do your will.you herd of--Boils and plagues Plaster you o'er, that you may be abhorr'd Further than seen and one infect another Against the wind a mile!Hath he a sister?Prithee, bring me To the dead bodies of my queen and son: One grave shall be for both: upon them shall The causes of their death appear, unto Our shame perpetual.Now, pray, sir, get you gone: You have done a brave deed.Marcius!O that deceit should dwell In such a gorgeous palace!I swear to do this, though a present death Had been more merciful.What, do you tremble?In saying so, you shall but say the truth.Answer to this: I, now the voice of the recorded law, Pronounce a sentence on your brother's life: Might there not be a charity in sin To save this brother's life?Where is he, hear you?As full of valour as of royal blood: Both have I spill'd; O would the deed were good!Tranio, since for the great desire I had To see fair Padua, nursery of arts, I am arrived for fruitful Lombardy, The pleasant garden of great Italy; And by my father's love and leave am arm'd With his good will and thy good company, My trusty servant, well approved in all, Here let us breathe and haply institute A course of learning and ingenious studies.Go on, go on Thou canst not speak too much; I have deserved All tongues to talk their bitterest.Love me or love me not, I like the cap; And it I will have, or I will have none.'Tis the more honour, because more dangerous.and what's thy quarrel?More wonderful, when angels are so angry.I thank thee, master.How!Ay, almost slain, for he is taken prisoner, Either betray'd by falsehood of his guard Or by his foe surprised at unawares: And, as I further have to understand, Is new committed to the Bishop of York, Fell Warwick's brother and by that our foe.I am half through; The one part suffer'd, the other will I do.So shall you quietly enjoy your hope, And marry sweet Bianca with consent.Ha!Let me twine Mine arms about that body, where against My grained ash an hundred times hath broke And scarr'd the moon with splinters: here I clip The anvil of my sword, and do contest As hotly and as nobly with thy love As ever in ambitious strength I did Contend against thy valour.Kind Tyrrel, am I happy in thy news?Speak briefly, can you like of Paris' love?But come in: Let me commend thee first to those that shall Say yea to thy desires.How will my mother for a father's death Take on with me and ne'er be satisfied!Sir, that's to-morrow.Now civil wounds are stopp'd, peace lives again: That she may long live here, God say amen!Well said, Hermione.Before he should thus stoop to the herd, but that The violent fit o' the time craves it as physic For the whole state, I would put mine armour on, Which I can scarcely bear.I fear me both are false.Sir, we were talking that our garments seem now as fresh as when we were at Tunis at the marriage of your daughter, who is now queen.The noble duke hath been too much abused.Where did you study all this goodly speech?Faith, mistress, then I have no cause to stay.Walk before toward the sea-side; go on the right hand: I will but look upon the hedge and follow you.Why, he that wears her like a medal, hanging About his neck, Bohemia: who, if I Had servants true about me, that bare eyes To see alike mine honour as their profits, Their own particular thrifts, they would do that Which should undo more doing: ay, and thou, His cupbearer,--whom I from meaner form Have benched and reared to worship, who mayst see Plainly as heaven sees earth and earth sees heaven, How I am galled,--mightst bespice a cup, To give mine enemy a lasting wink; Which draught to me were cordial.Why, 'tis not amiss, Pompey.I will about it straight; No longer staying but to give the mother Notice of my affair.By giving liberty unto thine eyes; Examine other beauties.Is Lewis so brave?O, he hath murdered his master!I'll take it up for pity: yet I'll tarry till my son come; he hallooed but even now.My clown, who wants but something to be a reasonable man, grew so in love with the wenches' song, that he would not stir his pettitoes till he had both tune and words; which so drew the rest of the herd to me that all their other senses stuck in ears: you might have pinched a placket, it was senseless; 'twas nothing to geld a codpiece of a purse; I could have filed keys off that hung in chains: no hearing, no feeling, but my sir's song, and admiring the nothing of it.Tell him he must awake, and that quickly too.O heavy day!nothing but songs of death?Lo, here, this long-usurped royalty From the dead temples of this bloody wretch Have I pluck'd off, to grace thy brows withal: Wear it, enjoy it, and make much of it.Pray you, avoid the house.You are deceived, your brother Gloucester hates you.How shall this bisson multitude digest The senate's courtesy?Ah, well-a-day!There is thy gold, worse poison to men's souls, Doing more murders in this loathsome world, Than these poor compounds that thou mayst not sell.Nay, do not pause; for I did kill King Henry, But 'twas thy beauty that provoked me.Which I'll not call a creature of thy place, Lest barbarism, making me the precedent, Should a like language use to all degrees And mannerly distinguishment leave out Betwixt the prince and beggar: I have said She's an adulteress; I have said with whom: More, she's a traitor and Camillo is A federary with her, and one that knows What she should shame to know herself But with her most vile principal, that she's A bed-swerver, even as bad as those That vulgars give bold'st titles, ay, and privy To this their late escape.O flattering glass, Like to my followers in prosperity, Thou dost beguile me!You being their mouths, why rule you not their teeth?In this the heaven figures some event.Thou desirest me to stop in my tale against the hair.The image of it gives me content already; and I trust it will grow to a most prosperous perfection.Alas, I am not coop'd here for defence!Not so; even through the hollow eyes of death I spy life peering; but I dare not say How near the tidings of our comfort is.Ay, by my troth, the case may be amended.and have I such a lady?Madam, 'tis now in tune.Yet, as we may, we'll meet both thee and Warwick.He was?O, no, he loves me, and he holds me dear: Go you to him from me.False-boding woman, end thy frantic curse, Lest to thy harm thou move our patience.Your actions are my dreams; You had a bastard by Polixenes, And I but dream'd it.No, sir, nor I mean it not.It would seem strange unto him when he waked.Then let the earth be drunken with our blood: I'll kill my horse, because I will not fly.Come, sir, now I am for you again: pray you, sit by us, And tell 's a tale.What authority surfeits on would relieve us: if they would yield us but the superfluity, while it were wholesome, we might guess they relieved us humanely; but they think we are too dear: the leanness that afflicts us, the object of our misery, is as an inventory to particularise their abundance; our sufferance is a gain to them Let us revenge this with our pikes, ere we become rakes: for the gods know I speak this in hunger for bread, not in thirst for revenge.Three, they say: but 'tis thought of every one Coriolanus will carry it.Impairing Henry, strengthening misproud York, The common people swarm like summer flies; And whither fly the gnats but to the sun?Nay, but speak not maliciously.Let me unkiss the oath 'twixt thee and me; And yet not so, for with a kiss 'twas made.All lost!What?Good news, good news; the ladies have prevail'd, The Volscians are dislodged, and Marcius gone: A merrier day did never yet greet Rome, No, not the expulsion of the Tarquins.The loss of those three lords torments my heart: I'll write unto them and entreat them fair.Come, I'll question you Of my lord's tricks and yours when you were boys: You were pretty lordings then?A thousand times the worse, to want thy light.He said he had wounds, which he could show in private; And with his hat, thus waving it in scorn, 'I would be consul,' says he: 'aged custom, But by your voices, will not so permit me; Your voices therefore.'Here come the lords of Buckingham and Derby.You soothed not, therefore hurt not: but your people, I love them as they weigh.For doting, not for loving, pupil mine.Name of mercy, when was this, boy?Love loving not itself none other can.I fear it is: and yet, methinks, it should not, For he hath still been tried a holy man.Master, if ever I said loose-bodied gown, sew me in the skirts of it, and beat me to death with a bottom of brown thread: I said a gown.March on, my fellows: Make good this ostentation, and you shall Divide in all with us.Madam, farewell.Ay, and have been so any time these four hours.Or cloy the hungry edge of appetite By bare imagination of a feast?Grim-visaged war hath smooth'd his wrinkled front; And now, instead of mounting barded steeds To fright the souls of fearful adversaries, He capers nimbly in a lady's chamber To the lascivious pleasing of a lute.No?I shall not sleep in quiet at the Tower.Did ever dragon keep so fair a cave?Peter!So, to our tent; Where, ere we do repose us, we will write To Rome of our success.My Lord of Warwick, hear me but one word: Let me for this my life-time reign as king.I go.But O, the thorns we stand upon!But I would be loath to fall into my dreams again: I will therefore tarry in despite of the flesh and the blood.O, the most piteous cry of the poor souls!Hear me speak: As I do know the consul's worthiness, So can I name his faults,-- Consul!All my services You have paid home: but that you have vouchsafed, With your crown'd brother and these your contracted Heirs of your kingdoms, my poor house to visit, It is a surplus of your grace, which never My life may last to answer.let us lay hands upon him.O Buckingham, now do I play the touch, To try if thou be current gold indeed Young Edward lives: think now what I would say.Sir, let me be so bold as ask you, Did you yet ever see Baptista's daughter?I shall, sir.Go; I'll to dinner: hie you to the cell.I'll entreat no more.Hark ye; The queen your mother rounds apace: we shall Present our services to a fine new prince One of these days; and then you'ld wanton with us, If we would have you.3 KING HENRY VI Now, Clifford, I have singled thee alone: Suppose this arm is for the Duke of York, And this for Rutland; both bound to revenge, Wert thou environ'd with a brazen wall.Avaunt, thou dreadful minister of hell!Abate the edge of traitors, gracious Lord, That would reduce these bloody days again, And make poor England weep in streams of blood!Sweet sir, much better than I was; I can stand and walk: I will even take my leave of you, and pace softly towards my kinsman's.And he's as like to do't as any man I can imagine.I cannot tell; expect they are busied about a counterfeit assurance: take you assurance of her, 'cum privilegio ad imprimendum solum:' to the church; take the priest, clerk, and some sufficient honest witnesses: If this be not that you look for, I have no more to say, But bid Bianca farewell for ever and a day.God save the king!Becomes it thee to be thus bold in terms Before thy sovereign and thy lawful king?Come, come, we know your meaning, brother Gloucester; You envy my advancement and my friends': God grant we never may have need of you!What is my offence?Make haste, make haste.Best.Nay, I am the very pink of courtesy.Never, Paulina; so be blest my spirit!We are accounted poor citizens, the patricians good.If so thou think'st, vex him with eager words.Fill me a bowl of wine.I must needs wake you; Lady!Why, knows not Montague that of itself England is safe, if true within itself?I do the wrong, and first begin to brawl.What say you, Hugh Rebeck?I came from Edward as ambassador, But I return his sworn and mortal foe: Matter of marriage was the charge he gave me, But dreadful war shall answer his demand.And she's fair I love.Let's before as he bids us: he was provided to do us good.Do you hear how he misplaces?He'll beat Aufidius 'head below his knee And tread upon his neck.cheerly, cheerly, my hearts!what news?I minded him how royal 'twas to pardon When it was less expected: he replied, It was a bare petition of a state To one whom they had punish'd.muffle me, night, awhile.Peace, master marquess, you are malapert: Your fire-new stamp of honour is scarce current.There's no more to be said, but he is banish'd, As enemy to the people and his country: It shall be so.whence grows this insolence?Right well, dear madam.Musicians, O, musicians, 'Heart's ease, Heart's ease:' O, an you will have me live, play 'Heart's ease.'Romeo, I come!Thus then in brief: The valiant Paris seeks you for his love.I call them forth to credit her.This is the way to kindle, not to quench.Why stops my lord, shall I not hear my task?I am content.The ripest fruit first falls, and so doth he; His time is spent, our pilgrimage must be.O, woe the day!The king and prince at prayers!Being i' the war Their mutinies and revolts, wherein they show'd Most valour, spoke not for them: the accusation Which they have often made against the senate, All cause unborn, could never be the motive Of our so frank donation.This is the chase: I am gone for ever.What shall I swear by?Tell him from me that he hath done me wrong, And therefore I'll uncrown him ere't be long.Would they else be content to die?Well, let them rest.What, resists he?Richard yet lives, hell's black intelligencer, Only reserved their factor, to buy souls And send them thither: but at hand, at hand, Ensues his piteous and unpitied end: Earth gapes, hell burns, fiends roar, saints pray.or who pronounced The bitter sentence of poor Clarence' death?I go, my lord.nay, then, good night our part!Unto my mother's prayers I bend my knee.O bloody Richard!The citizens of Corioli have issued, And given to Lartius and to Marcius battle: I saw our party to their trenches driven, And then I came away.'Tis this slave;-- Go whip him, 'fore the people's eyes:--his raising; Nothing but his report.Happy, indeed, as we have spent the day.I have advertised him by secret means That if about this hour he make his way Under the colour of his usual game, He shall here find his friends with horse and men To set him free from his captivity.down, king!is meeting noses?He is both king and Duke of Lancaster; And that the Lord of Westmoreland shall maintain.True, my good lord; I know you for no less.What, pray you, became of Antigonus, that carried hence the child?I am the greatest, able to do least, Yet most suspected, as the time and place Doth make against me of this direful murder; And here I stand, both to impeach and purge Myself condemned and myself excused.Look to your babe, my lord; 'tis yours: Jove send her A better guiding spirit!Go, masters, get you home; be not dismay'd: These are a side that would be glad to have This true which they so seem to fear.friends, part!'Sir Paris, I will make a desperate tender Of my child's love: I think she will be ruled In all respects by me; nay, more, I doubt it not.Ill blows the wind that profits nobody.Repent what you have spoke.Now, now: I have not winked since I saw these sights: the men are not yet cold under water, nor the bear half dined on the gentleman: he's at it now.Well, you are come to me in a happy time; The rather for I have some sport in hand Wherein your cunning can assist me much.Old John of Gaunt is grievous sick, my lord, Suddenly taken; and hath sent post haste To entreat your majesty to visit him.Sir, but you shall come to it, by your honour's leave.Come on; obey: Thy nerves are in their infancy again And have no vigour in them.Come, we are fellows and friends: he was ever too hard for him; I have heard him say so himself.You tallow-face!You lords and heads o' the state, perfidiously He has betray'd your business, and given up, For certain drops of salt, your city Rome, I say 'your city,' to his wife and mother; Breaking his oath and resolution like A twist of rotten silk, never admitting Counsel o' the war, but at his nurse's tears He whined and roar'd away your victory, That pages blush'd at him and men of heart Look'd wondering each at other.He who shall speak for her is afar off guilty But that he speaks.I hardly yet have learn'd To insinuate, flatter, bow, and bend my limbs: Give sorrow leave awhile to tutor me To this submission.Now, by Saint Paul, this news is bad indeed.What is become of Bushy?Come on, bawd; I will instruct thee in my trade; follow.But how long fairly shall her sweet lie last?Nor, gentle daughter, fear you not at all.O most wicked fiend!Then I will give you the serving-creature.Thy hounds shall make the welkin answer them And fetch shrill echoes from the hollow earth.Why does the world report that Kate doth limp?How now!while we reason here, A royal battle might be won and lost Some one take order Buckingham be brought To Salisbury; the rest march on with me.And, in good time, here comes the noble duke.Help me into some house, Benvolio, Or I shall faint.No.In dreadful war mayst thou be overcome, Or live in peace abandon'd and despised!that in his reprieve, Longer or shorter, he may be so fitted That his soul sicken not.O calm, dishonourable, vile submission!Carthage?Claudio to prison?Well, I will do't: Yet, were there but this single plot to lose, This mould of Marcius, they to dust should grind it And throw't against the wind.Of whence are you?Farewell, my lord: securely I espy Virtue with valour couched in thine eye.Faith, sir, if you had told as many lies in his behalf as you have uttered words in your own, you should not pass here; no, though it were as virtuous to lie as to live chastely.O, make them joyful, grant their lawful suit!As fast lock'd up in sleep as guiltless labour When it lies starkly in the traveller's bones: He will not wake.Dost lack any money?Hold, then; go home, be merry, give consent To marry Paris: Wednesday is to-morrow: To-morrow night look that thou lie alone; Let not thy nurse lie with thee in thy chamber: Take thou this vial, being then in bed, And this distilled liquor drink thou off; When presently through all thy veins shall run A cold and drowsy humour, for no pulse Shall keep his native progress, but surcease: No warmth, no breath, shall testify thou livest; The roses in thy lips and cheeks shall fade To paly ashes, thy eyes' windows fall, Like death, when he shuts up the day of life; Each part, deprived of supple government, Shall, stiff and stark and cold, appear like death: And in this borrow'd likeness of shrunk death Thou shalt continue two and forty hours, And then awake as from a pleasant sleep.Come, come, you mock me; this is not the way To win our daughter.Is she not proud?But as a discontented friend, grief-shot With his unkindness?Such a fellow is not to be talked withal.A dog of the house of Montague moves me.Is not this well?More than prince of cats, I can tell you.Where is he?Alas, that Warwick had no more forecast, But, whiles he thought to steal the single ten, The king was slily finger'd from the deck!What service wilt thou do me, if I give them?I'll tell you how these lands are to be got.In the mean time, against thou shalt awake, Shall Romeo by my letters know our drift, And hither shall he come: and he and I Will watch thy waking, and that very night Shall Romeo bear thee hence to Mantua.Lords, farewell.'Tis not four days gone Since I heard thence; these are the words: I think I have the letter here; yes, here it is.Ay, like a dastard and a treacherous coward, As thou didst kill our tender brother Rutland; But ere sunset I'll make thee curse the deed.Is not my teeming date drunk up with time?Most holy sir, I thank you.How fares my noble lord?Prepare you, lords; Summon a session, that we may arraign Our most disloyal lady, for, as she hath Been publicly accused, so shall she have A just and open trial.He must before the deputy, sir; he has given him warning: the deputy cannot abide a whoremaster: if he be a whoremonger, and comes before him, he were as good go a mile on his errand.My Lord Aumerle, I know your daring tongue Scorns to unsay what once it hath deliver'd.Gentle my lord, You scarce can right me throughly then to say You did mistake.Not in this heat, sir, now.In that there's comfort.And thus I prophesy, that many a thousand, Which now mistrust no parcel of my fear, And many an old man's sigh and many a widow's, And many an orphan's water-standing eye-- Men for their sons, wives for their husbands, And orphans for their parents timeless death-- Shall rue the hour that ever thou wast born.I'm out of patience.Slander to the state!O, let me clip ye In arms as sound as when I woo'd, in heart As merry as when our nuptial day was done, And tapers burn'd to bedward!Spare him, spare him!Even as a flattering dream or worthless fancy.He seems to be the more noble in being fantastical: a great man, I'll warrant; I know by the picking on's teeth.Courage, man; the hurt cannot be much.Hear me profess sincerely: had I a dozen sons, each in my love alike and none less dear than thine and my good Marcius, I had rather had eleven die nobly for their country than one voluptuously surfeit out of action.Your love deserves my thanks; but my desert Unmeritable shuns your high request.Nay, as they dare.Name him.I must be married to my brother's daughter, Or else my kingdom stands on brittle glass.Tush, I will stir about, And all things shall be well, I warrant thee, wife: Go thou to Juliet, help to deck up her; I'll not to bed to-night; let me alone; I'll play the housewife for this once.To your court Whiles he was hastening, in the chase, it seems, Of this fair couple, meets he on the way The father of this seeming lady and Her brother, having both their country quitted With this young prince.Soft son!Thou liest, malignant thing!We see the very wreck that we must suffer; And unavoided is the danger now, For suffering so the causes of our wreck.where rode he the whilst?Have you collected them by tribes?What figure of us think you he will bear?Methinks a father Is at the nuptial of his son a guest That best becomes the table.Myself I throw, dread sovereign, at thy foot.Yea, Richard, when I know; for I protest As yet I do not: but, as I can learn, He hearkens after prophecies and dreams; And from the cross-row plucks the letter G.Will you laugh me asleep, for I am very heavy?when my old wife lived, upon This day she was both pantler, butler, cook, Both dame and servant; welcomed all, served all; Would sing her song and dance her turn; now here, At upper end o' the table, now i' the middle; On his shoulder, and his; her face o' fire With labour and the thing she took to quench it, She would to each one sip.But canst thou guess that he doth aim at it?I pray you, daughter, sing; or express yourself in a more comfortable sort: if my son were my husband, I should freelier rejoice in that absence wherein he won honour than in the embracements of his bed where he would show most love.If it be honour in your wars to seem The same you are not, which, for your best ends, You adopt your policy, how is it less or worse, That it shall hold companionship in peace With honour, as in war, since that to both It stands in like request?Therefore take with thee my most heavy curse; Which, in the day of battle, tire thee more Than all the complete armour that thou wear'st!This torture should be roar'd in dismal hell.There's some ill planet reigns: I must be patient till the heavens look With an aspect more favourable.Thus have I politicly begun my reign, And 'tis my hope to end successfully.Write to me very shortly.Why then 'tis mine, if but by Warwick's gift.Was't you that revell'd in our parliament, And made a preachment of your high descent?O thou wicked Hannibal!The fardel there?Will you not push her out?Of all the horses, Whereof we have ta'en good and good store, of all The treasure in this field achieved and city, We render you the tenth, to be ta'en forth, Before the common distribution, at Your only choice.What is the city but the people?Who is most inward with the royal duke?Marry, I will; and this is wisely done.why, thy horn is a foot; and so long am I at the least.O, had it been a stranger, not my child, To smooth his fault I should have been more mild: A partial slander sought I to avoid, And in the sentence my own life destroy'd.Ha!Let me desire your company: he must come, Or what is worst will follow.'Tis such as you, That creep like shadows by him and do sigh At each his needless heavings, such as you Nourish the cause of his awaking: I Do come with words as medicinal as true, Honest as either, to purge him of that humour That presses him from sleep.But who comes here?Farewell.Come, sir; come, sir; come, sir; foh, sir!O, now I want the priest that spake to me: I now repent I told the pursuivant As 'twere triumphing at mine enemies, How they at Pomfret bloodily were butcher'd, And I myself secure in grace and favour.Thou hast never in thy life Show'd thy dear mother any courtesy, When she, poor hen, fond of no second brood, Has cluck'd thee to the wars and safely home, Loaden with honour.Traitors!much upon this time have I promised here to meet.The warrants for yourself; take heed to't.Yours, if you talk of tails: and so farewell.Speak ere thou diest.O sweet Juliet, Thy beauty hath made me effeminate And in my temper soften'd valour's steel!No.Come, sir, leave me your snatches, and yield me a direct answer.O noble prince, I can discover all The unlucky manage of this fatal brawl: There lies the man, slain by young Romeo, That slew thy kinsman, brave Mercutio.I have laboured for the poor gentleman to the extremest shore of my modesty: but my brother justice have I found so severe, that he hath forced me to tell him he is indeed Justice.I would I were a Roman; for I cannot, Being a Volsce, be that I am.'Tis some odd humour pricks him to this fashion; Yet oftentimes he goes but mean-apparell'd.I prithee now, sweet son, as thou hast said My praises made thee first a soldier, so, To have my praise for this, perform a part Thou hast not done before.Come, Camillo, And take her by the hand, whose worth and honesty Is richly noted and here justified By us, a pair of kings.foul treason!Shall I have some water?Go you before, and I will follow you.'Tis figured in my tongue.I will not seal your knowledge with showing them.My lord, you told me you would tell the rest, When weeping made you break the story off, of our two cousins coming into London.Will you go along with us?But might you do't, and do the world no wrong, If so your heart were touch'd with that remorse As mine is to him?Take my cap, Jupiter, and I thank thee.Ah, what a shame were this!I think you have As little skill to fear as I have purpose To put you to't.Shall I so much dishonour my fair stars, On equal terms to give him chastisement?O Margaret, thus 'twill be; and thou, poor soul, Art then forsaken, as thou went'st forlorn!Your guest, then, madam: To be your prisoner should import offending; Which is for me less easy to commit Than you to punish.why, 'twas my care And what loss is it to be rid of care?Where is the duke my father with his power?lady!I tell you, 'tis incredible to believe How much she loves me: O, the kindest Kate!Aside, aside; here is more matter for a hot brain: every lane's end, every shop, church, session, hanging, yields a careful man work.What fit is this, good lady?Go on before; I'll talk with this good fellow.What fray was here?What valiant foemen, like to autumn's corn, Have we mow'd down, in tops of all their pride!'Tis done by me, and ends in 'Margaret.'Back, I say, go; lest I let forth your half-pint of blood; back,--that's the utmost of your having: back.Thou, now a-dying, say'st thou flatterest me.Go, say I sent thee forth to purchase honour And not the king exiled thee; or suppose Devouring pestilence hangs in our air And thou art flying to a fresher clime: Look, what thy soul holds dear, imagine it To lie that way thou go'st, not whence thou comest: Suppose the singing birds musicians, The grass whereon thou tread'st the presence strew'd, The flowers fair ladies, and thy steps no more Than a delightful measure or a dance; For gnarling sorrow hath less power to bite The man that mocks at it and sets it light.thy famous grandfather Doth live again in thee: long mayst thou live To bear his image and renew his glories!come, tell me true: it shall be the better for you.Prove this, thou wicked Hannibal, or I'll have mine action of battery on thee.A dish that I do love to feed upon.Thou old traitor, I am sorry that by hanging thee I can But shorten thy life one week.You have an unspeakable comfort of your young prince Mamillius: it is a gentleman of the greatest promise that ever came into my note.That apprehends no further than this world, And squarest thy life according.Hadst thou but loved him half so well as I, Or felt that pain which I did for him once, Or nourish'd him as I did with my blood, Thou wouldst have left thy dearest heart-blood there, Rather than have that savage duke thine heir And disinherited thine only son.They have scared away two of my best sheep, which I fear the wolf will sooner find than the master: if any where I have them, 'tis by the seaside, browsing of ivy.Thy overflow of good converts to bad, And thy abundant goodness shall excuse This deadly blot in thy digressing son.Tybalt, Mercutio, the prince expressly hath Forbidden bandying in Verona streets: Hold, Tybalt!If he were dead, what would betide of me?Come and lead me Unto these sorrows.I mind to tell him plainly what I think.Friends now fast sworn, Whose double bosoms seem to wear one heart, Whose house, whose bed, whose meal, and exercise, Are still together, who twin, as 'twere, in love Unseparable, shall within this hour, On a dissension of a doit, break out To bitterest enmity: so, fellest foes, Whose passions and whose plots have broke their sleep, To take the one the other, by some chance, Some trick not worth an egg, shall grow dear friends And interjoin their issues.my master is mad.Where is he wounded?But wilt thou make a fire, or shall I complain on thee to our mistress, whose hand, she being now at hand, thou shalt soon feel, to thy cold comfort, for being slow in thy hot office?The assault that Angelo hath made to you, fortune hath conveyed to my understanding; and, but that frailty hath examples for his falling, I should wonder at Angelo.He's poor in no one fault, but stored with all.If heaven have any grievous plague in store Exceeding those that I can wish upon thee, O, let them keep it till thy sins be ripe, And then hurl down their indignation On thee, the troubler of the poor world's peace!Is not his heir a well-deserving son?no mates for you, Unless you were of gentler, milder mould.Why that way?the tribunes do attend you: arm yourself To answer mildly; for they are prepared With accusations, as I hear, more strong Than are upon you yet.if you be he, sir, I desire some confidence with you.A murrain on't!Call him my king by whose injurious doom My elder brother, the Lord Aubrey Vere, Was done to death?3 KING HENRY VI I wonder how our princely father 'scaped, Or whether he be 'scaped away or no From Clifford's and Northumberland's pursuit: Had he been ta'en, we should have heard the news; Had he been slain, we should have heard the news; Or had he 'scaped, methinks we should have heard The happy tidings of his good escape.here lies the county slain, And Juliet bleeding, warm, and newly dead, Who here hath lain these two days buried.I would there were no age between sixteen and three-and-twenty, or that youth would sleep out the rest; for there is nothing in the between but getting wenches with child, wronging the ancientry, stealing, fighting--Hark you now!That we have been familiar, Ingrate forgetfulness shall poison, rather Than pity note how much.That doth utter all men's ware-a.Maiden, no remedy.Where is he wounded?Well, come, my Kate; we will unto your father's Even in these honest mean habiliments: Our purses shall be proud, our garments poor; For 'tis the mind that makes the body rich; And as the sun breaks through the darkest clouds, So honour peereth in the meanest habit.Villains, set down the corse; or, by Saint Paul, I'll make a corse of him that disobeys.O wife, look how our daughter bleeds!Gentlemen, content ye; I am resolved: Go in, Bianca: And for I know she taketh most delight In music, instruments and poetry, Schoolmasters will I keep within my house, Fit to instruct her youth.The visitor will not give him o'er so.Boy!Never, my lord; therefore prepare to die.Well said: follow me this jest now till thou hast worn out thy pump, that when the single sole of it is worn, the jest may remain after the wearing sole singular.Yet of your royal presence I'll adventure The borrow of a week.the sun: it is not moonlight now.Ay, by my faith, for a poor earl to give: I'll do thee service for so good a gift.Taste of it first, as thou art wont to do.Farewell, sweet masters both; I must be gone.Sir, I will give you as much as this old man does when the business is performed, and remain, as he says, your pawn till it be brought you.No, coz, I rather weep.Oh for my husband, for my dear lord Edward!This lies glowing, I can tell you, and is almost mature for the violent breaking out.fiend angelical!Our natures do pursue, Like rats that ravin down their proper bane, A thirsty evil; and when we drink we die.To express the like kindness, myself, that have been more kindly beholding to you than any, freely give unto you this young scholar, that hath been long studying at Rheims; as cunning in Greek, Latin, and other languages, as the other in music and mathematics: his name is Cambio; pray, accept his service.Bliss and goodness on you!Despised, distressed, hated, martyr'd, kill'd!Hail sir!Most worthy madam, Your honour and your goodness is so evident That your free undertaking cannot miss A thriving issue: there is no lady living So meet for this great errand.Right, As snow in harvest.There is our commission, From which we would not have you warp.I tell thee, We have a power on foot; and I had purpose Once more to hew thy target from thy brawn, Or lose mine arm fort: thou hast beat me out Twelve several times, and I have nightly since Dreamt of encounters 'twixt thyself and me; We have been down together in my sleep, Unbuckling helms, fisting each other's throat, And waked half dead with nothing.He dreads his wife.Even for our kitchens We kill the fowl of season: shall we serve heaven With less respect than we do minister To our gross selves?But, hark, what noise?Hover about her; say, that right for right Hath dimm'd your infant morn to aged night.Let it be virtuous to be obstinate.Most royal sir, from thence; from him, whose daughter His tears proclaim'd his, parting with her: thence, A prosperous south-wind friendly, we have cross'd, To execute the charge my father gave me For visiting your highness: my best train I have from your Sicilian shores dismiss'd; Who for Bohemia bend, to signify Not only my success in Libya, sir, But my arrival and my wife's in safety Here where we are.Take him to prison, officer: Correction and instruction must both work Ere this rude beast will profit.Hail, most royal sir!I must confess to you, sir, I am no fighter: I am false of heart that way; and that he knew, I warrant him.What became of his bark and his followers?Why 'Heart's ease?'Having waste ground enough, Shall we desire to raze the sanctuary And pitch our evils there?Does your worship mean to geld and splay all the youth of the city?Thy friends suspect for traitors while thou livest, And take deep traitors for thy dearest friends!Ah, that thy father had been so resolved!Read the indictment.For myself, son, I purpose not to wait on fortune till These wars determine: if I cannot persuade thee Rather to show a noble grace to both parts Than seek the end of one, thou shalt no sooner March to assault thy country than to tread-- Trust to't, thou shalt not--on thy mother's womb, That brought thee to this world.Gentle my liege,-- You do but lose your labour.I do not know what witchcraft's in him, but Your soldiers use him as the grace 'fore meat, Their talk at table, and their thanks at end; And you are darken'd in this action, sir, Even by your own.Let them have scope: though what they do impart Help not all, yet do they ease the heart.But in the other's silence do I see Maid's mild behavior and sobriety.how began it first?I know it pleaseth neither of us well.3 KING HENRY VI Master lieutenant, now that God and friends Have shaken Edward from the regal seat, And turn'd my captive state to liberty, My fear to hope, my sorrows unto joys, At our enlargement what are thy due fees?God shield I should disturb devotion!lack I credit?Such a nature, Tickled with good success, disdains the shadow Which he treads on at noon: but I do wonder His insolence can brook to be commanded Under Cominius.it stinted and said 'Ay.'I have loved thee,-- Make that thy question, and go rot!Good lady, No court in Europe is too good for thee; What dost thou then in prison?As I remember, this should be the house.For I have heard it said There is an art which in their piedness shares With great creating nature.I tell thee what: get thee to church o' Thursday, Or never after look me in the face: Speak not, reply not, do not answer me; My fingers itch.To-morrow; to-day; presently; you shall have the drum struck up this afternoon: 'tis, as it were, a parcel of their feast, and to be executed ere they wipe their lips.We will give you sleepy drinks, that your senses, unintelligent of our insufficience, may, though they cannot praise us, as little accuse us.This is thy sheath; there rust, and let me die.My lord, cheer up your spirits: our foes are nigh, And this soft courage makes your followers faint.Clifford, ask mercy and obtain no grace.What, is the man lunatic?What shouts are these?I'll to my brother: Though he hath fallen by prompture of the blood, Yet hath he in him such a mind of honour.He'll go, he says, and sowl the porter of Rome gates by the ears: he will mow all down before him, and leave his passage polled.Forward, I pray, since we have come so far, And be it moon, or sun, or what you please: An if you please to call it a rush-candle, Henceforth I vow it shall be so for me.set her two courses off to sea again; lay her off.Whate'er it be, be thou still like thyself, And sit thee by our side: Yield not thy neck To fortune's yoke, but let thy dauntless mind Still ride in triumph over all mischance.Better it is to die, better to starve, Than crave the hire which first we do deserve.She is too fair, too wise, wisely too fair, To merit bliss by making me despair: She hath forsworn to love, and in that vow Do I live dead that live to tell it now.His neck will come to your waist,--a cord, sir.No, no, men living flatter those that die.Ratcliff, about the mid of night come to my tent And help to arm me.Do you not smile at this, Lord Angelo?Go you to Juliet ere you go to bed, Prepare her, wife, against this wedding-day.Though there the people had more absolute power, I say, they nourish'd disobedience, fed The ruin of the state.He kills her in her own humour.Be opposite all planets of good luck To my proceedings, if, with pure heart's love, Immaculate devotion, holy thoughts, I tender not thy beauteous princely daughter!What, at the wheels of Caesar?The brightness of her cheek would shame those stars, As daylight doth a lamp; her eyes in heaven Would through the airy region stream so bright That birds would sing and think it were not night.That Edward is escaped from your brother, And fled, as he hears since, to Burgundy.How fares the prince?must we part?Force me to keep you as a prisoner, Not like a guest; so you shall pay your fees When you depart, and save your thanks.He sits in his state, as a thing made for Alexander.Let her alone, lady: as she is now, she will but disease our better mirth.Here, Hastings; I will never more remember Our former hatred, so thrive I and mine!And by an eminent body that enforced The law against it!Stay, officer: he shall not go to prison.You have paid the heavens your function, and the prisoner the very debt of your calling.A pair of tribunes that have rack'd for Rome, To make coals cheap,--a noble memory!Ay, but thou talk'st as if thou wert a king.Here do we make his friends Blush that the world goes well, who rather had, Though they themselves did suffer by't, behold Dissentious numbers pestering streets than see Our tradesmen with in their shops and going About their functions friendly.What sorrow craves acquaintance at my hand, That I yet know not?And leave out thee?Northumberland, thou ladder wherewithal The mounting Bolingbroke ascends my throne, The time shall not be many hours of age More than it is ere foul sin gathering head Shalt break into corruption: thou shalt think, Though he divide the realm and give thee half, It is too little, helping him to all; And he shall think that thou, which know'st the way To plant unrightful kings, wilt know again, Being ne'er so little urged, another way To pluck him headlong from the usurped throne.O royal piece, There's magic in thy majesty, which has My evils conjured to remembrance and From thy admiring daughter took the spirits, Standing like stone with thee.I'll make you quiet.Was ever man so proud as is this Marcius?But, leaving this, what is your grace's pleasure?Should a villain say so, The most replenish'd villain in the world, He were as much more villain: you, my lord, Do but mistake.These words hereafter thy tormentors be!And, Clarence, now then it is more than needful Forthwith that Edward be pronounced a traitor, And all his lands and goods be confiscate.And this thy son's blood cleaving to my blade Shall rust upon my weapon, till thy blood, Congeal'd with this, do make me wipe off both.I had rather chop this hand off at a blow, And with the other fling it at thy face, Than bear so low a sail, to strike to thee.Further I say and further will maintain Upon his bad life to make all this good, That he did plot the Duke of Gloucester's death, Suggest his soon-believing adversaries, And consequently, like a traitor coward, Sluiced out his innocent soul through streams of blood: Which blood, like sacrificing Abel's, cries, Even from the tongueless caverns of the earth, To me for justice and rough chastisement; And, by the glorious worth of my descent, This arm shall do it, or this life be spent.Good lords, make all the speedy haste you may.Even when you please, since you will have it so.No farther than the Tower; and, as I guess, Upon the like devotion as yourselves, To gratulate the gentle princes there.This dagger hath mista'en--for, lo, his house Is empty on the back of Montague,-- And it mis-sheathed in my daughter's bosom!Come, sir, your passado.How!O my good lord!By my heel, I care not.What's your will, good friar?or did I dream it so?God mark thee to his grace!No joyful tongue gave him his welcome home: But dust was thrown upon his sacred head: Which with such gentle sorrow he shook off, His face still combating with tears and smiles, The badges of his grief and patience, That had not God, for some strong purpose, steel'd The hearts of men, they must perforce have melted And barbarism itself have pitied him.O, but impatience waiteth on true sorrow.Upon his party: he, mistrusting them, Hoisted sail and made away for Brittany.Sir, he may live: I saw him beat the surges under him, And ride upon their backs; he trod the water, Whose enmity he flung aside, and breasted The surge most swoln that met him; his bold head 'Bove the contentious waves he kept, and oar'd Himself with his good arms in lusty stroke To the shore, that o'er his wave-worn basis bow'd, As stooping to relieve him: I not doubt He came alive to land.That jade hath eat bread from my royal hand; This hand hath made him proud with clapping him.Can thy dam?--may't be?-- Affection!Bootless are plaints, and cureless are my wounds; No way to fly, nor strength to hold out flight: The foe is merciless, and will not pity; For at their hands I have deserved no pity.Then must your brother die.Come, you shall go with us.At my poor house look to behold this night Earth-treading stars that make dark heaven light: Such comfort as do lusty young men feel When well-apparell'd April on the heel Of limping winter treads, even such delight Among fresh female buds shall you this night Inherit at my house; hear all, all see, And like her most whose merit most shall be: Which on more view, of many mine being one May stand in number, though in reckoning none, Come, go with me.But now the Duke of Buckingham and I Are come from visiting his majesty.Go, bear them hence; I will not hear them speak.Nay, if thy wits run the wild-goose chase, I have done, for thou hast more of the wild-goose in one of thy wits than, I am sure, I have in my whole five: was I with you there for the goose?Make war upon themselves; blood against blood, Self against self: O, preposterous And frantic outrage, end thy damned spleen; Or let me die, to look on death no more!Thus have you breathed your curse against yourself.Why, thou Mars!John Duke of Norfolk, Walter Lord Ferrers, Sir Robert Brakenbury, and Sir William Brandon.Why, what's a moveable?you have crafted fair!And the queen's sons and brothers haught and proud: And were they to be ruled, and not to rule, This sickly land might solace as before.How oddly thou repliest!We thank you both: yet one but flatters us, As well appeareth by the cause you come; Namely to appeal each other of high treason.Your highness shall do well to grant her suit; It were dishonour to deny it her.His word is more than the miraculous harp; he hath raised the wall and houses too.The senators of Rome are this good belly, And you the mutinous members; for examine Their counsels and their cares, digest things rightly Touching the weal o' the common, you shall find No public benefit which you receive But it proceeds or comes from them to you And no way from yourselves.What Eve, what serpent, hath suggested thee To make a second fall of cursed man?O day!should it then be thus?What dreadful noise of waters in mine ears!Or as 'twere perfumed by a fen.Now, afore God!If thou deny'st it twenty times, thou liest; And I will turn thy falsehood to thy heart, Where it was forged, with my rapier's point.I mean, in a sort.You must in no way say he is covetous.For you, be that you are, long; and your misery increase with your age!Petruchio, go thy ways; the field is won.Let that suffice.Ay, on my life; and hopes to find forward Upon his party for the gain thereof: And thereupon he sends you this good news, That this same very day your enemies, The kindred of the queen, must die at Pomfret.And have you nuns no farther privileges?Be it so; go back: the virtue of your name Is not here passable.whose breath I hate As reek o' the rotten fens, whose loves I prize As the dead carcasses of unburied men That do corrupt my air, I banish you; And here remain with your uncertainty!There's nothing ill can dwell in such a temple: If the ill spirit have so fair a house, Good things will strive to dwell with't.But, Warwick, Thou and Oxford, with five thousand men, Shall cross the seas, and bid false Edward battle; And, as occasion serves, this noble queen And prince shall follow with a fresh supply.How now, sirrah!I will wish her speedy strength, and visit her with my prayers; but I cannot go thither.Alack, poor soul!Our business is not unknown to the senate; they have had inkling this fortnight what we intend to do, which now we'll show 'em in deeds.Come on, and kiss me, Kate.O, give me thy hand, One writ with me in sour misfortune's book!I do beseech you, By all the battles wherein we have fought, By the blood we have shed together, by the vows We have made to endure friends, that you directly Set me against Aufidius and his Antiates; And that you not delay the present, but, Filling the air with swords advanced and darts, We prove this very hour.Not I, believe me: thus I'll visit her.Nor is your firm resolve unknown to me, In the preferment of the eldest sister.Yet one word more: grief boundeth where it falls, Not with the empty hollowness, but weight: I take my leave before I have begun, For sorrow ends not when it seemeth done.She's dead, deceased, she's dead; alack the day!Then let my father's blood open it again: He is a man, and, Clifford, cope with him.But come; since this bar in law makes us friends, it shall be so far forth friendly maintained all by helping Baptista's eldest daughter to a husband we set his youngest free for a husband, and then have to't a fresh.More than mistress of Which comes to me in name of fault, I must not At all acknowledge.If you can, pace your wisdom In that good path that I would wish it go, And you shall have your bosom on this wretch, Grace of the duke, revenges to your heart, And general honour.Who hath committed them?Let them not live to taste this land's increase That would with treason wound this fair land's peace!Then his good report should have been my son; I therein would have found issue.Besides, if things go well, Opinion that so sticks on Marcius shall Of his demerits rob Cominius.First kiss me, Kate, and we will.Not I, believe me: you have dancing shoes With nimble soles: I have a soul of lead So stakes me to the ground I cannot move.I go, my lord.Who knew of Your intent and coming hither?My only love sprung from my only hate!by some severals Of head-piece extraordinary?This will I carry to Rome.Now, as fond fathers, Having bound up the threatening twigs of birch, Only to stick it in their children's sight For terror, not to use, in time the rod Becomes more mock'd than fear'd; so our decrees, Dead to infliction, to themselves are dead; And liberty plucks justice by the nose; The baby beats the nurse, and quite athwart Goes all decorum.Did York's dread curse prevail so much with heaven?thy wife?A curse begin at very root on's heart, That is not glad to see thee!What, my old worshipful old master?I'll have this crown of mine cut from my shoulders Ere I will see the crown so foul misplaced.I know by that he's dead; and, by my soul, If this right hand would buy two hour's life, That I in all despite might rail at him, This hand should chop it off, and with the issuing blood Stifle the villain whose unstanched thirst York and young Rutland could not satisfy.I know not where; but wheresoever, I wish him well.O, this same thought did but forerun my need; And this same needy man must sell it me.conveyers are you all, That rise thus nimbly by a true king's fall.Nurse!This is a creature, Would she begin a sect, might quench the zeal Of all professors else, make proselytes Of who she but bid follow.you have all moved mine.Softly and swiftly, sir; for the priest is ready.The more fool you, for laying on my duty.Now Margaret's curse is fall'n upon our heads, For standing by when Richard stabb'd her son.Thy best of rest is sleep, And that thou oft provokest; yet grossly fear'st Thy death, which is no more.Thy father hath.say.I am
