question'd by my fears, of what may chance Or breed upon our absence; that may blow No sneaping winds at home, to make us say 'This is put forth too truly:' besides, I have stay'd To tire your royalty.Come.Not all the water in the rough rude sea Can wash the balm off from an anointed king; The breath of worldly men cannot depose The deputy elected by the Lord: For every man that Bolingbroke hath press'd To lift shrewd steel against our golden crown, God for his Richard hath in heavenly pay A glorious angel: then, if angels fight, Weak men must fall, for heaven still guards the right.Then, England's ground, farewell; sweet soil, adieu; My mother, and my nurse, that bears me yet!Heaven shield your grace from woe, As I, thus wrong'd, hence unbelieved go!I do make myself believe that you may most uprighteously do a poor wronged lady a merited benefit; redeem your brother from the angry law; do no stain to your own gracious person; and much please the absent duke, if peradventure he shall ever return to have hearing of this business.Marry, this Claudio is condemned for untrussing.I met the youthful lord at Laurence' cell; And gave him what becomed love I might, Not step o'er the bounds of modesty.Hark how I'll bribe you: good my lord, turn back.Come, lead me to the block; bear him my head.Patience perforce with wilful choler meeting Makes my flesh tremble in their different greeting.There is my gage, the manual seal of death, That marks thee out for hell: I say, thou liest, And will maintain what thou hast said is false In thy heart-blood, though being all too base To stain the temper of my knightly sword.How!Yes, in good sooth, the vice is of a great kindred; it is well allied: but it is impossible to extirp it quite, friar, till eating and drinking be put down.Marry, sir, with needle and thread.He heareth not, he stirreth not, he moveth not; The ape is dead, and I must conjure him.Stop, Or all will fall in broil.That is my office, for my father's sake.Come, gentlemen, let's go.No; I will to Ireland to his majesty.No, Warwick, thou art worthy of the sway, To whom the heavens in thy nativity Adjudged an olive branch and laurel crown, As likely to be blest in peace and war; And therefore I yield thee my free consent.My business, sir, is to the king.If ever he have child, abortive be it, Prodigious, and untimely brought to light, Whose ugly and unnatural aspect May fright the hopeful mother at the view; And that be heir to his unhappiness!Lords, give us leave: I'll try this widow's wit.O Margaret, Margaret, now thy heavy curse Is lighted on poor Hastings' wretched head!Wrath makes him deaf: speak thou, Northumberland.Why faint you, lords?I'll reconcile me to Polixenes, New woo my queen, recall the good Camillo, Whom I proclaim a man of truth, of mercy; For, being transported by my jealousies To bloody thoughts and to revenge, I chose Camillo for the minister to poison My friend Polixenes: which had been done, But that the good mind of Camillo tardied My swift command, though I with death and with Reward did threaten and encourage him, Not doing 't and being done: he, most humane And fill'd with honour, to my kingly guest Unclasp'd my practise, quit his fortunes here, Which you knew great, and to the hazard Of all encertainties himself commended, No richer than his honour: how he glisters Thorough my rust!If he be not born to be hanged, our case is miserable.See, to beguile the old folks, how the young folks lay their heads together!Hail to you both!Great God of heaven, say Amen to all!But who comes here?If I do so, it will be of more price, Being spoke behind your back, than to your face.or strike, ungentle death!Who can be patient in such extremes?My cake is dough; but I'll in among the rest, Out of hope of all, but my share of the feast.Her cause and yours I'll perfect him withal, and he shall bring you Before the duke, and to the head of Angelo Accuse him home and home.Naught to do with mistress Shore!One i' the neck, and two i' the thigh,--there's nine that I know.Right, I mean you.I will pray, Pompey, to increase your bondage: If you take it not patiently, why, your mettle is the more.Here is the sister of the man condemn'd Desires access to you.To sue to live, I find I seek to die; And, seeking death, find life: let it come on.Hast thou no letters to me from the friar?Romeo!My sons, God knows what hath bechanced them: But this I know, they have demean'd themselves Like men born to renown by life or death.what, ladybird!This is the day that, in King Edward's time, I wish't might fall on me, when I was found False to his children or his wife's allies This is the day wherein I wish'd to fall By the false faith of him I trusted most; This, this All-Souls' day to my fearful soul Is the determined respite of my wrongs: That high All-Seer that I dallied with Hath turn'd my feigned prayer on my head And given in earnest what I begg'd in jest.I thank you.So, now prosperity begins to mellow And drop into the rotten mouth of death.It beats as it would fall in twenty pieces.No, I'll die here.Go some of you and fetch a looking-glass.what may I call your name?Come hither to me, Master Elbow; come hither, Master constable.Romeo!That 'only' came well in.'What, ho!'And must she die for this?Many good morrows to my noble lord!Come, enter with us.Why, hark you!True, so I am.You, sir, Charge him too coldly.A join'd-stool.Then, masters, look to see a troublous world.Welcome, gentlemen!Away with the joint-stools, remove the court-cupboard, look to the plate.Her natural posture!quoth he; And, pretty fool, it stinted and said 'Ay.'My lord, I like not of this flight of Edward's; For doubtless Burgundy will yield him help, And we shall have more wars before 't be long.Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?By heaven, I think there's no man is secure But the queen's kindred and night-walking heralds That trudge betwixt the king and Mistress Shore.But when the duke is slain, they'll quickly fly.And here's to right our gentle-hearted king.Nay, then indeed she cannot choose but hate thee, Having bought love with such a bloody spoil.I had rather be a country servant-maid Than a great queen, with this condition, To be thus taunted, scorn'd, and baited at: Small joy have I in being England's queen.Ay, all of them at Bristol lost their heads.A dire induction am I witness to, And will to France, hoping the consequence Will prove as bitter, black, and tragical.I know your virtue hath a licence in't, Which seems a little fouler than it is, To pluck on others.So do I ever: being well-advised.Look that my staves be sound, and not too heavy.Have not saints lips, and holy palmers too?tell me.I come, Plantagenet!Quarrel sir!But so is not she.But, if ever the duke return, as our prayers are he may, let me desire you to make your answer before him.Alas, alas!Why, how now, daughter Katharina!I know my duty; you are all undutiful: Lascivious Edward, and thou perjured George, And thou mis-shapen Dick, I tell ye all I am your better, traitors as ye are: And thou usurp'st my father's right and mine.mutton?A murderous villain, and so still thou art.I would they were in Tiber!How now, what news with you?O fine villain!Ay, what's o'clock?Open Thy gate of mercy, gracious God!Take that, thou likeness of this railer here.Ha!Petruchio, stand by a while.The exchange of thy love's faithful vow for mine.Hark, hark, my lord!And mine with hers, and thine, and Margaret's.If ever I was respected with her, or she with me, let not your worship think me the poor duke's officer.Wisely and slow; they stumble that run fast.Hath she had any more than one husband?Mistake me not, my lord; 'tis not my meaning To raze one title of your honour out: To you, my lord, I come, what lord you will, From the most gracious regent of this land, The Duke of York, to know what pricks you on To take advantage of the absent time And fright our native peace with self-born arms.Are you at leisure, holy father, now; Or shall I come to you at evening mass?Come your way, sir.We stood to't in good time.The latter end of his commonwealth forgets the beginning.what, is there such a place?will his majesty Give Richard leave to live till Richard die?Now, fair befal thee, good Petruchio!I can bear my part; you must know 'tis my occupation; have at it with you.It must be great that can inherit us So much as of a thought of ill in him.I prithee, grieve, to make me merry, York.Come, cousin you shall be the messenger.O Tullus,-- Thou hast done a deed whereat valour will weep.Pardon me, madam: little joy have I To breathe this news; yet what I say is true.How now!To, to, to-- To murder me?Come: Half all Cominius' honours are to Marcius.Lechery?But he, poor soul, by your first order died, And that a winged Mercury did bear: Some tardy cripple bore the countermand, That came too lag to see him buried.Well, but what's o'clock?And joy comes well in such a needy time: What are they, I beseech your ladyship?But, my daughter, Say you the like to him?You see, sweet maid, we marry A gentler scion to the wildest stock, And make conceive a bark of baser kind By bud of nobler race: this is an art Which does mend nature, change it rather, but The art itself is nature.Quick proceeders, marry!We must disguise ourselves.Here stand we both, and aim we at the best: And, for the time shall not seem tedious, I'll tell thee what befell me on a day In this self-place where now we mean to stand.Had I a glass, I would.Most mighty liege, and my companion peers, Take from my mouth the wish of happy years: As gentle and as jocund as to jest Go I to fight: truth hath a quiet breast.my mangled body shows, My blood, my want of strength, my sick heart shows.True, indeed!Alas!Welcome home, Grumio!what a foolish duty call you this?but they were none.There spake my brother; there my father's grave Did utter forth a voice.The gods themselves, Humbling their deities to love, have taken The shapes of beasts upon them: Jupiter Became a bull, and bellow'd; the green Neptune A ram, and bleated; and the fire-robed god, Golden Apollo, a poor humble swain, As I seem now.Where is that damned villain Tranio, That faced and braved me in this matter so?First if all obstacles were cut away, And that my path were even to the crown, As my ripe revenue and due by birth Yet so much is my poverty of spirit, So mighty and so many my defects, As I had rather hide me from my greatness, Being a bark to brook no mighty sea, Than in my greatness covet to be hid, And in the vapour of my glory smother'd.And what of him?Thou hast undone thyself, thy son and me; And given unto the house of York such head As thou shalt reign but by their sufferance.A man, as you are.Why, what a peevish fool was that of Crete, That taught his son the office of a fowl!So.This liberty is all that I request, That, upon knowledge of my parentage, I may have welcome 'mongst the rest that woo And free access and favour as the rest: And, toward the education of your daughters, I here bestow a simple instrument, And this small packet of Greek and Latin books: If you accept them, then their worth is great.Awaked you not with this sore agony?What is the wager?We'll make an instrument of this, omit Nothing may give us aid.O, look!I sometime lay here in Corioli At a poor man's house; he used me kindly: He cried to me; I saw him prisoner; But then Aufidius was within my view, And wrath o'erwhelm'd my pity: I request you To give my poor host freedom.Well, be't so, prithee.What will you read to her?For Edward, for my brother, for his sake: Why, sirs, He sends ye not to murder me for this For in this sin he is as deep as I. If God will be revenged for this deed.Montague hath breathed his last; And to the latest gasp cried out for Warwick, And said 'Commend me to my valiant brother.'Thine eyes, sweet lady, have infected mine.To the most of men this is a Caliban And they to him are angels.Take thou that: Live, and be prosperous: and farewell, good fellow.Will you be ready?why, no; I, that do speak a word.We'll surety him.Why, here is the note of the fashion to testify Read it.Do you know this lady?'Tis so: and as war, in some sort, may be said to be a ravisher, so it cannot be denied but peace is a great maker of cuckolds.Why, very well; I hope here be truths.I fear, too early: for my mind misgives Some consequence yet hanging in the stars Shall bitterly begin his fearful date With this night's revels and expire the term Of a despised life closed in my breast By some vile forfeit of untimely death.When we were chosen tribunes for the people,-- Mark'd you his lip and eyes?How say you, Signior Gremio?What is her mother?Let him, my son: he shall not need to grieve At knowing of thy choice.Not a word, a word; we stand upon our manners.But since you come too late of our intents, Yet witness what you hear we did intend: And so, my good lord mayor, we bid farewell.Go, villain, fetch a surgeon.Tranio, let's go: one thing more rests, that thyself execute, to make one among these wooers: if thou ask me why, sufficeth, my reasons are both good and weighty.Now tell me, madam, do you love your children?So did we all.how love to me and to her son Hath made her break out into terms of rage!Well-minded Clarence, be thou fortunate!My lord, 'tis nothing.Sirs, I will practise on this drunken man.Masters of the people, Your multiplying spawn how can he flatter-- That's thousand to one good one--when you now see He had rather venture all his limbs for honour Than one on's ears to hear it?This royal throne of kings, this scepter'd isle, This earth of majesty, this seat of Mars, This other Eden, demi-paradise, This fortress built by Nature for herself Against infection and the hand of war, This happy breed of men, this little world, This precious stone set in the silver sea, Which serves it in the office of a wall, Or as a moat defensive to a house, Against the envy of less happier lands, This blessed plot, this earth, this realm, this England, This nurse, this teeming womb of royal kings, Fear'd by their breed and famous by their birth, Renowned for their deeds as far from home, For Christian service and true chivalry, As is the sepulchre in stubborn Jewry, Of the world's ransom, blessed Mary's Son, This land of such dear souls, this dear dear land, Dear for her reputation through the world, Is now leased out, I die pronouncing it, Like to a tenement or pelting farm: England, bound in with the triumphant sea Whose rocky shore beats back the envious siege Of watery Neptune, is now bound in with shame, With inky blots and rotten parchment bonds: That England, that was wont to conquer others, Hath made a shameful conquest of itself.Earl of Northumberland, he slew thy father.O, these I lack, To make you garlands of, and my sweet friend, To strew him o'er and o'er!I have.Let's ha't, good Grumio.So many guests invite as here are writ.I pray thee, chide not; she whom I love now Doth grace for grace and love for love allow; The other did not so.Alas, alas!And not a jot of Tranio in your mouth: Tranio is changed into Lucentio.The king enacts more wonders than a man, Daring an opposite to every danger: His horse is slain, and all on foot he fights, Seeking for Richmond in the throat of death.We wait upon your grace.Sir, my liege, Your eye hath too much youth in't: not a month 'Fore your queen died, she was more worth such gazes Than what you look on now.But, gentle Lady Anne, To leave this keen encounter of our wits, And fall somewhat into a slower method, Is not the causer of the timeless deaths Of these Plantagenets, Henry and Edward, As blameful as the executioner?widow Dido!We can both sing it: if thou'lt bear a part, thou shalt hear; 'tis in three parts.I hear my master.Camillo and Polixenes Laugh at me, make their pastime at my sorrow: They should not laugh if I could reach them, nor Shall she within my power.Now the good gods forbid That our renowned Rome, whose gratitude Towards her deserved children is enroll'd In Jove's own book, like an unnatural dam Should now eat up her own!Your aery buildeth in our aery's nest.But is there any?Dreams are toys: Yet for this once, yea, superstitiously, I will be squared by this.We are true subjects to the king, King Edward.What, shall we suffer this?Now, Montague, sit fast; I seek for thee, That Warwick's bones may keep thine company.He hath paid you all he promised you; may be, he has paid you more, which will shame you to give him again.an hasty-witted body Would say your head and butt were head and horn.But how did you desire it should be made?O deadly sin!See them deliver'd over To execution and the hand of death.And,--do you mark me, sir?Who does infect her?drunk all, and left no friendly drop To help me after?3 KING HENRY VI Now, brother Richard, Lord Hastings, and the rest, Yet thus far fortune maketh us amends, And says that once more I shall interchange My waned state for Henry's regal crown.Marry, farewell!O, let her live, And I'll corrupt her manners, stain her beauty; Slander myself as false to Edward's bed; Throw over her the veil of infamy: So she may live unscarr'd of bleeding slaughter, I will confess she was not Edward's daughter.Nor I. Come, cousin, let us tell the queen these news.Give me your hand: I'll privily away.Then move not, while my prayer's effect I take.Sir, your honour cannot come to that yet.Ay, millstones; as be lesson'd us to weep.I take thy hand, this hand, As soft as dove's down and as white as it, Or Ethiopian's tooth, or the fann'd snow that's bolted By the northern blasts twice o'er.Where left we last?Thou wast the prettiest babe that e'er I nursed: An I might live to see thee married once, I have my wish.Not to kill him, having a warrant for it; but to be damned for killing him, from which no warrant can defend us.it is not yet near day: It was the nightingale, and not the lark, That pierced the fearful hollow of thine ear; Nightly she sings on yon pomegranate-tree: Believe me, love, it was the nightingale.Is he won yet?I pray you, come.This needs must be a practise.Thyself a queen, for me that was a queen, Outlive thy glory, like my wretched self!Sweet Duke of York, our prop to lean upon, Now thou art gone, we have no staff, no stay.I am most fortunate, thus accidentally to encounter you: you have ended my business, and I will merrily accompany you home.Can no man tell me of my unthrifty son?Is the chair empty?Why, be so still; here's nobody will steal that from thee: yet for the outside of thy poverty we must make an exchange; therefore discase thee instantly, --thou must think there's a necessity in't,--and change garments with this gentleman: though the pennyworth on his side be the worst, yet hold thee, there's some boot.Great king, within this coffin I present Thy buried fear: herein all breathless lies The mightiest of thy greatest enemies, Richard of Bordeaux, by me hither brought.I pray you, uncle, give me this dagger.the best?My gracious father, by your kingly leave, I'll draw it as apparent to the crown, And in that quarrel use it to the death.But come, my lord, let us away.The worthy fellow is our general: he's the rock, the oak not to be wind-shaken.And so do I. Victorious Prince of York, Before I see thee seated in that throne Which now the house of Lancaster usurps, I vow by heaven these eyes shall never close.Who should have died when Claudio lost his head; As like almost to Claudio as himself.Why I descend into this bed of death, Is partly to behold my lady's face; But chiefly to take thence from her dead finger A precious ring, a ring that I must use In dear employment: therefore hence, be gone: But if thou, jealous, dost return to pry In what I further shall intend to do, By heaven, I will tear thee joint by joint And strew this hungry churchyard with thy limbs: The time and my intents are savage-wild, More fierce and more inexorable far Than empty tigers or the roaring sea.How will this grieve you, When you shall come to clearer knowledge, that You thus have publish'd me!The taming-school!That, being mad herself, she's madly mated.I'll rest betide the chamber where thou liest!But, sirrah, not for my sake, but your master's, I advise You use your manners discreetly in all kind of companies: When I am alone, why, then I am Tranio; But in all places else your master Lucentio.When did she cross thee with a bitter word?Farewell, farewell.If not by war, by surfeit die your king, As ours by murder, to make him a king!Dost grant me, hedgehog?speak; tell me.If it were so,-- What do ye talk?I thank thee: thou shalt not lose by it.Truly, sir, I am a poor fellow that would live.Lord Warwick, on thy shoulder will I lean; And when thou fail'st--as God forbid the hour!-- Must Edward fall, which peril heaven forfend!My very worthy cousin, fairly met!And when the king comes, offer no violence, Unless he seek to thrust you out perforce.what masquing stuff is here?My lord, I warrant you we will play our part, As he shall think by our true diligence He is no less than what we say he is.Ay, but why?Methought I had; and often did I strive To yield the ghost: but still the envious flood Kept in my soul, and would not let it forth To seek the empty, vast and wandering air; But smother'd it within my panting bulk, Which almost burst to belch it in the sea.Well you deserve: they well deserve to have, That know the strong'st and surest way to get.3 KING HENRY VI Brother, though I be youngest, give me leave.He, sir!A gentleman.Dry up your tears, and stick your rosemary On this fair corse; and, as the custom is, In all her best array bear her to church: For though fond nature bids us an lament, Yet nature's tears are reason's merriment.Ay, and mine, That brought you forth this boy, to keep your name Living to time.All hail, great master!Set down, set down your honourable load, If honour may be shrouded in a hearse, Whilst I awhile obsequiously lament The untimely fall of virtuous Lancaster.'Twas a sweet marriage, and we prosper well in our return.My lord!You tempt him over-much.When I would pray and think, I think and pray To several subjects.Yes, faith, sir.Hoyday, a riddle!And wilt thou learn of me?I, that please some, try all, both joy and terror Of good and bad, that makes and unfolds error, Now take upon me, in the name of Time, To use my wings.'Tis more than you deserve; But since you teach me how to flatter you, Imagine I have said farewell already.Have done, have done.Fear not thou, man, thou shalt lose nothing here.That's not my fear; my meed hath got me fame: I have not stopp'd mine ears to their demands, Nor posted off their suits with slow delays; My pity hath been balm to heal their wounds, My mildness hath allay'd their swelling griefs, My mercy dried their water-flowing tears; I have not been desirous of their wealth, Nor much oppress'd them with great subsidies.How often said, my dignity would last But till 'twere known!Speakest thou from thy heart?Clubs, bills, and partisans!Sirrah, thou art said to have a stubborn soul.or is it fear That makes him close his eyes?Not a resemblance, but a certainty.Why dost thou run so many mile about, When thou mayst tell thy tale a nearer way?Little.you are to blame.Take up those cords: poor ropes, you are beguiled, Both you and I; for Romeo is exiled: He made you for a highway to my bed; But I, a maid, die maiden-widowed.Have you importuned him by any means?Younger than she are happy mothers made.A king, perhaps, perhaps,-- My lord!Father of Warwick, know you what this means?Sneak not away, sir; for the friar and you Must have a word anon.For your broken shin.They have ta'en note of us: keep on your way.This is true, on mine honour; and so, I pray, go with us.Why do you look on us, and shake your head, And call us wretches, orphans, castaways If that our noble father be alive?How fares my brother?Afore me!So smile the heavens upon this holy act, That after hours with sorrow chide us not!Your eyes drop millstones, when fools' eyes drop tears: I like you, lads; about your business straight; Go, go, dispatch.I will tell her, sir, that you do protest; which, as I take it, is a gentlemanlike offer.do not honour him so much To prick thy finger, though to wound his heart: What valour were it, when a cur doth grin, For one to thrust his hand between his teeth, When he might spurn him with his foot away?Must I with base tongue give my noble heart A lie that it must bear?how sweet is love itself possess'd, When but love's shadows are so rich in joy!Women!No, you are deceived; therefore, back to Rome, and prepare for your execution: you are condemned, our general has sworn you out of reprieve and pardon.My affairs Are servanted to others: though I owe My revenge properly, my remission lies In Volscian breasts.Why, love, I say!As I say, this Mistress Elbow, being, as I say, with child, and being great-bellied, and longing, as I said, for prunes; and having but two in the dish, as I said, Master Froth here, this very man, having eaten the rest, as I said, and, as I say, paying for them very honestly; for, as you know, Master Froth, I could not give you three-pence again.This paltering Becomes not Rome, nor has Coriolanus Deserved this so dishonour'd rub, laid falsely I' the plain way of his merit.I am none of his flirt-gills; I am none of his skains-mates.I prophesy the fearful'st time to thee That ever wretched age hath look'd upon.But I'ld say he had not, And I'll be sworn you would believe my saying, Howe'er you lean to the nayward.Sir, be prosperous In more than this deed does require!Even he that makes her queen who should be else?Look, when he fawns, he bites; and when he bites, His venom tooth will rankle to the death: Have not to do with him, beware of him; Sin, death, and hell have set their marks on him, And all their ministers attend on him.Well, bear you well in this new spring of time, Lest you be cropp'd before you come to prime.Do you so, sir?Another way I have to man my haggard, To make her come and know her keeper's call, That is, to watch her, as we watch these kites That bate and beat and will not be obedient.My lord, the army of the Duke of Buckingham-- Out on you, owls!Sister, content you in my discontent.Face not me: thou hast braved many men; brave not me; I will neither be faced nor braved.Here, sir; as foolish as I was before.Now, fellow, What's there?Ay, sir, it is too true; God help the while!No, not a denier.3 KING HENRY VI Here burns my candle out; ay, here it dies, Which, whiles it lasted, gave King Henry light.I cannot speak So well, nothing so well; no, nor mean better: By the pattern of mine own thoughts I cut out The purity of his.Thy false uncle-- Dost thou attend me?God and your arms be praised, victorious friends, The day is ours, the bloody dog is dead.Safely in harbour Is the king's ship; in the deep nook, where once Thou call'dst me up at midnight to fetch dew From the still-vex'd Bermoothes, there she's hid: The mariners all under hatches stow'd; Who, with a charm join'd to their suffer'd labour, I have left asleep; and for the rest o' the fleet Which I dispersed, they all have met again And are upon the Mediterranean flote, Bound sadly home for Naples, Supposing that they saw the king's ship wreck'd And his great person perish.I would not for the world they saw thee here.Ay, wherefore else guard we his royal tent, But to defend his person from night-foes?Yea, say you so?It is, my lord.The princes both make high account of you; For they account his head upon the bridge.O, that's the sword to it.The fires i' the lowest hell fold-in the people!Mistake not, uncle, further than you should.but come what sorrow can, It cannot countervail the exchange of joy That one short minute gives me in her sight: Do thou but close our hands with holy words, Then love-devouring death do what he dare; It is enough I may but call her mine.From all dishonesty he can: in this, Unless he take the course that you have done, Commit me for committing honour, trust it, He shall not rule me.O, speak no more, for I have heard too much.What talk you of debating?O Dorset, speak not to me, get thee hence!A heavy sentence, my most sovereign liege, And all unlook'd for from your highness' mouth: A dearer merit, not so deep a maim As to be cast forth in the common air, Have I deserved at your highness' hands.What, shall I groan and tell thee?What's this, what's this?We are not safe, Clarence; we are not safe.What ailest thou, man?the queen, the queen, The sweet'st, dear'st creature's dead, and vengeance for't Not dropp'd down yet.What, wilt thou not?Why, and I challenge nothing but my dukedom, As being well content with that alone.Why, then thou canst not break her to the lute?The most you sought was her promotion; For 'twas your heaven she should be advanced: And weep ye now, seeing she is advanced Above the clouds, as high as heaven itself?Would I were dead!How will you do to content this substitute, and to save your brother?Sad-hearted men, much overgone with care, Here sits a king more woful than you are.He cannot, sir; he's out at elbow.The people are incensed against him.Nay, behold 's: This boy, that cannot tell what he would have But kneels and holds up bands for fellowship, Does reason our petition with more strength Than thou hast to deny 't.I am not made of stone, But penetrable to your.How!They are rising, they are rising.Well have we pass'd and now repass'd the seas And brought desired help from Burgundy: What then remains, we being thus arrived From Ravenspurgh haven before the gates of York, But that we enter, as into our dukedom?I had rather you did lack than I, my lord, Upon this ground; and more it would content me To have her honour true than your suspicion, Be blamed for't how you might.daffodils, That come before the swallow dares, and take The winds of March with beauty; violets dim, But sweeter than the lids of Juno's eyes Or Cytherea's breath; pale primroses That die unmarried, ere they can behold Bight Phoebus in his strength--a malady Most incident to maids; bold oxlips and The crown imperial; lilies of all kinds, The flower-de-luce being one!Let him thank me, that holp to send him thither; For he was fitter for that place than earth.Have we not had a taste of his obedience?Yes, Warwick, Edward dares, and leads the way.Would you proceed especially against Caius Marcius?Not in a grave, To lay one in, another out to have.or thee?Well, well; there's one yonder arrested and carried to prison was worth five thousand of you all.Tell Bolingbroke--for yond methinks he stands-- That every stride he makes upon my land Is dangerous treason: he is come to open The purple testament of bleeding war; But ere the crown he looks for live in peace, Ten thousand bloody crowns of mothers' sons Shall ill become the flower of England's face, Change the complexion of her maid-pale peace To scarlet indignation and bedew Her pastures' grass with faithful English blood.My women, come; you have leave.Custom calls me to't: What custom wills, in all things should we do't, The dust on antique time would lie unswept, And mountainous error be too highly heapt For truth to o'er-peer.Why, our battalion trebles that account: Besides, the king's name is a tower of strength, Which they upon the adverse party want.But, hark!Wine, wine, wine!This, my lord.Get you gone, and let me hear no more of you.But to the goal: My last good deed was to entreat his stay: What was my first?Well said, my hearts!Draw thy tool!Stay, yet look back with me unto the Tower.As I do think, to-morrow.My tongue will tell the anger of my heart, Or else my heart concealing it will break, And rather than it shall, I will be free Even to the uttermost, as I please, in words.Enough, with over-measure.What!Condemn the fault and not the actor of it?Thou hadst a Clarence too, and Richard kill'd him.hear?alas, I rather hate myself For hateful deeds committed by myself!Strong as a tower in hope, I cry amen.By his great authority; Which often hath no less prevail'd than so On your command.Very sooth, to-morrow.But, come on, Contract us 'fore these witnesses.Now, good my liege Sir, royal sir, forgive a foolish woman: The love I bore your queen--lo, fool again!-- I'll speak of her no more, nor of your children; I'll not remember you of my own lord, Who is lost too: take your patience to you, And I'll say nothing.fie upon him!Stay: whence are you?And who shines now but Henry's enemies?Is there no manners left among maids?What think you, if he were convey'd to bed, Wrapp'd in sweet clothes, rings put upon his fingers, A most delicious banquet by his bed, And brave attendants near him when he wakes, Would not the beggar then forget himself?I cannot stay to hear these articles.We have been called so of many; not that our heads are some brown, some black, some auburn, some bald, but that our wits are so diversely coloured: and truly I think if all our wits were to issue out of one skull, they would fly east, west, north, south, and their consent of one direct way should be at once to all the points o' the compass.Thou art not here: murder is thy alms-deed; Petitioners for blood thou ne'er put'st back.if my deep prayers cannot appease thee, But thou wilt be avenged on my misdeeds, Yet execute thy wrath in me alone, O, spare my guiltless wife and my poor children!Prithee, let him.How does my father?Nor I, but stoop with patience to my fortune.If The cause were not in being,--part o' the cause, She the adulteress; for the harlot king Is quite beyond mine arm, out of the blank And level of my brain, plot-proof; but she I can hook to me: say that she were gone, Given to the fire, a moiety of my rest Might come to me again.Where's Bohemia?Plainly conceive, I love you.And thou must stand by too, and suffer every knave to use me at his pleasure?Be it with resolution then to fight.This Is the third man that e'er I saw, the first That e'er I sigh'd for: pity move my father To be inclined my way!Have we more sons?Give me, give me!I will be his conduct.What, ho!Even as thou wilt, sweet Warwick, let it be; For in thy shoulder do I build my seat, And never will I undertake the thing Wherein thy counsel and consent is wanting.Farewell.How near is our master?O, the blood is spilt O my dear kinsman!Thanks, provost, for thy care and secrecy: We shill employ thee in a worthier place.I do remember well where I should be, And there I am.or are we like to have?I hope thou art not mad: This is a man, old, wrinkled, faded, wither'd, And not a maiden, as thou say'st he is.Is whispering nothing?I'll drown more sailors than the mermaid shall; I'll slay more gazers than the basilisk; I'll play the orator as well as Nestor, Deceive more slily than Ulysses could, And, like a Sinon, take another Troy.Alas, that love, so gentle in his view, Should be so tyrannous and rough in proof!O, she's warm!and let the devil Be sometime honour'd for his burning throne!Alas for both, both mine, Edward and Clarence!quoth he, as if He had been aboard, carousing to his mates After a storm; quaff'd off the muscadel And threw the sops all in the sexton's face; Having no other reason But that his beard grew thin and hungerly And seem'd to ask him sops as he was drinking.What, wilt thou wash him from his grave with tears?Care not for issue; The crown will find an heir: great Alexander Left his to the worthiest; so his successor Was like to be the best.He's a bear indeed, that lives like a lamb.Snakes, in my heart-blood warm'd, that sting my heart!'Tis nothing less: conceit is still derived From some forefather grief; mine is not so, For nothing had begot my something grief; Or something hath the nothing that I grieve: 'Tis in reversion that I do possess; But what it is, that is not yet known; what I cannot name; 'tis nameless woe, I wot.Immoderately she weeps for Tybalt's death, And therefore have I little talk'd of love; For Venus smiles not in a house of tears.O my most gracious lord, I hope you will not mock me with a husband.My crown is in my heart, not on my head; Not decked with diamonds and Indian stones, Nor to be seen: my crown is called content: A crown it is that seldom kings enjoy.O, she says nothing, sir, but weeps and weeps; And now falls on her bed; and then starts up, And Tybalt calls; and then on Romeo cries, And then down falls again.is it most certain?'Twill be deliver'd back on good condition.Sweet Clifford, hear me speak before I die.Hath any well-advised friend proclaim'd Reward to him that brings the traitor in?What studied torments, tyrant, hast for me?This do and do it kindly, gentle sirs: It will be pastime passing excellent, If it be husbanded with modesty.But never once again turn back and fly.It is my fashion, when I see a crab.My lord?O Romeo, Romeo, brave Mercutio's dead!Where is the Duke of Norfolk, gentle Warwick?Confirm the crown to me and to mine heirs, And thou shalt reign in quiet while thou livest.how sweet!Even so; an't please your worship, Brakenbury, You may partake of any thing we say: We speak no treason, man: we say the king Is wise and virtuous, and his noble queen Well struck in years, fair, and not jealous; We say that Shore's wife hath a pretty foot, A cherry lip, a bonny eye, a passing pleasing tongue; And that the queen's kindred are made gentle-folks: How say you sir?O, they are at it!Come, bloody Clifford, rough Northumberland, I dare your quenchless fury to more rage: I am your butt, and I abide your shot.Will't please your lordship drink a cup of sack?Now, by my mother's son, and that's myself, It shall be moon, or star, or what I list, Or ere I journey to your father's house.A vengeance on your crafty wither'd hide!The present wars devour him: he is grown Too proud to be so valiant.Katharina, that cap of yours becomes you not: Off with that bauble, throw it under-foot.Even or odd, of all days in the year, Come Lammas-eve at night shall she be fourteen.Thou wilt amend thy life?Was ever man so beaten?I do love thee so, That I will shortly send thy soul to heaven, If heaven will take the present at our hands.Nay, I told you your son was well beloved in Padua.One, gentlewoman, that God hath made for himself to mar.How now!But, gentle sir, methinks you walk like a stranger: may I be so bold to know the cause of your coming?Mass, and well said; a merry whoreson, ha!that he did but see The flatness of my misery, yet with eyes Of pity, not revenge!Fare you well, then.Which to recure, we heartily solicit Your gracious self to take on you the charge And kingly government of this your land, Not as protector, steward, substitute, Or lowly factor for another's gain; But as successively from blood to blood, Your right of birth, your empery, your own.Pardon, old father, my mistaking eyes, That have been so bedazzled with the sun That everything I look on seemeth green: Now I perceive thou art a reverend father; Pardon, I pray thee, for my mad mistaking.I would be glad to receive some instruction from my fellow partner.Tell me, sweet Kate, and tell me truly too, Hast thou beheld a fresher gentlewoman?speak, thou wretch.A laughter.O that I were a mockery king of snow, Standing before the sun of Bolingbroke, To melt myself away in water-drops!See how my sword weeps for the poor king's death!For my part, I'll resign unto your grace The seal I keep: and so betide to me As well I tender you and all of yours!Will you buy any tape, Or lace for your cape, My dainty duck, my dear-a?This night I hold an old accustom'd feast, Whereto I have invited many a guest, Such as I love; and you, among the store, One more, most welcome, makes my number more.What good condition can a treaty find I' the part that is at mercy?I do confess it, and repent it, father.Ay; 'tis an honester service than to meddle with thy mistress.May be a precedent and witness good That thou respect'st not spilling Edward's blood: Join with the present sickness that I have; And thy unkindness be like crooked age, To crop at once a too long wither'd flower.O traitors!It makes the consuls base: and my soul aches To know, when two authorities are up, Neither supreme, how soon confusion May enter 'twixt the gap of both and take The one by the other.Pray you, let us go: Let them accuse me by invention, I Will answer in mine honour.Above an hour, my lord.But now I'll tell thee joyful tidings, girl.Fiend, thou torment'st me ere I come to hell!and give King Henry leave to speak.Why, so!But, my good lord, your grace's word shall serve, As well as I had seen and heard him speak And doubt you not, right noble princes both, But I'll acquaint our duteous citizens With all your just proceedings in this cause.Let us be clear'd Of being tyrannous, since we so openly Proceed in justice, which shall have due course, Even to the guilt or the purgation.I will withdraw: but this intrusion shall Now seeming sweet convert to bitter gall.Your knee, sirrah.The mayor is here at hand: intend some fear; Be not you spoke with, but by mighty suit: And look you get a prayer-book in your hand, And stand betwixt two churchmen, good my lord; For on that ground I'll build a holy descant: And be not easily won to our request: Play the maid's part, still answer nay, and take it.Holy Franciscan friar!Edward and Richard, you shall stay with me; My brother Montague shall post to London: Let noble Warwick, Cobham, and the rest, Whom we have left protectors of the king, With powerful policy strengthen themselves, And trust not simple Henry nor his oaths.The secret mischiefs that I set abroach I lay unto the grievous charge of others.How far off is our brother Montague?to me?And if he hear thee, thou wilt anger him.Let not my cold words here accuse my zeal: 'Tis not the trial of a woman's war, The bitter clamour of two eager tongues, Can arbitrate this cause betwixt us twain; The blood is hot that must be cool'd for this: Yet can I not of such tame patience boast As to be hush'd and nought at all to say: First, the fair reverence of your highness curbs me From giving reins and spurs to my free speech; Which else would post until it had return'd These terms of treason doubled down his throat.Away, you fool!If you head and hang all that offend that way but for ten year together, you'll be glad to give out a commission for more heads: if this law hold in Vienna ten year, I'll rent the fairest house in it after three-pence a bay: if you live to see this come to pass, say Pompey told you so.Very well.Go in to him, and fetch him out.Women are made to bear, and so are you.O, let me make the period to my curse!Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus!Yet you are wither'd.Kind sister, thanks: we'll enter all together.But yet hear this: mistake me not; no life, I prize it not a straw, but for mine honour, Which I would free, if I shall be condemn'd Upon surmises, all proofs sleeping else But what your jealousies awake, I tell you 'Tis rigor and not law.Away towards Salisbury!What, will you go unto the Tower, my lord?I saw the wound, I saw it with mine eyes,-- God save the mark!--here on his manly breast: A piteous corse, a bloody piteous corse; Pale, pale as ashes, all bedaub'd in blood, All in gore-blood; I swounded at the sight.And yet I come not well.Yes, I accept her, for she well deserves it; And here, to pledge my vow, I give my hand.the great King of kings Hath in the tables of his law commanded That thou shalt do no murder: and wilt thou, then, Spurn at his edict and fulfil a man's?And why so, my lord?Why, that's my fortune too; therefore I'll stay.A jewel in a ten-times-barr'd-up chest Is a bold spirit in a loyal breast.I hope so, sir; for I have about me many parcels of charge.My sometime general, I have seen thee stem, and thou hast oft beheld Heart-hardening spectacles; tell these sad women 'Tis fond to wail inevitable strokes, As 'tis to laugh at 'em.Sir, you seem a sober ancient gentleman by your habit, but your words show you a madman.Nay, but hear me.what mean'st thou, that thou help'st me not?Do not swear at all; Or, if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self, Which is the god of my idolatry, And I'll believe thee.On, to the Capitol!Why, she's a devil, a devil, the devil's dam.Sit down; For thou must now know farther.it is nor hand, nor foot, Nor arm, nor face, nor any other part Belonging to a man.The devil take Henry of Lancaster and thee!Look how thy servants do attend on thee, Each in his office ready at thy beck.O, do not slander him, for he is kind.O, remember, God To hear her prayers for them, as now for us And for my sister and her princely sons, Be satisfied, dear God, with our true blood, Which, as thou know'st, unjustly must be spilt.'Tis so with me.my niece Plantagenet Led in the hand of her kind aunt of Gloucester?As if that name, Shot from the deadly level of a gun, Did murder her; as that name's cursed hand Murder'd her kinsman.By holy Paul, they love his grace but lightly That fill his ears with such dissentious rumours.'Zounds, a dog, a rat, a mouse, a cat, to scratch a man to death!Return unto thy lord; commend me to him: Tell him the queen hath heartily consented He shall espouse Elizabeth her daughter.The better that your lordship please to ask.His name, my lord, is Tyrrel.Pardon me, good father; it is against my oath.Speak, nephew, were you by when it began?Let me ask my sister pardon.'Stay, hold, peace!'Good night.Who goes there?So will ye, I am sure, that you love me.I'll make all speed.That hand shall burn in never-quenching fire That staggers thus my person.Good friar, I know you do, and have found it.Pray you, be gone: I'll try whether my old wit be in request With those that have but little: this must be patch'd With cloth of any colour.Too late?Too modest are you; More cruel to your good report than grateful To us that give you truly: by your patience, If 'gainst yourself you be incensed, we'll put you, Like one that means his proper harm, in manacles, Then reason safely with you.How!There on the ground, with his own tears made drunk.Will you be gone?None, but that there is so great a fever on goodness, that the dissolution of it must cure it: novelty is only in request; and it is as dangerous to be aged in any kind of course, as it is virtuous to be constant in any undertaking.Would yet he had lived!Let this friar be found.Brother, farewell: I will unto the king; And whatsoever you will employ me in, Were it to call King Edward's widow sister, I will perform it to enfranchise you.Alas, alas!Good my friends, If you have heard your general talk of Rome, And of his friends there, it is lots to blanks, My name hath touch'd your ears it is Menenius.Infer fair England's peace by this alliance.Besides, he tells me that, if peradventure He speak against me on the adverse side, I should not think it strange; for 'tis a physic That's bitter to sweet end.The matter?by my fay, a goodly nap.I confess two sleeves.Anon!Lay't so to his charge: He's with the king your father.wast thou with Rosaline?Shall's to the Capitol?Thus stands it with me: upon a true contract I got possession of Julietta's bed: You know the lady; she is fast my wife, Save that we do the denunciation lack Of outward order: this we came not to, Only for propagation of a dower Remaining in the coffer of her friends, From whom we thought it meet to hide our love Till time had made them for us.But, wherefore, villain, didst thou kill my cousin?Master, for my hand, Both our inventions meet and jump in one.It is my soul that calls upon my name: How silver-sweet sound lovers' tongues by night, Like softest music to attending ears!I cannot tarry: I knew a wench married in an afternoon as she went to the garden for parsley to stuff a rabbit; and so may you, sir: and so, adieu, sir.Do so, and bid my sweet prepare to chide.Smile, gentle heaven!Marry.Here's one to a very doleful tune, how a usurer's wife was brought to bed of twenty money-bags at a burthen and how she longed to eat adders' heads and toads carbonadoed.Now, for my life, Hortensio fears his widow.Now, for my life, the knave doth court my love: Pedascule, I'll watch you better yet.fie, these filthy vices!Must he needs die?Yes, by Saint Anne, do I.neither good nor bad!Truly, the souls of men are full of dread: Ye cannot reason almost with a man That looks not heavily and full of fear.It was.What follows this?To Bolingbroke are we sworn subjects now, Whose state and honour I for aye allow.But when they shall see, sir, his crest up again, and the man in blood, they will out of their burrows, like conies after rain, and revel all with him.O, he is the courageous captain of compliments.3 KING HENRY VI This battle fares like to the morning's war, When dying clouds contend with growing light, What time the shepherd, blowing of his nails, Can neither call it perfect day nor night.You have a holy father, A graceful gentleman; against whose person, So sacred as it is, I have done sin: For which the heavens, taking angry note, Have left me issueless; and your father's blest, As he from heaven merits it, with you Worthy his goodness.Relenting fool, and shallow, changing woman!The white sheet bleaching on the hedge, With heigh!Well, I must do't: Away, my disposition, and possess me Some harlot's spirit!Draw, if you be men.If could speak so wisely under an arrest, I would send for certain of my creditors: and yet, to say the truth, I had as lief have the foppery of freedom as the morality of imprisonment.How does the boy?I blame not her, she could say little less; She had the wrong.Such a mad marriage never was before: Hark, hark!O sir, such a life, with such a wife, were strange!What wilt thou tell her, nurse?Let's hear our tribune: peace Speak, speak, speak.Kill, kill, kill, kill, kill him!Let's not meet her.You scarcely have the hearts to tell me so, And therefore cannot have the hearts to do it.It is held That valour is the chiefest virtue, and Most dignifies the haver: if it be, The man I speak of cannot in the world Be singly counterpoised.Herein your highness wrongs both them and me.This shall determine that.Commend me to Lord William: tell him, Catesby, His ancient knot of dangerous adversaries To-morrow are let blood at Pomfret-castle; And bid my friend, for joy of this good news, Give mistress Shore one gentle kiss the more.my master calls for him.To him!As wicked dew as e'er my mother brush'd With raven's feather from unwholesome fen Drop on you both!Why 'her unhappy brother'?'Tis the way To call hers exquisite, in question more: These happy masks that kiss fair ladies' brows Being black put us in mind they hide the fair; He that is strucken blind cannot forget The precious treasure of his eyesight lost: Show me a mistress that is passing fair, What doth her beauty serve, but as a note Where I may read who pass'd that passing fair?I mean to shift my bush; And then pursue me as you draw your bow.Are you mankind?Tyrants themselves wept when it was reported.Undone!Rest you merry!I'll pheeze you, in faith.What but to speak of would offend again.In this point charge him home, that he affects Tyrannical power: if he evade us there, Enforce him with his envy to the people, And that the spoil got on the Antiates Was ne'er distributed.Come, bring away thy pack after me.Thou shalt not stir a foot to seek a foe.Thou hast found mine; But how, is to be question'd; for I saw her, As I thought, dead, and have in vain said many A prayer upon her grave.No, nor a man that fears you less than he, That's lesser than a little.No, I'll none of you.Come, Kate, we'll to bed.Here comes the rogue.Give her the bastard.More reasons for this action At our more leisure shall I render you; Only, this one: Lord Angelo is precise; Stands at a guard with envy; scarce confesses That his blood flows, or that his appetite Is more to bread than stone: hence shall we see, If power change purpose, what our seemers be.You are all resolved rather to die than to famish?I will converse with iron-witted fools And unrespective boys: none are for me That look into me with considerate eyes: High-reaching Buckingham grows circumspect.Have you done there?Hast thou forgot The foul witch Sycorax, who with age and envy Was grown into a hoop?Why do you put these sayings upon me?What was his reason?Why, how now, long-tongued Warwick!Sent by the king your father To greet him and to give him comforts.No marvel, my lord, though it affrighted you; I promise, I am afraid to hear you tell it.Take thy commission.Thou art always figuring diseases in me; but thou art full of error; I am sound.Yet tell me not, for I have heard it all.Well, my lord, If you may please to think I love the king And through him what is nearest to him, which is Your gracious self, embrace but my direction: If your more ponderous and settled project May suffer alteration, on mine honour, I'll point you where you shall have such receiving As shall become your highness; where you may Enjoy your mistress, from the whom, I see, There's no disjunction to be made, but by-- As heavens forefend!--your ruin; marry her, And, with my best endeavours in your absence, Your discontenting father strive to qualify And bring him up to liking.Poor souls, they perish'd.Why, my sweet lord?This Marcius is grown from man to dragon: he has wings; he's more than a creeping thing.It is no other: show your wisdom, daughter, In your close patience.What fellow's this?Yet read the gamut of Hortensio.that I ask again; For nothing can be ill, if she be well.Pray you, Emilia, Commend my best obedience to the queen: If she dares trust me with her little babe, I'll show't the king and undertake to be Her advocate to the loud'st.O, sweet my mother, cast me not away!Commend me to the prison, Pompey: you will turn good husband now, Pompey; you will keep the house.But not, as I am, royal.We'll make foul weather with despised tears; Our sighs and they shall lodge the summer corn, And make a dearth in this revolting land.let me see her: out, alas!The prince himself is about a piece of iniquity, stealing away from his father with his clog at his heels: if I thought it were a piece of honesty to acquaint the king withal, I would not do't: I hold it the more knavery to conceal it; and therein am I constant to my profession.what can he say in this?Draw near, Queen Margaret, and be a witness That Bona shall be wife to the English king.For such a warped slip of wilderness Ne'er issued from his blood.I dare assure you, sir, 'tis almost two; And 'twill be supper-time ere you come there.when 'twas a little prating thing:--O, there is a nobleman in town, one Paris, that would fain lay knife aboard; but she, good soul, had as lief see a toad, a very toad, as see him.All the charms Of Sycorax, toads, beetles, bats, light on you!If thou'lt see a thing to talk on when thou art dead and rotten, come hither.No marrying 'mong his subjects?O, come, go in, And take our friendly senators by the hands; Who now are here, taking their leaves of me, Who am prepared against your territories, Though not for Rome itself.I had thought, sir, to have held my peace until You have drawn oaths from him not to stay.Hence, villain!Has he disciplined Aufidius soundly?Are you so hot?For me, the ransom of my bold attempt Shall be this cold corpse on the earth's cold face; But if I thrive, the gain of my attempt The least of you shall share his part thereof.But who is here?My lord?Nay, rather, every tedious stride I make Will but remember me what a deal of world I wander from the jewels that I love.God will revenge it.Was never widow had so dear a loss!One fairer than my love!I must indeed; and therefore came I hither.In truth, la, go with me; and I'll tell you excellent news of your husband.Up.By this we gather You have tripp'd since.Is thy name Tyrrel?O sir, I shall be hated to report it!Where hast thou been preserved?O, find him!Here's a strange alteration!I am attended at the cypress grove: I pray you-- 'Tis south the city mills--bring me word thither How the world goes, that to the pace of it I may spur on my journey.Gallows and knock are too powerful on the highway: beating and hanging are terrors to me: for the life to come, I sleep out the thought of it.Go, go, up to the leads; the lord mayor knocks.'Tis very true: you were in presence then; And you can witness with me this is true.Some say he is with the Emperor of Russia; other some, he is in Rome: but where is he, think you?But see where Somerset and Clarence come!I do, my lord; but long I shall not stay I shall return before your lordship thence.speak.Master, master, look about you: who goes there, ha?Kill'd!An easy task; 'tis but to love a king.Pray you, poor gentleman, take up some other station; here's no place for you; pray you, avoid: come.A senseless villain!And, though unskilful, why not Ned and I For once allow'd the skilful pilot's charge?Apollo's angry; and the heavens themselves Do strike at my injustice.Soft, swain, awhile, beseech you; Have you a father?Mark you that?'I would he had'!With a proud heart he wore his humble weeds.By the vow of mine order I warrant you, if my instructions may be your guide.Whose hand soever lanced their tender hearts, Thy head, all indirectly, gave direction: No doubt the murderous knife was dull and blunt Till it was whetted on thy stone-hard heart, To revel in the entrails of my lambs.the wounds become him.How sometimes nature will betray its folly, Its tenderness, and make itself a pastime To harder bosoms!List to your tribunes.As near as I could sift him on that argument, On some apparent danger seen in him Aim'd at your highness, no inveterate malice.What, was I born to this, that my sad look Should grace the triumph of great Bolingbroke?As now she might have done, So much to my good comfort, as it is Now piercing to my soul.Nay, these are almost thoroughly persuaded; For though abundantly they lack discretion, Yet are they passing cowardly.be brief.Unless I have mista'en his colours much, Which well I am assured I have not done, His regiment lies half a mile at least South from the mighty power of the king.The wager?No, sir, I do not bite my thumb at you, sir, but I bite my thumb, sir.Thou dost advise me Even so as I mine own course have set down: I'll give no blemish to her honour, none.But why come you in arms?Now, by my George, my garter, and my crown,-- Profaned, dishonour'd, and the third usurp'd.Peace, children, peace!I am their fathers mother; I will see them.Thou art deceived: 'tis not thy southern power, Of Essex, Norfolk, Suffolk, nor of Kent, Which makes thee thus presumptuous and proud, Can set the duke up in despite of me.I am ashamed that women are so simple To offer war where they should kneel for peace; Or seek for rule, supremacy and sway, When they are bound to serve, love and obey.Nay, then, 'tis time to stir him from his trance.No, nor your manhood that durst make you stay.Will you go yet?For shame, bring Juliet forth; her lord is come.O, welcome, Oxford!Hark you, sir: I'll have them very fairly bound: All books of love, see that at any hand; And see you read no other lectures to her: You understand me: over and beside Signior Baptista's liberality, I'll mend it with a largess.That is, because the traitor murderer lives.From forth the kennel of thy womb hath crept A hell-hound that doth hunt us all to death: That dog, that had his teeth before his eyes, To worry lambs and lap their gentle blood, That foul defacer of God's handiwork, That excellent grand tyrant of the earth, That reigns in galled eyes of weeping souls, Thy womb let loose, to chase us to our graves.How?In good time.O, sir, the conceit is deeper than you think for: Take up my mistress' gown to his master's use!Art thou my calf?Sicilia cannot show himself over-kind to Bohemia.What, at your book so hard?These eyes, that now are dimm'd with death's black veil, Have been as piercing as the mid-day sun, To search the secret treasons of the world: The wrinkles in my brows, now filled with blood, Were liken'd oft to kingly sepulchres; For who lived king, but I could dig his grave?How long shall I be patient?I have.In earnest, it's true; I heard a senator speak it.I pray you, husband, be not so disquiet: The meat was well, if you were so contented.Prosper you, sweet sir!Nay Warwick, single out some other chase; For I myself will hunt this wolf to death.What think you of it?Wherefore that box?The sweetest sleep, and fairest-boding dreams That ever enter'd in a drowsy head, Have I since your departure had, my lords.kind entreats, Albeit against my conscience and my soul.Sovereign, here lies the County Paris slain; And Romeo dead; and Juliet, dead before, Warm and new kill'd.My lord,-- No lord of thine, thou haught insulting man, Nor no man's lord; I have no name, no title, No, not that name was given me at the font, But 'tis usurp'd: alack the heavy day, That I have worn so many winters out, And know not now what name to call myself!Farewell.Where's that?Speak, Clifford, dost thou know who speaks to thee?One seven-night longer.They love not poison that do poison need, Nor do I thee: though I did wish him dead, I hate the murderer, love him murdered.at the senate-house?'Tis all one, I will show myself a tyrant: when I have fought with the men, I will be cruel with the maids, and cut off their heads.You shall, my lord.If I could shake off but one seven years From these old arms and legs, by the good gods, I'ld with thee every foot.The gates made fast!Come your ways, sir; come.Why, what a ruthless thing is this in him, for the rebellion of a codpiece to take away the life of a man!No, by my troth, my lord.We must find An evident calamity, though we had Our wish, which side should win: for either thou Must, as a foreign recreant, be led With manacles thorough our streets, or else triumphantly tread on thy country's ruin, And bear the palm for having bravely shed Thy wife and children's blood.Meet on the market-place.Why, in good time.Peace, Tranio!I thank you, good my lord; and thank you all.O faithless coward!And so have I, boy.I do not say 'thwack our general;' but he was always good enough for him.Then, since the heavens have shaped my body so, Let hell make crook'd my mind to answer it.what cannot be avoided 'Twere childish weakness to lament or fear.Peter, take my fan, and go before and apace.You're welcome: what's your will?He is; and, see, he brings the mayor along.Antigonus, I charged thee that she should not come about me: I knew she would.Fortune speed us!How many stand for consulships?O that I were as great As is my grief, or lesser than my name!At Ely House.No, sir, God forbid; but ashamed to kiss.What do I fear?Poor key-cold figure of a holy king!See this dispatch'd with all the haste thou canst: Anon I'll give thee more instructions.My breast can better brook thy dagger's point Than can my ears that tragic history.I know her answer.I think thou dost; and, indeed, with most painful feeling of thy speech: I will, out of thine own confession, learn to begin thy health; but, whilst I live, forget to drink after thee.I raised him, and I pawn'd Mine honour for his truth: who being so heighten'd, He water'd his new plants with dews of flattery, Seducing so my friends; and, to this end, He bow'd his nature, never known before But to be rough, unswayable and free.Son Edward, she is fair and virtuous, Therefore delay not, give thy hand to Warwick; And, with thy hand, thy faith irrevocable, That only Warwick's daughter shall be thine.Look, sir.a million of beating may come to a great matter.No, my good lord, for that is not forgot Which ne'er I did remember: to my knowledge, I never in my life did look on him.O, You have, I know, petition'd all the gods For my prosperity!We know't, we know't.O this learning, what a thing it is!what's the matter?In God's name, I'll ascend the regal throne.What then!What have you to do here, fellow?At Pembroke, or at Harford-west, in Wales.And I in all unwillingness will go.He could never come better; he shall come in.The senate, Coriolanus, are well pleased To make thee consul.I do beseech you, Let me o'erleap that custom, for I cannot Put on the gown, stand naked and entreat them, For my wounds' sake, to give their suffrage: please you That I may pass this doing.I do suspect I have done some offence That seems disgracious in the city's eyes, And that you come to reprehend my ignorance.Lord, how my head aches!No, my lord, I'll fight.Come, my sweet Kate: Better once than never, for never too late.Go by, Jeronimy: go to thy cold bed, and warm thee.Say, is my kingdom lost?Therefore, go back.True!A thousand thanks, Signior Gremio.Thinkest thou, for that I insinuate, or toaze from thee thy business, I am therefore no courtier?When yet he was but tender-bodied and the only son of my womb, when youth with comeliness plucked all gaze his way, when for a day of kings' entreaties a mother should not sell him an hour from her beholding, I, considering how honour would become such a person.Now bless thyself: thou mettest with things dying, I with things newborn.Rivers and Hastings, take each other's hand; Dissemble not your hatred, swear your love.For all the rest is held at such a rate As brings a thousand-fold more care to keep Than in possession and jot of pleasure.These are the ushers of Marcius: before him he carries noise, and behind him he leaves tears: Death, that dark spirit, in 's nervy arm doth lie; Which, being advanced, declines, and then men die.Was not my lord The verier wag o' the two?He is, my lord, and safe in Leicester town; Whither, if it please you, we may now withdraw us.Richly in both, if justice had her right.Marcius is coming home: he has more cause to be proud.Henry of Lancaster, resign thy crown.God and our innocency defend and guard us!The wills above be done!Hark you, sir; you mean not her to-- Perhaps, him and her, sir: what have you to do?Well, sir, to do you courtesy, This will I do, and this I will advise you: First, tell me, have you ever been at Pisa?Here were the servants of your adversary, And yours, close fighting ere I did approach: I drew to part them: in the instant came The fiery Tybalt, with his sword prepared, Which, as he breathed defiance to my ears, He swung about his head and cut the winds, Who nothing hurt withal hiss'd him in scorn: While we were interchanging thrusts and blows, Came more and more and fought on part and part, Till the prince came, who parted either part.On, lusty gentlemen.Well may I get aboard!I have served Prince Florizel and in my time wore three-pile; but now I am out of service: But shall I go mourn for that, my dear?I call'd thee then vain flourish of my fortune; I call'd thee then poor shadow, painted queen; The presentation of but what I was; The flattering index of a direful pageant; One heaved a-high, to be hurl'd down below; A mother only mock'd with two sweet babes; A dream of what thou wert, a breath, a bubble, A sign of dignity, a garish flag, To be the aim of every dangerous shot, A queen in jest, only to fill the scene.My brother did love Juliet, And you tell me that he shall die for it.The woe's to come; the children yet unborn.sweet-heart!We two, my lord, Will guard your person while you take your rest, And watch your safety.My Lord of Gloucester, in those busy days Which here you urge to prove us enemies, We follow'd then our lord, our lawful king: So should we you, if you should be our king.Do not stand upon't.But for our trusty brother-in-law and the abbot, With all the rest of that consorted crew, Destruction straight shall dog them at the heels.Apollo, pardon My great profaneness 'gainst thine oracle!A plague o' both your houses!Is not Gaunt dead, and doth not Hereford live?So then it seems your most offenceful act Was mutually committed?By this at Dunsmore, marching hitherward.She may, my lord, for-- She may, Lord Rivers!What news, my friend?why dost thou look so pale?My father Capulet will have it so; And I am nothing slow to slack his haste.Poor painted queen, vain flourish of my fortune!Dispose of her To some more fitter place, and that with speed.Not to his father's; I spoke with his man.Aufidius, though I cannot make true wars, I'll frame convenient peace.Better do so than tarry and be hang'd.Where the devil should this Romeo be?You are a counsellor; if you can command these elements to silence, and work the peace of the present, we will not hand a rope more; use your authority: if you cannot, give thanks you have lived so long, and make yourself ready in your cabin for the mischance of the hour, if it so hap.Well, sir, in brief, the gown is not for me.Plantagenet, of thee and these thy sons, Thy kinsman and thy friends, I'll have more lives Than drops of blood were in my father's veins.Farewell, good Pompey.If thy revengeful heart cannot forgive, Lo, here I lend thee this sharp-pointed sword; Which if thou please to hide in this true bosom.by your dread 'Verily,' One of them you shall be.Withdraw yourselves.Their noise be our instruction.Honest nurse, farewell.make you a sword of me?So, slave; hence!heavens!And more he would have said, and more he spoke, Which sounded like a clamour in a vault, That mought not be distinguished; but at last I well might hear, delivered with a groan, 'O, farewell, Warwick!'But with a rear-ward following Tybalt's death, 'Romeo is banished,' to speak that word, Is father, mother, Tybalt, Romeo, Juliet, All slain, all dead.I thought, at least, he would have said the king; Or did he make the jest against his will?Gentles, methinks you frown: And wherefore gaze this goodly company, As if they saw some wondrous monument, Some comet or unusual prodigy?I dare not, sir My master knows not but I am gone hence; And fearfully did menace me with death, If I did stay to look on his intents.Elbow is your name?The Duke of Norfolk, sprightfully and bold, Stays but the summons of the appellant's trumpet.Let's have some merry ones.Open the gates; we are King Henry's friends.Nay, not as one would say, healthy; but so sound as things that are hollow: thy bones are hollow; impiety has made a feast of thee.Come quickly, Montague, or I am dead.Not possible; for who shall bear your part, And be in Padua here Vincentio's son, Keep house and ply his book, welcome his friends, Visit his countrymen and banquet them?At sixteen years, When Tarquin made a head for Rome, he fought Beyond the mark of others: our then dictator, Whom with all praise I point at, saw him fight, When with his Amazonian chin he drove The bristled lips before him: be bestrid An o'er-press'd Roman and i' the consul's view Slew three opposers: Tarquin's self he met, And struck him on his knee: in that day's feats, When he might act the woman in the scene, He proved best man i' the field, and for his meed Was brow-bound with the oak.Signior Baptista, will you be so strange?A good matter, surely: comes there any more of it?Suspicion always haunts the guilty mind; The thief doth fear each bush an officer.What is this?How couldst thou drain the life-blood of the child, To bid the father wipe his eyes withal, And yet be seen to bear a woman's face?Here come the clusters.Ho!I am the provost.His name!Stirr'd up by Dorset, Buckingham, and Ely, He makes for England, there to claim the crown.He was not so resolved when last we spake together.If, Biondello, thou wert come ashore, We could at once put us in readiness, And take a lodging fit to entertain Such friends as time in Padua shall beget.The forfeit, sovereign, of my servant's life; Who slew to-day a righteous gentleman Lately attendant on the Duke of Norfolk.This jealousy Is for a precious creature: as she's rare, Must it be great, and as his person's mighty, Must it be violent, and as he does conceive He is dishonour'd by a man which ever Profess'd to him, why, his revenges must In that be made more bitter.I think his understanding is bereft.The lark, that tirra-lyra chants, With heigh!Of government the properties to unfold, Would seem in me to affect speech and discourse; Since I am put to know that your own science Exceeds, in that, the lists of all advice My strength can give you: then no more remains, But that to your sufficiency, as your Worth is able, And let them work.Why, gentlemen, you do me double wrong, To strive for that which resteth in my choice: I am no breeching scholar in the schools; I'll not be tied to hours nor 'pointed times, But learn my lessons as I please myself.Barely in title, not in revenue.Here's a gentleman and a friend of mine.O heaven, the vanity of wretched fools!My gracious lord, I'll tell him what you say.Now, by the world-- 'Tis full of thy foul wrongs.Come, son, away; we may not linger thus.Ay, crook-back, here I stand to answer thee, Or any he the proudest of thy sort.Then get your husband's lands, to do them good.Were you sworn to the duke, or to the deputy?Why, no, sir.Skipper, stand back: 'tis age that nourisheth.For us to levy power Proportionable to the enemy Is all unpossible.Myself have often heard him say and swear That this his love was an eternal plant, Whereof the root was fix'd in virtue's ground, The leaves and fruit maintain'd with beauty's sun, Exempt from envy, but not from disdain, Unless the Lady Bona quit his pain.Hie thee to hell for shame, and leave the world, Thou cacodemon!I will trust you.My sovereign, with the loving citizens, Like to his island girt in with the ocean, Or modest Dian circled with her nymphs, Shall rest in London till we come to him.Now, this no more dishonours you at all Than to take in a town with gentle words, Which else would put you to your fortune and The hazard of much blood.Must all determine here?Now, go thy ways; thou hast tamed a curst shrew.Tut, that's a foolish observation: Richard, be Duke of Gloucester.Yet let us all together to our troops, And give them leave to fly that will not stay; And call them pillars that will stand to us; And, if we thrive, promise them such rewards As victors wear at the Olympian games: This may plant courage in their quailing breasts; For yet is hope of life and victory.It must needs be of subtle, tender and delicate temperance.Beshrew my very heart, I think you are happy in this second match, For it excels your first: or if it did not, Your first is dead; or 'twere as good he were, As living here and you no use of him.Braved in mine own house with a skein of thread?Send for the county; go tell him of this: I'll have this knot knit up to-morrow morning.Dispute not with her; she is lunatic.White-beards have arm'd their thin and hairless scalps Against thy majesty; boys, with women's voices, Strive to speak big and clap their female joints In stiff unwieldy arms against thy crown: The very beadsmen learn to bend their bows Of double-fatal yew against thy state; Yea, distaff-women manage rusty bills Against thy seat: both young and old rebel, And all goes worse than I have power to tell.I never long'd to hear a word till now; Say 'pardon,' king; let pity teach thee how: The word is short, but not so short as sweet; No word like 'pardon' for kings' mouths so meet.That Henry's death, my lovely Edward's death, Their kingdom's loss, my woful banishment, Could all but answer for that peevish brat?you granting of my suit, If that be sin, I'll make it my morn prayer To have it added to the faults of mine, And nothing of your answer.Or let us stand to our authority, Or let us lose it.He'ld make an end of thy posterity.O God!To Baptista Minola.But what said Henry's queen?Why, cousin, wert thou regent of the world, It were a shame to let this land by lease; But for thy world enjoying but this land, Is it not more than shame to shame it so?Ay, and for much more slaughter after this.Even now I tremble To think your father, by some accident, Should pass this way as you did: O, the Fates!I have provided for you: stay awhile, And you shall be conducted.Finds brotherhood in thee no sharper spur?The king's son have I landed by himself; Whom I left cooling of the air with sighs In an odd angle of the isle and sitting, His arms in this sad knot.and so perhaps he doth: 'Tis but his policy to counterfeit, Because he would avoid such bitter taunts Which in the time of death he gave our father.They were trained together in their childhoods; and there rooted betwixt them then such an affection, which cannot choose but branch now.Cannot thy master sleep these tedious nights?As Hercules Did shake down mellow fruit.When holy and devout religious men Are at their beads, 'tis hard to draw them thence, So sweet is zealous contemplation.Is Romeo slaughter'd, and is Tybalt dead?Indeed, 'tis true that Henry told me of; For I have often heard my mother say I came into the world with my legs forward: Had I not reason, think ye, to make haste, And seek their ruin that usurp'd our right?unknit that threatening unkind brow, And dart not scornful glances from those eyes, To wound thy lord, thy king, thy governor: It blots thy beauty as frosts do bite the meads, Confounds thy fame as whirlwinds shake fair buds, And in no sense is meet or amiable.Have you got leave to go to shrift to-day?Who would be thence that has the benefit of access?'tis lewd and filthy: Why, 'tis a cockle or a walnut-shell, A knack, a toy, a trick, a baby's cap: Away with it!what will he?Soft, sir!How, my lord!For filling a bottle with a tundish.Be the jacks fair within, the jills fair without, the carpets laid, and every thing in order?My lord, I know a discontented gentleman, Whose humble means match not his haughty mind: Gold were as good as twenty orators, And will, no doubt, tempt him to any thing.Born in Verona, old Antonio's son: My father dead, my fortune lives for me; And I do hope good days and long to see.Why?Montague, Montague, for Lancaster!Pray now, your news?Do you quarrel, sir?Not for myself, Lord Warwick, but my son, Whom I unnaturally shall disinherit.If you will hang me for it, you may; but I had rather it would please you I might be whipt.Do you hear, ho?But what, is Catesby gone?This blue-eyed hag was hither brought with child And here was left by the sailors.If at home, sir, He's all my exercise, my mirth, my matter, Now my sworn friend and then mine enemy, My parasite, my soldier, statesman, all: He makes a July's day short as December, And with his varying childness cures in me Thoughts that would thick my blood.Welcome, my son: who are the violets now That strew the green lap of the new come spring?What is the matter, uncle?The what?I am agreed; and would I had given him the best horse in Padua to begin his wooing that would thoroughly woo her, wed her and bed her and rid the house of her!Indeed, my lord, If I had thought the sight of my poor image Would thus have wrought you,--for the stone is mine-- I'ld not have show'd it.This letter, then, to Friar Peter give; 'Tis that he sent me of the duke's return: Say, by this token, I desire his company At Mariana's house to-night.Tailor, I'll pay thee for thy gown tomorrow: Take no unkindness of his hasty words: Away!O let no noble eye profane a tear For me, if I be gored with Mowbray's spear: As confident as is the falcon's flight Against a bird, do I with Mowbray fight.An it had not fallen flat-long.The son and heir of old Tiberio.O, no more, no more!Say, Scroop, where lies our uncle with his power?Go to, we pardon thee: therefore, in brief, Tell me their words as near as thou canst guess them.he will discredit our mystery.It is;
