you lie, you lie: I say thou liest, Camillo, and I hate thee, Pronounce thee a gross lout, a mindless slave, Or else a hovering temporizer, that Canst with thine eyes at once see good and evil, Inclining to them both: were my wife's liver Infected as her life, she would not live The running of one glass.No, 'tis impossible he should escape, For, though before his face I speak the words Your brother Richard mark'd him for the grave: And wheresoe'er he is, he's surely dead.Then 'twas my turn to fly, and now 'tis thine.A silken doublet!Tell thou the tale: but hadst thou not crossed me, thou shouldst have heard how her horse fell and she under her horse; thou shouldst have heard in how miry a place, how she was bemoiled, how he left her with the horse upon her, how he beat me because her horse stumbled, how she waded through the dirt to pluck him off me, how he swore, how she prayed, that never prayed before, how I cried, how the horses ran away, how her bridle was burst, how I lost my crupper, with many things of worthy memory, which now shall die in oblivion and thou return unexperienced to thy grave.I call thee not.Grace is grace, despite of all controversy: as, for example, thou thyself art a wicked villain, despite of all grace.He will require them, As if he did contemn what he requested Should be in them to give.My heart will sigh when I miscall it so, Which finds it an inforced pilgrimage.What, art thou stiff?Then, for his mind, be Edward England's king: But Henry now shall wear the English crown, And be true king indeed, thou but the shadow.Lord mayor, the reason we have sent-- Look back, defend thee, here are enemies.No, my good Lord; he hath forsook the court, Broken his staff of office and dispersed The household of the king.No, mighty King of France: now Margaret Must strike her sail and learn awhile to serve Where kings command.I have considered so much, Camillo, and with some care; so far that I have eyes under my service which look upon his removedness; from whom I have this intelligence, that he is seldom from the house of a most homely shepherd; a man, they say, that from very nothing, and beyond the imagination of his neighbours, is grown into an unspeakable estate.Delay this marriage for a month, a week; Or, if you do not, make the bridal bed In that dim monument where Tybalt lies.Happy thou art not; For what thou hast not, still thou strivest to get, And what thou hast, forget'st.No, sir: yet oft, When blows have made me stay, I fled from words.Hark, hark!For fear, I promise you, if I look pale.But you have all the vantage of her wrong.'tis not so much, 'tis not so much: 'Tis since the nuptials of Lucentio, Come pentecost as quickly as it will, Some five and twenty years; and then we mask'd.And, for that dowry, I'll assure her of Her widowhood, be it that she survive me, In all my lands and leases whatsoever: Let specialties be therefore drawn between us, That covenants may be kept on either hand.O Pomfret, Pomfret!But he which bore my letter, Friar John, Was stay'd by accident, and yesternight Return'd my letter back.Gentlemen, that I may soon make good What I have said, Bianca, get you in: And let it not displease thee, good Bianca, For I will love thee ne'er the less, my girl.Call all your tribes together, praise the gods, And make triumphant fires; strew flowers before them: Unshout the noise that banish'd Marcius, Repeal him with the welcome of his mother; Cry 'Welcome, ladies, welcome!'He said the truth: and what said Surrey then?What sayest thou to this tune, matter and method?Let me speak: I have been consul, and can show for Rome Her enemies' marks upon me.Thou, it seems, that calls for company to countenance her.When we granted that, Here was 'I thank you for your voices: thank you: Your most sweet voices: now you have left your voices, I have no further with you.'Upon his mere request, Being come to knowledge that there was complaint Intended 'gainst Lord Angelo, came I hither, To speak, as from his mouth, what he doth know Is true and false; and what he with his oath And all probation will make up full clear, Whensoever he's convented.Then I must not say no.There is no other way Unless thou couldst put on some other shape, And not be Richard that hath done all this.See where she comes and brings your froward wives As prisoners to her womanly persuasion.You have put me now to such a part which never I shall discharge to the life.to the Capitol!Thou dotard!may I know?Nay, I dare not swear it.now I hear them,--Ding-dong, bell.The miserable have no other medicine But only hope: I've hope to live, and am prepared to die.Now old desire doth in his death-bed lie, And young affection gapes to be his heir; That fair for which love groan'd for and would die, With tender Juliet match'd, is now not fair.Error i' the bill, sir; error i' the bill.To her, widow!I pray you, do not push me; I'll be gone.if this be not a lawful case for me to leave his service, look you, sir, he bid me knock him and rap him soundly, sir: well, was it fit for a servant to use his master so, being perhaps, for aught I see, two and thirty, a pip out?Nay, that you shall not: since you have begun, Have at you for a bitter jest or two!Many a time hath banish'd Norfolk fought For Jesu Christ in glorious Christian field, Streaming the ensign of the Christian cross Against black pagans, Turks, and Saracens: And toil'd with works of war, retired himself To Italy; and there at Venice gave His body to that pleasant country's earth, And his pure soul unto his captain Christ, Under whose colours he had fought so long.lay bolts enough upon him: let him speak no more.She shall not.Suppose, my lords, he did it unconstrain'd, Think you 'twere prejudicial to his crown?Urge it no more; lest that, instead of words, I send thee, Warwick, such a messenger As shall revenge his death before I stir.so that thy state might be no worse, I would my skill were subject to thy curse.Sir, it is a mystery.There is no other way but to tell the king she's a changeling and none of your flesh and blood.undone!Ay, good my lord, and leave us to our fortune.O that you could!He that knows better how to tame a shrew, Now let him speak: 'tis charity to show.Madam, the Lady Valeria is come to visit you.He does well in 't.Let my sheep go: come, good boy, the next way home.First, to thy sacred state wish I all happiness.I know she is an irksome brawling scold: If that be all, masters, I hear no harm.Nay, come, Kate, come; you must not look so sour.Ay, worthy Menenius; and with most prosperous approbation.Follow me, girls.His majesty Tendering my person's safety, hath appointed This conduct to convey me to the Tower.Why, I pray you?Well, call them again.My gracious lord, here in the parliament Let us assail the family of York.I have not sounded him, nor he deliver'd His gracious pleasure any way therein: But you, my noble lords, may name the time; And in the duke's behalf I'll give my voice, Which, I presume, he'll take in gentle part.Give you good morrow, sir.Dost thou desire her foully for those things That make her good?How now, fair maid?The lights burn blue.Let every feeble rumour shake your hearts!what comes the wool to?I thank your ladyship; well, good madam.for we want thy help.The nobles in great earnestness are going All to the senate-house: some news is come That turns their countenances.Let me have no lying: it becomes none but tradesmen, and they often give us soldiers the lie: but we pay them for it with stamped coin, not stabbing steel; therefore they do not give us the lie.Who's this?And if I were thy nurse, thy tongue to teach, 'Pardon' should be the first word of thy speech.what light through yonder window breaks?ah, how long Shall tender duty make me suffer wrong?We must to the king and show our strange sights: he must know 'tis none of your daughter nor my sister; we are gone else.Didst thou not say he comes?How much salt water thrown away in waste, To season love, that of it doth not taste!no outrage: peace!Worthy tribunes, There is a slave, whom we have put in prison, Reports, the Volsces with two several powers Are enter'd in the Roman territories, And with the deepest malice of the war Destroy what lies before 'em.Then would I hide my bones, not rest them here.We thank thee, gentle Percy, for thy pains; And to thy worth will add right worthy gains.it is too rough, Too rude, too boisterous, and it pricks like thorn.let me see the writing.Pray you now, if it may stand with the tune of your voices that I may be consul, I have here the customary gown.Did they not sometime cry, 'all hail!'Our hap is loss, our hope but sad despair; Our ranks are broke, and ruin follows us: What counsel give you?Let them lay by their helmets and their spears, And both return back to their chairs again: Withdraw with us: and let the trumpets sound While we return these dukes what we decree.A woeful pageant have we here beheld.About that which concerns your grace and us; The crown of England, father, which is yours.He had rather see the swords, and hear a drum, than look upon his school-master.First, an it like you, the house is a respected house; next, this is a respected fellow; and his mistress is a respected woman.So I would you did; then 'twere past all doubt You'ld call your children yours.Madam, undress you and come now to bed.get you away.They do me wrong, and I will not endure it: Who are they that complain unto the king, That I, forsooth, am stern, and love them not?Good madam,-- I have done.Had she affections and warm youthful blood, She would be as swift in motion as a ball; My words would bandy her to my sweet love, And his to me: But old folks, many feign as they were dead; Unwieldy, slow, heavy and pale as lead.What likelihood of his amendment, lords?Ourself and Bushy, Bagot here and Green Observed his courtship to the common people; How he did seem to dive into their hearts With humble and familiar courtesy, What reverence he did throw away on slaves, Wooing poor craftsmen with the craft of smiles And patient underbearing of his fortune, As 'twere to banish their affects with him.If my heart's dear love-- Well, do not swear: although I joy in thee, I have no joy of this contract to-night: It is too rash, too unadvised, too sudden; Too like the lightning, which doth cease to be Ere one can say 'It lightens.'We enjoin thee, As thou art liege-man to us, that thou carry This female bastard hence and that thou bear it To some remote and desert place quite out Of our dominions, and that there thou leave it, Without more mercy, to its own protection And favour of the climate.or had you tongues to cry Against the rectorship of judgment?Come; fear you not: good counsellors lack no clients: though you change your place, you need not change your trade; I'll be your tapster still.Tressel and Berkeley, go along with me.Let one attend him with a silver basin Full of rose-water and bestrew'd with flowers, Another bear the ewer, the third a diaper, And say 'Will't please your lordship cool your hands?'So thrive my soul-- A thousand times good night!Ah, tutor, look where bloody Clifford comes!Hadst thou foxship To banish him that struck more blows for Rome Than thou hast spoken words?But of all, the burst And the ear-deafening voice o' the oracle, Kin to Jove's thunder, so surprised my sense.Good even to my ghostly confessor.God forgive me, Marry, and amen, how sound is she asleep!pronounce but 'love' and 'dove;' Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word, One nick-name for her purblind son and heir, Young Adam Cupid, he that shot so trim, When King Cophetua loved the beggar-maid!So please you, sir, their speed Hath been beyond account.Or you stolen his?dost thou mean the crown?To-morrow, in mine opinion, is too sudden; For I myself am not so well provided As else I would be, were the day prolong'd.Yes, Warwick, I remember it to my grief; And, by his soul, thou and thy house shall rue it.For God's sake, lords, give signal to the fight.both with an R. Ah.Pity, you ancient stones, those tender babes Whom envy hath immured within your walls!Without his roe, like a dried herring: flesh, flesh, how art thou fishified!is the sword unsway'd?I know so.The lords at Pomfret, when they rode from London, Were jocund, and supposed their state was sure, And they indeed had no cause to mistrust; But yet, you see how soon the day o'ercast.Let me but meet you, ladies, one hour hence, And I'll salute your grace of York as mother, And reverend looker on, of two fair queens.O slanderous world!No doubt, my lord.Was ever son so rued a father's death?My pretty cousins, you mistake me much; I do lament the sickness of the king.Come, sir, along with us.then asks Bohemia forgiveness; then embraces his son-in-law; then again worries he his daughter with clipping her; now he thanks the old shepherd, which stands by like a weather-bitten conduit of many kings' reigns.Could we but learn from whence his sorrows grow.Upon what cause?Your temples burned in their cement, and Your franchises, whereon you stood, confined Into an auger's bore.for a thousand causes I would prolong awhile the traitor's life.You speak o' the people, As if you were a god to punish, not A man of their infirmity.Ha!Who 'scapes the lurking serpent's mortal sting?all deaths are too few, the sharpest too easy.Go to; let that be mine: Do you your office, or give up your place, And you shall well be spared.Thy brother's blood the thirsty earth hath drunk, Broach'd with the steely point of Clifford's lance; And in the very pangs of death he cried, Like to a dismal clangour heard from far, 'Warwick, revenge!See, where he stands between two clergymen!No doubt, no doubt; and so shall Clarence too; For they that were your enemies are his, And have prevail'd as much on him as you.Go, play, boy, play.Uncle, for God's sake, speak comfortable words.what a jaunt have I had!There is no remedy.I shall despair.Why dost thou spit at me?The people will remain uncertain whilst 'Twixt you there's difference; but the fall of either Makes the survivor heir of all.Is any woman wrong'd by this lewd fellow, As I have heard him swear himself there's one Whom he begot with child, let her appear, And he shall marry her: the nuptial finish'd, Let him be whipt and hang'd.I pray you, sir, what saucy merchant was this, that was so full of his ropery?Come on, our queen: to-morrow must we part; Be merry, for our time of stay is short Well, lords, the Duke of Lancaster is dead.'Your love says, like an honest gentleman, Where is your mother?'Has he any unbraided wares?Well, you have made a simple choice; you know not how to choose a man: Romeo!My Lord Aumerle, is Harry Hereford arm'd?Their sacred wills be done!O, but remember this another day, When he shall split thy very heart with sorrow, And say poor Margaret was a prophetess!our drums Are bringing forth our youth.And indeed, sir, there are cozeners abroad; therefore it behoves men to be wary.You're liars all.In that you brook it in, it makes him worse: Therefore, for God's sake, entertain good comfort, And cheer his grace with quick and merry words.Shake quoth the dove-house: 'twas no need, I trow, To bid me trudge: And since that time it is eleven years; For then she could stand alone; nay, by the rood, She could have run and waddled all about; For even the day before, she broke her brow: And then my husband--God be with his soul!What!Thus high, by thy advice And thy assistance, is King Richard seated; But shall we wear these honours for a day?Give me my boots, I say.Madam, we'll dance.Away!Here's packing, with a witness to deceive us all!Why, 'twas a commandment to command the captain and all the rest from their functions: they put forth to steal.Hold out my horse, and I will first be there.What's the news in Rome?Look, therefore, Lewis, that by this league and marriage Thou draw not on thy danger and dishonour; For though usurpers sway the rule awhile, Yet heavens are just, and time suppresseth wrongs.O, how it yearn'd my heart when I beheld In London streets, that coronation-day, When Bolingbroke rode on roan Barbary, That horse that thou so often hast bestrid, That horse that I so carefully have dress'd!That spirit's possessed with haste That wounds the unsisting postern with these strokes.And you, good sir!No, marry; I fear thee!O Lancaster, I fear thy overthrow More than my body's parting with my soul!I need not add more fuel to your fire, For well I wot ye blaze to burn them out Give signal to the fight, and to it, lords!By heaven, I love thee better than myself; For I come hither arm'd against myself: Stay not, be gone; live, and hereafter say, A madman's mercy bade thee run away.The king!an't like you, sir?Perpetual durance?If they do see thee, they will murder thee.My ashes, as the phoenix, may bring forth A bird that will revenge upon you all: And in that hope I throw mine eyes to heaven, Scorning whate'er you can afflict me with.The climate's delicate, the air most sweet, Fertile the isle, the temple much surpassing The common praise it bears.The king hath on him such a countenance As he had lost some province and a region Loved as he loves himself: even now I met him With customary compliment; when he, Wafting his eyes to the contrary and falling A lip of much contempt, speeds from me and So leaves me to consider what is breeding That changeth thus his manners.Good morrow, gentle mistress: where away?My lord, in the base court he doth attend To speak with you; may it please you to come down.Has said enough.My soul flies through these wounds to seek out Thee.This is the fruit of rashness!O, he hath kept an evil diet long, And overmuch consumed his royal person: 'Tis very grievous to be thought upon.High be our thoughts: I know my uncle York Hath power enough to serve our turn.'Twas odds, belike, when valiant Warwick fled: Oft have I heard his praises in pursuit, But ne'er till now his scandal of retire.What!Evermore weeping for your cousin's death?Roundly replied.Baptista is a noble gentleman, To whom my father is not all unknown; And were his daughter fairer than she is, She may more suitors have and me for one.Think upon me!But thus: if powers divine Behold our human actions, as they do, I doubt not then but innocence shall make False accusation blush and tyranny Tremble at patience.Right.With every minute you do change a mind, And call him noble that was now your hate, Him vile that was your garland.loss of some pitch'd battle against Warwick?Never hung poison on a fouler toad.Saddle white Surrey for the field to-morrow.Lives my sweet son?Thou, my slave, As thou report'st thyself, wast then her servant; And, for thou wast a spirit too delicate To act her earthy and abhorr'd commands, Refusing her grand hests, she did confine thee, By help of her more potent ministers And in her most unmitigable rage, Into a cloven pine; within which rift Imprison'd thou didst painfully remain A dozen years; within which space she died And left thee there; where thou didst vent thy groans As fast as mill-wheels strike.Wert thou the Hector That was the whip of your bragg'd progeny, Thou shouldst not scape me here.Though far more cause, yet much less spirit to curse Abides in me; I say amen to all.'tis not my fault, Nor wittingly have I infringed my vow.How durst you, villains, bring it from the dresser, And serve it thus to me that love it not?they are louder than the weather or our office.Many that are not mad Have, sure, more lack of reason.Here's ado, To lock up honesty and honour from The access of gentle visitors!'Tis time I should inform thee farther.'Signior Martino and his wife and daughters; County Anselme and his beauteous sisters; the lady widow of Vitravio; Signior Placentio and his lovely nieces; Mercutio and his brother Valentine; mine uncle Capulet, his wife and daughters; my fair niece Rosaline; Livia; Signior Valentio and his cousin Tybalt, Lucio and the lively Helena.'Stand up, stand up; stand, and you be a man: For Juliet's sake, for her sake, rise and stand; Why should you fall into so deep an O?Hence comes it that your kindred shuns your house, As beaten hence by your strange lunacy.The news is, sir, the Volsces are in arms.Not unlike, Each way, to better yours.Madam, we'll tell tales.Ye're long about it.I warrant thee, my man's as true as steel.Where's my spaniel Troilus?Son, I have overheard what hath passed between you and your sister.These were her words, utter'd with mad disdain: 'Tell him, in hope he'll prove a widower shortly, I'll wear the willow garland for his sake.'Welcome.Why he's a devil, a devil, a very fiend.I pray you, tell my lord and father, madam, I will not marry yet; and, when I do, I swear, It shall be Romeo, whom you know I hate, Rather than Paris.Plantagenet!Who comes with him?Or Daphne roaming through a thorny wood, Scratching her legs that one shall swear she bleeds, And at that sight shall sad Apollo weep, So workmanly the blood and tears are drawn.And shall I have?Ariel, thy charge Exactly is perform'd: but there's more work.'Tis very true: thou didst it excellent.What says his majesty?The tiger now hath seized the gentle hind; Insulting tyranny begins to jet Upon the innocent and aweless throne: Welcome, destruction, death, and massacre!Pray, get you out.My dukedom to a beggarly denier, I do mistake my person all this while: Upon my life, she finds, although I cannot, Myself to be a marvellous proper man.Then vail your stomachs, for it is no boot, And place your hands below your husband's foot: In token of which duty, if he please, My hand is ready; may it do him ease.With all our harts.Then, O you blessed ministers above, Keep me in patience, and with ripen'd time Unfold the evil which is here wrapt up In countenance!thou sleepest.Tranio, I saw her coral lips to move And with her breath she did perfume the air: Sacred and sweet was all I saw in her.Which when I saw, I reprehended them; And ask'd the mayor what meant this wilful silence: His answer was, the people were not wont To be spoke to but by the recorder.Now must the world point at poor Katharina, And say, 'Lo, there is mad Petruchio's wife, If it would please him come and marry her!'This music mads me; let it sound no more; For though it have holp madmen to their wits, In me it seems it will make wise men mad.I know they do; and I have well deserved it.Why either were you ignorant to see't, Or, seeing it, of such childish friendliness To yield your voices?Ah, hark!Let me peruse this face.Long live Edward the Fourth!What pleasure was he given to?the doxy over the dale, Why, then comes in the sweet o' the year; For the red blood reigns in the winter's pale.Art going to prison, Pompey?But what a fool am I to chat with you, When I should bid good morrow to my bride, And seal the title with a lovely kiss!O, let us hence; I stand on sudden haste.let's go learn the truth of it.3 KING HENRY VI Now tell me, brother Clarence, what think you Of this new marriage with the Lady Grey?Talk not to me: I will go sit and weep Till I can find occasion of revenge.a sleeve?I marvel Cambio comes not all this while.Worthy Camillo, What colour for my visitation shall I Hold up before him?Sweet flower, with flowers thy bridal bed I strew,-- O woe!Have you inform'd them sithence?and that those veins Did verily bear blood?A sad tale's best for winter: I have one Of sprites and goblins.For my part, I'll not trouble thee with words.What, is he in his bed?They have made worms' meat of me: I have it, And soundly too: your houses!O, what may man within him hide, Though angel on the outward side!Not I: No, God forbid that I should wish them sever'd Whom God hath join'd together; ay, and 'twere pity To sunder them that yoke so well together.Stand all apart Cousin of Buckingham!Why do you wring your hands, and beat your breast, And cry 'O Clarence, my unhappy son!'Make much of him, my lords, for this is he Must help you more than you are hurt by me.Farewell: buy food, and get thyself in flesh.An if I do not, may my hands rot off And never brandish more revengeful steel Over the glittering helmet of my foe!serious vanity!A title for a maid of all titles the worst.Go, sirrah, trudge about Through fair Verona; find those persons out Whose names are written there, and to them say, My house and welcome on their pleasure stay.they are quickly gone.Why, so I am, in mind; and that's enough.Let him know't.He did, my lord.Say that I slew them not?I am in your debt for your last exercise; Come the next Sabbath, and I will content you.O sir, I do; and will repute you ever The patron of my life and liberty.O, no, no, no.O, your desert speaks loud; and I should wrong it, To lock it in the wards of covert bosom, When it deserves, with characters of brass, A forted residence 'gainst the tooth of time And razure of oblivion.In all which time you and your husband Grey Were factious for the house of Lancaster; And, Rivers, so were you.From Scotland am I stol'n, even of pure love, To greet mine own land with my wishful sight.O, she knew well Thy love did read by rote and could not spell.I will not sup to-night.No hare, sir; unless a hare, sir, in a lenten pie, that is something stale and hoar ere it be spent.Nor I. Let's to the Capitol.Why, very well, then,-- Come, you are a tedious fool: to the purpose.The hour's now come; The very minute bids thee ope thine ear; Obey and be attentive.There's no trust, No faith, no honesty in men; all perjured, All forsworn, all naught, all dissemblers.sir, it is worse for me than so; For I have bills for money by exchange From Florence and must here deliver them.So she does any thing; though I report it, That should be silent: if young Doricles Do light upon her, she shall bring him that Which he not dreams of.Tranio hits you now.If judgement lie in them, then so do we, Because we ever have been near the king.Name not the god, thou boy of tears!Not so hot, good sir: I come to bring him sleep.O, she is lame!Why, York, what wilt thou do?Content.What is the business?Spoke like a tail fellow that respects his reputation.What advocate hast thou to him?Sir, The manner of your bearing towards him, with What you as from your father shall deliver, Things known betwixt us three, I'll write you down: The which shall point you forth at every sitting What you must say; that he shall not perceive But that you have your father's bosom there And speak his very heart.And may not young men die, as well as old?false hound!Put them in secret holds, both Barnardine and Claudio: Ere twice the sun hath made his journal greeting To the under generation, you shall find Your safety manifested.I'll return consul; Or never trust to what my tongue can do I' the way of flattery further.Be pitiful, dread lord, and grant it then.Worst in this royal presence may I speak, Yet best beseeming me to speak the truth.Why, so!hath sorrow struck So many blows upon this face of mine, And made no deeper wounds?No, my good lord; it is more pleasing stuff.Come, come away.are you lords o' the field?Come, bring them away: if these be good people in a commonweal that do nothing but use their abuses in common houses, I know no law: bring them away.What thinkest thou, will our friends prove all true?Shall we give o'er and drown?a lantern, slaughter'd youth, For here lies Juliet, and her beauty makes This vault a feasting presence full of light.The motion's good indeed and be it so, Petruchio, I shall be your ben venuto.No might nor greatness in mortality Can censure 'scape; back-wounding calumny The whitest virtue strikes.Faith, sirrah, an you'll not knock, I'll ring it; I'll try how you can sol, fa, and sing it.What, will you not suffer me?When have I injured thee?O, my son, my son!I am too mean a subject for thy wrath: Be thou revenged on men, and let me live.Yonder's the head of that arch-enemy That sought to be encompass'd with your crown: Doth not the object cheer your heart, my lord?What, ho!He shall, sure on't.let our bloody colours wave!No truly sir; not a penny.what day is this?There's other of our friends Will greet us here anon, my gentle Varrius.that it was no better than picture-like to hang by the wall, if renown made it not stir, was pleased to let him seek danger where he was like to find fame.Lay hold on him, I charge you, in the duke's name.Boy!When you and I met at Saint Alban's last, Your legs did better service than your hands.His own impatience Takes from Aufidius a great part of blame.This, by the way, I let you understand; my father is here look'd for every day, To pass assurance of a dower in marriage 'Twixt me and one Baptista's daughter here: In all these circumstances I'll instruct you: Go with me to clothe you as becomes you.Grandam, his nurse.Fie, fie!But shall you on your knowledge find this way?No, Pompey.Thy grief is but thy absence for a time.thou diest, though I the sicker be.I see your brows are full of discontent, Your hearts of sorrow and your eyes of tears: Come home with me to supper; and I'll lay A plot shall show us all a merry day.'Tis false.So said, so done, is well.And let the soul forth that adoreth thee, I lay it naked to the deadly stroke, And humbly beg the death upon my knee.What!to prison!That life is better life, past fearing death, Than that which lives to fear: make it your comfort, So happy is your brother.They sit conferring by the parlor fire.Reason thus with life: If I do lose thee, I do lose a thing That none but fools would keep: a breath thou art, Servile to all the skyey influences, That dost this habitation, where thou keep'st, Hourly afflict: merely, thou art death's fool; For him thou labour'st by thy flight to shun And yet runn'st toward him still.Come, come, you wasp; i' faith, you are too angry.Condition!Our Earl of Warwick, Edward's greatest friend.So our virtues Lie in the interpretation of the time: And power, unto itself most commendable, Hath not a tomb so evident as a chair To extol what it hath done.With all my heart I pardon him.Some honest Christian trust me with a gage That Norfolk lies: here do I throw down this, If he may be repeal'd, to try his honour.Now, fair befall you!No, I serve not thy master.Mum.Ay, my lord; But I had rather kill two enemies.So that in this time of lethargy I picked and cut most of their festival purses; and had not the old man come in with a whoo-bub against his daughter and the king's son and scared my choughs from the chaff, I had not left a purse alive in the whole army.He's in the right.To your good prayers will scarcely say amen.To bide upon't, thou art not honest, or, If thou inclinest that way, thou art a coward, Which hoxes honesty behind, restraining From course required; or else thou must be counted A servant grafted in my serious trust And therein negligent; or else a fool That seest a game play'd home, the rich stake drawn, And takest it all for jest.Hark!Travel you far on, or are you at the farthest?Look he's winding up the watch of his wit; by and by it will strike.Out of our way, I say.Why uncle, thou hast many years to live.I would he had.Blue, my lord.But now the blood of twenty thousand men Did triumph in my face, and they are fled; And, till so much blood thither come again, Have I not reason to look pale and dead?Call it a travel that thou takest for pleasure.Here come more voices.No; for he could not so resign his crown But that the next heir should succeed and reign.nay, come again, Good Kate; I am a gentleman.When steel grows soft as the parasite's silk, Let him be made a coverture for the wars!O pity, pity, gentle heaven, pity!Thereon I pawn my credit and mine honour.Tush, tush!So then the Volsces stand but as at first, Ready, when time shall prompt them, to make road.It is fifteen years since I saw my country: though I have for the most part been aired abroad, I desire to lay my bones there.Come, where be these gallants?What, ho, Barnardine!Gentle my lord, turn back.Tends that thou wouldst speak to the Duke of Hereford?A good swift simile, but something currish.that which we call a rose By any other name would smell as sweet; So Romeo would, were he not Romeo call'd, Retain that dear perfection which he owes Without that title.I do; and bear the shame most patiently.I wish you much mirth.Give me another horse: bind up my wounds.Softly, my masters!How may likeness made in crimes, Making practise on the times, To draw with idle spiders' strings Most ponderous and substantial things!O, whither?By my troth, it is well said; 'for himself to mar,' quoth a'?Take him to prison; And see our pleasure herein executed.Fie, fie, fie!'Tis right.Ay, a thousand times.Come, therefore, let us fly while we may fly: If Warwick take us we are sure to die.Answer me like men: 'When griping grief the heart doth wound, And doleful dumps the mind oppress, Then music with her silver sound'-- why 'silver sound'?While you are thus employ'd, what resteth more, But that I seek occasion how to rise, And yet the king not privy to my drift, Nor any of the house of Lancaster?Friar, where's the provost?Be it lawful that I invocate thy ghost, To hear the lamentations of Poor Anne, Wife to thy Edward, to thy slaughter'd son, Stabb'd by the selfsame hand that made these wounds!is there man has rebused your worship?Shepherdess, A fair one are you--well you fit our ages With flowers of winter.it more becomes a man Than gilt his trophy: the breasts of Hecuba, When she did suckle Hector, look'd not lovelier Than Hector's forehead when it spit forth blood At Grecian sword, contemning.Speak it in French, king; say, 'pardonne moi.'That Shall be when your first queen's again in breath; Never till then.Canst thou believe thy living is a life, So stinkingly depending?Peter, stay at the gate.Friar, not I I have been drinking hard all night, and I will have more time to prepare me, or they shall beat out my brains with billets: I will not consent to die this day, that's certain.Is Bushy, Green, and the Earl of Wiltshire dead?Cursed the blood that let this blood from hence!Tell me thine first.Nay, that's not so.A challenge, on my life.and what's the matter?Depress'd he is already, and deposed 'Tis doubt he will be: letters came last night To a dear friend of the good Duke of York's, That tell black tidings.And yet I wish but for the thing I have: My bounty is as boundless as the sea, My love as deep; the more I give to thee, The more I have, for both are infinite.Urge it no more, my Lord Northumberland.Welcome, my lord what is the news?Ah, where's my man?Thou chidest me well: proud Bolingbroke, I come To change blows with thee for our day of doom.Did you such a thing?Should we be silent and not speak, our raiment And state of bodies would bewray what life We have led since thy exile.For now the devil, that told me I did well, Says that this deed is chronicled in hell.How but well, sir?Lord mayor,-- Look to the drawbridge there!Good man, the wounds that he does bear for Rome!Since their more mature dignities and royal necessities made separation of their society, their encounters, though not personal, have been royally attorneyed with interchange of gifts, letters, loving embassies; that they have seemed to be together, though absent, shook hands, as over a vast, and embraced, as it were, from the ends of opposed winds.But when goes this forward?By Jupiter!But I can give thee more: For I will raise her statue in pure gold; That while Verona by that name is known, There shall no figure at such rate be set As that of true and faithful Juliet.By Him that raised me to this careful height From that contented hap which I enjoy'd, I never did incense his majesty Against the Duke of Clarence, but have been An earnest advocate to plead for him.Ay, with my heart And punish them to your height of pleasure.my throat of war be turn'd, Which quired with my drum, into a pipe Small as an eunuch, or the virgin voice That babies lulls asleep!Nay, 'tis no matter, sir, what he 'leges in Latin.Two, two; a shirt and a smock.I think He told me Paris should have married Juliet: Said he not so?Take thou the fee, and tell him what I say; For I repent me that the duke is slain.Art thou my son?The widow likes it not, for she looks very sad.Against him first: he's a very dog to the commonalty.You are well met, sir.This found I on my tent this morning.O serpent heart, hid with a flowering face!After him, fellows; bring him to the block.Madam, I am not well.Enforced thee!Thither will I with you; for little office The hateful commons will perform for us, Except like curs to tear us all to pieces.I think it cites us, brother, to the field, That we, the sons of brave Plantagenet, Each one already blazing by our meeds, Should notwithstanding join our lights together And over-shine the earth as this the world.Brave followers, yonder stands the thorny wood, Which, by the heavens' assistance and your strength, Must by the roots be hewn up yet ere night.He who the sword of heaven will bear Should be as holy as severe; Pattern in himself to know, Grace to stand, and virtue go; More nor less to others paying Than by self-offences weighing.Marry, will I; and you shall help to put him i' the ground.why, now thou hast thy will: For raging wind blows up incessant showers, And when the rage allays, the rain begins.Go, call the people: in whose name myself Attach thee as a traitorous innovator, A foe to the public weal: obey, I charge thee, And follow to thine answer.Were he the butcher of my son, he should Be free as is the wind.Farewell, my friend.Now, the gods crown thee!give room!Let me hear you speak farther.I will make my very house reel tonight: a letter for me!Madam, we did: he desires to make atonement Betwixt the Duke of Gloucester and your brothers, And betwixt them and my lord chamberlain; And sent to warn them to his royal presence.Come, come, you froward and unable worms!I, that kill'd her husband and his father, To take her in her heart's extremest hate, With curses in her mouth, tears in her eyes, The bleeding witness of her hatred by; Having God, her conscience, and these bars against me, And I nothing to back my suit at all, But the plain devil and dissembling looks, And yet to win her, all the world to nothing!I am sped.To-morrow, then, we will attend your grace: And so most joyfully we take our leave.O, yes, it doth; a thousand-fold it doth.Would he were here, my lord!I tell thee, daughter, I sprang not more in joy at first hearing he was a man-child than now in first seeing he had proved himself a man.To thee, that hast nor honesty nor grace.Do, good old grandsire; and withal make known Which way thou travellest: if along with us, We shall be joyful of thy company.Now are our brows bound with victorious wreaths; Our bruised arms hung up for monuments; Our stern alarums changed to merry meetings, Our dreadful marches to delightful measures.Some dungeon.Sir, pardon me in what I have to say: Your plainness and your shortness please me well.He has done nobly, and cannot go without any honest man's voice.For Gloucester's death, I slew him not; but to my own disgrace Neglected my sworn duty in that case.I would I were, to be revenged on thee.What ever have been thought on in this state, That could be brought to bodily act ere Rome Had circumvention?Bate, I beseech you, widow Dido.Proceed by process; Lest parties, as he is beloved, break out, And sack great Rome with Romans.And say, what store of parting tears were shed?To lose itself in a fog, where being three parts melted away with rotten dews, the fourth would return for conscience sake, to help to get thee a wife.You show too much of that For which the people stir: if you will pass To where you are bound, you must inquire your way, Which you are out of, with a gentler spirit, Or never be so noble as a consul, Nor yoke with him for tribune.Thus it is: the Volsces have an army forth; against whom Cominius the general is gone, with one part of our Roman power: your lord and Titus Lartius are set down before their city Corioli; they nothing doubt prevailing and to make it brief wars.Was it not she and that good man of worship, Anthony Woodville, her brother there, That made him send Lord Hastings to the Tower, From whence this present day he is deliver'd?Here is a wonder, if you talk of a wonder.O, I am undone!Take Hereford's rights away, and take from Time His charters and his customary rights; Let not to-morrow then ensue to-day; Be not thyself; for how art thou a king But by fair sequence and succession?'Tis nothing but some bond, that he is enter'd into For gay apparel 'gainst the triumph day.'I Pray, sir'--Plague upon't!And in the breath of bitter words let's smother My damned son, which thy two sweet sons smother'd.It is, it is: hie hence, be gone, away!And too soon marr'd are those so early made.But Montague is bound as well as I, In penalty alike; and 'tis not hard, I think, For men so old as we to keep the peace.Be not uncertain; For, by the honour of my parents, I Have utter'd truth: which if you seek to prove, I dare not stand by; nor shall you be safer Than one condemn'd by the king's own mouth, thereon His execution sworn.Your cares set up do not pluck my cares down.If, Tullus, Not yet thou knowest me, and, seeing me, dost not Think me for the man I am, necessity Commands me name myself.Richard!Even he, my lord.This damn'd witch Sycorax, For mischiefs manifold and sorceries terrible To enter human hearing, from Argier, Thou know'st, was banish'd: for one thing she did They would not take her life.Little have you to say When you depart from him, but, soft and low, 'Remember now my brother.'Is there no remedy?Know you not the cause?What, canst not rule her?Yet since I see you fearful, that neither my coat, integrity, nor persuasion can with ease attempt you, I will go further than I meant, to pluck all fears out of you.Now, Kate, I am a husband for your turn; For, by this light, whereby I see thy beauty, Thy beauty, that doth make me like thee well, Thou must be married to no man but me; For I am he am born to tame you Kate, And bring you from a wild Kate to a Kate Conformable as other household Kates.Have to my widow!I am a poor fellow, sir.Ay, my good lord.Hark!At this same ancient feast of Capulet's Sups the fair Rosaline whom thou so lovest, With all the admired beauties of Verona: Go thither; and, with unattainted eye, Compare her face with some that I shall show, And I will make thee think thy swan a crow.Of Pisa, sir; son to Vincentio.Live in thy shame, but die not shame with thee!I humbly thank you: Commend me to my brother: soon at night I'll send him certain word of my success.Fitzwater, thou art damn'd to hell for this.I pray, you, tell me, hath any body inquired for me here to-day?Good Peter, to hide her face; for her fan's the fairer face.A virtuous and a Christian-like conclusion, To pray for them that have done scathe to us.You shall not be admitted to his sight.But not a minute, king, that thou canst give: Shorten my days thou canst with sullen sorrow, And pluck nights from me, but not lend a morrow; Thou canst help time to furrow me with age, But stop no wrinkle in his pilgrimage; Thy word is current with him for my death, But dead, thy kingdom cannot buy my breath.Conceiving the dishonour of his mother, He straight declined, droop'd, took it deeply, Fasten'd and fix'd the shame on't in himself, Threw off his spirit, his appetite, his sleep, And downright languish'd.Let's to the Capitol; And carry with us ears and eyes for the time, But hearts for the event.Is not a dukedom, sir, a goodly gift?What, art thou ashamed of me?Did you confer with him?It fits, when such a villain is a guest: I'll not endure him.Yet 'banished'?I speak to subjects, and a subject speaks, Stirr'd up by God, thus boldly for his king: My Lord of Hereford here, whom you call king, Is a foul traitor to proud Hereford's king: And if you crown him, let me prophesy: The blood of English shall manure the ground, And future ages groan for this foul act; Peace shall go sleep with Turks and infidels, And in this seat of peace tumultuous wars Shall kin with kin and kind with kind confound; Disorder, horror, fear and mutiny Shall here inhabit, and this land be call'd The field of Golgotha and dead men's skulls.Spoke he of me?What now remains, my lords, for us to do But march to London with our soldiers?But had he died in the business, madam; how then?What we will do, we do upon command.Once more, sweet lords farewell.Thy slanders I forgive; and therewithal Remit thy other forfeits.Then at my lodging, an it like you: There doth my father lie; and there, this night, We'll pass the business privately and well.And to poor we Thine enmity's most capital: thou barr'st us Our prayers to the gods, which is a comfort That all but we enjoy; for how can we, Alas, how can we for our country pray.Has the porter his eyes in his head; that he gives entrance to such companions?Good faith, 'tis day: The county will be here with music straight, For so he said he would: I hear him near.Believe me, lord, I think he cannot choose.Poor Clarence did forsake his father, Warwick; Yea, and forswore himself,--which Jesu pardon!-- Which God revenge!Go, get thee hence, for I will not away.What he cannot help in his nature, you account a vice in him.My dismal scene I needs must act alone.Where is thy power, then, to beat him back?Come to me, Tyrrel, soon at after supper, And thou shalt tell the process of their death.Forgiveness, horse!She for an Edward weeps, and so do I; I for a Clarence weep, so doth not she: These babes for Clarence weep and so do I; I for an Edward weep, so do not they: Alas, you three, on me, threefold distress'd, Pour all your tears!Fly to the duke: Post thou to Salisbury When thou comest thither-- Dull, unmindful villain, Why stand'st thou still, and go'st not to the duke?Here.Stood the state so?In your affairs, my lord, If ever I were wilful-negligent, It was my folly; if industriously I play'd the fool, it was my negligence, Not weighing well the end; if ever fearful To do a thing, where I the issue doubted, Where of the execution did cry out Against the non-performance, 'twas a fear Which oft infects the wisest: these, my lord, Are such allow'd infirmities that honesty Is never free of.You, my lord, best know, Who least will seem to do so, my past life Hath been as continent, as chaste, as true, As I am now unhappy; which is more Than history can pattern, though devised And play'd to take spectators.Is the world as it was, man?You do blaspheme the good in mocking me.I am always bound to you.How far off lie these armies?For night-owls shriek where mounting larks should sing.Environed he was with many foes, And stood against them, as the hope of Troy Against the Greeks that would have enter'd Troy.Bring her to try with main-course.Fine apparition!Were never orphans had so dear a loss!I' the commonwealth I would by contraries Execute all things; for no kind of traffic Would I admit; no name of magistrate; Letters should not be known; riches, poverty, And use of service, none; contract, succession, Bourn, bound of land, tilth, vineyard, none; No use of metal, corn, or wine, or oil; No occupation; all men idle, all; And women too, but innocent and pure; No sovereignty;-- Yet he would be king on't.Traitor!Amen.This last old man, Whom with a crack'd heart I have sent to Rome, Loved me above the measure of a father; Nay, godded me, indeed.why, who's that?Perhaps thou wilt object my holy oath: To keep that oath were more impiety Than Jephthah's, when he sacrificed his daughter.I will despair, and be at enmity With cozening hope: he is a flatterer, A parasite, a keeper back of death, Who gently would dissolve the bands of life, Which false hope lingers in extremity.Why, then I would not fly.Therefore indeed, my father, I have on Angelo imposed the office; Who may, in the ambush of my name, strike home, And yet my nature never in the fight To do in slander.heavy matters!Marry, sir, 'tis an ill cook that cannot lick his own fingers: therefore he that cannot lick his fingers goes not with me.Thou art the cause, and most accursed effect.I respected with her before I was married to her!Within these three hours, Tullus, Alone I fought in your Corioli walls, And made what work I pleased: 'tis not my blood Wherein thou seest me mask'd; for thy revenge Wrench up thy power to the highest.I thank you, sir.What fear is this which startles in our ears?And I the house of York.There is another friar that set them on; Let him be sent for.Indeed, I have had earnest: but I cannot with conscience take it.You holy clergymen, is there no plot To rid the realm of this pernicious blot?Go, counsellor; Thou and my bosom henceforth shall be twain.For what offence?Was that my father that went hence so fast?Happily we met; the happier for thy son.Brother, this is Sir John Montgomery, Our trusty friend, unless I be deceived.call her forth to me.Thou talk'st of nothing.O no, my reasons are too deep and dead; Too deep and dead, poor infants, in their grave.Hang him, Jack!Fie, fie, thou shamest thy shape, thy love, thy wit; Which, like a usurer, abound'st in all, And usest none in that true use indeed Which should bedeck thy shape, thy love, thy wit: Thy noble shape is but a form of wax, Digressing from the valour of a man; Thy dear love sworn but hollow perjury, Killing that love which thou hast vow'd to cherish; Thy wit, that ornament to shape and love, Misshapen in the conduct of them both, Like powder in a skitless soldier's flask, Is set afire by thine own ignorance, And thou dismember'd with thine own defence.Out of their saddles into the dirt; and thereby hangs a tale.The people are abused; set on.Heaven keep your honour!Here come those I have done good to against my will, and already appearing in the blossoms of their fortune.Signior Hortensio, come you to part the fray?And till the tears that she hath shed for thee Like envious floods o'er-run her lovely face, She was the fairest creature in the world; And yet she is inferior to none.But, for me, What case stand I in?Once more, take her hence.To me the difference forges dread; your greatness Hath not been used to fear.He shows his reason for that: to have a dispatch of complaints, and to deliver us from devices hereafter, which shall then have no power to stand against us.Then, as I said, the duke, great Bolingbroke, Mounted upon a hot and fiery steed Which his aspiring rider seem'd to know, With slow but stately pace kept on his course, Whilst all tongues cried 'God save thee, Bolingbroke!'It shall be to him then as our good wills, A sure destruction.O, what a beast was I to chide at him!I pray the gods she may with all my heart!Ay, sir, in Pisa have I often been, Pisa renowned for grave citizens.Hence will I to my ghostly father's cell, His help to crave, and my dear hap to tell.I do love My country's good with a respect more tender, More holy and profound, than mine own life, My dear wife's estimate, her womb's increase, And treasure of my loins; then if I would Speak that,-- We know your drift: speak what?I will presently to Saint Luke's: there, at the moated grange, resides this dejected Mariana.and let her sport herself With that she's big with; for 'tis Polixenes Has made thee swell thus.Rescue, fair lord, or else the day is lost!Pray you then, Conduct me to the queen.Cheerly, good hearts!Why, boy, how is it?Cousin, throw up your gage; do you begin.why dost thou wring thy hands?That's enough.I have sent for these strawberries.My lord, most villanously; believe it.I know you'ld fain be gone.I have no more sons of the royal blood For thee to murder: for my daughters, Richard, They shall be praying nuns, not weeping queens; And therefore level not to hit their lives.Good morrow to you both.To whom do lions cast their gentle looks?Well, think of marriage now; younger than you, Here in Verona, ladies of esteem, Are made already mothers: by my count, I was your mother much upon these years That you are now a maid.The kingly-crowned head, the vigilant eye, The counsellor heart, the arm our soldier, Our steed the leg, the tongue our trumpeter.Repent you, fair one, of the sin you carry?Hold thy peace: He that hath suffer'd this disorder'd spring Hath now himself met with the fall of leaf: The weeds which his broad-spreading leaves did shelter, That seem'd in eating him to hold him up, Are pluck'd up root and all by Bolingbroke, I mean the Earl of Wiltshire, Bushy, Green.What countryman?Indeed, I never shall be satisfied With Romeo, till I behold him--dead-- Is my poor heart for a kinsman vex'd.Who is't that calls?Good friar, let's hear it.Spoke like an officer; ha' to thee, lad!O prince!this gentleman will out-talk us all.Good sooth, even thus; therefore ha' done with words: To me she's married, not unto my clothes: Could I repair what she will wear in me, As I can change these poor accoutrements, 'Twere well for Kate and better for myself.marry, come up, I trow; Is this the poultice for my aching bones?What my tongue dares not, that my heart shall say.Both, both, my girl: By foul play, as thou say'st, were we heaved thence, But blessedly holp hither.I am a feather for each wind that blows: Shall I live on to see this bastard kneel And call me father?Why, how now, father!Nay, temperately; your promise.They know the corn Was not our recompense, resting well assured That ne'er did service for't: being press'd to the war, Even when the navel of the state was touch'd, They would not thread the gates.'Tis wondrous strange, the like yet never heard of.when drums and trumpets shall I' the field prove flatterers, let courts and cities be Made all of false-faced soothing!Thy wit is a very bitter sweeting; it is a most sharp sauce.Pompey.I commanded the sleeves should be cut out and sewed up again; and that I'll prove upon thee, though thy little finger be armed in a thimble.And look to have it yielded with all willingness.When every grief is entertain'd that's offer'd, Comes to the entertainer-- A dollar.They say!all gold!Any silk, any thread, Any toys for your head, Of the new'st and finest, finest wear-a?Discomfortable cousin!What, not a word?I must Once in a month recount what thou hast been, Which thou forget'st.Long live Gonzalo!You have said you will not grant us any thing; For we have nothing else to ask, but that Which you deny already: yet we will ask; That, if you fail in our request, the blame May hang upon your hardness: therefore hear us.What countryman, I pray?Not?But 'tis gone.Come, cordial and not poison, go with me To Juliet's grave; for there must I use thee.Let me see; what am I to buy for our sheep-shearing feast?Note but this fool.Shall I go win my daughter to thy will?Thou shalt accompany us to the place; where we will, not appearing what we are, have some question with the shepherd; from whose simplicity I think it not uneasy to get the cause of my son's resort thither.what a man are you!This is a merry ballad, but a very pretty one.I say, a devil.Sir, I shall not be slack: in sign whereof, Please ye we may contrive this afternoon, And quaff carouses to our mistress' health, And do as adversaries do in law, Strive mightily, but eat and drink as friends.Welcome, brave Warwick!The harder match'd, the greater victory: My mind presageth happy gain and conquest.Art thou, indeed?Sleep dwell upon thine eyes, peace in thy breast!But sadly tell me who.O, for a falconer's voice, To lure this tassel-gentle back again!'tis he should hear me speak.No, as I am a man.Scurvy knave!Mine honour lives when his dishonour dies, Or my shamed life in his dishonour lies: Thou kill'st me in his life; giving him breath, The traitor lives, the true man's put to death.Good aunt, you wept not for our father's death; How can we aid you with our kindred tears?God save you, Signior Gremio.'Tis most like he will.These letters at fit time deliver me The provost knows our purpose and our plot.O, musicians, because my heart itself plays 'My heart is full of woe:' O, play me some merry dump, to comfort me.That I was nothing.These fifteen years you have been in a dream; Or when you waked, so waked as if you slept.I cry you mercy: I mean the lord protector.Do so, and after two days I will discharge thee.The word is 'mildly.'I have your alms: adieu.Marcius coming home!Or is the adder better than the eel, Because his painted skin contents the eye?Good morrow to my sovereign king and queen: And, princely peers, a happy time of day!So, bring us to our palace; where we'll show What's yet behind, that's meet you all should know.Hap what hap may, I'll roundly go about her: It shall go hard if Cambio go without her.Master, there is three carters, three shepherds, three neat-herds, three swine-herds, that have made themselves all men of hair, they call themselves Saltiers, and they have a dance which the wenches say is a gallimaufry of gambols, because they are not in't; but they themselves are o' the mind, if it be not too rough for some that know little but bowling, it will please plentifully.Will you swear Never to marry but by my free leave?They are.We will go walk a little in the orchard, And then to dinner.Please you To hear Cominius speak?What cursed foot wanders this way to-night, To cross my obsequies and true love's rite?Soldiers, away with him!You left poor Henry at the Bishop's palace, And, ten to one, you'll meet him in the Tower.So.At last, though long, our jarring notes agree: And time it is, when raging war is done, To smile at scapes and perils overblown.You're a made old man: if the sins of your youth are forgiven you, you're well to live.Thou shalt be logger-head.I wonder at this haste; that I must wed Ere he, that should be husband, comes to woo.He that runs fastest gets the ring.Edward the Fourth, by the grace of God, king of England and France, and lord of Ireland, &c. And whosoe'er gainsays King Edward's right, By this I challenge him to single fight.I'll be with you straight.Away with him to prison!Verily!Ye shall, my Lord.What, Warwick, wilt thou leave the town and fight?a braggart, a rogue, a villain, that fights by the book of arithmetic!She hung about my neck; and kiss on kiss She vied so fast, protesting oath on oath, That in a twink she won me to her love.Mine eyes are full of tears, I cannot see: And yet salt water blinds them not so much But they can see a sort of traitors here.We have.And so did I.Five justices' hands at it, and witnesses more than my pack will hold.He's hearing of a cause; he will come straight I'll tell him of you.Ay, the woman's maid of the house.My lord, there needs no such apology: I rather do beseech you pardon me, Who, earnest in the service of my God, Neglect the visitation of my friends.I think so.You Edward, shall unto my Lord Cobham, With whom the Kentishmen will willingly rise: In them I trust; for they are soldiers, Witty, courteous, liberal, full of spirit.The lamb.this do I drink to thee.Take your paper too, And let me have them very well perfumed For she is sweeter than perfume itself To whom they go to.Ay, ay, the cords.And lack of temper'd judgment afterward.Of Mantua.It is now dead midnight.You have pray'd well to-day: This morning for ten thousand of your throats I'd not have given a doit.Hark, come hither, Tyrrel Go, by this token: rise, and lend thine ear: There is no more but so: say it is done, And I will love thee, and prefer thee too.A pretty one; a very pretty one: sure, some 'scape: though I am not bookish, yet I can read waiting-gentlewoman in the 'scape.Saw you the king to-day, my Lord of Derby?Gentle son Edward, thou wilt stay with me?Assay the power you have.Saddle my horse.What traitor hears me, and says not amen?I pray thee, mark me.That I must yield my body to the earth And, by my fall, the conquest to my foe.Sirrah, where have you been?Is't possible that so short a time can alter the condition of a man!And what of him, Tranio?Either be patient, and entreat me fair, Or with the clamorous report of war Thus will I drown your exclamations.Pardon, good Mercutio, my business was great; and in such a case as mine a man may strain courtesy.Amen.And shall I stand, and thou sit in my throne?Most notedly, sir.Well demanded, wench: My tale provokes that question.Benvolio, who began this bloody fray?My name is Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk; Who hither come engaged by my oath-- Which God defend a knight should violate!-- Both to defend my loyalty and truth To God, my king and my succeeding issue, Against the Duke of Hereford that appeals me And, by the grace of God and this mine arm, To prove him, in defending of myself, A traitor to my God, my king, and me: And as I truly fight, defend me heaven!Renowned queen, with patience calm the storm, While we bethink a means to break it off.But your petition Is yet unanswer'd.O, it is excellent To have a giant's strength; but it is tyrannous To use it like a giant.Shake it off.Can I do this, and cannot get a crown?My lord, her wits, I fear me, are not firm: She hath been a suitor to me for her brother Cut off by course of justice,-- By course of justice!My liege, old Gaunt commends him to your majesty.So you have: but I was a gentleman born before my father; for the king's son took me by the hand, and called me brother; and then the two kings called my father brother; and then the prince my brother and the princess my sister called my father father; and so we wept, and there was the first gentleman-like tears that ever we shed.Most true, if ever truth were pregnant by circumstance: that which you hear you'll swear you see, there is such unity in the proofs.'Tis far off And rather like a dream than an assurance That my remembrance warrants.What work's, my countrymen, in hand?I like it well: good Grumio, fetch it me.Here in the prison, father, There died this morning of a cruel fever One Ragozine, a most notorious pirate, A man of Claudio's years; his beard and head Just of his colour.Why, what is that to me More than to Richmond?This is fairy gold, boy, and 'twill prove so: up with't, keep it close: home, home, the next way.In his tongue.Thus play I in one person many people, And none contented: sometimes am I king; Then treasons make me wish myself a beggar, And so I am: then crushing penury Persuades me I was better when a king; Then am I king'd again: and by and by Think that I am unking'd by Bolingbroke, And straight am nothing: but whate'er I be, Nor I nor any man that but man is With nothing shall be pleased, till he be eased With being nothing.No more of this; it does offend my heart: Pray now, no more.he deserved his death; And you my good lords, both have well proceeded, To warn false traitors from the like attempts.O, thus she stood, Even with such life of majesty, warm life, As now it coldly stands, when first I woo'd her!O, kill me too!Say 'better:' here comes one of my master's kinsmen.no, not he; though his face be better than any man's, yet his leg excels all men's; and for a hand, and a foot, and a body, though they be not to be talked on, yet they are past compare: he is not the flower of courtesy, but, I'll warrant him, as gentle as a lamb.To mitigate the scorn he gives his uncle, He prettily and aptly taunts himself: So cunning and so young is wonderful.How!I will not.No, first let's reason with him.I'll not be long behind; though I be old, I doubt not but to ride as fast as York: And never will I rise up from the ground Till Bolingbroke have pardon'd thee.Fear thou no wife; I'll have no wife, Paulina.My gracious lord, I tender you my service, Such as it is, being tender, raw and young: Which elder days shall ripen and confirm To more approved service and desert.So shows a snowy dove trooping with crows, As yonder lady o'er her fellows shows.Brother, give me thy hand; and, gentle Warwick, Let me embrace thee in my weary arms: I, that did never weep, now melt with woe That winter should cut off our spring-time so.Beseech you, father.Come, York and Richard, Warwick and the rest; I stabb'd your fathers' bosoms, split my breast.There is no end, no limit, measure, bound, In that word's death; no words can that woe sound.Your high self, The gracious mark o' the land, you have obscured With a swain's wearing, and me, poor lowly maid, Most goddess-like prank'd up: but that our feasts In every mess have folly and the feeders Digest it with a custom, I should blush To see you so attired, sworn, I think, To show myself a glass.Those gracious words revive my drooping thoughts And give my tongue-tied sorrows leave to speak.why, thou wilt quarrel with a man that hath a hair more, or a hair less, in his beard, than thou hast: thou wilt quarrel with a man for cracking nuts, having no other reason but because thou hast hazel eyes: what eye but such an eye would spy out such a quarrel?Here is in our prison a common executioner, who in his office lacks a helper: if you will take it on you to assist him, it shall redeem you from your gyves; if not, you shall have your full time of imprisonment and your deliverance with an unpitied whipping, for you have been a notorious bawd.I may not, verily.My good lords both, with all the heed I may.None that I more love than myself.No, madam.The wretched, bloody, and usurping boar, That spoil'd your summer fields and fruitful vines, Swills your warm blood like wash, and makes his trough In your embowell'd bosoms, this foul swine Lies now even in the centre of this isle, Near to the town of Leicester, as we learn From Tamworth thither is but one day's march.Nor now my scandal, Richard, dost thou hear; For thou shalt know this strong right hand of mine Can pluck the diadem from faint Henry's head, And wring the awful sceptre from his fist, Were he as famous and as bold in war As he is famed for mildness, peace, and prayer.O, cut my lace in sunder, that my pent heart May have some scope to beat, or else I swoon With this dead-killing news!Am I but three inches?For one poor grain or two!To Coriolanus come all joy and honour!If I have kill'd the issue of your womb, To quicken your increase, I will beget Mine issue of your blood upon your daughter A grandam's name is little less in love Than is the doting title of a mother; They are as children but one step below, Even of your mettle, of your very blood; Of an one pain, save for a night of groans Endured of her, for whom you bid like sorrow.And I resign my gage.Your grace mistakes; only to be brief Left I his title out.They are at hand, and you shall quickly know.One that gives out himself Prince Florizel, Son of Polixenes, with his princess, she The fairest I have yet beheld, desires access To your high presence.Would they were basilisks, to strike thee dead!Know you that Friar Lodowick that she speaks of?If I might die within this hour, I have lived To die when I desire.So when this thief, this traitor, Bolingbroke, Who all this while hath revell'd in the night Whilst we were wandering with the antipodes, Shall see us rising in our throne, the east, His treasons will sit blushing in his face, Not able to endure the sight of day, But self-affrighted tremble at his sin.Thou art a lord, and nothing but a lord: Thou hast a lady far more beautiful Than any woman in this waning age.Else wherefore breathe I in a Christian land?Come, my captain knows you not.Then is your cause gone too.I should have been more strange, I must confess, But that thou overheard'st, ere I was ware, My true love's passion: therefore pardon me, And not impute this yielding to light love, Which the dark night hath so discovered.Yonder comes news.It is in mine authority to command The keys of all the posterns: please your highness To take the urgent hour.As good to chide the waves as speak them fair.Is it for him you do envy me so?He wants nothing of a god but eternity and a heaven to throne in.Do you call, sir?Sweet, so would I: Yet I should kill thee with much cherishing.Would I were sleep and peace, so sweet to rest!Our slaughter'd friends the tackles; what of these?I can't say your worships have delivered the matter well, when I find the ass in compound with the major part of your syllables: and though I must be content to bear with those that say you are reverend grave men, yet they lie deadly that tell you you have good faces.he comes not Like to his father's greatness: his approach, So out of circumstance and sudden, tells us 'Tis not a visitation framed, but forced By need and accident.And the rarest that e'er came there.Help, son!York is too far gone with grief, Or else he never would compare between.rewards he my true service With such deep contempt made I him king for this?Hold, valiant Clifford!Did ever Dian so become a grove As Kate this chamber with her princely gait?Your knees to me?for what purpose, love?The proudest of you all Have been beholding to him in his life; Yet none of you would once plead for his life.Come, captain, We must be neat; not neat, but cleanly, captain: And yet the steer, the heifer and the calf Are all call'd neat.--Still virginalling Upon his palm!--How now, you wanton calf!Why, then we shall have a stirring world again.Ah, what a life were this!No, no, my heart will burst, and if I speak: And I will speak, that so my heart may burst.We are all frail.A footman, sweet sir, a footman.'Tis a lucky day, boy, and we'll do good deeds on't.'Tis passing good: I prithee let me have it.Did not the one deserve to have an heir?God's is the quarrel; for God's substitute, His deputy anointed in His sight, Hath caused his death: the which if wrongfully, Let heaven revenge; for I may never lift An angry arm against His minister.Why stay we now?With old Menenius, and those senators That always favour'd him.I can tell you; but young Romeo will be older when you have found him than he was when you sought him: I am the youngest of that name, for fault of a worse.I am bound to you: There is some sap in this.God grant that some, less noble and less loyal, Nearer in bloody thoughts, but not in blood, Deserve not worse than wretched Clarence did, And yet go current from suspicion!Done.A knot you are of damned blood-suckers!O my lord!the trumpets.My tears shall wipe away these bloody marks; And no more words till they have flow'd their fill.But I am in So far in blood that sin will pluck on sin: Tear-falling pity dwells not in this eye.So do not I: go, coward as thou art.I thought all for the best.Gallop apace, you fiery-footed steeds, Towards Phoebus' lodging: such a wagoner As Phaethon would whip you to the west, And bring in cloudy night immediately.For this last, Before and in Corioli, let me say, I cannot speak him home: he stopp'd the fliers; And by his rare example made the coward Turn terror into sport: as weeds before A vessel under sail, so men obey'd And fell below his stem: his sword, death's stamp, Where it did mark, it took; from face to foot He was a thing of blood, whose every motion Was timed with dying cries: alone he enter'd The mortal gate of the city, which he painted With shunless destiny; aidless came off, And with a sudden reinforcement struck Corioli like a planet: now all's his: When, by and by, the din of war gan pierce His ready sense; then straight his doubled spirit Re-quicken'd what in flesh was fatigate, And to the battle came he; where he did Run reeking o'er the lives of men, as if 'Twere a perpetual spoil: and till we call'd Both field and city ours, he never stood To ease his breast with panting.No.My gracious sovereign?To thee I do commend my watchful soul, Ere I let fall the windows of mine eyes: Sleeping and waking, O, defend me still!for he is coming hither.Therefore, be it known, As to us, to all the world, that Caius Marcius Wears this war's garland: in token of the which, My noble steed, known to the camp, I give him, With all his trim belonging; and from this time, For what he did before Corioli, call him, With all the applause and clamour of the host, CAIUS MARCIUS CORIOLANUS!Sir, I have been an unlawful bawd time out of mind; but yet I will be content to be a lawful hangman.He is coming, sir, he is coming; I hear his straw rustle.Not her that chides, sir, at any hand, I pray.The base is right; 'tis the base knave that jars.I must believe my master; else, I promise you, I should be arguing still upon that doubt: But let it rest.Has censured him Already; and, as I hear, the provost hath A warrant for his execution.Not swear it, now I am a gentleman?Saint Francis be my speed!Enrich the time to come with smooth-faced peace, With smiling plenty and fair prosperous days!Nay, if there be no remedy for it, but that you will needs buy and sell men and women like beasts, we shall have all the world drink brown and white bastard.Madam, and you, my mother, will you go To give your censures in this weighty business?Cease; no more.Fear not our care, sir.Go bear this lance to Thomas, Duke of Norfolk.A good direction, warlike sovereign.No, at a word, madam; indeed, I must not.What would you have, you curs, That like nor peace nor war?Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.A sweeter and a lovelier gentleman, Framed in the prodigality of nature, Young, valiant, wise, and, no doubt, right royal, The spacious world cannot again afford And will she yet debase her eyes on me, That cropp'd the golden prime of this sweet prince, And made her widow to a woful bed?Thou, old Adam's likeness, set to dress this garden, How dares thy harsh rude tongue sound this unpleasing news?And, I beseech you, look into Master Froth here, sir; a man of four-score pound a year; whose father died at Hallowmas: was't not at Hallowmas, Master Froth?Whither?Well, then, no more but this: go, gentle Catesby, And, as it were far off sound thou Lord Hastings, How doth he stand affected to our purpose; And summon him to-morrow to the Tower, To sit about the coronation.Say we read lectures to you.This being granted in course,--and now follows all,--we shall advise this wronged maid to stead up your appointment, go in your place; if the encounter acknowledge itself hereafter, it may compel him to her recompense: and here, by this, is your brother saved, your honour untainted, the poor Mariana advantaged, and the corrupt deputy scaled.The note lies in's throat, if he say I said so.O vile, Intolerable, not to be endured!Why, what wouldst thou do there before I go?Your honour's players, heating your amendment, Are come to play a pleasant comedy; For so your doctors hold it very meet, Seeing too much sadness hath congeal'd your blood, And melancholy is the nurse of frenzy: Therefore they thought it good you hear a play And frame your mind to mirth and merriment, Which bars a thousand harms and lengthens life.Shall I be charged no further than this present?Sir, it is; And I am constant.You will not bail me, then, sir?Yes, Caliban her son.O thou varlet!What should the people do with these bald tribunes?He shall know you better, sir, if I may live to report you.Farewell, my gracious lord; I'll to my castle.Dost thou love pictures?I am return'd your soldier, No more infected with my country's love Than when I parted hence, but still subsisting Under your great command.Welcome!If you can behold it, I'll make the statue move indeed, descend And take you by the hand; but then you'll think-- Which I protest against--I am assisted By wicked powers.What, lamb!Ay, sir; whom, I thank heaven, is an honest woman,-- Dost thou detest her therefore?How, sir!What, nurse, I say!O, well-a-day, that ever I was born!My gracious lord,-- Fair cousin, you debase your princely knee To make the base earth proud with kissing it: Me rather had my heart might feel your love Than my unpleased eye see your courtesy.They have a leader, Tullus Aufidius, that will put you to 't.Now Lord be thanked for my good amends!We are not to stay all together, but to come by him where he stands, by ones, by twos, and by threes.wherefore storm you so?What sport shall we devise here in this garden, To drive away the heavy thought of care?If it be possible for you to displace it with your little finger, there is some hope the ladies of Rome, especially his mother, may prevail with him.Let them hang.And so in me; and so, I think, in all: Yet, since it is but green, it should be put To no apparent likelihood of breach, Which haply by much company might be urged: Therefore I say with noble Buckingham, That it is meet so few should fetch the prince.The mayor towards Guildhall hies him in all post: There, at your meet'st advantage of the time, Infer the bastardy of Edward's children: Tell them how Edward put to death a citizen, Only for saying he would make his son Heir to the crown; meaning indeed his house, Which, by the sign thereof was termed so.Go, rate thy minions, proud insulting boy!Art thou against us, Duke of Exeter?Some one with child by him?Take my prayers with you.Off with his head, and set it on York gates; So York may overlook the town of York.You common cry of curs!This is good news: I will go meet the ladies.My conscience hath a thousand several tongues, And every tongue brings in a several tale, And every tale condemns me for a villain.What you will have, I'll give, and willing too; For do we must what force will have us do.The fouler fortune mine, and there an end.Pluto and hell!Farewell; be trusty, and I'll quit thy pains: Farewell; commend me to thy mistress.'Tis very late, she'll not come down to-night: I promise you, but for your company, I would have been a-bed an hour ago.hold your tongue, Good prudence; smatter with your gossips, go.You have no children, butchers!Clarence and Gloucester, love my lovely queen; And kiss your princely nephew, brothers both.Beat thou the drum, that it speak mournfully: Trail your steel pikes.how lovely!Romeo, there dead, was husband to that Juliet; And she, there dead, that Romeo's faithful wife: I married them; and their stol'n marriage-day Was Tybalt's dooms-day, whose untimely death Banish'd the new-made bridegroom from the city, For whom, and not for Tybalt, Juliet pined.Our haste from hence is of so quick condition That it prefers itself and leaves unquestion'd Matters of needful value.Your grant, or your denial, shall be mine: Yet I confess that often ere this day, When I have heard your king's desert recounted, Mine ear hath tempted judgment to desire.and all eyes Blind with the pin and web but theirs, theirs only, That would unseen be wicked?What must I call her?A good demand.they have confessed you did.Come, lady, come.What should I do?I not deny, The jury, passing on the prisoner's life, May in the sworn twelve have a thief or two Guiltier than him they try.What's yet in this That bears the name of life?Tutus Aufidius, is he within your walls?My lord, you shall o'er-rule my mind for once.I do believe thee: I saw his heart in 's face.Why, so he doth, now he delivers thee From this world's thraldom to the joys of heaven.To-morrow next We will for Ireland; and 'tis time, I trow: And we create, in absence of ourself, Our uncle York lord governor of England; For he is just and always loved us well.Now, by the stock and honour of my kin, To strike him dead, I hold it not a sin.If he be slain, say 'I'; or if not, no: Brief sounds determine of my weal or woe.That last is true; the sweeter rest was mine.Had I been any god of power, I would Have sunk the sea within the earth or ere It should the good ship so have swallow'd and The fraughting souls within her.What, neither?wilt thou go along?I'll know His pleasure; may be he will relent.How?Now, afore God, 'tis shame such wrongs are borne In him, a royal prince, and many moe Of noble blood in this declining land.No more such wives; therefore, no wife: one worse, And better used, would make her sainted spirit Again possess her corpse, and on this stage, Where we're offenders now, appear soul-vex'd, And begin, 'Why to me?'Will't
