please you, sir, be gone?Go to: what quality are they of?You said so much before, and yet you fled.Let this be done.Pray you, sir, a word: and as I told you, my young lady bade me inquire you out; what she bade me say, I will keep to myself: but first let me tell ye, if ye should lead her into a fool's paradise, as they say, it were a very gross kind of behavior, as they say: for the gentlewoman is young; and, therefore, if you should deal double with her, truly it were an ill thing to be offered to any gentlewoman, and very weak dealing.grief more than common grief!why, who knows not so?Speak 'pardon' as 'tis current in our land; The chopping French we do not understand.Why, this was known before.For this new-married man approaching here, Whose salt imagination yet hath wrong'd Your well defended honour, you must pardon For Mariana's sake: but as he adjudged your brother,-- Being criminal, in double violation Of sacred chastity and of promise-breach Thereon dependent, for your brother's life,-- The very mercy of the law cries out Most audible, even from his proper tongue, 'An Angelo for Claudio, death for death!'The matter being afoot, keep your instruction, And hold you ever to our special drift; Though sometimes you do blench from this to that, As cause doth minister.Pray you, let's hear.what hap?A thousand knees Ten thousand years together, naked, fasting, Upon a barren mountain and still winter In storm perpetual, could not move the gods To look that way thou wert.the second cock hath crow'd, The curfew-bell hath rung, 'tis three o'clock: Look to the baked meats, good Angelica: Spare not for the cost.At Antium lives he?doth she not give us thanks?The duke's unjust, Thus to retort your manifest appeal, And put your trial in the villain's mouth Which here you come to accuse.I was not made a horse; And yet I bear a burthen like an ass, Spurr'd, gall'd and tired by jouncing Bolingbroke.Why dost thou stay?Past the mid season.I know it, uncle, and oppose not myself Against their will.How lush and lusty the grass looks!That fellow is a fellow of much licence: let him be called before us.Here, Signior Tranio.An't please you, sir, to undertake the business for us, here is that gold I have: I'll make it as much more and leave this young man in pawn till I bring it you.Now, in good time!I know it well, Lord Warwick; blame me not: 'Tis love I bear thy glories makes me speak.As near the dawning, provost, as it is, You shall hear more ere morning.Pardon it; The phrase is to the matter.O, father, you'll know more of that hereafter.A fair assembly: whither should they come?Pray, good shepherd, what fair swain is this Which dances with your daughter?Here's no place for you: pray, go to the door.My heart is ten times lighter than my looks.O piteous spectacle!As with a man busied about decrees: Condemning some to death, and some to exile; Ransoming him, or pitying, threatening the other; Holding Corioli in the name of Rome, Even like a fawning greyhound in the leash, To let him slip at will.I might call him A thing divine, for nothing natural I ever saw so noble.Be it forbid, my lord!You, tribunes To the people!Cut me to pieces, Volsces; men and lads, Stain all your edges on me.O, ho!Madam, his majesty doth call for you, And for your grace; and you, my noble lords.Set on towards London, cousin, is it so?Signior Hortensio, I have often heard Of your entire affection to Bianca; And since mine eyes are witness of her lightness, I will with you, if you be so contented, Forswear Bianca and her love for ever.pray, what's the news?Bring forth the gallant, let us hear him speak.Caius Marcius was A worthy officer i' the war; but insolent, O'ercome with pride, ambitious past all thinking, Self-loving,-- And affecting one sole throne, Without assistance.What means this scene of rude impatience?I am weary; yea, my memory is tired.You do him injury to scorn his corse.Where is he?'Tis the Lord Hastings, the king's chiefest friend.Either this is the envy in you, folly, or mistaking: the very stream of his life and the business he hath helmed must upon a warranted need give him a better proclamation.bloody cannibals!one dead, or drunk?On what occasion, God he knows, not I, The queen your mother, and your brother York, Have taken sanctuary: the tender prince Would fain have come with me to meet your grace, But by his mother was perforce withheld.thou hast hawks will soar Above the morning lark or wilt thou hunt?I have used thee, Filth as thou art, with human care, and lodged thee In mine own cell, till thou didst seek to violate The honour of my child.What you can make her do, I am content to look on: what to speak, I am content to hear; for 'tis as easy To make her speak as move.See, how she leans her cheek upon her hand!And I the rather wean me from despair For love of Edward's offspring in my womb: This is it that makes me bridle passion And bear with mildness my misfortune's cross; Ay, ay, for this I draw in many a tear And stop the rising of blood-sucking sighs, Lest with my sighs or tears I blast or drown King Edward's fruit, true heir to the English crown.Young Romeo is it?Mark what I say, which you shall find By every syllable a faithful verity: The duke comes home to-morrow; nay, dry your eyes; One of our convent, and his confessor, Gives me this instance: already he hath carried Notice to Escalus and Angelo, Who do prepare to meet him at the gates, There to give up their power.Must I do so?She will indite him to some supper.What offence hath this man made you, sir?Come, go with me; Under our tents I'll play the eaves-dropper, To see if any mean to shrink from me.O Clifford, how thy words revive my heart!Groan!Or, he that slew her brothers and her uncles?Why, this is a passing merry one and goes to the tune of 'Two maids wooing a man:' there's scarce a maid westward but she sings it; 'tis in request, I can tell you.There's not a soldier of us all, that, in the thanksgiving before meat, do relish the petition well that prays for peace.Of my kind uncle, that I know will give; And being but a toy, which is no grief to give.The heavens give safety to your purposes!Thou wretch, despite o'erwhelm thee!God in heaven bless her!what noise?Nay, pray, be patient: if you refuse your aid In this so never-needed help, yet do not Upbraid's with our distress.What holier than, for royalty's repair, For present comfort and for future good, To bless the bed of majesty again With a sweet fellow to't?Well have you argued, sir; and, for your pains, Of capital treason we arrest you here.That I'll straight do; and, knowing myself again, Repair to the senate-house.But reason with the fellow, Before you punish him, where he heard this, Lest you shall chance to whip your information And beat the messenger who bids beware Of what is to be dreaded.Petruchio is my name; Antonio's son, A man well known throughout all Italy.My husband and my lord, my lord and husband; I am your wife in all obedience.A bawd, a bawd, a bawd!I am directed by you.He should have lived, Save that riotous youth, with dangerous sense, Might in the times to come have ta'en revenge, By so receiving a dishonour'd life With ransom of such shame.But, most of all, agreeing with the proclamation.Why look you so upon me?I pray you all, tell me what they deserve That do conspire my death with devilish plots Of damned witchcraft, and that have prevail'd Upon my body with their hellish charms?I did; with his contract with Lady Lucy, And his contract by deputy in France; The insatiate greediness of his desires, And his enforcement of the city wives; His tyranny for trifles; his own bastardy, As being got, your father then in France, His resemblance, being not like the duke; Withal I did infer your lineaments, Being the right idea of your father, Both in your form and nobleness of mind; Laid open all your victories in Scotland, Your dicipline in war, wisdom in peace, Your bounty, virtue, fair humility: Indeed, left nothing fitting for the purpose Untouch'd, or slightly handled, in discourse And when mine oratory grew to an end I bid them that did love their country's good Cry 'God save Richard, England's royal king!'I'll go along, no such sight to be shown, But to rejoice in splendor of mine own.No other harm but loss of such a lord.I am made to understand that you have lent him visitation.what is the prince's doom?So prosper I, as I swear perfect love!now, I promise you You have show'd a tender fatherly regard, To wish me wed to one half lunatic; A mad-cup ruffian and a swearing Jack, That thinks with oaths to face the matter out.I know him not, but I have heard of him; A merchant of incomparable wealth.Where is the king?An officer!If Jupiter Should from yond cloud speak divine things, And say 'Tis true,' I'ld not believe them more Than thee, all noble Marcius.Where slept our scouts, or how are they seduced, That we could hear no news of his repair?As loath to lose him, not your father's death; It were lost sorrow to wail one that's lost.and yours, fair queen?O child!He that trusts to you, Where he should find you lions, finds you hares; Where foxes, geese: you are no surer, no, Than is the coal of fire upon the ice, Or hailstone in the sun.you are welcome.This cheers my heart, to see your forwardness.to London will we march amain, And once again bestride our foaming steeds, And once again cry 'Charge upon our foes!'That's likewise part of my intelligence; but, I fear, the angle that plucks our son thither.O worthy duke, You bid me seek redemption of the devil: Hear me yourself; for that which I must speak Must either punish me, not being believed, Or wring redress from you.I'll tell thee, ere thou ask it me again.Away with her, and waft her hence to France.Come, come, have with you.Faith, as you say, there's small choice in rotten apples.Hence-banished is banish'd from the world, And world's exile is death: then banished, Is death mis-term'd: calling death banishment, Thou cutt'st my head off with a golden axe, And smilest upon the stroke that murders me.You'll make a mutiny among my guests!Being in night, all this is but a dream, Too flattering-sweet to be substantial.He that will give good words to thee will flatter Beneath abhorring.Why, how now, kinsman!Cousin, I am too young to be your father, Though you are old enough to be my heir.So do I too, if it be not too much: brings a' victory in his pocket?I have deliver'd to Lord Angelo, A man of stricture and firm abstinence, My absolute power and place here in Vienna, And he supposes me travell'd to Poland; For so I have strew'd it in the common ear, And so it is received.Thou art the first knave that e'er madest a duke.What, cheerly, my hearts!I go: and towards three or four o'clock Look for the news that the Guildhall affords.Proof?The sky, it seems, would pour down stinking pitch, But that the sea, mounting to the welkin's cheek, Dashes the fire out.Why wither not the leaves the sap being gone?durst the traitor breathe out so proud words?Why rail'st thou on thy birth, the heaven, and earth?I talk of you: Why did you wish me milder?How fondly dost thou spur a forward horse!Most mighty prince, my Lord Northumberland, What says King Bolingbroke?I thank thee, good Sir John, with all my heart.And come to Padua, careless of your life?The citizens are up, and Tybalt slain.The trumpets, sackbuts, psalteries and fifes, Tabours and cymbals and the shouting Romans, Make the sun dance.Ay, my good lord; a very virtuous maid, And to be shortly of a sisterhood, If not already.He will shake Your Rome about your ears.In that dead time when Gloucester's death was plotted, I heard you say, 'Is not my arm of length, That reacheth from the restful English court As far as Calais, to mine uncle's head?'By the elements, If e'er again I meet him beard to beard, He's mine, or I am his: mine emulation Hath not that honour in't it had; for where I thought to crush him in an equal force, True sword to sword, I'll potch at him some way Or wrath or craft may get him.Go take this shape And hither come in't: go, hence with diligence!The sight of any of the house of York Is as a fury to torment my soul; And till I root out their accursed line And leave not one alive, I live in hell.Lord cardinal, will your grace Persuade the queen to send the Duke of York Unto his princely brother presently?Good sir, adieu.O, pardon me, my lord; it oft falls out, To have what we would have, we speak not what we mean: I something do excuse the thing I hate, For his advantage that I dearly love.What's your name, Master tapster?On, good Camillo.Upon the stroke of ten.Ay, this is he that took King Henry's chair, And this is he was his adopted heir.Say not we brought it.He was not taken well; he had not dined: The veins unfill'd, our blood is cold, and then We pout upon the morning, are unapt To give or to forgive; but when we have stuff'd These and these conveyances of our blood With wine and feeding, we have suppler souls Than in our priest-like fasts: therefore I'll watch him Till he be dieted to my request, And then I'll set upon him.All comfort that the dark night can afford Be to thy person, noble father-in-law!Temperance was a delicate wench.How now, good fellow!Ay, boy.You have fought together.Seeming, seeming!He being thus lorded, Not only with what my revenue yielded, But what my power might else exact, like one Who having into truth, by telling of it, Made such a sinner of his memory, To credit his own lie, he did believe He was indeed the duke; out o' the substitution And executing the outward face of royalty, With all prerogative: hence his ambition growing-- Dost thou hear?ha, ha!My comfort is that heaven will take our souls And plague injustice with the pains of hell.How now?'Madam,' and nothing else: so lords call ladies.Now, by Saint Paul I swear, I will not dine until I see the same.Only, good master, while we do admire This virtue and this moral discipline, Let's be no stoics nor no stocks, I pray; Or so devote to Aristotle's cheques As Ovid be an outcast quite abjured: Balk logic with acquaintance that you have And practise rhetoric in your common talk; Music and poesy use to quicken you; The mathematics and the metaphysics, Fall to them as you find your stomach serves you; No profit grows where is no pleasure ta'en: In brief, sir, study what you most affect.away!Here's one, a friend, and one that knows you well.I am, and by my fancy: if my reason Will thereto be obedient, I have reason; If not, my senses, better pleased with madness, Do bid it welcome.A pretty peat!To the rock, to the rock with him!I fear, I fear,-- What should you fear?Hoo!Come hither, Mariana.Poison, I see, hath been his timeless end: O churl!Dull thing, I say so; he, that Caliban Whom now I keep in service.There's thy reward: be gone.The gods forbid!I saw no man use you a pleasure; if I had, my weapon should quickly have been out, I warrant you: I dare draw as soon as another man, if I see occasion in a good quarrel, and the law on my side.Go to Lord Angelo, And let him learn to know, when maidens sue, Men give like gods; but when they weep and kneel, All their petitions are as freely theirs As they themselves would owe them.Thou know'st the mask of night is on my face, Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek For that which thou hast heard me speak to-night Fain would I dwell on form, fain, fain deny What I have spoke: but farewell compliment!Obey the bride, you that attend on her; Go to the feast, revel and domineer, Carouse full measure to her maidenhead, Be mad and merry, or go hang yourselves: But for my bonny Kate, she must with me.Rescue, my Lord of Norfolk, rescue, rescue!Pray you, a word.caught of me!So stood the state when Henry the Sixth Was crown'd in Paris but at nine months old.Go home, And show no sign of fear.First, provost, let me bail these gentle three.Thou worthiest Marcius!I saw her laid low in her kindred's vault, And presently took post to tell it you: O, pardon me for bringing these ill news, Since you did leave it for my office, sir.Thus wisdom wishes to appear most bright When it doth tax itself; as these black masks Proclaim an enshield beauty ten times louder Than beauty could, display'd.At my depart, these were his very words: 'Go tell false Edward, thy supposed king, That Lewis of France is sending over masquers To revel it with him and his new bride.'Pisa renown'd for grave citizens Gave me my being and my father first, A merchant of great traffic through the world, Vincetino come of Bentivolii.Return again, and take an oath with thee.Thou seest, thou wicked varlet, now, what's come upon thee: thou art to continue now, thou varlet; thou art to continue.But if you have a stomach, to't i' God's name: You shall have me assisting you in all.A thousand hearts are great within my bosom: Advance our standards, set upon our foes Our ancient word of courage, fair Saint George, Inspire us with the spleen of fiery dragons!Go ply thy needle; meddle not with her.So, your opinion is, Aufidius, That they of Rome are entered in our counsels And know how we proceed.Keep your hundred pounds to yourself: he shall need none, so long as I live.Where is Nathaniel, Gregory, Philip?Pardon, madam: The one I have almost forgot,--your pardon,-- The other, when she has obtain'd your eye, Will have your tongue too.My father hath a power; inquire of him And learn to make a body of a limb.Comfort, good comfort!Mended again.She was, good Curtis, before this frost: but, thou knowest, winter tames man, woman and beast; for it hath tamed my old master and my new mistress and myself, fellow Curtis.All souls that will be safe fly from my side, For time hath set a blot upon my pride.For what, lieutenant?What, what?A savage clamour!Some comfort, nurse.God keep your lordship in that gracious mind!Sweet Bianca!Courage, my masters!Join not with grief, fair woman, do not so, To make my end too sudden: learn, good soul, To think our former state a happy dream; From which awaked, the truth of what we are Shows us but this: I am sworn brother, sweet, To grim Necessity, and he and I Will keep a league till death.Will't please you walk aside?Nay, never bear me hence, dispatch me here, Here sheathe thy sword, I'll pardon thee my death: What, wilt thou not?For I am all the subjects that you have, Which first was mine own king: and here you sty me In this hard rock, whiles you do keep from me The rest o' the island.If, rather than to marry County Paris, Thou hast the strength of will to slay thyself, Then is it likely thou wilt undertake A thing like death to chide away this shame, That copest with death himself to scape from it: And, if thou darest, I'll give thee remedy.O ho, Petruchio!The more we stay, the stronger grows our foe.Vouchsafe, defused infection of a man, For these known evils, but to give me leave, By circumstance, to curse thy cursed self.moody?Thank, gentle uncle.Sons, peace!I am thine.Farewell!At the queen's be't: 'good' should be pertinent But, so it is, it is not.It cannot fail but by The violation of my faith; and then Let nature crush the sides o' the earth together And mar the seeds within!Are you call'd forth from out a world of men To slay the innocent?My gracious uncle, let me know my fault: On what condition stands it and wherein?Prithee, peace.In his tail.Master lieutenant, pray you, by your leave, How doth the prince, and my young son of York?You seem'd of late to make the law a tyrant; And rather proved the sliding of your brother A merriment than a vice.O, think on that; And mercy then will breathe within your lips, Like man new made.Groping for trouts in a peculiar river.can he speak?Hist!What wrong is this unto the prince your son!Do I speak feelingly now?Torments him so, that he will sure run mad.O Phoebus, hadst thou never given consent That Phaethon should cheque thy fiery steeds, Thy burning car never had scorch'd the earth!One that, above all other strifes, contended especially to know himself.Think'st thou it honourable for a noble man Still to remember wrongs?Go, hop me over every kennel home, For you shall hop without my custom, sir: I'll none of it: hence!I'll have thy beauty scratch'd with briers, and made More homely than thy state.The gods have well prevented it, and Rome Sits safe and still without him.Let him be apprehended.Then Clarence is at hand, I hear his drum.Sweetly in force unto her fair life's end.Why stay we to be baited With one that wants her wits?Well, what then?He was convey'd by Richard Duke of Gloucester And the Lord Hastings, who attended him In secret ambush on the forest side And from the bishop's huntsmen rescued him; For hunting was his daily exercise.All that you speak shows fair.Harp on it still shall I till heart-strings break.Villain, I say, knock me here soundly.Not any yet: But as the unthought-on accident is guilty To what we wildly do, so we profess Ourselves to be the slaves of chance and flies Of every wind that blows.Good my lord, be good to me; your honour is accounted a merciful man; good my lord.It grieves me for the death of Claudio; But there's no remedy.James Tyrrel, and your most obedient subject.How shall we do for money for these wars?What, with five thousand men?How!And then?And, madam, I must be present at your conference.I cry thee mercy: There is my purse to cure that blow of thine.Is love a tender thing?look upon my brother: both your pardons, That e'er I put between your holy looks My ill suspicion.I thought my mother, and my brother York, Would long ere this have met us on the way Fie, what a slug is Hastings, that he comes not To tell us whether they will come or no!Have I not heard the sea puff'd up with winds Rage like an angry boar chafed with sweat?Relent, and save your souls.I should sin To think but nobly of my grandmother: Good wombs have borne bad sons.Consider this: he has been bred i' the wars Since he could draw a sword, and is ill school'd In bolted language; meal and bran together He throws without distinction.Mine ear is open and my heart prepared; The worst is worldly loss thou canst unfold.Come on, come on; where is your boar-spear, man?Worthy voices!I thought it would have mounted.Ay, that Petruchio came.Nay, be thou sure I'll well requite thy kindness, For that it made my imprisonment a pleasure; Ay, such a pleasure as incaged birds Conceive when after many moody thoughts At last by notes of household harmony They quite forget their loss of liberty.For her, my lord, I dare my life lay down and will do't, sir, Please you to accept it, that the queen is spotless I' the eyes of heaven and to you; I mean, In this which you accuse her.The state, whereon I studied Is like a good thing, being often read, Grown fear'd and tedious; yea, my gravity, Wherein--let no man hear me--I take pride, Could I with boot change for an idle plume, Which the air beats for vain.Will you hence, Before the tag return?Why, uncle, what's the matter?I shall, sir.Tell her, Emilia.Then give me leave to read philosophy, And while I pause, serve in your harmony.Such proclamation hath been made, my liege.wert thou as we are.O, thou think'st To serve me last, that I may longest keep Thy sorrow in my breast.Let him die for't.At what o'clock to-morrow Shall I send to thee?O, put me in thy books!Farewell, good cousin; farewell, gentle friends.Your highness said even now, I made you a duke: good my lord, do not recompense me in making me a cuckold.Where is the county's page, that raised the watch?Yea, but not change his spots: take but my shame.You'll see your Rome embraced with fire before You'll speak with Coriolanus.Inquire me out some mean-born gentleman, Whom I will marry straight to Clarence' daughter: The boy is foolish, and I fear not him.Then, God be bless'd, it is the blessed sun: But sun it is not, when you say it is not; And the moon changes even as your mind.That shows thee a weak slave; for the weakest goes to the wall.Do me the common right To let me see them and to make me know The nature of their crimes, that I may minister To them accordingly.how oft to-night Have my old feet stumbled at graves!Peter, didst ever see the like?what's the news?Not a word: if you have any thing to say to me, come to my ward; for thence will not I to-day.I know not: but I am sure 'tis safer to Avoid what's grown than question how 'tis born.Bear from hence his body; And mourn you for him: let him be regarded As the most noble corse that ever herald Did follow to his urn.I sin in envying his nobility, And were I any thing but what I am, I would wish me only he.I'll give my reasons, More worthier than their voices.He loves your people But tie him not to be their bedfellow.I' faith, he'll have a lusty widow now, That shall be wood and wedded in a day.Towards Chertsey, noble lord?if thou account'st it shame.When he stands where I am and sees you there.Why, this was moulded on a porringer; A velvet dish: fie, fie!Thou flea, thou nit, thou winter-cricket thou!My voice is now the king's, my looks mine own.Sure the gods do this year connive at us, and we may do any thing extempore.My lord, I have from Oxford sent to London The heads of Brocas and Sir Bennet Seely, Two of the dangerous consorted traitors That sought at Oxford thy dire overthrow.Summon the town.Edward Plantagenet, arise a knight; And learn this lesson, draw thy sword in right.Gentle Mercutio, put thy rapier up.How camest thou hither, tell me, and wherefore?'Tis better said than done, my gracious lord: I am a subject fit to jest withal, But far unfit to be a sovereign.Do as thou list Thy valiantness was mine, thou suck'dst it from me, But owe thy pride thyself.Now, my liege, Tell me what blessings I have here alive, That I should fear to die?My lord, this is one Lucio's information against me.Well, bring our lady hither to our sight; And once again, a pot o' the smallest ale.What, art thou hurt?You are pleasant, sir, and speak apace.If I should be!What must I do?O, the sacrifice!Yes; I do think that you might pardon him, And neither heaven nor man grieve at the mercy.Say, where, when, and how, Camest thou by this ill tidings?To the pot, I warrant him.hadst thou not order?I beseech you, peace: Or, if you'ld ask, remember this before: The thing I have forsworn to grant may never Be held by you denials.Fix thy foot.Where's Potpan, that he helps not to take away?Were I but now the lord of such hot youth As when brave Gaunt, thy father, and myself Rescued the Black Prince, that young Mars of men, From forth the ranks of many thousand French, O, then how quickly should this arm of mine.Ay, sir; a mystery Painting, sir, I have heard say, is a mystery; and your whores, sir, being members of my occupation, using painting, do prove my occupation a mystery: but what mystery there should be in hanging, if I should be hanged, I cannot imagine.No, sir,'twas never my desire yet to trouble the poor with begging.Where is this viper That would depopulate the city and Be every man himself?By the apostle Paul, shadows to-night Have struck more terror to the soul of Richard Than can the substance of ten thousand soldiers Armed in proof, and led by shallow Richmond.Had he been slaughter-man to all my kin, I should not for my life but weep with him.What is the matter That being pass'd for consul with full voice, I am so dishonour'd that the very hour You take it off again?Here's such a coil!Mildly!A parlous boy: go to, you are too shrewd.Lo, in these windows that let forth thy life, I pour the helpless balm of my poor eyes.Nor forward of revenge, though they much err'd: Then why should they love Edward more than me?Audience: peace, I say!Me they shall feel while I am able to stand: and 'tis known I am a pretty piece of flesh.'tis not so.They lie in view; but have not spoke as yet.Merry or sad shall't be?You have made fair work, I fear me.--Pray, your news?-- If Marcius should be join'd with Volscians,-- If!What, had he so?Call it not patience, Gaunt; it is despair: In suffering thus thy brother to be slaughter'd, Thou showest the naked pathway to thy life, Teaching stern murder how to butcher thee: That which in mean men we intitle patience Is pale cold cowardice in noble breasts.Do as I bid thee, go.Still live they and for ever may they last!King Henry, be thy title right or wrong, Lord Clifford vows to fight in thy defence: May that ground gape and swallow me alive, Where I shall kneel to him that slew my father!Poor soul, She speaks this in the infirmity of sense.It is my son, young Harry Percy, Sent from my brother Worcester, whencesoever.Let's hence, and hear How the dispatch is made, and in what fashion, More than his singularity, he goes Upon this present action.To thee I pray; sweet Clifford, pity me!We'll attend you there: Where, if you bring not Marcius, we'll proceed In our first way.hang 'em!How fares our noble uncle, Lancaster?Then, since the case so stands as now it doth, I think it best you married with the county.Killing our enemies, the blood he hath lost-- Which, I dare vouch, is more than that he hath, By many an ounce--he dropp'd it for his country; And what is left, to lose it by his country, Were to us all, that do't and suffer it, A brand to the end o' the world.I was hardly moved to come to thee; but being assured none but myself could move thee, I have been blown out of your gates with sighs; and conjure thee to pardon Rome, and thy petitionary countrymen.Can you deny all this?To prove him tyrant this reason may suffice, That Henry liveth still: but were he dead, Yet here Prince Edward stands, King Henry's son.I' the city of kites and crows.A bridegroom say you?Nay, but you will?I'll in to counsel them; haply my presence May well abate the over-merry spleen Which otherwise would grow into extremes.He's simple and tells much.Stanley, I will requite thy forwardness.You must be so good, sir, to rise and be put to death.Thus both are gone with conscience and remorse; They could not speak; and so I left them both, To bring this tidings to the bloody king.My brother's love, the devil, and my rage.Thou pitied'st Rutland; I will pity thee.As I did sleep under this yew-tree here, I dreamt my master and another fought, And that my master slew him.This is strange.Bid her devise Some means to come to shrift this afternoon; And there she shall at Friar Laurence' cell Be shrived and married.Why should he die, sir?Your honours all, I do refer me to the oracle: Apollo be my judge!Or shall they last, and we rejoice in them?This gentleman told somewhat of my tale,-- Right.Sir, you yourself Have said and writ so, but your writing now Is colder than that theme, 'She had not been, Nor was not to be equall'd;'--thus your verse Flow'd with her beauty once: 'tis shrewdly ebb'd, To say you have seen a better.Ay, brother, to our grief, as it is yours: Too late he died that might have kept that title, Which by his death hath lost much majesty.men their creation mar In profiting by them.The trick of it?Let's be calm.Pardon me, sir, the boldness is mine own, That, being a stranger in this city here, Do make myself a suitor to your daughter, Unto Bianca, fair and virtuous.The sorrow that delivers us thus changed Makes you think so.O brave young prince!She speaks yet she says nothing: what of that?Who told me, in the field by Tewksbury When Oxford had me down, he rescued me, And said, 'Dear brother, live, and be a king'?Search, seek, and know how this foul murder comes.He's the devil.If that be right which Warwick says is right, There is no wrong, but every thing is right.Good lords, conduct him to his regiment: I'll strive, with troubled thoughts, to take a nap, Lest leaden slumber peise me down to-morrow, When I should mount with wings of victory: Once more, good night, kind lords and gentlemen.Farewell, thou woful welcomer of glory!Shall I speak ill of him that is my husband?Why, then you should discover a brace of unmeriting, proud, violent, testy magistrates, alias fools, as any in Rome.Poor queen!Treason!Come, leave your tears: a brief farewell: the beast With many heads butts me away.How now!My lord, will't please you pass along?A lack, when once our grace we have forgot, Nothing goes right: we would, and we would not.The gods grant them true!He was too hard for him directly, to say the troth on't: before Corioli he scotched him and notched him like a carbon ado.Vail your regard Upon a wrong'd, I would fain have said, a maid!Lets along.No, Exeter, these graces challenge grace: And when the lion fawns upon the lamb, The lamb will never cease to follow him.All hail, my sovereign liege!For them!Well, if you be a king crown'd with content, Your crown content and you must be contented To go along with us; for as we think, You are the king King Edward hath deposed; And we his subjects sworn in all allegiance Will apprehend you as his enemy.Al'ce madam, or Joan madam?My gracious lord, Henry your foe is taken, And brought your prisoner to your palace gate.But he, my lord, is gone to Ravenspurgh, To offer service to the Duke of Hereford, And sent me over by Berkeley, to discover What power the Duke of York had levied there; Then with directions to repair to Ravenspurgh.Rude ragged nurse, old sullen playfellow For tender princes, use my babies well!How long hath he been there?a puny subject strikes At thy great glory.Come, quench your blushes and present yourself That which you are, mistress o' the feast: come on, And bid us welcome to your sheep-shearing, As your good flock shall prosper.O, may such purple tears be alway shed From those that wish the downfall of our house!Agreed.Ah, timorous wretch!The king is not at the palace; he is gone aboard a new ship to purge melancholy and air himself: for, if thou beest capable of things serious, thou must know the king is full of grief.Therefore you speak unskilfully: or if your knowledge be more it is much darkened in your malice.What early tongue so sweet saluteth me?there's a fearful point!Adieu, trusty Pompey.Now, my spruce companions, is all ready, and all things neat?O my poor father!I am no pilot; yet, wert thou as far As that vast shore wash'd with the farthest sea, I would adventure for such merchandise.Where dwellest thou?Knows he of this?Give me excuse, good madam; I will obey you in every thing hereafter.No news so bad abroad as this at home; The King is sickly, weak and melancholy, And his physicians fear him mightily.Convey me to my bed, then to my grave: Love they to live that love and honour have.Strives Bolingbroke to be as great as we?we'll fit him to our turn,-- And he shall be Vincentio of Pisa; And make assurance here in Padua Of greater sums than I have promised.What, household stuff?My prettiest Perdita!To London, all in post; and, as I guess, To make a bloody supper in the Tower.All seeing heaven, what a world is this!If so, then be not tongue-tied: go with me.Turn this way, Henry, and regard them not.Speak thou, boy: Perhaps thy childishness will move him more Than can our reasons.Go, girl; I cannot blame thee now to weep; For such an injury would vex a very saint, Much more a shrew of thy impatient humour.I am in health, I breathe, and see thee ill.But I fear They'll roar him in again.There rest.I thought thou hadst been resolute.Will not King Richard let me speak with him?And, friends unknown, you shall bear witness to 't: I give my daughter to him, and will make Her portion equal his.Lady, by yonder blessed moon I swear That tips with silver all these fruit-tree tops-- O, swear not by the moon, the inconstant moon, That monthly changes in her circled orb, Lest that thy love prove likewise variable.Withdraw thee, wretched Margaret: who comes here?Anon!Than my Lord Hastings no man might be bolder; His lordship knows me well, and loves me well.Ay, no; no, ay; for I must nothing be; Therefore no no, for I resign to thee.Sirrah, get thee to Plashy, to my sister Gloucester; Bid her send me presently a thousand pound: Hold, take my ring.No, no, good friends, God wot; For then this land was famously enrich'd With politic grave counsel; then the king Had virtuous uncles to protect his grace.Him I accuse The city ports by this hath enter'd and Intends to appear before the people, hoping To purge herself with words: dispatch.I would the gods had nothing else to do But to confirm my curses!To tell you plain, I had rather lie in prison.I hear the minstrels play.If without peril it be possible, Good Captain Blunt, bear my good-night to him, And give him from me this most needful scroll.what news?Faith, we may put up our pipes, and be gone.A holy day shall this be kept hereafter: I would to God all strifes were well compounded.Where then, alas, may I complain myself?Away, away!Desolate, desolate, will I hence and die: The last leave of thee takes my weeping eye.This is strange: methinks My favour here begins to warp.In very good time: speak not you to him till we call upon you.Will you we show our title to the crown?Go thy ways, wench; serve God.No doubt but he hath got a quiet catch.Bad is the world; and all will come to nought, When such bad dealings must be seen in thought.Alas, this gentleman Whom I would save, had a most noble father!But, I beseech you, What says the other troop?Thou fond mad woman, Wilt thou conceal this dark conspiracy?My prayers on the adverse party fight; And there the little souls of Edward's children Whisper the spirits of thine enemies And promise them success and victory.Come, mistress Kate, I'll bear you company.Give me a calendar.A dozen of them here have ta'en the sacrament, And interchangeably set down their hands, To kill the king at Oxford.What canst thou swear by now?But wherefore stay we?Dear, they durst not, So dear the love my people bore me, nor set A mark so bloody on the business, but With colours fairer painted their foul ends.What wheels?Have I not heard great ordnance in the field, And heaven's artillery thunder in the skies?Mock not my senseless conjuration, lords: This earth shall have a feeling and these stones Prove armed soldiers, ere her native king Shall falter under foul rebellion's arms.You lie, in faith; for you are call'd plain Kate, And bonny Kate and sometimes Kate the curst; But Kate, the prettiest Kate in Christendom Kate of Kate Hall, my super-dainty Kate, For dainties are all Kates, and therefore, Kate, Take this of me, Kate of my consolation; Hearing thy mildness praised in every town, Thy virtues spoke of, and thy beauty sounded, Yet not so deeply as to thee belongs, Myself am moved to woo thee for my wife.To wail the tide, as her mother doth.And blessing Against this cruelty fight on thy side, Poor thing, condemn'd to loss!Patience is for poltroons, such as he: He durst not sit there, had your father lived.and wherefore comest thou hither, Before King Richard in his royal lists?There, take the crown, and, with the crown, my curse; And in thy need such comfort come to thee As now I reap at thy too cruel hand!Will you along?multitudes, and fear?This is a poor epitome of yours, Which by the interpretation of full time May show like all yourself.O, that she knew she were!My lord, I must confess I know this woman: And five years since there was some speech of marriage Betwixt myself and her; which was broke off, Partly for that her promised proportions Came short of composition, but in chief For that her reputation was disvalued In levity: since which time of five years I never spake with her, saw her, nor heard from her, Upon my faith and honour.Wherefore did they not That hour destroy us?to your corrected son?How now, my as fair as noble ladies,--and the moon, were she earthly, no nobler,--whither do you follow your eyes so fast?So shall my virtue be his vice's bawd; And he shall spend mine honour with his shame, As thriftless sons their scraping fathers' gold.Why, tell me, is not this my Cambio?How?You'll not endure him!To whom God will, there be the victory!But thine doth fry.Indeed, no, by your patience; I'll not over the threshold till my lord return from the wars.Why, then is my pump well flowered.A callat Of boundless tongue, who late hath beat her husband And now baits me!Dismiss them home.Ay, say you so?Full fathom five thy father lies; Of his bones are coral made; Those are pearls that were his eyes: Nothing of him that doth fade But doth suffer a sea-change Into something rich and strange.Come, come, he must not.Though news be sad, yet tell them merrily; If good, thou shamest the music of sweet news By playing it to me with so sour a face.Why, very well; I telling you then, if you be remembered, that such a one and such a one were past cure of the thing you wot of, unless they kept very good diet, as I told you,-- All this is true.Stay a little while.Yea, leave that labour to great Hercules; And let it be more than Alcides' twelve.No.A bawd, sir?What, go you toward the Tower?Come down?is this nothing?Master, master!You may not so extenuate his offence For I have had such faults; but rather tell me, When I, that censure him, do so offend, Let mine own judgment pattern out my death, And nothing come in partial.Ay, and a subtle; as he most learnedly delivered.Come, cords, come, nurse; I'll to my wedding-bed; And death, not Romeo, take my maidenhead!That power I have, discharge; and let them go To ear the land that hath some hope to grow, For I have none: let no man speak again To alter this, for counsel is but vain.So, fare you well; To the hopeful execution do I leave you Of your commissions.Sir, I was an inward of his.Here is Cominius.Your tale, sir, would cure deafness.Now I arise: Sit still, and hear the last of our sea-sorrow.Why do you say 'thwack our general '?how green!You cram these words into mine ears against The stomach of my sense.That you might know it, would much better please me Than to demand what 'tis.Doth your honour see any harm in his face?And, lords, towards Coventry bend we our course Where peremptory Warwick now remains: The sun shines hot; and, if we use delay, Cold biting winter mars our hoped-for hay.O, my fair cousin, I must not say so.Cushions, leaden spoons, Irons of a doit, doublets that hangmen would Bury with those that wore them, these base slaves, Ere yet the fight be done, pack up: down with them!Mopsa must be your mistress: marry, garlic, To mend her kissing with!Stand, and go back.Stanley, look to your wife; if she convey Letters to Richmond, you shall answer it.That you might still have worn the petticoat, And ne'er have stol'n the breech from Lancaster.Prithee, no more: thou dost talk nothing to me.If your worship will take order for the drabs and the knaves, you need not to fear the bawds.He fights as you sing prick-song, keeps time, distance, and proportion; rests me his minim rest, one, two, and the third in your bosom: the very butcher of a silk button, a duellist, a duellist; a gentleman of the very first house, of the first and second cause: ah, the immortal passado!Most lamentable day, most woful day, That ever, ever, I did yet behold!Good king of cats, nothing but one of your nine lives; that I mean to make bold withal, and as you shall use me hereafter, drybeat the rest of the eight.We are advertised by our loving friends That they do hold their course toward Tewksbury: We, having now the best at Barnet field, Will thither straight, for willingness rids way; And, as we march, our strength will be augmented In every county as we go along.I long till Edward fall by war's mischance, For mocking marriage with a dame of France.Why that's my spirit!I conjure thee by Rosaline's bright eyes, By her high forehead and her scarlet lip, By her fine foot, straight leg and quivering thigh And the demesnes that there adjacent lie, That in thy likeness thou appear to us!What seest thou else In the dark backward and abysm of time?I would he knew that I had saved his brother!Be not so long to speak; I long to die, If what thou speak'st speak not of remedy.Where be these knaves?Good queen, my lord, Good queen; I say good queen; And would by combat make her good, so were I A man, the worst about you.How would he look, to see his work so noble Vilely bound up?Look, what I will not, that I cannot do.Forslow no longer, make we hence amain.Your heart is full of something that does take Your mind from feasting.Now, by my holidame, here comes Katharina!Brother, we done deeds of charity; Made peace enmity, fair love of hate, Between these swelling wrong-incensed peers.Is it even so?Why, foolish boy, the king is left behind, And in my loyal bosom lies his power.not life, but love in death!God save you, gentlemen!I say, sir, I will detest myself also, as well as she, that this house, if it be not a bawd's house, it is pity of her life, for it is a naughty house.I pray thee, let me hear it.We need not put new matter to his charge: What you have seen him do and heard him speak, Beating your officers, cursing yourselves, Opposing laws with strokes and here defying Those whose great power must try him; even this, So criminal and in such capital kind, Deserves the extremest death.Untimely storms make men expect a dearth.One of these is true: I think affliction may subdue the cheek, But not take in the mind.And now to London with triumphant march, There to be crowned England's royal king: From whence shall Warwick cut the sea to France, And ask the Lady Bona for thy queen: So shalt thou sinew both these lands together; And, having France thy friend, thou shalt not dread The scatter'd foe that hopes to rise again; For though they cannot greatly sting to hurt, Yet look to have them buzz to offend thine ears.is he dead already?Good heart, at what?My lords of England, let me tell you this: I have had feeling of my cousin's wrongs And laboured all I could to do him right; But in this kind to come, in braving arms, Be his own carver and cut out his way, To find out right with wrong, it may not be; And you that do abet him in this kind Cherish rebellion and are rebels all.Ay, my good lord.He receives comfort like cold porridge.What will you give us?The poorest service is repaid with thanks; And so shall mine, before you touch the meat.As surely as I live, my lord.Which never dreamt on aught but butcheries: Didst thou not kill this king?Tell Valeria, We are fit to bid her welcome.Yet welcome, warriors: We call a nettle but a nettle and The faults of fools but folly.That would be ten days' wonder at the least.Who told me how the poor soul did forsake The mighty Warwick, and did fight for me?you were got in fear, Though you were born in Rome:' his bloody brow With his mail'd hand then wiping, forth he goes, Like to a harvest-man that's task'd to mow Or all or lose his hire.Alack, and what shall good old York there see But empty lodgings and unfurnish'd walls, Unpeopled offices, untrodden stones?Why, there's a wench!I will confess to you that I love him.The gates are open, let us enter too.But since he hath Served well for Rome,-- What do you prate of service?And his offence is so, as it appears, Accountant to the law upon that pain.Marry, peace it bodes, and love and quiet life, And awful rule and right supremacy; And, to be short, what not, that's sweet and happy?But come, let us in, To comfort Edward with our company.The dignity of this act was worth the audience of kings and princes; for by such was it acted.Madam!Yes, mercy, if you report him truly.Take in the topsail.Let 't alone.Help, help!He shall well know The noble tribunes are the people's mouths, And we their hands.Come, we'll in here; tarry for the mourners, and stay dinner.This peace is nothing, but to rust iron, increase tailors, and breed ballad-makers.O Tybalt, Tybalt, the best friend I had!You know the cause, air, of my standing here.He's not prepared for death.But it is certain that when he makes water his urine is congealed ice; that I know to be true: and he is a motion generative; that's infallible.How canst thou woo her?We hope to find you our friend; and therefore give you our voices heartily.I know my remedy; I must go fetch the third--borough.What, Grumio!thou art preparing fire for us; look thee, here's water to quench it.What's the matter?I am come to know your pleasure.Men's eyes were made to look, and let them gaze; I will not budge for no man's pleasure, I. Well, peace be with you, sir: here comes my man.O God, I fear thy justice will take hold On me, and you, and mine, and yours for this!But soft, but see, or rather do not see, My fair rose wither: yet look up, behold, That you in pity may dissolve to dew, And wash him fresh again with true-love tears.Father, you cannot disinherit me: If you be king, why should not I succeed?My title's good, and better far than his.Come, come, we'll prompt you.If thou wouldst, There shouldst thou find one heinous article, Containing the deposing of a king And cracking the strong warrant of an oath, Mark'd with a blot, damn'd in the book of heaven: Nay, all of you that stand and look upon, Whilst that my wretchedness doth bait myself, Though some of you with Pilate wash your hands Showing an outward pity; yet you Pilates Have here deliver'd me to my sour cross, And water cannot wash away your sin.Royally!The noble duke hath sworn his coming is But for his own; and for the right of that We all have strongly sworn to give him aid; And let him ne'er see joy that breaks that oath!This island's mine, by Sycorax my mother, Which thou takest from me.Then we are rid of Licio.the devil'--there the villain stopp'd Whilst Dighton thus told on: 'We smothered The most replenished sweet work of nature, That from the prime creation e'er she framed.'Take heed, Signior Baptista, lest you be cony-catched in this business: I dare swear this is the right Vincentio.do you like this haste?Nor you, as we are, loyal.Fool, of thyself speak well: fool, do not flatter.This swears he, as he is a prince, is just; And, as I am a gentleman, I credit him.But, sirs, be sudden in the execution, Withal obdurate, do not hear him plead; For Clarence is well-spoken, and perhaps May move your hearts to pity if you mark him.O, do not swear, my lord of Buckingham.I fear no uncles dead.I'll in, to urge his hatred more to Clarence, With lies well steel'd with weighty arguments; And, if I fall not in my deep intent, Clarence hath not another day to live: Which done, God take King Edward to his mercy, And leave the world for me to bustle in!I have bethought me of another fault.Prithee, Kate, let's stand aside and see the end of this controversy.If thou mayest discern by that which is left of him what he is, fetch me to the sight of him.What!Out upon you!Now in good time, here comes the duke himself.What say you, Simon Catling?This shall be done, good father, presently.Now, to seem to affect the malice and displeasure of the people is as bad as that which he dislikes, to flatter them for their love.Now sir, the sound that tells what hour it is Are clamorous groans, which strike upon my heart, Which is the bell: so sighs and tears and groans Show minutes, times, and hours: but my time Runs posting on in Bolingbroke's proud joy, While I stand fooling here, his Jack o' the clock.Our praises are our wages: you may ride's With one soft kiss a thousand furlongs ere With spur we beat an acre.Ah, dear Juliet, Why art thou yet so fair?So proudly as if he disdain'd the ground.O, me alone!wilt thou slay thyself?I partly know the man: go, call him hither.A flourish, trumpets!His heart's his mouth: What his breast forges, that his tongue must vent; And, being angry, does forget that ever He heard the name of death.Tell him from me, as he will win my love, He bear himself with honourable action, Such as he hath observed in noble ladies Unto their lords, by them accomplished: Such duty to the drunkard let him do With soft low tongue and lowly courtesy, And say 'What is't your honour will command, Wherein your lady and your humble wife May show her duty and make known her love?'Go call at Flavius' house, And tell him where I stay: give the like notice To Valentinus, Rowland, and to Crassus, And bid them bring the trumpets to the gate; But send me Flavius first.Ha!But my father hath made her mistress of the feast, and she lays it on.By my white beard, You offer him, if this be so, a wrong Something unfilial: reason my son Should choose himself a wife, but as good reason The father, all whose joy is nothing else But fair posterity, should hold some counsel In such a business.Why in this woolvish toge should I stand here, To beg of Hob and Dick, that do appear, Their needless vouches?Almost at point to enter.slave!A sickness caught of me, and yet I well!How far into the morning is it, lords?Ah, so much interest have I in thy sorrow As I had title in thy noble husband!Fool-hardiness; not I. Nor I. See, they have shut him in.Sir, my mistress sends you word That she is busy and she cannot come.Then cursed she Hastings, then cursed she Buckingham, Then cursed she Richard.Sweet father, do so; set it on your head.Camillo, sir; I spake with him; who now Has these poor men in question.He's irremoveable, Resolved for flight.Take it up.Be plain, Queen Margaret, and tell thy grief; It shall be eased, if France can yield relief.You may not pass, you must return: our general Will no more hear from thence.Safe-conducting the rebels from their ships!Is there no pity sitting in the clouds, That sees into the bottom of my grief?To tell thee whence thou camest, of whom derived, Were shame enough to shame thee, wert thou not shameless.Teach thy necessity to reason thus; There is no virtue like necessity.Come, lay aside your stitchery; I must have you play the idle husewife with me this afternoon.I find not Myself disposed to sleep.In God's name, lead; your king's name be obey'd: And what God will, that let your king perform; And what he will, I humbly yield unto.To do this deed, Promotion follows.I had thought, my lord, to have learn'd his health of you.Your mother was most true to wedlock, prince; For she did print your royal father off, Conceiving you: were I but twenty-one, Your father's image is so hit in you, His very air, that I should call you brother, As I did him, and speak of something wildly By us perform'd before.Behold, these are the tribunes of the people, The tongues o' the common mouth: I do despise them; For they do prank them in authority, Against all noble sufferance.No, no, forsooth; I dare not for my life.I'll join with black despair against my soul, And to myself become an enemy.Death and destruction dog thee at the heels; Thy mother's name is ominous to children.Is't possible, friend Licio, that Mistress Bianca Doth fancy any other but Lucentio?Has he affections in him, That thus can make him bite the law by the nose, When he would force it?Thou art not thyself; For thou exist'st on many a thousand grains That issue out of dust.Please your ladyship To visit the next room, I'll presently Acquaint the queen of your most noble offer; Who but to-day hammer'd of this design, But durst not tempt a minister of honour, Lest she should be denied.And here have I the daintiness of ear To cheque time broke in a disorder'd string; But for the concord of my state and time Had not an ear to hear my true time broke.May I change these garments?O master, if you did but hear the pedlar at the door, you would never dance again after a tabour and pipe; no, the bagpipe could not move you: he sings several tunes faster than you'll tell money; he utters them as he had eaten ballads and all men's ears grew to his tunes.where is Green?Peace and prosperity!Age, thou hast lost thy labour.Of much less value is my company Than your good words.No.Sir, I will serve him; for I do find your hangman is a more penitent trade than your bawd; he doth oftener ask forgiveness.Commend me to thy lady.Hadst thou been kill'd when first thou didst presume, Thou hadst not lived to kill a son of mine.No, no, my lord.To horse, to horse!Minion, thou liest.I thank you, general; But cannot make my heart consent to take A bribe to pay my sword: I do refuse it; And stand upon my common part with those That have beheld the doing.My unsoil'd name, the austereness of my life, My vouch against you, and my place i' the state, Will so your accusation overweigh, That you shall stifle in your own report And smell of calumny.How hast thou offended?Such it seems As may beseem a monarch like himself.You are pardon'd, Isabel: And now, dear maid, be you as free to us.Say thou wilt course; thy greyhounds are as swift As breathed stags, ay, fleeter than the roe.Nay, an there were two such, we should have none shortly, for one would kill the other.Or thee?Would all were well!Ratcliff!It is your former promise.And 'twere the cheaper way: Better it were a brother died at once, Than that a sister, by redeeming him, Should die for ever.Landlord of England art thou now, not king: Thy state of law is bondslave to the law; And thou-- A lunatic lean-witted fool, Presuming on an ague's privilege, Darest with thy frozen admonition Make pale our cheek, chasing the royal blood With fury from his native residence.And she will speak most bitterly and strange.You know him not, sir.Thou wilt fall backward when thou comest to age; Wilt thou not, Jule?'My Lord of Westminster, be it your charge To keep him safely till his day of trial.And I, I hope, shall reconcile them all.Two of thy name, both Dukes of Somerset, Have sold their lives unto the house of York; And thou shalt be the third if this sword hold.O God, which this blood madest, revenge his death!Hear me, gentle liege.Once, sir?Pray you, be gone.My prisoner?There he must stay until the officer Arise to let him in: he is call'd up.By whose direction found'st thou out this place?Hark, how the villain would close now, after his treasonable abuses!Leave me, I say.Now put it, God, in the physician's mind To help him to his grave immediately!and Trust, his sworn brother, a very simple gentleman!Here's goodly work!Is not a comondy a Christmas gambold or a tumbling-trick?The time 'twixt six and now Must by us both be spent most preciously.Please you, sir, Do not omit the heavy offer of it: It seldom visits sorrow; when it doth, It is a comforter.Ay, mistress, and Petruchio is the master; That teacheth tricks eleven and twenty long, To tame a shrew and charm her chattering tongue.You souls of geese, That bear the shapes of men, how have you run From slaves that apes would beat!Go about it.When I was last in Holborn, I saw good strawberries in your garden there I do beseech you send for some of them.wife!know you where you are?a gracious innocent soul, More free than he is jealous.O, a kiss Long as my exile, sweet as my revenge!Well, he is gone; and with him go these thoughts.I thank thee for that gird, good Tranio.If to have done the thing you gave in charge Beget your happiness, be happy then, For it is done, my lord.To the ground, mistress.would't had been done!I was promised them against the feast; but they come not too late now.Yea, brother of Clarence, are thou here too?Nicanor?Show me how, good father.what's this?He cannot plead his estimation with you; he hath been a bawd.What news, friar, of the duke?I beseech your honour, ask me.Stay, gentle Margaret, and hear me speak.Here in these confines slily have I lurk'd, To watch the waning of mine adversaries.No harm.Up with my tent there!Did I let pass the abuse done to my niece?one word more Shall make me chide thee, if not hate thee.Who knows that Lodowick?wear the garland!I could myself Take up a brace o' the best of them; yea, the two tribunes: But now 'tis odds beyond arithmetic; And manhood is call'd foolery, when it stands Against a falling fabric.Ay, what of that?Good morrow, Catesby; you are early stirring What news, what news, in this our tottering state?Speak to me, son: Thou hast affected the fine strains of honour, To imitate the graces of the gods; To tear with thunder the wide cheeks o' the air, And yet to charge thy sulphur with a bolt That should but rive an oak.What if he had said 'widower AEneas' too?How!Here's a sight for thee; look thee, a bearing-cloth for a squire's child!Send for your daughter by your servant here: My boy shall fetch the scrivener presently.O miserable lady!Prodigious birth of love it is to me, That I must love a loathed enemy.Here did she fall a tear; here in this place I'll set a bank of rue, sour herb of grace: Rue, even for ruth, here shortly shall be seen, In the remembrance of a weeping queen.Wherefore was I born?Master Froth, I would not have you acquainted with tapsters: they will draw you, Master Froth, and you will hang them.O cunning enemy, that, to catch a saint, With saints dost bait thy hook!For mine own part, When I said, banish him, I said 'twas pity.To three thousand dolours a year.I know you can do very little alone; for your helps are many, or else your actions would grow wondrous single: your abilities are too infant-like for doing much alone.'Peace, peace, peace!'If I should tell thee o'er this thy day's work, Thou'ldst not believe thy deeds: but I'll report it Where senators shall mingle tears with smiles, Where great patricians shall attend and shrug, I' the end admire, where ladies shall be frighted, And, gladly quaked, hear more; where the dull tribunes, That, with the fusty plebeians, hate thine honours, Shall say against their hearts 'We thank the gods Our Rome hath such a soldier.'My lord, no leave take I; for I will ride, As far as land will let me, by your side.I think there is not half a kiss to choose Who loves another best.I remember them too well: Thou slewest my husband Henry in the Tower, And Edward, my poor son, at Tewksbury.Many years of happy days befal My gracious sovereign, my most loving liege!And patient fools, Whose children he hath slain, their base throats tear With giving him glory.in few words, If you'll not here proclaim yourself our king, I'll leave you to your fortune and be gone To keep them back that come to succor you: Why shall we fight, if you pretend no title?And thou, fresh piece Of excellent witchcraft, who of force must know The royal fool thou copest with,-- O, my heart!You are ambitious for poor knaves' caps and legs: you wear out a good wholesome forenoon in hearing a cause between an orange wife and a fosset-seller; and then rejourn the controversy of three pence to a second day of audience.please your honour, I know not well what they are: but precise villains they are, that I am sure of; and void of all profanation in the world that good Christians ought to have.And more a friend than e'er an enemy; Yet, Marcius, that was much.You have made Good work, you and your cry!what, Paris too?Say, Signior Gremio, What can you assure her?None, sir, none.what consul?You saw my master wink and laugh upon you?Ay, forsooth.Pray, sir, by your good favour,--for surely, sir, a good favour you have, but that you have a hanging look,--do you call, sir, your occupation a mystery?How is it with our general?Nay, nothing; all is said His tongue is now a stringless instrument; Words, life and all, old Lancaster hath spent.Thou think'st there is no more such shapes as he, Having seen but him and Caliban: foolish wench!Down, court!No, I warrant you; I will not adventure my discretion so weakly.So foolish sorrow bids your stones farewell.My lord, we'll do it throughly.No, not a whit: I find you passing gentle.King Lewis and Lady Bona, hear me speak, Before you answer Warwick.Ha!His better doth not breathe upon the earth.Let me be ta'en, let me be put to death; I am content, so thou wilt have it so.They say poor suitors have strong breaths: they shall know we have strong arms too.Thou art perfect then, our ship hath touch'd upon The deserts of Bohemia?Ah, ha, my lord, this prince is not an Edward!He's sudden, if a thing comes in his head.May your grace speak of it?While we pursued the horsemen of the north, He slily stole away and left his men: Whereat the great Lord of Northumberland, Whose warlike ears could never brook retreat, Cheer'd up the drooping army; and himself, Lord Clifford and Lord Stafford, all abreast, Charged our main battle's front, and breaking in Were by the swords of common soldiers slain.Dear brother, how shall Bona be revenged But by thy help to this distressed queen?O gods He has the stamp of Marcius; and I have Before-time seen him thus.Keep thou the napkin, and go boast of this: And if thou tell'st the heavy story right, Upon my soul, the hearers will shed tears; Yea even my foes will shed fast-falling tears, And say 'Alas, it was a piteous deed!'See who it is: and, now the battle's ended, If friend or foe, let him be gently used.My Lord of Norfolk,-- Here, most gracious liege.Embrace each other's love in banishment; Nor never look upon each other's face; Nor never write, regreet, nor reconcile This louring tempest of your home-bred hate; Nor never by advised purpose meet To plot, contrive, or complot any ill 'Gainst us, our state, our subjects, or our land.A sail, a sail!What else?Ere you go, hear this:-- As far as doth the Capitol exceed The meanest house in Rome, so far my son-- This lady's husband here, this, do you see-- Whom you have banish'd, does exceed you all.Hark you!And when such time they have begun to cry, Let them not cease, but with a din confused Enforce the present execution Of what we chance to sentence.Go to your bosom; Knock there, and ask your heart what it doth know That's like my brother's fault: if it confess A natural guiltiness such as is his, Let it not sound a thought upon your tongue Against my brother's life.My lord?'Con tutto il cuore, ben trovato,' may I say.Upon's again.First he was A noble servant to them; but he could not Carry his honours even: whether 'twas pride, Which out of daily fortune ever taints The happy man; whether defect of judgment, To fail in the disposing of those chances Which he was lord of; or whether nature, Not to be other than one thing, not moving From the casque to the cushion, but commanding peace Even with the same austerity and garb As he controll'd the war; but one of these-- As he hath spices of them all, not all, For I dare so far free him--made him fear'd, So hated, and so banish'd: but he has a merit, To choke it in the utterance.Well, I have done: but yet,-- He will be talking.The belly answer'd-- Well, sir, what answer made the belly?Most sweet voices!Thanks, gentle Somerset; sweet Oxford, thanks.My conscience tells me he is lawful king.In her chamber, making a sermon of continency to her; And rails, and swears, and rates, that she, poor soul, Knows not which way to stand, to look, to speak, And sits as one new-risen from a dream.My unblown flowers, new-appearing sweets!I have done so, but he's not to be found.Go play, Mamillius; thou'rt an honest man.I will go call the watch.In sadness, cousin, I do love a woman.But first I'll turn yon fellow in his grave; And then return lamenting to my love.But whither shall we then?Peace is a very apoplexy, lethargy; mulled, deaf, sleepy, insensible; a getter of more bastard children than war's a destroyer of men.trouble us not.As I remember, Henry the Sixth Did prophesy that Richmond should be king, When Richmond was a little peevish boy.Seest thou not the air of the court in these enfoldings?Give me some ink and paper.That sort was well fished for.How dost thou feel thyself now?I have begun, And now I give my sensual race the rein: Fit thy consent to my sharp appetite; Lay by all nicety and prolixious blushes, That banish what they sue for; redeem thy brother By yielding up thy body to my will; Or else he must not only die the death, But thy unkindness shall his death draw out To lingering sufferance.If you think it meet, compound with him by the year, and let him abide here with you; if not, use him for the present and dismiss him.I thank your grace.Wipe thou thine eyes; have comfort.I mean to stride your steed, and at all times To undercrest your good addition To the fairness of my power.Is she so hot a shrew as she's reported?How?My first son.Lucentio, gentle sir.Juliet!What is the news i' the court?Upon the stroke of four.My mind is changed, sir, my mind is changed.Off with the crown, and with the crown his head; And, whilst we breathe, take time to do him dead.More than I have said, loving countrymen, The leisure and enforcement of the time Forbids to dwell upon: yet remember this, God and our good cause fight upon our side; The prayers of holy saints and wronged souls, Like high-rear'd bulwarks, stand before our faces; Richard except, those whom we fight against Had rather have us win than him they follow: For what is he they follow?See you yond coign o' the Capitol, yond corner-stone?Yes, madam: yet I cannot choose but laugh, To think it should leave crying and say 'Ay.'Humbly complaining to her deity Got my lord chamberlain his liberty.Our lands, our lives and all are Bolingbroke's, And nothing can we call our own but death And that small model of the barren earth Which serves as paste and cover to our bones.thy form cries out thou art: Thy tears are womanish; thy wild acts denote The unreasonable fury of a beast: Unseemly woman in a seeming man!You so remain.On the sudden, I warrant him consul.Gremio, 'tis now no time to vent our love: Listen to me, and if you speak me fair, I'll tell you news indifferent good for either.Pray now What colour are your eyebrows?Marry, bachelor, Her mother is the lady of the house, And a good lady, and a wise and virtuous I nursed her daughter, that you talk'd withal; I tell you, he that can lay hold of her Shall have the chinks.If 'twere not she, I cannot tell who told me.What is it thou didst say?He is their god: he leads them like a thing Made by some other deity than nature, That shapes man better; and they follow him, Against us brats, with no less confidence Than boys pursuing summer butterflies, Or butchers killing flies.What, ho!O, cut my lace, lest my heart, cracking it, Break too.That Angelo is an adulterous thief, An hypocrite, a virgin-violator; Is it not strange and strange?Camillo,-- As you are certainly a gentleman, thereto Clerk-like experienced, which no less adorns Our gentry than our parents' noble names, In whose success we are gentle,--I beseech you, If you know aught which does behove my knowledge Thereof to be inform'd, imprison't not In ignorant concealment.Forewarn him that he use no scurrilous words in 's tunes.Hold; get you gone, be strong and prosperous In this resolve: I'll send a friar with speed To Mantua, with my letters to thy lord.Biondello, let's away.O most kind maid, It was the swift celerity of his death, Which I did think with slower foot came on, That brain'd my purpose.Though thou speak'st truth, Methinks thou speak'st not well.and away.Pray you, put up your dagger, and put out your wit.Feather of lead, bright smoke, cold fire, sick health!Which is his house, beseech you?So longest way shall have the longest moans.Where lies he?any of them?Hence with him to the Tower; let him not speak.Call you me daughter?Wise!I know you are now, sir, a gentleman born.The tender love I bear your grace, my lord, Makes me most forward in this noble presence To doom the offenders, whatsoever they be I say, my lord, they have deserved death.I must Forsake the court: to do't, or no, is certain To me a break-neck.Who builds his hopes in air of your good looks, Lives like a drunken sailor on a mast, Ready, with every nod, to tumble down Into the fatal bowels of the deep.How long is't since?Being moved, he will not spare to gird the gods.What Tranio did, myself enforced him to; Then pardon him, sweet father, for my sake.To weep is to make less the depth of grief: Tears then for babes; blows and revenge for me Richard, I bear thy name; I'll venge thy death, Or die renowned by attempting it.Good morrow, Kate; for that's your name, I hear.Pitchers have ears.He shift a trencher?Ever right.What good is cover'd with the face of heaven, To be discover'd, that can do me good?A gentleman of mine I have dispatch'd With letters of your love to her at large.Nay, now dispatch; 'twas I that stabb'd young Edward, But 'twas thy heavenly face that set me on.And yet, I warrant, it had upon its brow A bump as big as a young cockerel's stone; A parlous knock; and it cried bitterly: 'Yea,' quoth my husband,'fall'st upon thy face?I know the boy will well usurp the grace, Voice, gait and action of a gentlewoman: I long to hear him call the drunkard husband, And how my men will stay themselves from laughter When they do homage to this simple peasant.Content thee, gentle coz, let him alone; He bears him like a portly gentleman; And, to say truth, Verona brags of him To be a virtuous and well-govern'd youth: I would not for the wealth of all the town Here in my house do him disparagement: Therefore be patient, take no note of him: It is my will, the which if thou respect, Show a fair presence and put off these frowns, And ill-beseeming semblance for a feast.Thy friend no less Than those she placeth highest!Make me not sighted like the basilisk: I have look'd on thousands, who have sped the better By my regard, but kill'd none so.Thou detestable maw, thou womb of death, Gorged with the dearest morsel of the earth, Thus I enforce thy rotten jaws to open, And, in despite, I'll cram thee with more food!For you, my noble Lord of Lancaster, The honourable father to my foe Once did I lay an ambush for your life, A trespass that doth vex my grieved soul But ere I last received the sacrament I did confess it, and exactly begg'd Your grace's pardon, and I hope I had it.Certainly He flouted us downright.So, fare you well; Unless you please to enter in the castle And there repose you for this night.Reignier, her father, to the king of France Hath pawn'd the Sicils and Jerusalem, And hither have they sent it for her ransom.O thou untaught!What is yond gentleman?There have been, Or I am much deceived, cuckolds ere now; And many a man there is, even at this present, Now while I speak this, holds his wife by the arm, That little thinks she has been sluiced in's absence And his pond fish'd by his next neighbour, by Sir Smile, his neighbour: nay, there's comfort in't Whiles other men have gates and those gates open'd, As mine, against their will.I say to you, as I was said to, Away!I will be mild and gentle in my speech.I do not think.We did believe no less.Great Lord of Warwick, if we should recount Our baleful news, and at each word's deliverance Stab poniards in our flesh till all were told, The words would add more anguish than the wounds.We are not, sir, nor are we like to be; The stars, I see, will kiss the valleys first: The odds for high and low's alike.the order was reversed.Where doth the world thrust forth a vanity-- So it be new, there's no respect how vile-- That is not quickly buzzed into his ears?I shall obey him.see, see what showers arise, Blown with the windy tempest of my heart, Upon thy words, that kill mine eye and heart!What is't I dream on?Wife!What corruption in this life, that it will let this man live!I hope better.Go: fresh horses!'Tis time; descend; be stone no more; approach; Strike all that look upon with marvel.My lords, at once: the cause why we are met Is, to determine of the coronation.Be not ta'en tardy by unwise delay.Part us, Northumberland; I toward the north, Where shivering cold and sickness pines the clime; My wife to France: from whence, set forth in pomp, She came adorned hither like sweet May, Sent back like Hallowmas or short'st of day.Lend thine ear.Holla, within!I have a brother is condemn'd to die: I do beseech you, let it be his fault, And not my brother.Art thou so hasty?Now, in good sadness, son Petruchio, I think thou hast the veriest shrew of all.But yet I run before my horse to market: Clarence still breathes; Edward still lives and reigns: When they are gone, then must I count my gains.What seal is that, that hangs without thy bosom?His pupil age Man-enter'd thus, he waxed like a sea, And in the brunt of seventeen battles since He lurch'd all swords of the garland.Come on, strike up!Drummer, strike up, and let us march away.Farewell: if heart's presages be not vain, We three here art that ne'er shall meet again.The means that heaven yields must be embraced, And not neglected; else, if heaven would, And we will not, heaven's offer we refuse, The proffer'd means of succor and redress.Cousin, stand forth, and look upon that man.Worthy Menenius Agrippa; one that hath always loved the people.Mi perdonato, gentle master mine, I am in all affected as yourself; Glad that you thus continue your resolve To suck the sweets of sweet philosophy.If this inducement force her not to love, Send her a story of thy noble acts; Tell her thou madest away her uncle Clarence, Her uncle Rivers; yea, and, for her sake, Madest quick conveyance with her good aunt Anne.The prince your son, with mere conceit and fear Of the queen's speed, is gone.Away!Now, they believe it; and withal whet me To be revenged on Rivers, Vaughan, Grey: But then I sigh; and, with a piece of scripture, Tell them that God bids us do good for evil: And thus I clothe my naked villany With old odd ends stolen out of holy writ; And seem a saint, when most I play the devil.What, thou?Beseech you, sir, Remember since you owed no more to time Than I do now: with thought of such affections, Step forth mine advocate; at your request My father will grant precious things as trifles.First, you know Caius Marcius is chief enemy to the people.He is, and feasts the nobles of the state At his house this night.Give me thy torch, boy: hence, and stand aloof: Yet put it out, for I would not be seen.No, 'tis not so deep as a well, nor so wide as a church-door; but 'tis enough,'twill serve: ask for me to-morrow, and you shall find me a grave man.that's the dog's name; R is for the--No; I know it begins with some other letter:--and she hath the prettiest sententious of it, of you and rosemary, that it would do you good to hear it.and a copatain hat!Boldly, at least.then have at thee, boy!Richard, where art thou?And hark, what noise the general makes!Weapons, weapons, weapons!Why, so I did; but look'd for no reply.Edward's seven sons, whereof thyself art one, Were as seven vials of his sacred blood, Or seven fair branches springing from one root: Some of those seven are dried by nature's course, Some of those branches by the Destinies cut; But Thomas, my dear lord, my life, my Gloucester, One vial full of Edward's sacred blood, One flourishing branch of his most royal root, Is crack'd, and all the precious liquor spilt, Is hack'd down, and his summer leaves all faded, By envy's hand and murder's bloody axe.I may not answer.Clarence, excuse me to the king my brother; I'll hence to London on a serious matter: Ere ye come there, be sure to hear some news.a horse!And thou the velvet: thou art good velvet; thou'rt a three-piled piece, I warrant thee: I had as lief be a list of an English kersey as be piled, as thou art piled, for a French velvet.You have told them home; And, by my troth, you have cause.Is my master and his wife coming, Grumio?There is written in your brow, provost, honesty and constancy: if I read it not truly, my ancient skill beguiles me; but, in the boldness of my cunning, I will lay myself in hazard.He bears himself more proudlier, Even to my person, than I thought he would When first I did embrace him: yet his nature In that's no changeling; and I must excuse What cannot be amended.Now, were not I a little pot and soon hot, my very lips might freeze to my teeth, my tongue to the roof of my mouth, my heart in my belly, ere I should come by a fire to thaw me: but I, with blowing the fire, shall warm myself;
