for, considering the weather, a taller man than I will take cold.What have you done?To-day, to-day, unhappy day, too late, O'erthrows thy joys, friends, fortune and thy state: For all the Welshmen, hearing thou wert dead.This is a brave fellow.Or with pale beggar-fear impeach my height Before this out-dared dastard?Pray, let us go.I never did her any, to my knowledge.Renowned prince, how shall poor Henry live, Unless thou rescue him from foul despair?Henceforward I am ever ruled by you.Master, has my fellow Tranio stolen your clothes?I'll bear thee hence; and let them fight that will, For I have murdered where I should not kill.Is Rosaline, whom thou didst love so dear, So soon forsaken?Came he not home to-night?Thy voice is thunder, but thy looks are humble.You whoreson villain!let's partake.A man that apprehends death no more dreadfully but as a drunken sleep; careless, reckless, and fearless of what's past, present, or to come; insensible of mortality, and desperately mortal.I prithee, spare.What said Northumberland as touching Richmond?Where art thou, keeper?If you would not so, You pity not the state, nor the remembrance Of his most sovereign name; consider little What dangers, by his highness' fail of issue, May drop upon his kingdom and devour Incertain lookers on.I cannot bring My tongue to such a pace:--'Look, sir, my wounds!Think what you will, we seize into our hands His plate, his goods, his money and his lands.Let me embrace with old Vincentio, And wander we to see thy honest son, Who will of thy arrival be full joyous.Call them forth.Therefore, let's hence, And with our fair entreaties haste them on.I make a broken delivery of the business; but the changes I perceived in the king and Camillo were very notes of admiration: they seemed almost, with staring on one another, to tear the cases of their eyes; there was speech in their dumbness, language in their very gesture; they looked as they had heard of a world ransomed, or one destroyed: a notable passion of wonder appeared in them; but the wisest beholder, that knew no more but seeing, could not say if the importance were joy or sorrow; but in the extremity of the one, it must needs be.I would the fool were married to her grave!Nay, call us ten times frail; For we are soft as our complexions are, And credulous to false prints.These your unusual weeds to each part of you Do give a life: no shepherdess, but Flora Peering in April's front.Consider further, That when he speaks not like a citizen, You find him like a soldier: do not take His rougher accents for malicious sounds, But, as I say, such as become a soldier, Rather than envy you.By your renouncement an immortal spirit, And to be talk'd with in sincerity, As with a saint.Did you perceive He did solicit you in free contempt When he did need your loves, and do you think That his contempt shall not be bruising to you, When he hath power to crush?And Montague our topmost; what of him?Only fair speech.Take our good meaning, for our judgment sits Five times in that ere once in our five wits.Dear my brother, Let him that was the cause of this have power To take off so much grief from you as he Will piece up in himself.An honour!he was wont to come home wounded.What's worse than murderer, that I may name it?A little gale will soon disperse that cloud And blow it to the source from whence it came: The very beams will dry those vapours up, For every cloud engenders not a storm.Let's fetch him off, or make remain alike.or those doves' eyes, Which can make gods forsworn?I never saw a better-fashion'd gown, More quaint, more pleasing, nor more commendable: Belike you mean to make a puppet of me.I say it is the moon that shines so bright.Well, I say no: and therefore for assurance Let's each one send unto his wife; And he whose wife is most obedient To come at first when he doth send for her, Shall win the wager which we will propose.Come, madam wife, sit by my side and let the world slip: we shall ne'er be younger.Harry of Hereford, Lancaster and Derby Am I; who ready here do stand in arms, To prove, by God's grace and my body's valour, In lists, on Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk, That he is a traitor, foul and dangerous, To God of heaven, King Richard and to me; And as I truly fight, defend me heaven!Come, you are so full of cony-catching!Then, window, let day in, and let life out.I'll make my heaven in a lady's lap, And deck my body in gay ornaments, And witch sweet ladies with my words and looks.How now, how now, chop-logic!Is it e'en so?That's off, that's off; I would you rather had been silent.It was an answer: how apply you this?Lend me thy hand, I'll help thee: come, lend me thy hand.Sir, I will tell you; Since I am charged in honour and by him That I think honourable: therefore mark my counsel, Which must be even as swiftly follow'd as I mean to utter it, or both yourself and me Cry lost, and so good night!Oft have I heard of sanctuary men; But sanctuary children ne'er till now.Prithee bring him in; and let him approach singing.He dies for Claudio's death.Great Duke of Lancaster, I come to thee From plume-pluck'd Richard; who with willing soul Adopts thee heir, and his high sceptre yields To the possession of thy royal hand: Ascend his throne, descending now from him; And long live Henry, fourth of that name!What is this?the all-seeing sun Ne'er saw her match since first the world begun.Sirs, take up the corse.What say you to a neat's foot?Send to her, by the man that slew her brothers, A pair of bleeding-hearts; thereon engrave Edward and York; then haply she will weep: Therefore present to her--as sometime Margaret Did to thy father, steep'd in Rutland's blood,-- A handkerchief; which, say to her, did drain The purple sap from her sweet brother's body And bid her dry her weeping eyes therewith.The good old man would fain that all were well, So 'twere not 'long of him; but being enter'd, I doubt not, I, but we shall soon persuade Both him and all his brothers unto reason.Fair lovely maid, once more good day to thee.By Jove himself!Temptations have since then been born to's; for In those unfledged days was my wife a girl; Your precious self had then not cross'd the eyes Of my young play-fellow.O Brakenbury, I have done those things, Which now bear evidence against my soul, For Edward's sake; and see how he requites me!My noble lords and cousins all, good morrow.Blessed be your royal grace!Saints do not move, though grant for prayers' sake.a horse!he's gone, he's kill'd, he's dead!Who have we here?Death is a fearful thing.If these shows be not outward, which of you But is four Volsces?Name it, fair cousin.For never henceforth shall I joy again, Never, O never shall I see more joy!I hear his drum: be copious in exclaims.King Henry and the prince his son are gone: Clarence, thy turn is next, and then the rest, Counting myself but bad till I be best.Yet may he live awhile; and, it may be, As long as you or I yet he must die.Would the nobility lay aside their ruth, And let me use my sword, I'll make a quarry With thousands of these quarter'd slaves, as high As I could pick my lance.he is already dead; stabbed with a white wench's black eye; shot through the ear with a love-song; the very pin of his heart cleft with the blind bow-boy's butt-shaft: and is he a man to encounter Tybalt?Why should she live, to fill the world with words?And why, my lady wisdom?My charity is outrage, life my shame And in that shame still live my sorrow's rage.Away to heaven, respective lenity, And fire-eyed fury be my conduct now!Be not so hasty to confound my meaning: I mean, that with my soul I love thy daughter, And mean to make her queen of England.So, let's see: it was told me I should be rich by the fairies.Your bed-chamber.My lord, Before I freely speak my mind herein, You shall not only take the sacrament To bury mine intents, but also to effect Whatever I shall happen to devise.Why, am I dead?I would not--though 'tis my familiar sin With maids to seem the lapwing and to jest, Tongue far from heart--play with all virgins so: I hold you as a thing ensky'd and sainted.Both are my kinsmen: The one is my sovereign, whom both my oath And duty bids defend; the other again Is my kinsman, whom the king hath wrong'd, Whom conscience and my kindred bids to right.Faith, nothing; but has left me here behind, to expound the meaning or moral of his signs and tokens.What says he?Were I a tyrant, Where were her life?Lord Angelo is severe.Go, get aboard; Look to thy bark: I'll not be long before I call upon thee.You that will follow me to this attempt, Applaud the name of Henry with your leader.Fair lords, take leave and stand not to reply.Now, brother Richard, will you stand by us?And would you not do much to do them good?Hail, lords!It is your husband mock'd you with a husband.Mine honour is my life; both grow in one: Take honour from me, and my life is done: Then, dear my liege, mine honour let me try; In that I live and for that will I die.Teach not thy lips such scorn, for they were made For kissing, lady, not for such contempt.ay, widow Dido.would I had died a maid And never seen thee, never borne thee son, Seeing thou hast proved so unnatural a father Hath he deserved to lose his birthright thus?Dogs, easily won to fawn on any man!Will you speak well of him that kill'd your cousin?This precious book of love, this unbound lover, To beautify him, only lacks a cover: The fish lives in the sea, and 'tis much pride For fair without the fair within to hide: That book in many's eyes doth share the glory, That in gold clasps locks in the golden story; So shall you share all that he doth possess, By having him, making yourself no less.How often have I told you 'twould be thus!have you chose this man?He would not stay at your petitions: made His business more material.Following the fliers at the very heels, With them he enters; who, upon the sudden, Clapp'd to their gates: he is himself alone, To answer all the city.Good king, great king, and yet not greatly good, An if my word be sterling yet in England, Let it command a mirror hither straight, That it may show me what a face I have, Since it is bankrupt of his majesty.He has a son, who shall be flayed alive; then 'nointed over with honey, set on the head of a wasp's nest; then stand till he be three quarters and a dram dead; then recovered again with aqua-vitae or some other hot infusion; then, raw as he is, and in the hottest day prognostication proclaims, shall be be set against a brick-wall, the sun looking with a southward eye upon him, where he is to behold him with flies blown to death.What news abroad i' the world?The ground indeed is tawny.But now you partly may perceive my mind.You are they That made the air unwholesome, when you cast Your stinking greasy caps in hooting at Coriolanus' exile.Bless me from marrying a usurer!It were no less; but yet I'll make a pause.Whence are you, sir?Youngling, thou canst not love so dear as I. Graybeard, thy love doth freeze.Now, what's the matter.come, musicians, play.What the vengeance!Were half to half the world by the ears and he. Upon my party, I'ld revolt to make Only my wars with him: he is a lion That I am proud to hunt.Have done thy charm, thou hateful wither'd hag!Now, sir, to you.for whose sake did I that ill deed?Turn back, dull earth, and find thy centre out.A mankind witch!Let me put in your minds, if you forget, What you have been ere now, and what you are; Withal, what I have been, and what I am.Wherefore do you come?So, here comes a brace.Here in Vienna, sir.I shall inform them.Is this done?Where were you born, friend?I'll prove the contrary, if you'll hear me speak.Come, good sweet lady.I'll venture so much of my hawk or hound, But twenty times so much upon my wife.Nay, now I see She is your treasure, she must have a husband; I must dance bare-foot on her wedding day And for your love to her lead apes in hell.why call you for a sword?Come, what talk you Of Marcius?O me!grave sir, hail!O no!Were you well served, you would be taught your duty.I would most gladly know the issue of it.When clouds appear, wise men put on their cloaks; When great leaves fall, the winter is at hand; When the sun sets, who doth not look for night?I told you.Sir, praise me not; My work hath yet not warm'd me: fare you well: The blood I drop is rather physical Than dangerous to me: to Aufidius thus I will appear, and fight.That's a good deed.Then go with me to make the matter good.the king doth love you well: Incapable and shallow innocents, You cannot guess who caused your father's death.Do, good my lord, lest all the land do rue it.myself?'Tis like enough, for I stay dinner there.For this time, all the rest depart away: You Capulet; shall go along with me: And, Montague, come you this afternoon, To know our further pleasure in this case, To old Free-town, our common judgment-place.I shall be, if I claim by open war.Then, England's messenger, return in post, And tell false Edward, thy supposed king, That Lewis of France is sending over masquers To revel it with him and his new bride: Thou seest what's past, go fear thy king withal.then I'll be brief.Pembroke and Stafford, you in our behalf Go levy men, and make prepare for war; They are already, or quickly will be landed: Myself in person will straight follow you.Trust Ye?Ah, Exeter!Thou wouldst be fee'd, I see, to make me sport: York cannot speak, unless he wear a crown.What then, sir?Leave me awhile with the maid: my mind promises with my habit no loss shall touch her by my company.A shepherd's daughter, And what to her adheres, which follows after, Is the argument of Time.This love feel I, that feel no love in this.And I, my lord, will bear him company.The price is to ask it kindly.Now God in heaven forbid!God make your majesty joyful as you have been!Put thy sword up, traitor; Who makest a show but darest not strike, thy conscience Is so possess'd with guilt: come from thy ward, For I can here disarm thee with this stick And make thy weapon drop.Good pilgrim, you do wrong your hand too much, Which mannerly devotion shows in this; For saints have hands that pilgrims' hands do touch, And palm to palm is holy palmers' kiss.And, father, do but think How sweet a thing it is to wear a crown; Within whose circuit is Elysium And all that poets feign of bliss and joy.Kindly!This has been some stair-work, some trunk-work, some behind-door-work: they were warmer that got this than the poor thing is here.Why ask I that?Before I be convict by course of law, To threaten me with death is most unlawful.and must I ravel out My weaved-up folly?Lady, Dear queen, that ended when I but began, Give me that hand of yours to kiss.Death, lie thou there, by a dead man interr'd.Away with her!Why, such is love's transgression.What means Sicilia?Despised substance of divinest show!Show me thy humble heart, and not thy knee, Whose duty is deceiveable and false.turn thy back and run?Fly, lords, and save yourselves; For Warwick bids you all farewell to meet in heaven.Thy father was, as thou art, Duke of York; Thy grandfather, Roger Mortimer, Earl of March: I am the son of Henry the Fifth, Who made the Dauphin and the French to stoop And seized upon their towns and provinces.What is the time o' the day?Good-morrow, cousin.He shall be none; We'll keep him here: then what is that to him?Warwick, what are thy news?Tedious it were to tell, and harsh to hear: Sufficeth I am come to keep my word, Though in some part enforced to digress; Which, at more leisure, I will so excuse As you shall well be satisfied withal.my lady's dead!Would it were mortal poison, for thy sake!This ague fit of fear is over-blown; An easy task it is to win our own.The pox of such antic, lisping, affecting fantasticoes; these new tuners of accents!Why, courage then!My life, sir!O Ratcliff, I fear, I fear,-- Nay, good my lord, be not afraid of shadows.Prithee, fellow, remember my name is Menenius, always factionary on the party of your general.The readiest way to make the wench amends Is to become her husband and her father: The which will I; not all so much for love As for another secret close intent, By marrying her which I must reach unto.What trade are you of, sir?lower messes Perchance are to this business purblind?I may make my case as Claudio's, to cross this in the smallest.Why, then I will do what your grace commands.Ratcliff, my lord; 'tis I.Twenty crowns.To see his nobleness!What might I have been, Might I a son and daughter now have look'd on, Such goodly things as you!When at Bohemia You take my lord, I'll give him my commission To let him there a month behind the gest Prefix'd for's parting: yet, good deed, Leontes, I love thee not a jar o' the clock behind What lady-she her lord.Methought their souls, whose bodies Richard murder'd, Came to my tent, and cried on victory: I promise you, my soul is very jocund In the remembrance of so fair a dream.Alive, in triumph!Come, come, my son, I'll bring thee on thy way: Had I thy youth and cause, I would not stay.Stir with the lark to-morrow, gentle Norfolk.Go in: and tell my lady I am gone, Having displeased my father, to Laurence' cell, To make confession and to be absolved.Sir, a word ere you go; Are you a suitor to the maid you talk of, yea or no?Here comes the furious Tybalt back again.Look, what I speak, my life shall prove it true; That Mowbray hath received eight thousand nobles In name of lendings for your highness' soldiers, The which he hath detain'd for lewd employments, Like a false traitor and injurious villain.This is all: Do't and thou hast the one half of my heart; Do't not, thou split'st thine own.You'll sup with me?all lost!Put them not to't: Pray you, go fit you to the custom and Take to you, as your predecessors have, Your honour with your form.What!Thou art not noble; For all the accommodations that thou bear'st Are nursed by baseness.What, will he come?How came it that the absent duke had not either delivered him to his liberty or executed him?Under the canopy!Saw'st thou the melancholy Lord Northumberland?So fared our father with his enemies; So fled his enemies my warlike father: Methinks, 'tis prize enough to be his son.I have not yet made known to Mariana A word of this.Yet am I sick for fear: speak it again; Twice saying 'pardon' doth not pardon twain, But makes one pardon strong.O my son, my son!O, widow Dido!Hold, Richard, hold; for we have done too much.It is required You do awake your faith.Well, I beseech you, let it be proclaimed betimes i' the morn; I'll call you at your house: give notice to such men of sort and suit as are to meet him.O, let me see thee walk: thou dost not halt.Yet lives our pilot still.my child is dead; And with my child my joys are buried.Most mighty sovereign, You have no cause to hold my friendship doubtful: I never was nor never will be false.And little Ned Plantagenet, his son?A gentle cousin, were it light enough.That's a certain text.That at her hands which the king's King forbids.who calls?A horse!It is a quarrel most unnatural, To be revenged on him that loveth you.A plague o' both your houses!Be thou a prey unto the house of York, And die in bands for this unmanly deed!For 'tis a sore upon us, You cannot tent yourself: be gone, beseech you.O my accursed womb, the bed of death!Rode he on Barbary?He that is giddy thinks the world turns round.I am known to be a humorous patrician, and one that loves a cup of hot wine with not a drop of allaying Tiber in't; said to be something imperfect in favouring the first complaint; hasty and tinder-like upon too trivial motion; one that converses more with the buttock of the night than with the forehead of the morning: what I think I utter, and spend my malice in my breath.A little fire is quickly trodden out; Which, being suffer'd, rivers cannot quench.Dorset is fled to Richmond.I could weep And I could laugh, I am light and heavy.My master hath appointed me to go to Saint Luke's, to bid the priest be ready to come against you come with your appendix.did Angelo so leave her?And who is England's king but great York's heir?why, now thou hast thy wish: Wouldst have me weep?love, lord, ay, husband, friend!Note me this, good friend; Your most grave belly was deliberate, Not rash like his accusers, and thus answer'd: 'True is it, my incorporate friends,' quoth he, 'That I receive the general food at first, Which you do live upon; and fit it is, Because I am the store-house and the shop Of the whole body: but, if you do remember, I send it through the rivers of your blood, Even to the court, the heart, to the seat o' the brain; And, through the cranks and offices of man, The strongest nerves and small inferior veins From me receive that natural competency Whereby they live: and though that all at once, You, my good friends,'--this says the belly, mark me,-- Ay, sir; well, well.Farewell: yet for the love I bear my sweet Bianca, if I can by any means light on a fit man to teach her that wherein she delights, I will wish him to her father.What hast here?Let me know the point.Each day still better other's happiness; Until the heavens, envying earth's good hap, Add an immortal title to your crown!Out!Well, sir.Go mend, go mend.O, my lord, You said that idle weeds are fast in growth The prince my brother hath outgrown me far.Is this true?The noble sister of Publicola, The moon of Rome, chaste as the icicle That's curdied by the frost from purest snow And hangs on Dian's temple: dear Valeria!God in thy good cause make thee prosperous!Your fellow Tranio here, to save my life, Puts my apparel and my countenance on, And I for my escape have put on his; For in a quarrel since I came ashore I kill'd a man and fear I was descried: Wait you on him, I charge you, as becomes, While I make way from hence to save my life: You understand me?Now Romeo is beloved and loves again, Alike betwitched by the charm of looks, But to his foe supposed he must complain, And she steal love's sweet bait from fearful hooks: Being held a foe, he may not have access To breathe such vows as lovers use to swear; And she as much in love, her means much less To meet her new-beloved any where: But passion lends them power, time means, to meet Tempering extremities with extreme sweet.That thou dost love my daughter from thy soul: So from thy soul's love didst thou love her brothers; And from my heart's love I do thank thee for it.who spake of love?Why, when, I say?Cousin, farewell; and, uncle, bid him so: Six years we banish him, and he shall go.Thank you, sir: farewell.You will be welcome with this intelligence, Nicanor.I do beseech you, sir, have patience: Your looks are pale and wild, and do import Some misadventure.Good morrow, neighbour Gremio.By mine honesty, If she be mad,--as I believe no other,-- Her madness hath the oddest frame of sense, Such a dependency of thing on thing, As e'er I heard in madness.Or else you would not have bestow'd the heir Of the Lord Bonville on your new wife's son, And leave your brothers to go speed elsewhere.Help, three o' the chiefest soldiers; I'll be one.And I choose Clarence only for protector.My gracious silence, hail!Let boors and franklins say it, I'll swear it.'Tis a vile thing to die, my gracious lord, When men are unprepared and look not for it.wolvish-ravening lamb!When the sun sets, the air doth drizzle dew; But for the sunset of my brother's son It rains downright.Down with him, down with him!Give me a case to put my visage in: A visor for a visor!First, for this woman.What, ho!Peace, you mumbling fool!Marry, sir, to get a husband for her sister.Marshal, ask yonder knight in arms, Both who he is and why he cometh hither Thus plated in habiliments of war, And formally, according to our law, Depose him in the justice of his cause.O good but most unwise patricians!You fight in justice: then, in God's name, lords, Be valiant and give signal to the fight.No, sir.Had she such power, She had just cause.Peter!and, by my holidame, The pretty wretch left crying and said 'Ay.'Alack, for pity!thou hast slain The flower of Europe for his chivalry; And treacherously hast thou vanquish'd him, For hand to hand he would have vanquish'd thee.Virtue is bold, and goodness never fearful.'Save your honour!Ay; and you'll look pale Before you find it other.That may be must be, love, on Thursday next.here, sir!If but one of his pockets could speak, would it not say he lies?Thou concludest like the sanctimonious pirate, that went to sea with the Ten Commandments, but scraped one out of the table.She weeps, and says her Henry is deposed; He smiles, and says his Edward is install'd; That she, poor wretch, for grief can speak no more; Whiles Warwick tells his title, smooths the wrong, Inferreth arguments of mighty strength, And in conclusion wins the king from her, With promise of his sister, and what else, To strengthen and support King Edward's place.why, 'tis impossible.She's not fourteen.Mark our contract.Hark!Arms, take your last embrace!Hail to you, provost!My lord, Fear none of this: I think you know my fortunes Do all lie there: it shall be so my care To have you royally appointed as if The scene you play were mine.Worthy Marcius, Had we no quarrel else to Rome, but that Thou art thence banish'd, we would muster all From twelve to seventy, and pouring war Into the bowels of ungrateful Rome, Like a bold flood o'er-bear.I fear, sir, my shoulder-blade is out.Come, your hand; And, daughter, yours.Deny thy father and refuse thy name; Or, if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love, And I'll no longer be a Capulet.Take up the sword again, or take up me.Valiant gentlemen, Let us survey the vantage of the field Call for some men of sound direction Let's want no discipline, make no delay, For, lords, to-morrow is a busy day.And I am one that love Bianca more Than words can witness, or your thoughts can guess.Come me to what was done to her.Old Gaunt indeed, and gaunt in being old: Within me grief hath kept a tedious fast; And who abstains from meat that is not gaunt?This way the king will come; this is the way To Julius Caesar's ill-erected tower, To whose flint bosom my condemned lord Is doom'd a prisoner by proud Bolingbroke: Here let us rest, if this rebellious earth Have any resting for her true king's queen.Heaven hath my empty words; Whilst my invention, hearing not my tongue, Anchors on Isabel: Heaven in my mouth, As if I did but only chew his name; And in my heart the strong and swelling evil Of my conception.He doth appear.Uncle, farewell: and, cousin too, adieu: Your mother well hath pray'd, and prove you true.I cannot do't without counters.O brother Montague, give me thy hand: This is my daughter's jointure, for no more Can I demand.They have not been commanded, mighty sovereign: Please it your majesty to give me leave, I'll muster up my friends, and meet your grace Where and what time your majesty shall please.Ay, to such mercy as his ruthless arm, With downright payment, show'd unto my father.Preposterous ass, that never read so far To know the cause why music was ordain'd!Put him to choler straight: he hath been used Ever to conquer, and to have his worth Of contradiction: being once chafed, he cannot Be rein'd again to temperance; then he speaks What's in his heart; and that is there which looks With us to break his neck.saw you him to-day?good Kate, I will not burden thee; For, knowing thee to be but young and light-- Too light for such a swain as you to catch; And yet as heavy as my weight should be.Sorry I am my noble cousin should Suspect me, that I mean no good to him: By heaven, I come in perfect love to him; And so once more return and tell his grace.Tell him, when that our princely father York Bless'd his three sons with his victorious arm, And charged us from his soul to love each other, He little thought of this divided friendship: Bid Gloucester think of this, and he will weep.hath not my gait in it the measure of the court?Let's levy men, and beat him back again.Do not draw the curtain.These both put by a poor petitioner, A care-crazed mother of a many children, A beauty-waning and distressed widow, Even in the afternoon of her best days, Made prize and purchase of his lustful eye, Seduced the pitch and height of all his thoughts To base declension and loathed bigamy By her, in his unlawful bed, he got This Edward, whom our manners term the prince.Be ready, Claudio, for your death tomorrow.Three pound of sugar, five pound of currants, rice,--what will this sister of mine do with rice?Lucio, a word with you.Hark!Bids't thou me rage?O, to what purpose dost thou hoard thy words, That thou return'st no greeting to thy friends?And then?God save your lordship!Vincetino's son brought up in Florence It shall become to serve all hopes conceived, To deck his fortune with his virtuous deeds: And therefore, Tranio, for the time I study, Virtue and that part of philosophy Will I apply that treats of happiness By virtue specially to be achieved.If I did take the kingdom from your sons, To make amends, Ill give it to your daughter.I say it is the moon.Thou slander of thy mother's heavy womb!In faith, I will.Could I meet 'em But once a-day, it would unclog my heart Of what lies heavy to't.Well are you welcome to the open air.3 KING HENRY VI Come on, my masters, each man take his stand: The king by this is set him down to sleep.If then we shall shake off our slavish yoke, Imp out our drooping country's broken wing, Redeem from broking pawn the blemish'd crown, Wipe off the dust that hides our sceptre's gilt And make high majesty look like itself, Away with me in post to Ravenspurgh; But if you faint, as fearing to do so, Stay and be secret, and myself will go.I am the last of noble Edward's sons, Of whom thy father, Prince of Wales, was first: In war was never lion raged more fierce, In peace was never gentle lamb more mild, Than was that young and princely gentleman.O injurious love, That respites me a life, whose very comfort Is still a dying horror!You shall have none ill, sir; for I'll try if they can lick their fingers.Or wallow naked in December snow By thinking on fantastic summer's heat?This your request Is altogether just: therefore bring forth, And in Apollos name, his oracle.For you must know, we have with special soul Elected him our absence to supply, Lent him our terror, dress'd him with our love, And given his deputation all the organs Of our own power: what think you of it?Yet in this life Lie hid moe thousand deaths: yet death we fear, That makes these odds all even.Talk not to me, for I'll not speak a word: Do as thou wilt, for I have done with thee.But Hercules himself must yield to odds; And many strokes, though with a little axe, Hew down and fell the hardest-timber'd oak.But in a few, Signior Hortensio, thus it stands with me: Antonio, my father, is deceased; And I have thrust myself into this maze, Haply to wive and thrive as best I may: Crowns in my purse I have and goods at home, And so am come abroad to see the world.You shall ha' it, worthy sir.see where Oxford comes!Against all sense you do importune her: Should she kneel down in mercy of this fact, Her brother's ghost his paved bed would break, And take her hence in horror.Dispatch; the limit of your lives is out.Hie you to church; I must another way, To fetch a ladder, by the which your love Must climb a bird's nest soon when it is dark: I am the drudge and toil in your delight, But you shall bear the burden soon at night.Pretty!Say thou wilt walk; we will bestrew the ground: Or wilt thou ride?You were kneel'd to and importuned otherwise By all of us, and the fair soul herself Weigh'd between loathness and obedience, at Which end o' the beam should bow.And Richard but a ragged fatal rock?Enough of this; I pray thee, hold thy peace.Madam, the guests are come, supper served up, you called, my young lady asked for, the nurse cursed in the pantry, and every thing in extremity.Sir, I beseech you, think you he'll carry Rome?Look, what is done cannot be now amended: Men shall deal unadvisedly sometimes, Which after hours give leisure to repent.How she holds up the neb, the bill to him!You should have said That as his worthy deeds did claim no less Than what he stood for, so his gracious nature Would think upon you for your voices and Translate his malice towards you into love, Standing your friendly lord.And hath he too Exposed this paragon to the fearful usage, At least ungentle, of the dreadful Neptune, To greet a man not worth her pains, much less The adventure of her person?Ay, I thank God, my father, and yourself.To unbuild the city and to lay all flat.'Twere pity they should lose their father's lands.My liberty.I'll buy him of you.Thy mother felt more than a mother's pain, And, yet brought forth less than a mother's hope, To wit, an indigested and deformed lump, Not like the fruit of such a goodly tree.You two are old men: tell me one thing that I shall ask you.Lo, this is all:--nay, yet depart not so; Though this be all, do not so quickly go; I shall remember more.I'll open them.Stanley did dream the boar did raze his helm; But I disdain'd it, and did scorn to fly: Three times to-day my foot-cloth horse did stumble, And startled, when he look'd upon the Tower, As loath to bear me to the slaughter-house.To entail him and his heirs unto the crown, What is it, but to make thy sepulchre And creep into it far before thy time?God keep me from false friends!I do owe them still My life and services.i' the air or the earth?It is determined, not concluded yet: But so it must be, if the king miscarry.Once more, on pain of death, all men depart.Well begun, Tranio.I'll tell thee what; yet go: Nay, but thou shalt stay too: I would my son Were in Arabia, and thy tribe before him, His good sword in his hand.Princes have but their tides for their glories, An outward honour for an inward toil; And, for unfelt imagination, They often feel a world of restless cares: So that, betwixt their tides and low names, There's nothing differs but the outward fame.I weigh it lightly, were it heavier.Thrice noble lord, let me entreat of you To pardon me yet for a night or two, Or, if not so, until the sun be set: For your physicians have expressly charged, In peril to incur your former malady, That I should yet absent me from your bed: I hope this reason stands for my excuse.O, I do fear thee, Claudio; and I quake, Lest thou a feverous life shouldst entertain, And six or seven winters more respect Than a perpetual honour.He something seems unsettled.It is but needful: Mercy is not itself, that oft looks so; Pardon is still the nurse of second woe: But yet,--poor Claudio!When I wore it at your daughter's marriage?Stay, or thou diest!Were I the ghost that walk'd, I'ld bid you mark Her eye, and tell me for what dull part in't You chose her; then I'ld shriek, that even your ears Should rift to hear me; and the words that follow'd Should be 'Remember mine.'They are all forth.O, true-bred!We'll hear no more.I know ye well enough.It sounds no more: and sure, it waits upon Some god o' the island.Is he gone, and hath nothing?When he wakes!So cowards fight when they can fly no further; So doves do peck the falcon's piercing talons; So desperate thieves, all hopeless of their lives, Breathe out invectives 'gainst the officers.Is lechery so look'd after?My Lord of York will still be cross in talk: Uncle, your grace knows how to bear with him.Shall feel this day as sharp to them as thorn.I would Friar Peter-- O, peace!Young budding virgin, fair and fresh and sweet, Whither away, or where is thy abode?What is your will?O mother, mother!But come, my lord; and with a heavy heart, Thinking on them, go I unto the Tower.What storm is this that blows so contrary?What counterfeit did I give you?Welcome, my lord: what, will our mother come?Out-- Of love?Sweet madam.What say'st thou?then, Clarence, do it thou.company is coming here.The gods begin to mock me.Come, Kate, and wash, and welcome heartily.Make a swift return; For I would commune with you of such things That want no ear but yours.'Tis he, my lord.were not I thine only nurse, I would say thou hadst suck'd wisdom from thy teat.Should they not, Well might they fester 'gainst ingratitude, And tent themselves with death.'Scape being drunk for want of wine.where go you With bats and clubs?But 'tis all one to me; for had I been the finder out of this secret, it would not have relished among my other discredits.Is that an answer?Lo, at their births good stars were opposite.He that no more must say is listen'd more Than they whom youth and ease have taught to glose; More are men's ends mark'd than their lives before: The setting sun, and music at the close, As the last taste of sweets, is sweetest last, Writ in remembrance more than things long past: Though Richard my life's counsel would not hear, My death's sad tale may yet undeaf his ear.Lead their successes as we wish our own, That both our powers, with smiling fronts encountering, May give you thankful sacrifice.Not that I know.It shall be so, it shall be so; let him away: He's banish'd, and it shall be so.O, good sir, tenderly, O!Thanks, brave Montgomery; and thanks unto you all: If fortune serve me, I'll requite this kindness.Well, well, we'll leave you.Ere a fortnight make me elder, I'll send some packing that yet think not on it.My gracious lady, go; And thither bear your treasure and your goods.well then, amen.O, is it so?Come, cousin, canst thou quake, and change thy colour, Murder thy breath in the middle of a word, And then begin again, and stop again, As if thou wert distraught and mad with terror?'Tis a spell, you see, of much power: you know the way home again.O, pale!I spoke it but according to the trick.My Lord of Hereford, my message is to you.My lord, I'll tell my lady you will come.As thus, to drop them still upon one place, Till they have fretted us a pair of graves Within the earth; and, therein laid,--there lies Two kinsmen digg'd their graves with weeping eyes.Bid him--ah, what?-- With all good speed at Plashy visit me.What are your offices?Which had you rather, that the most just law Now took your brother's life; or, to redeem him, Give up your body to such sweet uncleanness As she that he hath stain'd?Heaven and yourself Had part in this fair maid; now heaven hath all, And all the better is it for the maid: Your part in her you could not keep from death, But heaven keeps his part in eternal life.But, soft!Heaven keep your honour safe!The red rose and the white are on his face, The fatal colours of our striving houses: The one his purple blood right well resembles; The other his pale cheeks, methinks, presenteth: Wither one rose, and let the other flourish; If you contend, a thousand lives must wither.What must be shall be.My care is loss of care, by old care done; Your care is gain of care, by new care won: The cares I give I have, though given away; They tend the crown, yet still with me they stay.He neither does nor shall.No, no; by God's good grace his son shall reign.I thank my liege, that in regard of me He shortens four years of my son's exile: But little vantage shall I reap thereby; For, ere the six years that he hath to spend Can change their moons and bring their times about My oil-dried lamp and time-bewasted light Shall be extinct with age and endless night; My inch of taper will be burnt and done, And blindfold death not let me see my son.I, thus neglecting worldly ends, all dedicated To closeness and the bettering of my mind With that which, but by being so retired, O'er-prized all popular rate, in my false brother Awaked an evil nature; and my trust, Like a good parent, did beget of him A falsehood in its contrary as great As my trust was; which had indeed no limit, A confidence sans bound.My affairs Do even drag me homeward: which to hinder Were in your love a whip to me; my stay To you a charge and trouble: to save both, Farewell, our brother.No matter where; of comfort no man speak: Let's talk of graves, of worms, and epitaphs; Make dust our paper and with rainy eyes Write sorrow on the bosom of the earth, Let's choose executors and talk of wills: And yet not so, for what can we bequeath Save our deposed bodies to the ground?But think you, lords, that Clifford fled with them?I protest I love the duke as I love myself.I would speak with Clarence, and I came hither on my legs.Why whisper you, my lords, and answer not?He did, my gracious lord, begin that place; Which, since, succeeding ages have re-edified.Good, then; if his face be the worst thing about him, how could Master Froth do the constable's wife any harm?Pray you, let's to him.You gods, look down And from your sacred vials pour your graces Upon my daughter's head!I wish mine eyes Would, with themselves, shut up my thoughts: I find They are inclined to do so.Then know, that from my soul I love thy daughter.I am as well acquainted here as I was in our house of profession: one would think it were Mistress Overdone's own house, for here be many of her old customers.Thus with a kiss I die.We hear not of him, neither need we fear him; His remedies are tame i' the present peace And quietness of the people, which before Were in wild hurry.My lord, the mind of Bolingbroke is changed: You must to Pomfret, not unto the Tower.Nay, then she must needs come.A fire good Curtis.Seven year and a half, sir.'tis no time to talk.And, like a traitor to the name of God, Didst break that vow; and with thy treacherous blade Unrip'dst the bowels of thy sovereign's son.I am courted now with a double occasion, gold and a means to do the prince my master good; which who knows how that may turn back to my advancement?Come, come, they are almost here.Still thus, and thus; still worse!I, an old turtle, Will wing me to some wither'd bough and there My mate, that's never to be found again, Lament till I am lost.In love?Most noble sir, If you do hold the same intent wherein You wish'd us parties, we'll deliver you Of your great danger.What's here?From too much liberty, my Lucio, liberty: As surfeit is the father of much fast, So every scope by the immoderate use Turns to restraint.I pardon him, as God shall pardon me.And yet you halt not.Take hands, a bargain!Comfort, dear mother: God is much displeased That you take with unthankfulness, his doing: In common worldly things, 'tis call'd ungrateful, With dull unwilligness to repay a debt Which with a bounteous hand was kindly lent; Much more to be thus opposite with heaven, For it requires the royal debt it lent you.Now welcome more, and ten times more beloved, Than if thou never hadst deserved our hate.Dead art thou!Sir, it is three days since I saw the prince.now we are undone and brought to nothing.'Widow Dido' said you?Saw'st thou not, boy, how Silver made it good At the hedge-corner, in the coldest fault?What comfort, man?I, not remembering how I cried out then, Will cry it o'er again: it is a hint That wrings mine eyes to't.3 KING HENRY VI The army of the queen hath got the field: My uncles both are slain in rescuing me; And all my followers to the eager foe Turn back and fly, like ships before the wind Or lambs pursued by hunger-starved wolves.Hath not our brother made a worthy choice?O heavens!'Thou shalt not steal'?Bold gentleman, Prosperity be thy page!The nobles they are fled, the commons they are cold, And will, I fear, revolt on Hereford's side.Then none but I shall turn his jest to sorrow.I must be the poisoner Of good Polixenes; and my ground to do't Is the obedience to a master, one Who in rebellion with himself will have All that are his so too.Think'st thou I am an executioner?Get you hence, for I must go Where it fits not you to know.You were not bid to speak.No, I'll nor sell nor give him: lend you him I will For half a hundred years.you take your pennyworths now; Sleep for a week; for the next night, I warrant, The County Paris hath set up his rest, That you shall rest but little.is supper ready, the house trimmed, rushes strewed, cobwebs swept; the serving-men in their new fustian, their white stockings, and every officer his wedding-garment on?Your reasons are too shallow and too quick.Fair sir, and you my merry mistress, That with your strange encounter much amazed me, My name is call'd Vincentio; my dwelling Pisa; And bound I am to Padua; there to visit A son of mine, which long I have not seen.Well, my lord.I have it, Tranio.Well, I'll hear it, sir: yet you must not think to fob off our disgrace with a tale: but, an 't please you, deliver.This deed unshapes me quite, makes me unpregnant And dull to all proceedings.Come on, then, And give't me in mine ear.Is this the man that you did tell us of?Why with some little train, my Lord of Buckingham?Here comes a messenger.disobedient wretch!Wert thou not banished on pain of death?Oh, if you love my brother, hate not me; I am his brother, and I love him well.But, let it come.Nay, stay; lets hear the orisons he makes.For corn at their own rates; whereof, they say, The city is well stored.Dispatch it presently; the hour draws on Prefix'd by Angelo: see this be done, And sent according to command; whiles I Persuade this rude wretch willingly to die.As merry as you will.First, let her show her face, and after speak.Did I put Henry from his native right?But is it true?Can this be so?What is this?Ay, what else?Call hither Barnardine and Claudio: The one has my pity; not a jot the other, Being a murderer, though he were my brother.Why, thou unreverend and unhallow'd friar, Is't not enough thou hast suborn'd these women To accuse this worthy man, but, in foul mouth And in the witness of his proper ear, To call him villain?You might have been enough the man you are, With striving less to be so; lesser had been The thwartings of your dispositions, if You had not show'd them how ye were disposed Ere they lack'd power to cross you.Ay, my good lord:--my lord, I should say rather; 'Tis sin to flatter; 'good' was little better: 'Good Gloucester' and 'good devil' were alike, And both preposterous; therefore, not 'good lord.'first resolve me that.One on 's father's moods.Ay, and burn too.One word, good citizens.Then fare you well, for I will hence again: I came to serve a king and not a duke.I pray thee, peace: my soul is full of sorrow.Hark, Tranio!For shame!Their power, I think, is thirty thousand strong: Now, if the help of Norfolk and myself, With all the friends that thou, brave Earl of March, Amongst the loving Welshmen canst procure, Will but amount to five and twenty thousand, Why, Via!I had forgot myself; am I not king?Fear and be slain; no worse can come to fight: And fight and die is death destroying death; Where fearing dying pays death servile breath.God pardon sin!'Twill grieve your grace my sons should call you father.or else is it your pleasure, Like pleasant travellers, to break a jest Upon the company you overtake?Call your executioner, and off with Barnardine's head: I will give him a present shrift and advise him for a better place.His name is Romeo, and a Montague; The only son of your great enemy.Lo, citizens, he says he is content: The warlike service he has done, consider; think Upon the wounds his body bears, which show Like graves i' the holy churchyard.we see it, and will say it.No, not a whit: what!Adding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs; But all so soon as the all-cheering sun Should in the furthest east begin to draw The shady curtains from Aurora's bed, Away from the light steals home my heavy son, And private in his chamber pens himself, Shuts up his windows, locks far daylight out And makes himself an artificial night: Black and portentous must this humour prove, Unless good counsel may the cause remove.Didst thou not hear me swear I would not do it?Thou most lying slave, Whom stripes may move, not kindness!I thank you, gentle uncle.Go to, go to; You are a saucy boy: is't so, indeed?This shows a sound affection.Why, you bald-pated, lying rascal, you must be hooded, must you?What, man!Why, then you mean not as I thought you did.'Romeo is banished!'That's soon perform'd, because I am a subject.'Tis a wonder, by your leave, she will be tamed so.Madam, madam, madam!O, would he did!Yes, yes, yes; the senate has letters from the general, wherein he gives my son the whole name of the war: he hath in this action outdone his former deeds doubly In troth, there's wondrous things spoke of him.Have you deliver'd to her our decree?Neither.Say no more: Here come the lords.I thought you had been willing to resign.Please you, farther.Nay, if I turn mine eyes upon myself, I find myself a traitor with the rest; For I have given here my soul's consent To undeck the pompous body of a king; Made glory base and sovereignty a slave, Proud majesty a subject, state a peasant.To-day the lords you talk of are beheaded.Doth your honour mark his face?Come, go along, and see the truth hereof; For our first merriment hath made thee jealous.By whom, Camillo?urge doubts to them that fear.Mark'd you not How that the guilty kindred of the queen Look'd pale when they did hear of Clarence' death?I wish no better Than have him hold that purpose and to put it In execution.Away with her!He smiled and said 'The better for our purpose.'O heavens!To have him suddenly convey'd away.'Tis done, my gracious lord.Shall we hear from you, Catesby, ere we sleep?Now, my fair'st friend, I would I had some flowers o' the spring that might Become your time of day; and yours, and yours, That wear upon your virgin branches yet Your maidenheads growing: O Proserpina, For the flowers now, that frighted thou let'st fall From Dis's waggon!Could great men thunder As Jove himself does, Jove would ne'er be quiet, For every pelting, petty officer Would use his heaven for thunder; Nothing but thunder!Behind the tuft of pines I met them; never Saw I men scour so on their way: I eyed them Even to their ships.and strength shall help afford.Well guess'd, believe me; for that was my meaning.you must rise and be hanged.Methinks these peers of France should smile at that.By many hands your father was subdued; But only slaughter'd by the ireful arm Of unrelenting Clifford and the queen, Who crown'd the gracious duke in high despite, Laugh'd in his face; and when with grief he wept, The ruthless queen gave him to dry his cheeks A napkin steeped in the harmless blood Of sweet young Rutland, by rough Clifford slain: And after many scorns, many foul taunts, They took his head, and on the gates of York They set the same; and there it doth remain, The saddest spectacle that e'er I view'd.Therefore at last I firmly am resolved You shall have aid.Was ever match clapp'd up so suddenly?An I were so apt to quarrel as thou art, any man should buy the fee-simple of my life for an hour and a quarter.O trespass sweetly urged!Ay, and more.And, as he fell, did Romeo turn and fly.Nay, not so neither: but I take him to be the greater soldier.I cannot help it now, Unless, by using means, I lame the foot Of our design.Ratcliff!All will be naught else.My valour's poison'd With only suffering stain by him; for him Shall fly out of itself: nor sleep nor sanctuary, Being naked, sick, nor fane nor Capitol, The prayers of priests nor times of sacrifice, Embarquements all of fury, shall lift up Their rotten privilege and custom 'gainst My hate to Marcius: where I find him, were it At home, upon my brother's guard, even there, Against the hospitable canon, would I Wash my fierce hand in's heart.Say, you chose him More after our commandment than as guided By your own true affections, and that your minds, Preoccupied with what you rather must do Than what you should, made you against the grain To voice him consul: lay the fault on us.The Tower, the Tower.Believe me, sister, of all the men alive I never yet beheld that special face Which I could fancy more than any other.This is a thing that Angelo knows not; for he this very day receives letters of strange tenor; perchance of the duke's death; perchance entering into some monastery; but, by chance, nothing of what is writ.Here's Lucentio, Right son to the right Vincentio; That have by marriage made thy daughter mine, While counterfeit supposes bleared thine eyne.you are marvellous forward.Your sense pursues not mine: either you are ignorant, Or seem so craftily; and that's not good.let's withdraw.Nay, this way, man: see where the huntsmen stand.Famous Plantagenet, most gracious prince, Lend favourable ears to our request; And pardon us the interruption Of thy devotion and right Christian zeal.I would thou hadst my bones, and I thy news: Nay, come, I pray thee, speak; good, good nurse, speak.Honourable Menenius, my boy Marcius approaches; for the love of Juno, let's go.A goodly city is this Antium.Fear you not him.Cambio is changed into Lucentio.Welcome, ladies, Welcome!Yet give leave, my lord, That we may bring you something on the way.Romeo!Come, Camillo; I will respect thee as a father if Thou bear'st my life off hence: let us avoid.Good my lords, I am not prone to weeping, as our sex Commonly are; the want of which vain dew Perchance shall dry your pities: but I have That honourable grief lodged here which burns Worse than tears drown: beseech you all, my lords, With thoughts so qualified as your charities Shall best instruct you, measure me; and so The king's will be perform'd!Away, be gone!Is it concluded that he shall be protector?Camillo was his help in this, his pander: There is a plot against my life, my crown; All's true that is mistrusted: that false villain Whom I employ'd was pre-employ'd by him: He has discover'd my design, and I Remain a pinch'd thing; yea, a very trick For them to play at will.In bed asleep, while they do dream things true.But He, that hath the steerage of my course, Direct my sail!You have deserved nobly of your country, and you have not deserved nobly.I'ld have you do it ever: when you sing, I'ld have you buy and sell so, so give alms, Pray so; and, for the ordering your affairs, To sing them too: when you do dance, I wish you A wave o' the sea, that you might ever do Nothing but that; move still, still so, And own no other function: each your doing, So singular in each particular, Crowns what you are doing in the present deed, That all your acts are queens.Why, then All-Souls' day is my body's doomsday.What is six winters?Come, sister,--cousin, I would say--pray, pardon me.Even so lies she, Blubbering and weeping, weeping and blubbering.I must believe you, sir: I do; and will fetch off Bohemia for't; Provided that, when he's removed, your highness Will take again your queen as yours at first, Even for your son's sake; and thereby for sealing The injury of tongues in courts and kingdoms Known and allied to yours.How now!I never sued to friend nor enemy; My tongue could never learn sweet smoothing word; But now thy beauty is proposed my fee, My proud heart sues, and prompts my tongue to speak.But who comes here?And what of all this?If the wars eat us not up, they will; and there's all the love they bear us.Thus stands the case: you know our king, my brother, Is prisoner to the bishop here, at whose hands He hath good usage and great liberty, And, often but attended with weak guard, Comes hunting this way to disport himself.I play the torturer, by small and small To lengthen out the worst that must be spoken: Your uncle York is join'd with Bolingbroke, And all your northern castles yielded up, And all your southern gentlemen in arms Upon his party.I pray she may; as well for the encouragement of the like, which else would stand under grievous imposition, as for the enjoying of thy life, who I would be sorry should be thus foolishly lost at a game of tick-tack.In Warwickshire I have true-hearted friends, Not mutinous in peace, yet bold in war; Those will I muster up: and thou, son Clarence, Shalt stir up in Suffolk, Norfolk, and in Kent, The knights and gentlemen to come with thee: Thou, brother Montague, in Buckingham, Northampton and in Leicestershire, shalt find Men well inclined to hear what thou command'st: And thou, brave Oxford, wondrous well beloved, In Oxfordshire shalt muster up thy friends.Good Hortensio, I bade the rascal knock upon your gate And could not get him for my heart to do it.We are merely cheated of our lives by drunkards: This wide-chapp'd rascal--would thou mightst lie drowning The washing of ten tides!The orchard walls are high and hard to climb, And the place death, considering who thou art, If any of my kinsmen find thee here.Soft!You have not been inquired after: I have sat here all day.Soft!Rather say I play The man I am.I must have saffron to colour the warden pies; mace; dates?--none, that's out of my note; nutmegs, seven; a race or two of ginger, but that I may beg; four pound of prunes, and as many of raisins o' the sun.Woe me!or both?Why dost thou ask again?What, sweeting, all amort?Such news, my lord, as grieves me to unfold.O Thou, whose captain I account myself, Look on my forces with a gracious eye; Put in their hands thy bruising irons of wrath, That they may crush down with a heavy fall The usurping helmets of our adversaries!Sir, this is the gentleman I told you of: I pray you stand good father to me now, Give me Bianca for my patrimony.O Lord, I could have stay'd here all the night To hear good counsel: O, what learning is!I know you well, sir, and you know me: your name, I think, is Adrian.Wherefore?Please your highness, posts From those you sent to the oracle are come An hour since: Cleomenes and Dion, Being well arrived from Delphos, are both landed, Hasting to the court.I pray thee, good Mercutio, let's retire: The day is hot, the Capulets abroad, And, if we meet, we shall not scape a brawl; For now, these hot days, is the mad blood stirring.A whoreson beetle-headed, flap-ear'd knave!I have been long a sleeper; but, I hope, My absence doth neglect no great designs, Which by my presence might have been concluded.Raised only, that the weaker sort may wish Good Marcius home again.Stay your thanks a while; And pay them when you part.Thou didst usurp my place, and dost thou not Usurp the just proportion of my sorrow?Think you I can a resolution fetch From flowery tenderness?Thy Edward he is dead, that stabb'd my Edward: Thy other Edward dead, to quit my Edward; Young York he is but boot, because both they Match not the high perfection of my loss: Thy Clarence he is dead that kill'd my Edward; And the beholders of this tragic play, The adulterate Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey, Untimely smother'd in their dusky graves.Your hand: most welcome!my life is my foe's debt.Go thou, and like an executioner, Cut off the heads of too fast growing sprays, That look too lofty in our commonwealth: All must be even in our government.Do then: but I'll not hear.O, bid me leap, rather than marry Paris, From off the battlements of yonder tower; Or walk in thievish ways; or bid me lurk Where serpents are; chain me with roaring bears; Or shut me nightly in a charnel-house, O'er-cover'd quite with dead men's rattling bones, With reeky shanks and yellow chapless skulls; Or bid me go into a new-made grave And hide me with a dead man in his shroud; Things that, to hear them told, have made me tremble; And I will do it without fear or doubt, To live an unstain'd wife to my sweet love.Why, so he did, I am sure.Ay; and that thou and the proudest of you all shall find when he comes home.Shall I bring thee on the way?Construe them.Merely awry: when he did love his country, It honour'd him.It will be dangerous to go on: no further.At thy choice, then: To beg of thee, it is my more dishonour Than thou of them.Thy mother was a piece of virtue, and She said thou wast my daughter; and thy father Was Duke of Milan; and thou his only heir And princess no worse issued.As if it had lungs and rotten ones.Well, believe this, No ceremony that to great ones 'longs, Not the king's crown, nor the deputed sword, The marshal's truncheon, nor the judge's robe, Become them with one half so good a grace As mercy does.You twain, of all the rest, Are near to Warwick by blood and by alliance: Tell me if you love Warwick more than me?See, ruthless queen, a hapless father's tears: This cloth thou dip'dst in blood of my sweet boy, And I with tears do wash the blood away.Would I were dead, but that, methinks, already-- What was he that did make it?Ay, in despite of all that shall withstand you.When must he die?O monstrous arrogance!Joy absent, grief is present for that time.His demand Springs not from Edward's well-meant honest love, But from deceit bred by necessity; For how can tyrants safely govern home, Unless abroad they purchase great alliance?Fie, you confine yourself most unreasonably: come, you must go visit the good lady that lies in.Banish'd this frail sepulchre of our flesh, As now our flesh is banish'd from this land: Confess thy treasons ere thou fly the realm; Since thou hast far to go, bear not along The clogging burthen of a guilty soul.why, lady!Why, sir?Go, then my mother, to thy daughter go Make bold her bashful years with your experience; Prepare her ears to hear a wooer's tale Put in her tender heart the aspiring flame Of golden sovereignty; acquaint the princess With the sweet silent hours of marriage joys And when this arm of mine hath chastised The petty rebel, dull-brain'd Buckingham, Bound with triumphant garlands will I come And lead thy daughter to a conqueror's bed; To whom I will retail my conquest won, And she shall be sole victress, Caesar's Caesar.O thou damnable fellow!Is't not Hortensio?To tell thee plain, I aim to lie with thee.Come, let's away.If, by the tribunes' leave, and yours, good people, I may be heard, I would crave a word or two; The which shall turn you to no further harm Than so much loss of time.O shut the door!At Antium.Now the condition.Farewell, ancient lady; farewell, 'lady, lady, lady.'And let them die that age and sullens have; For both hast thou, and both become the grave.Come, come, peace.His name that valiant duke hath left with thee; His dukedom and his chair with me is left.Well, death's the end of all.thy canopy is dust and stones;-- Which with sweet water nightly I will dew, Or, wanting that, with tears distill'd by moans: The obsequies that I for thee will keep Nightly shall be to strew thy grave and weep.And am I then a man to be beloved?And so will I.I prithee tell me; cram's with praise, and make's As fat as tame things: one good deed dying tongueless Slaughters a thousand waiting upon that.'Tis he,'tis he: O, he is grown most kind of late.No, misery makes sport to mock itself: Since thou dost seek to kill my name in me, I mock my name, great king, to flatter thee.I'll be supposed upon a book, his face is the worst thing about him.Before the times of change, still is it so: By a divine instinct men's minds mistrust Ensuing dangers; as by proof, we see The waters swell before a boisterous storm.Swear not by time to come; for that thou hast Misused ere used, by time misused o'erpast.Rage must be withstood: Give me his gage: lions make leopards tame.How fiery and forward our pedant is!why, sir, what am I, sir, that I should knock you here, sir?O lamentable day!Nay, if thou be that princely eagle's bird, Show thy descent by gazing 'gainst the sun: For chair and dukedom, throne and kingdom say; Either that is thine, or else thou wert not his.Either I must, or have mine honour soil'd With the attainder of his slanderous lips.Satisfy!Thoughts tending to ambition, they do plot Unlikely wonders; how these vain weak nails May tear a passage through the flinty ribs Of this hard world, my ragged prison walls, And, for they cannot, die in their own pride.Third, or fourth, or fifth borough, I'll answer him by law: I'll not budge an inch, boy: let him come, and kindly.Be eloquent in my behalf to her.Weep, wretched man, I'll aid thee tear for tear; And let our hearts and eyes, like civil war, Be blind with tears, and break o'ercharged with grief.If I dare eat, or drink, or breathe, or live, I dare meet Surrey in a wilderness, And spit upon him, whilst I say he lies, And lies, and lies: there is my bond of faith, To tie thee to my strong correction.I do beseech you, either not believe The envious slanders of her false accusers; Or, if she be accused in true report, Bear with her weakness, which, I think proceeds From wayward sickness, and no grounded malice.We hate alike: Not Afric owns a serpent I abhor More than thy fame and envy.My lord the king, the king!Six frozen winter spent, Return with welcome home from banishment.Sham it be put to that?Amen!Where is that slave Which told me they had beat you to your trenches?He would be drunk too; that let me inform you.Are you contented to resign the crown?So two, together weeping, make one woe.Marry, that 'marry' is the very theme I came to talk of.strike!Madam, your mother craves a word with you.At Southam I did leave him with his forces, And do expect him here some two hours hence.not for all this land Would I be guilty of so deep a sin.Since thou dost give me pains, Let me remember thee what thou hast promised, Which is not yet perform'd me.go to.Ah, Warwick, Warwick!No, mighty liege; therefore mistrust me not.I come To answer thy best pleasure; be't to fly, To swim, to dive into the fire, to ride On the curl'd clouds, to thy strong bidding task Ariel and all his quality.but that will never be I fear our happiness is at the highest.Off goes his bonnet to an oyster-wench; A brace of draymen bid God speed him well And had the tribute of his supple knee, With 'Thanks, my countrymen, my loving friends;' As were our England in reversion his, And he our subjects' next degree in hope.Be you content, fair maid; It is the law, not I condemn your brother: Were he my kinsman, brother, or my son, It should be thus with him: he must die tomorrow.Leave me, or tarry, Edward will be king, And not be tied unto his brother's will.Are there no other tokens Between you 'greed concerning her observance?How now, wife!Here is everything advantageous to life.As for the brat of this accursed duke, Whose father slew my father, he shall die.Will't not off?Mark what mercy his mother shall bring from him: there is no more mercy in him than there is milk in a male tiger; that shall our poor city find: and all this is long of you.If his own life answer the straitness of his proceeding, it shall become him well; wherein if he chance to fail, he hath sentenced himself.now arms must rule.Well, your imprisonment shall not be long; Meantime, have patience.Six or seven thousand is their utmost power.The first that there did greet my stranger soul, Was my great father-in-law, renowned Warwick; Who cried aloud, 'What scourge for perjury Can this dark monarchy afford false Clarence?'stand'st out?By so much is the wonder in extremes.Come, cousin Angelo; In this I'll be impartial; be you judge Of your own cause.Your husband, being troubled with a shrew, Measures my husband's sorrow by his woe: And now you know my meaning, A very mean meaning.My mother bows; As if Olympus to a molehill should In supplication nod: and my young boy Hath an aspect of intercession, which Great nature cries 'Deny not.'Is't not drowned i' the last rain, ha?Whither wilt thou go?Dost thou think, Claudio?All this I know; and to the marriage Her nurse is privy: and, if aught in this Miscarried by my fault, let my old life Be sacrificed, some hour before his time, Unto the rigour of severest law.He will hear none: he hath evermore had the liberty of the prison; give him leave to escape hence, he would not: drunk many times a day, if not many days entirely drunk.The doubt is that he will seduce the rest.All hope is gone, Unless you have the grace by your fair prayer To soften Angelo: and that's my pith of business 'Twixt you and your poor brother.Thinkest thou, Hortensio, though her father be very rich, any man is so very a fool to be married to hell?The commons hath he pill'd with grievous taxes, And quite lost their hearts: the nobles hath he fined For ancient quarrels, and quite lost their hearts.By'r lady, thirty years.Good my lord, be cured Of this diseased opinion, and betimes; For 'tis most dangerous.Despising, For you, the city, thus I turn my back: There is a world elsewhere.Gentlemen, go, muster up your men, And meet me presently at Berkeley.I come, I come!What foul play had we, that we came from thence?A cockatrice hast thou hatch'd to the world, Whose unavoided eye is murderous.O, good madam, there can be none yet.Hark, how they knock!How now!Moved!and how his pity Does my deeds make the blacker!Hang, cur!As I bethink me, you should not be king Till our King Henry had shook hands with death.The heads of the maids?Constable, what say you to it?Are you now going to dispatch this deed?lover!O dear account!Verily, I do not jest with you; there came news from him last night.From whence?Come, Escalus, You must walk by us on our other hand; And good supporters are you.This deserves death.Now, you companion, I'll say an errand for you: You shall know now that I am in estimation; you shall perceive that a Jack guardant cannot office me from my son Coriolanus: guess, but by my entertainment with him, if thou standest not i' the state of hanging, or of some death more long in spectatorship, and crueller in suffering; behold now presently, and swoon for what's to come upon thee.Now thou'rt troublesome.I pray thee, stay a while: I hope my holy humour will change; 'twas wont to hold me but while one would tell twenty.And I unto the sea from whence I came.King Edward, valiant Richard, Montague, Stay we no longer, dreaming of renown, But sound the trumpets, and about our task.And here I take the unfeigned oath, Never to marry with her though she would entreat: Fie on her!He hath no friends but who are friends for fear.For ever Unvenerable be thy hands, if thou Takest up the princess by that forced baseness Which he has put upon't!Is the axe upon the block, sirrah?why, happy man be's dole!Darest thou die?A beggar, brother?Unless his noble mother, and his wife; Who, as I hear, mean to solicit him For mercy to his country.And shall have your will, because our king: Yet hasty marriage seldom proveth well.I pray, awake, sir: if you love the maid, Bend thoughts and wits to achieve her.I have been studying how I may compare This prison where I live unto the world: And for because the world is populous And here is not a creature but myself, I cannot do it; yet I'll hammer it out.Which the rather We shall be blest to do, if he remember A kinder value of the people than He hath hereto prized them at.thy horses shall be trapp'd, Their harness studded all with gold and pearl.We may live, son, to shed many more.But one, poor one, one poor and loving child, But one thing to rejoice and solace in, And cruel death hath catch'd it from my sight!That cannot be; the noise of thy cross-bow Will scare the herd, and so my shoot is lost.The same, sir.fie, you slug-a-bed!The gods preserve our noble tribunes!You mar our labour: keep your cabins: you do assist the storm.A widow, then?pluck but off these rags; and then, death, death!I did but tell her she mistook her frets, And bow'd her hand to teach her fingering; When, with a most impatient devilish spirit, 'Frets, call you these?'Three, my most gracious lord.Queen Margaret, Prince Edward, and Oxford, Vouchsafe, at our request, to stand aside, While I use further conference with Warwick.Too familiar Is my dear son with such sour company: I bring thee tidings of the prince's doom.what doth he with a bond That he is bound to?Unreasonable creatures feed their young; And though man's face be fearful to their eyes, Yet, in protection of their tender ones, Who hath not seen them, even with those wings Which sometime they have used with fearful flight, Make war with him that climb'd unto their nest, Offer their own lives in their young's defence?Come, let's not weep.True, too true, my lord: If, one by one, you wedded all the world, Or from the all that are took something good, To make a perfect woman, she you kill'd Would be unparallel'd.For what?Ask Marian Hacket, the fat ale-wife of Wincot, if she know me not: if she say I am not fourteen pence on the score for sheer ale, score me up for the lyingest knave in Christendom.Merciful Heaven, Thou rather with thy sharp and sulphurous bolt Split'st the unwedgeable and gnarled oak Than the soft myrtle: but man, proud man, Drest in a little brief authority, Most ignorant of what he's most assured, His glassy essence, like an angry ape, Plays such fantastic tricks before high heaven As make the angels weep; who, with our spleens, Would all themselves laugh mortal.Dare he presume to scorn us in this manner?A deflower'd maid!You'll kiss me hard and speak to me as if I were a baby still.Fie, what an indirect and peevish course Is this of hers!Then, in the name of God and all these rights, Advance your standards, draw your willing swords.The old cock.Knock, sir!To take is not to give.Thomas the Earl of Surrey, and himself, Much about cock-shut time, from troop to troop Went through the army, cheering up the soldiers.Come, now towards Chertsey with your holy load, Taken from Paul's to be interred there; And still, as you are weary of the weight, Rest you, whiles I lament King Henry's corse.Unless philosophy can make a Juliet, Displant a town, reverse a prince's doom, It helps not, it prevails not: talk no more.What satisfaction canst thou have to-night?Nay, gentlemen, prepare not to be gone; We have a trifling foolish banquet towards.Why, a horse.then true noblesse would Learn him forbearance from so foul a wrong.We shall entreat you to abide here till he come and enforce them against him: we shall find this friar a notable fellow.She had; and would incense me To murder her I married.Whence are you, sir?Bring me to hear them speak, where I may be concealed.Hadst thou been meek, our title still had slept; And we, in pity of the gentle king, Had slipp'd our claim until another age.I took him for the plainest harmless creature That breathed upon this earth a Christian; Made him my book wherein my soul recorded The history of all her secret thoughts: So smooth he daub'd his vice with show of virtue, That, his apparent open guilt omitted, I mean, his conversation with Shore's wife, He lived from all attainder of suspect.Away!Sound drums and trumpets!The day frowns more and more: thou'rt like to have A lullaby too rough: I never saw The heavens so dim by day.Prithee, son, do; for we must be gentle, now we are gentlemen.Not a soul But felt a fever of the mad and play'd Some tricks of desperation.Wrong not her birth, she is of royal blood.Your affairs there, what, with whom, the condition of that fardel, the place of your dwelling, your names, your ages, of what having, breeding, and any thing that is fitting to be known, discover.True.You weary those that refresh us: pray, let's see these four threes of herdsmen.O excellent devise!Good morrow, neighbour Baptista.There was casting up of eyes, holding up of hands, with countenances of such distraction that they were to be known by garment, not by favour.Is there not milking-time, when you are going to bed, or kiln-hole, to whistle off these secrets, but you must be tittle-tattling before all our guests?And I for winking at your discords too Have lost a brace of kinsmen: all are punish'd.And you, enchantment.-- Worthy enough a herdsman: yea, him too, That makes himself, but for our honour therein, Unworthy thee,--if ever henceforth thou These rural latches to his entrance open, Or hoop his body more with thy embraces, I will devise a death as cruel for thee As thou art tender to't.Do, good my lord, your citizens entreat you.A gentler judgment vanish'd from his lips, Not body's death, but body's banishment.Will not the mayor then and his brethren come?No, not till Thursday; there is time enough.Thou hast a grim appearance, and thy face Bears a command in't; though thy tackle's torn.her father's brother Would be her lord?From thee, even from thy virtue!In God's name, speak: when is the royal day?If thou remember'st aught ere thou camest here, How thou camest here thou mayst.Wend you with this letter: Command these fretting waters from your eyes With a light heart; trust not my holy order, If I pervert your course.I'll wait upon your honour.If not, why cease you till you are so?His bloody brow!O, he's a lovely gentleman!He was torn to pieces with a bear: this avouches the shepherd's son; who has not only his innocence, which seems much, to justify him, but a handkerchief and rings of his that Paulina knows.There's time enough for that; Lest they desire upon this push to trouble Your joys with like relation.Take not, good cousin, further than you should.Think but upon the wrong he did us all, And that will quickly dry thy melting tears.And that his bags shall prove.Bear the boy hence; he shall not come about her; Away with him!O, good!Tut, she's a lamb, a dove, a fool to him!Even in condition of the worst degree, In gross rebellion and detested treason: Thou art a banish'd man, and here art come Before the expiration of thy time, In braving arms against thy sovereign.Let's take leave of him.Here, sirrah Grumio; knock, I say.But wherefore dost thou come?My gracious lord, I come but for mine own.Now thy proud neck bears half my burthen'd yoke; From which even here I slip my weary neck, And leave the burthen of it all on thee.By such despair, I should accuse myself.Stay, madam; I must speak a word with you.take that, to end thy agony.which of your hips has the most profound sciatica?I leave your honours.Lay hands upon him, And bear him to the rock.You, sir, come you hither; You that have been so tenderly officious With Lady Margery, your midwife there, To save this bastard's life,--for 'tis a bastard, So sure as this beard's grey, --what will you adventure To save this brat's life?And what to?O lady Fortune, Stand you auspicious!Did not I pluck thee by the nose for thy speeches?She hath prevented me.O true apothecary!That's a brave fellow; but he's vengeance proud, and loves not the common people.But for a kingdom any oath may be broken: I would break a thousand oaths to reign one year.Go on, and fetch our horses back again.And for these great affairs do ask some charge, Towards our assistance we do seize to us The plate, corn, revenues and moveables, Whereof our uncle Gaunt did stand possess'd.Shrug'st thou, malice?The wanton Edward, and the lusty George?Spake you not these words plain, 'Sirrah, knock me here, rap me here, knock me well, and knock me soundly'?it is so very very late, That we may call it early by and by.You are welcome, sir.Not to relent is beastly, savage, devilish.Now it's twenty-seven: every gash was an enemy's grave.Mistake no more: I am not Licio, Nor a musician, as I seem to be; But one that scorn to live in this disguise, For such a one as leaves a gentleman, And makes a god of such a cullion: Know, sir, that I am call'd Hortensio.Northumberland, then present, wept to see it.The maid will I frame and make fit for his attempt.Therefore-- O, let me pray before I take my death!In vain thou speak'st, poor boy; my father's blood Hath stopp'd the passage where thy words should enter.for all your friends are fled, And Warwick rages like a chafed bull: Away!My fair Bianca, bid my father welcome, While I with self-same kindness welcome thine.Nor did you think it folly To keep your great pretences veil'd till when They needs must show themselves; which in the hatching, It seem'd, appear'd to Rome.This day's black fate on more days doth depend; This but begins the woe, others must end.and gaze your fill.Well, Wednesday is too soon, O' Thursday let it be: o' Thursday, tell her, She shall be married to this noble earl.O blessed heavens!Alack, there lies more peril in thine eye
