Than twenty of their swords: look thou but sweet, And I am proof against their enmity.Is leaning cheek to cheek?Withdraw yourselves, and leave us here alone.Counsel me, Tranio, for I know thou canst; Assist me, Tranio, for I know thou wilt.Sir, spare your threats: The bug which you would fright me with I seek.Go do it instantly.And to behold his sway, I will, as 'twere a brother of your order, Visit both prince and people: therefore, I prithee, Supply me with the habit and instruct me How I may formally in person bear me Like a true friar.All-hallond eve.Methinks a woman of this valiant spirit Should, if a coward heard her speak these words, Infuse his breast with magnanimity And make him, naked, foil a man at arms.And may you prove, sir, master of your art!Sirrah, leave us to ourselves: we must confer.Is she your cousin?To please the king I did; to please myself I cannot do it; yet I know no cause Why I should welcome such a guest as grief, Save bidding farewell to so sweet a guest As my sweet Richard: yet again, methinks, Some unborn sorrow, ripe in fortune's womb, Is coming towards me, and my inward soul With nothing trembles: at some thing it grieves, More than with parting from my lord the king.Then thus I turn me from my country's light, To dwell in solemn shades of endless night.Last night, I hear, they lay at Northampton; At Stony-Stratford will they be to-night: To-morrow, or next day, they will be here.O heavens!But that a joy past joy calls out on me, It were a grief, so brief to part with thee: Farewell.Go, after, after, cousin Buckingham.Marcius, 'tis true that you have lately told us; The Volsces are in arms.No longer stay.A most royal one; the centurions and their charges, distinctly billeted, already in the entertainment, and to be on foot at an hour's warning.'Tis but thy name that is my enemy; Thou art thyself, though not a Montague.Was it not to refresh the mind of man After his studies or his usual pain?Our very priests must become mockers, if they shall encounter such ridiculous subjects as you are.No, good-faced sir; no, sweet sir.I pray now, call her.If thou deny, their blood upon thy head; For York in justice puts his armour on.Is dead.We will not from the helm to sit and weep, But keep our course, though the rough wind say no, From shelves and rocks that threaten us with wreck.And, in this resolution, I defy thee; Not willing any longer conference, Since thou deniest the gentle king to speak.Yes, one place else, if you will hear me name it.For that I have not wash'd My nose that bled, or foil'd some debile wretch.-- Which, without note, here's many else have done,-- You shout me forth In acclamations hyperbolical; As if I loved my little should be dieted In praises sauced with lies.slave!Nay, whom they shall obey, and love thee too, Unless they seek for hatred at my hands; Which if they do, yet will I keep thee safe, And they shall feel the vengeance of my wrath.Yet shall you have all kindness at my hand That your estate requires and mine can yield.to safeguard thine own life, The best way is to venge my Gloucester's death.He ran this way, and leap'd this orchard wall: Call, good Mercutio.You have, my lord: would it might please your grace, At our entreaties, to amend that fault!Go see this rumourer whipp'd.Nay, I'll not warrant that; for I can speak Against the thing I say.A crack, madam.In my conscience, The heavens with that we have in hand are angry And frown upon 's.Tell me, daughter Juliet, How stands your disposition to be married?And mark how well the sequel hangs together: Eleven hours I spent to write it over, For yesternight by Catesby was it brought me; The precedent was full as long a-doing: And yet within these five hours lived Lord Hastings, Untainted, unexamined, free, at liberty Here's a good world the while!Lady, come from that nest Of death, contagion, and unnatural sleep: A greater power than we can contradict Hath thwarted our intents.Such duty as the subject owes the prince Even such a woman oweth to her husband; And when she is froward, peevish, sullen, sour, And not obedient to his honest will, What is she but a foul contending rebel And graceless traitor to her loving lord?How now, Catesby, what says your lord?For I have heard that she was there in place.Why, what need we Commune with you of this, but rather follow Our forceful instigation?Is Signior Lucentio within, sir?Seize on the shame-faced Henry, bear him hence; And once again proclaim us King of England.Sir, how comes't that you Have holp to make this rescue?Speak thou for me and tell them what I did.See, where he comes: so please you, step aside; I'll know his grievance, or be much denied.There is no world without Verona walls, But purgatory, torture, hell itself.Who calls so loud?Off with his son George's head!That she is living, Were it but told you, should be hooted at Like an old tale: but it appears she lives, Though yet she speak not.Sir, the people Must have their voices; neither will they bate One jot of ceremony.I'll have her; but I will not keep her long.Break up the seals and read.Give me the crown.my cousin Romeo!Go, get thee gone, thou false deluding slave, That feed'st me with the very name of meat: Sorrow on thee and all the pack of you, That triumph thus upon my misery!I cheer'd them up with justice of our cause, With promise of high pay and great rewards: But all in vain; they had no heart to fight, And we in them no hope to win the day; So that we fled; the king unto the queen; Lord George your brother, Norfolk and myself, In haste, post-haste, are come to join with you: For in the marches here we heard you were, Making another head to fight again.I am sorry, one so learned and so wise As you, Lord Angelo, have still appear'd, Should slip so grossly, both in the heat of blood.When you speak, sweet.Say, I, her sovereign, am her subject love.This letter he early bid me give his father, And threatened me with death, going in the vault, I departed not and left him there.I think she'll sooner prove a soldier Iron may hold with her, but never lutes.What's this?How would you be, If He, which is the top of judgment, should But judge you as you are?thou hast slept well; Awake!Say, then: 'tis true, I ought so.Death is my son-in-law, Death is my heir; My daughter he hath wedded: I will die, And leave him all; life, living, all is Death's.Why, every fault's condemn'd ere it be done: Mine were the very cipher of a function, To fine the faults whose fine stands in record, And let go by the actor.O, belike it is the Bishop of Carlisle.Day, yield me not thy light; nor, night, thy rest!No,'tis his kind of speech: he did not mock us.away with't!Shall I forget myself to be myself?Thou hast nor youth nor age, But, as it were, an after-dinner's sleep, Dreaming on both; for all thy blessed youth Becomes as aged, and doth beg the alms Of palsied eld; and when thou art old and rich, Thou hast neither heat, affection, limb, nor beauty, To make thy riches pleasant.Will not you go?Look not pale, Bianca; thy father will not frown.This news is mortal to the queen: look down And see what death is doing.The custom of request you have discharged: The people do admit you, and are summon'd To meet anon, upon your approbation.Cousin of Buckingham, a word with you.I talk of that, that know it.You take my part from me, sir; I have the most cause to be glad of yours.Say, she shall be a high and mighty queen.Ay, my good lord; and no one in this presence But his red colour hath forsook his cheeks.You're welcome, sir; and he, for your good sake.And reason too: Who should succeed the father but the son?what?Welcome from Mantua: what says Romeo?Peace be with you!What say you?He seems to be of great authority: close with him, give him gold; and though authority be a stubborn bear, yet he is oft led by the nose with gold: show the inside of your purse to the outside of his hand, and no more ado.Not speak?He--to give fear to use and liberty, Which have for long run by the hideous law, As mice by lions--hath pick'd out an act, Under whose heavy sense your brother's life Falls into forfeit: he arrests him on it; And follows close the rigour of the statute, To make him an example.So, underneath the belly of their steeds, That stain'd their fetlocks in his smoking blood, The noble gentleman gave up the ghost.He's a lamb indeed, that baes like a bear.A marvellous poor one.This man, whom hand to hand I slew in fight, May be possessed with some store of crowns; And I, that haply take them from him now, May yet ere night yield both my life and them To some man else, as this dead man doth me.let's talk; it is not day.Be he the fire, I'll be the yielding water: The rage be his, whilst on the earth I rain My waters; on the earth, and not on him.He misses not much.How likes Gremio these quick-witted folks?Exton, I thank thee not; for thou hast wrought A deed of slander with thy fatal hand Upon my head and all this famous land.I ne'er heard yet That any of these bolder vices wanted Less impudence to gainsay what they did Than to perform it first.what a fool Honesty is!none of you but is Able to bear against the great Aufidius A shield as hard as his.What, sovereign sir, I did not well I meant well.Will't please your honour taste of these conserves?wilt thou kneel for grace, And set thy diadem upon my head; Or bide the mortal fortune of the field?Tell me, thou villain slave, where are my children?With Rosaline, my ghostly father?Thou chid'st me oft for loving Rosaline.Hang 'em!Come hither, Isabel.How!Cursed be the hand that made these fatal holes!But mark how heavily this befell to the poor gentlewoman: there she lost a noble and renowned brother, in his love toward her ever most kind and natural; with him, the portion and sinew of her fortune, her marriage-dowry; with both, her combinate husband, this well-seeming Angelo.Yes; if there were no other excuse why they should desire to live.Tell me, moreover, hast thou sounded him, If he appeal the duke on ancient malice; Or worthily, as a good subject should, On some known ground of treachery in him?He is not lolling on a lewd day-bed, But on his knees at meditation; Not dallying with a brace of courtezans, But meditating with two deep divines; Not sleeping, to engross his idle body, But praying, to enrich his watchful soul: Happy were England, would this gracious prince Take on himself the sovereignty thereof: But, sure, I fear, we shall ne'er win him to it.Truly, sir, in my poor opinion, they will to't then.Come, boy; I am past moe children, but thy sons and daughters will be all gentlemen born.'Tis beauty that doth oft make women proud; But, God he knows, thy share thereof is small: 'Tis virtue that doth make them most admired; The contrary doth make thee wonder'd at: 'Tis government that makes them seem divine; The want thereof makes thee abominable: Thou art as opposite to every good As the Antipodes are unto us, Or as the south to the septentrion.Plantagenet shall speak first: hear him, lords; And be you silent and attentive too, For he that interrupts him shall not live.Sir, go you in; and, madam, go with him; And go, Sir Paris; every one prepare To follow this fair corse unto her grave: The heavens do lour upon you for some ill; Move them no more by crossing their high will.But yet, Paulina, Hermione was not so much wrinkled, nothing So aged as this seems.Spies of the Volsces Held me in chase, that I was forced to wheel Three or four miles about, else had I, sir, Half an hour since brought my report.Very true, and but a month old.Brother Petruchio, sister Katharina, And thou, Hortensio, with thy loving widow, Feast with the best, and welcome to my house: My banquet is to close our stomachs up, After our great good cheer.He hath a garden circummured with brick, Whose western side is with a vineyard back'd; And to that vineyard is a planched gate, That makes his opening with this bigger key: This other doth command a little door Which from the vineyard to the garden leads; There have I made my promise Upon the heavy middle of the night To call upon him.My nobler friends, I crave their pardons: For the mutable, rank-scented many, let them Regard me as I do not flatter, and Therein behold themselves: I say again, In soothing them, we nourish 'gainst our senate The cockle of rebellion, insolence, sedition, Which we ourselves have plough'd for, sow'd, and scatter'd, By mingling them with us, the honour'd number, Who lack not virtue, no, nor power, but that Which they have given to beggars.O, give me pardon, That I, your vassal, have employ'd and pain'd Your unknown sovereignty!That same villain, Romeo.We'll touse you Joint by joint, but we will know his purpose.Myself, a prince by fortune of my birth, Near to the king in blood, and near in love Till you did make him misinterpret me, Have stoop'd my neck under your injuries, And sigh'd my English breath in foreign clouds, Eating the bitter bread of banishment; Whilst you have fed upon my signories, Dispark'd my parks and fell'd my forest woods, From my own windows torn my household coat, Razed out my imprese, leaving me no sign, Save men's opinions and my living blood, To show the world I am a gentleman.But is this true, sir?But you will take exceptions to my boon.My poverty, but not my will, consents.art thou led in triumph?Mine own desert.O Lord, they fight!Take him up.Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?And be a happy mother by the deed.And now, I pray you, sir, For still 'tis beating in my mind, your reason For raising this sea-storm?Good my lord, She came from Libya.Dost thou not bring me letters from the friar?Edward thy son, which now is Prince of Wales, For Edward my son, which was Prince of Wales, Die in his youth by like untimely violence!The fitter for the King of heaven, that hath him.What may she not?A right good mark-man!Please you to do't, I'll take it as a peril to my soul, It is no sin at all, but charity.Provost?Holla, ho!what wouldst thou?Whither away?The king is come: deal mildly with his youth; For young hot colts being raged do rage the more.Ay, here's a deer whose skin's a keeper's fee: This is the quondam king; let's seize upon him.By yond clouds, Let me deserve so ill as you, and make me Your fellow tribune.I am sorry for't: All faults I make, when I shall come to know them, I do repent.But how is it that great Plantagenet Is crown'd so soon, and broke his solemn oath?They say it is a copy out of mine.But what talk I of this?But stay, here come the gardeners: Let's step into the shadow of these trees.look upon his face; His eyes do drop no tears, his prayers are in jest; His words come from his mouth, ours from our breast: He prays but faintly and would be denied; We pray with heart and soul and all beside: His weary joints would gladly rise, I know; Our knees shall kneel till to the ground they grow: His prayers are full of false hypocrisy; Ours of true zeal and deep integrity.Some troops pursue the bloody-minded queen, That led calm Henry, though he were a king, As doth a sail, fill'd with a fretting gust, Command an argosy to stem the waves.Ah sir!O Jupiter, no blood!whom should I knock?'My daughter.'Lift up thy looks: From my succession wipe me, father; I Am heir to my affection.Marry, my lord, lest, by a multitude, The new-heal'd wound of malice should break out, Which would be so much the more dangerous By how much the estate is green and yet ungovern'd: Where every horse bears his commanding rein, And may direct his course as please himself, As well the fear of harm, as harm apparent, In my opinion, ought to be prevented.Alack, for mercy!Ay, that the king is dead.'Tis even so; yet you are Warwick still.I know them both.Look you, sir, here is the hand and seal of the duke: you know the character, I doubt not; and the signet is not strange to you.nay, bigger; women grow by men.Why, how now, dame!See here these movers that do prize their hours At a crack'd drachm!And pluck the mangled Tybalt from his shroud?Was he met there?Nay, I have ta'en you napping, gentle love, And have forsworn you with Hortensio.Mine innocency and Saint George to thrive!Come, you promised me a tawdry-lace and a pair of sweet gloves.No!O gentle villain, do not turn away!In some sort, sir: but though my case be a pitiful one, I hope I shall not be flayed out of it.Remember, as thou read'st, thy promise pass'd: I do repent me; read not my name there My heart is not confederate with my hand.And that is more than I will yield unto: I know I am too mean to be your queen, And yet too good to be your concubine.we are spoiled and--yonder he is: deny him, forswear him, or else we are all undone.I am sorry that such sorrow I procure: And so deep sticks it in my penitent heart That I crave death more willingly than mercy; 'Tis my deserving, and I do entreat it.I beseech your highness, do not marry me to a whore.Even so thy breast encloseth my poor heart; Wear both of them, for both of them are thine.But leave we him to his events, with a prayer they may prove prosperous; and let me desire to know how you find Claudio prepared.I'll claim that promise at your grace's hands.Thou art the list.And were the king on't, what would I do?I am his cupbearer: If from me he have wholesome beverage, Account me not your servant.How blest am I In my just censure, in my true opinion!Tut, tut, Thou troublest me; am not in the vein.First, he commends him to your noble lordship.Besides, the penitent king, my master, hath sent for me; to whose feeling sorrows I might be some allay, or I o'erween to think so, which is another spur to my departure.I say, without characters, fame lives long.I am unfit for state and majesty; I do beseech you, take it not amiss; I cannot nor I will not yield to you.For here, I hope, begins our lasting joy.Fear o'ershades me: Good expedition be my friend, and comfort The gracious queen, part of his theme, but nothing Of his ill-ta'en suspicion!But once before I spoke to the purpose: when?Thou'rt by no means valiant; For thou dost fear the soft and tender fork Of a poor worm.This is another prisoner that I saved.I pray God he be not, I say.Swell'st thou, proud heart?A witty mother!I see this is the time that the unjust man doth thrive.He would not seem to know me.But O, the noble combat that 'twixt joy and sorrow was fought in Paulina!'Brutus!'That he was never trained up in arms.I am glad at heart To be so rid o' the business.Well, girl, thou weep'st not so much for his death, As that the villain lives which slaughter'd him.The lining of his coffers shall make coats To deck our soldiers for these Irish wars.Ay me!Never saw I Wretches so quake: they kneel, they kiss the earth; Forswear themselves as often as they speak: Bohemia stops his ears, and threatens them With divers deaths in death.A boy?What stars do spangle heaven with such beauty, As those two eyes become that heavenly face?You are at point to lose your liberties: Marcius would have all from you; Marcius, Whom late you have named for consul.No, wrangling woman, we'll no longer stay: These words will cost ten thousand lives this day.After I have done what I promised?Ha, ha!I sell thee poison; thou hast sold me none.Where's Romeo's man?The duke, I say to thee again, would eat mutton on Fridays.But thou preferr'st thy life before thine honour: And seeing thou dost, I here divorce myself Both from thy table, Henry, and thy bed, Until that act of parliament be repeal'd Whereby my son is disinherited.Now would I give a thousand furlongs of sea for an acre of barren ground, long heath, brown furze, any thing.My brother had but justice, In that he did the thing for which he died: For Angelo, His act did not o'ertake his bad intent, And must be buried but as an intent That perish'd by the way: thoughts are no subjects; Intents but merely thoughts.They mock thee, Clifford: swear as thou wast wont.No more, but that you read These accusations and these grievous crimes Committed by your person and your followers Against the state and profit of this land; That, by confessing them, the souls of men May deem that you are worthily deposed.'Tis well; and I have met a gentleman Hath promised me to help me to another, A fine musician to instruct our mistress; So shall I no whit be behind in duty To fair Bianca, so beloved of me.Mine ears against your suits are stronger than Your gates against my force.Strike the drum.convey?Lay it by too: another.Sirrah, go see what trumpet 'tis that sounds: Belike, some noble gentleman that means, Travelling some journey, to repose him here.Show those things you found about her, those secret things, all but what she has with her: this being done, let the law go whistle: I warrant you.Hear you this Triton of the minnows?Why, bishop, is Norfolk dead?What!Well then, I pray, your price o' the consulship?Come, come, we fear the worst; all shall be well.Worthy man!Call help.O, did you so?You will think you have made no offence, if the duke avouch the justice of your dealing?Lords, will you go with us?Cousin of Exeter, what thinks your lordship?Wondrous!Good father, I beseech you on my knees, Hear me with patience but to speak a word.Well, let that pass.Pray, Master Barnardine, awake till you are executed, and sleep afterwards.Pretty too!a devil.This is a strange abuse.Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus!I yield all this; But for some other reasons, my grave sir, Which 'tis not fit you know, I not acquaint My father of this business.Nay, speak thy mind; and let him ne'er speak more That speaks thy words again to do thee harm!'Twas you we laughed at.Welcome, my lord how far off lies your power?I' faith, I am sorry that thou art not well.I know it; And my pretext to strike at him admits A good construction.Where's Caius Marcius?Call Coriolanus.and when thou hast done so, Come weep with me; past hope, past cure, past help!The measure done, I'll watch her place of stand, And, touching hers, make blessed my rude hand.Patience, I pray you; 'twas a fault unwilling.Rumour it abroad That Anne, my wife, is sick and like to die: I will take order for her keeping close.She, Claudio, that you wrong'd, look you restore.And then for the land-service, to see how the bear tore out his shoulder-bone; how he cried to me for help and said his name was Antigonus, a nobleman.O Perdita, what have we twain forgot!He came with flowers to strew his lady's grave; And bid me stand aloof, and so I did: Anon comes one with light to ope the tomb; And by and by my master drew on him; And then I ran away to call the watch.Signior Baptista, you are happily met.Long mayst thou live in Richard's seat to sit, And soon lie Richard in an earthly pit!How brooks your grace the air, After your late tossing on the breaking seas?Hie to high fortune!Madam, so thrive I in my enterprise And dangerous success of bloody wars, As I intend more good to you and yours, Than ever you or yours were by me wrong'd!I love a ballad but even too well, if it be doleful matter merrily set down, or a very pleasant thing indeed and sung lamentably.Part, fools!All the contagion of the south light on you, You shames of Rome!Whoever gave that counsel, to give forth The corn o' the storehouse gratis, as 'twas used Sometime in Greece,-- Well, well, no more of that.Only their ends You have respected; stopp'd your ears against The general suit of Rome; never admitted A private whisper, no, not with such friends That thought them sure of you.I am denied to sue my livery here, And yet my letters-patents give me leave: My father's goods are all distrain'd and sold, And these and all are all amiss employ'd.dare not!I not purpose it.Good, good my lord, bethink you; Who is it that hath died for this offence?I would you did but see how it chafes, how it rages, how it takes up the shore!What would you say?You shall not be The grave of your deserving; Rome must know The value of her own: 'twere a concealment Worse than a theft, no less than a traducement, To hide your doings; and to silence that, Which, to the spire and top of praises vouch'd, Would seem but modest: therefore, I beseech you In sign of what you are, not to reward What you have done--before our army hear me.Happy the parents of so fair a child; Happier the man, whom favourable stars Allot thee for his lovely bed-fellow!How should this grow?God save the king!they join, embrace, and seem to kiss, As if they vow'd some league inviolable: Now are they but one lamp, one light, one sun.And I, with grief and sorrow, to the court.He will do all in all as Hastings doth.I will bite thee by the ear for that jest.This is All-Souls' day, fellows, is it not?The bird that hath been limed in a bush, With trembling wings misdoubteth every bush; And I, the hapless male to one sweet bird, Have now the fatal object in my eye Where my poor young was limed, was caught and kill'd.Make peace with God, for you must die, my lord.Ay, as the rocks cheer them that fear their wreck: To see this sight, it irks my very soul.To whom should I complain?A woman, and thy aunt, great king; 'tis I. Speak with me, pity me, open the door.My lord, wise men ne'er sit and wail their woes, But presently prevent the ways to wail.Am I not wise?To do that office of thine own good will Which tired majesty did make thee offer, The resignation of thy state and crown To Henry Bolingbroke.This man, Aufidius, Was my beloved in Rome: yet thou behold'st!Away with her to prison!Who knows not that?Amen, amen!I will away towards Barnet presently, And bid thee battle, Edward, if thou darest.What, is my daughter gone to Friar Laurence?These proclamations, So forcing faults upon Hermione, I little like.how should you govern any kingdom, That know not how to use ambassadors, Nor how to be contented with one wife, Nor how to use your brothers brotherly, Nor how to study for the people's welfare, Nor how to shroud yourself from enemies?I will go darkly to work with her.What sayest thou?I am too bold, 'tis not to me she speaks: Two of the fairest stars in all the heaven, Having some business, do entreat her eyes To twinkle in their spheres till they return.Yet I have faced it with a card of ten.Very foul.Why, how now, Claudio!Cancel his bond of life, dear God, I prey, That I may live to say, The dog is dead!Or shall we play the wantons with our woes, And make some pretty match with shedding tears?Here comes Romeo, here comes Romeo.Resolved.To men in joy; but grief makes one hour ten.Uncertain way of gain!Boy, let me see the writing.And, ere my knee rise from the earth's cold face, I throw my hands, mine eyes, my heart to thee, Thou setter up and plucker down of kings, Beseeching thee, if with they will it stands That to my foes this body must be prey, Yet that thy brazen gates of heaven may ope, And give sweet passage to my sinful soul!A' has a little gall'd me, I confess; And, as the jest did glance away from me, 'Tis ten to one it maim'd you two outright.Gentlemen, forward to the bridal dinner: I see a woman may be made a fool, If she had not a spirit to resist.Such hope have all the line of John of Gaunt!Certainly, sir, I can.Sir, I hope My words disbench'd you not.he turned me about with his finger and his thumb, as one would set up a top.Upon mine honour, thou shalt marry her.A torch for me: let wantons light of heart Tickle the senseless rushes with their heels, For I am proverb'd with a grandsire phrase; I'll be a candle-holder, and look on.Upon my life, Petruchio means but well, Whatever fortune stays him from his word: Though he be blunt, I know him passing wise; Though he be merry, yet withal he's honest.No good at all that I can do for him; Unless you call it good to pity him, Bereft and gelded of his patrimony.lady!Come, let us sup betimes, that afterwards We may digest our complots in some form.what's i' the fardel?Peace, foolish woman.Who was so firm, so constant, that this coil Would not infect his reason?True; and therefore women, being the weaker vessels, are ever thrust to the wall: therefore I will push Montague's men from the wall, and thrust his maids to the wall.Another word, Menenius, I will not hear thee speak.Needs must I like it well: I weep for joy To stand upon my kingdom once again.No; For we were subjects but while you were king.who is within there?Go fetch him hither; let me look upon him.Yet blessing on his heart that gives it me!Very nobly Have you deserved: it is my father's music To speak your deeds, not little of his care To have them recompensed as thought on.take me with you, take me with you, wife.You have a son, Aumerle, my noble cousin; Had you first died, and he been thus trod down, He should have found his uncle Gaunt a father, To rouse his wrongs and chase them to the bay.Swear by this sword Thou wilt perform my bidding.Now, for this night, let's harbour here in York; And when the morning sun shall raise his car Above the border of this horizon, We'll forward towards Warwick and his mates; For well I wot that Henry is no soldier.Tell him, my mourning weeds are laid aside, And I am ready to put armour on.then he shall have no odds.Be of good cheer: mother, how fares your grace?If ancient sorrow be most reverend, Give mine the benefit of seniory, And let my woes frown on the upper hand.Nay, but I know 'tis so: I saw him arrested, saw him carried away; and, which is more, within these three days his head to be chopped off.Methinks I hear hither your husband's drum, See him pluck Aufidius down by the hair, As children from a bear, the Volsces shunning him: Methinks I see him stamp thus, and call thus: 'Come on, you cowards!What is that curt'sy worth?Bishop, farewell: shield thee from Warwick's frown; And pray that I may repossess the crown.Be of comfort; My father's of a better nature, sir, Than he appears by speech: this is unwonted Which now came from him.Here comes his servant: how now, Catesby, What says he?How oft when men are at the point of death Have they been merry!Richard hath best deserved of all my sons.So is it in the music of men's lives.Went they not quickly, I should die with laughing.then, God grant me too Thou mayst be damned for that wicked deed!She eat no meat to-day, nor none shall eat; Last night she slept not, nor to-night she shall not; As with the meat, some undeserved fault I'll find about the making of the bed; And here I'll fling the pillow, there the bolster, This way the coverlet, another way the sheets: Ay, and amid this hurly I intend That all is done in reverend care of her; And in conclusion she shall watch all night: And if she chance to nod I'll rail and brawl And with the clamour keep her still awake.How accompanied?Mercy on 's, a barne a very pretty barne!Weep thou for me in France, I for thee here; Better far off than near, be ne'er the near.Is she not down so late, or up so early?Yes, he would give't thee, from this rank offence, So to offend him still.Or, with the rest, where is your darling Rutland?As much to you, good sister!He received in the repulse of Tarquin seven hurts i' the body.Nay, bear three daughters: by your leave I speak it, You love the breeder better than the male.Here is the head; I'll carry it myself.Bliss be upon you!Look, as I blow this feather from my face, And as the air blows it to me again, Obeying with my wind when I do blow, And yielding to another when it blows, Commanded always by the greater gust; Such is the lightness of you common men.Whoever got thee, there thy mother stands; For, well I wot, thou hast thy mother's tongue.Why, therefore Warwick came to seek you out; And therefore comes my brother Montague.What makes this change?So that by this intelligence we learn The Welshmen are dispersed, and Salisbury Is gone to meet the king, who lately landed With some few private friends upon this coast.O thou mine heir Of Naples and of Milan, what strange fish Hath made his meal on thee?no regard?What, you mean my face?Where be these enemies?Deposed he shall be, in despite of all.here's a madman will murder me.I must hence to wait; I beseech you, follow straight.whence come you?Your friar is now your prince: as I was then Advertising and holy to your business, Not changing heart with habit, I am still Attorney'd at your service.Quick, dispatch, and send the head to Angelo.Tut, I have lost myself; I am not here; This is not Romeo, he's some other where.there's other business for thee: Come, thou tortoise!why the great toe?On me, whose all not equals Edward's moiety?Then in plain terms tell her my loving tale.I cannot do it to the gods; Must I then do't to them?The earth hath swallow'd all my hopes but she, She is the hopeful lady of my earth: But woo her, gentle Paris, get her heart, My will to her consent is but a part; An she agree, within her scope of choice Lies my consent and fair according voice.Hark!If any such be here--as God forbid!-- Let him depart before we need his help.No, Caius Marcius; I'll lean upon one crutch and fight with t'other, Ere stay behind this business.Why, Belman is as good as he, my lord; He cried upon it at the merest loss And twice to-day pick'd out the dullest scent: Trust me, I take him for the better dog.I have, my liege.Then plainly know my heart's dear love is set On the fair daughter of rich Capulet: As mine on hers, so hers is set on mine; And all combined, save what thou must combine By holy marriage: when and where and how We met, we woo'd and made exchange of vow, I'll tell thee as we pass; but this I pray, That thou consent to marry us to-day.Plantagenet.Nor night nor day no rest: it is but weakness To bear the matter thus; mere weakness.Though in this city he Hath widow'd and unchilded many a one, Which to this hour bewail the injury, Yet he shall have a noble memory.For God's sake, a pot of small ale.Adieu, sir.And, when thou wed'st, let sorrow haunt thy bed; And be thy wife--if any be so mad-- As miserable by the life of thee As thou hast made me by my dear lord's death!You knew my father well, and in him me, Left solely heir to all his lands and goods, Which I have better'd rather than decreased: Then tell me, if I get your daughter's love, What dowry shall I have with her to wife?Was never mother had so dear a loss!there's a French salutation to your French slop.How far is it to Berkeley?That I enjoy, being the queen thereof.Must I go show them my unbarbed sconce?Then, since this earth affords no joy to me, But to command, to cheque, to o'erbear such As are of better person than myself, I'll make my heaven to dream upon the crown, And, whiles I live, to account this world but hell, Until my mis-shaped trunk that bears this head Be round impaled with a glorious crown.Nay, take me with thee, good sweet Exeter: Not that I fear to stay, but love to go Whither the queen intends.Ah me!Our guider, come; to the Roman camp conduct us.Things for the cook, sir; but I know not what.Now, pious sir, You will demand of me why I do this?more dances my rapt heart Than when I first my wedded mistress saw Bestride my threshold.But 'tis a spirit.And, in good time, here comes the sweating lord.What course I mean to hold Shall nothing benefit your knowledge, nor Concern me the reporting.Why then, the beef, and let the mustard rest.We have: whereupon the Earl of Worcester Hath broke his staff, resign'd his stewardship, And all the household servants fled with him To Bolingbroke.Sir, I cannot tell: We must proceed as we do find the people.Who will believe thee, Isabel?It is not truer he is Angelo Than this is all as true as it is strange: Nay, it is ten times true; for truth is truth To the end of reckoning.You are like to do such business.By this hand, sir, his wife is a more respected person than any of us all.O woful time!O how that name befits my composition!It is a rupture that you may easily heal: and the cure of it not only saves your brother, but keeps you from dishonour in doing it.I'll gladly learn.Thou hast one son; for his sake pity me, Lest in revenge thereof, sith God is just, He be as miserably slain as I. Ah, let me live in prison all my days; And when I give occasion of offence, Then let me die, for now thou hast no cause.As you were past all shame,-- Those of your fact are so--so past all truth: Which to deny concerns more than avails; for as Thy brat hath been cast out, like to itself, No father owning it,--which is, indeed, More criminal in thee than it,--so thou Shalt feel our justice, in whose easiest passage Look for no less than death.Thou goest to Coventry, there to behold Our cousin Hereford and fell Mowbray fight: O, sit my husband's wrongs on Hereford's spear, That it may enter butcher Mowbray's breast!See, what a scourge is laid upon your hate, That heaven finds means to kill your joys with love.I show it most of all when I show justice; For then I pity those I do not know, Which a dismiss'd offence would after gall; And do him right that, answering one foul wrong, Lives not to act another.for he indeed Hath set the women on to this complaint: Your provost knows the place where he abides And he may fetch him.You say you do not know the lady's mind: Uneven is the course, I like it not.Seal up the mouth of outrage for a while, Till we can clear these ambiguities, And know their spring, their head, their true descent; And then will I be general of your woes, And lead you even to death: meantime forbear, And let mischance be slave to patience.If it be so, sir, that you are the man Must stead us all and me amongst the rest, And if you break the ice and do this feat, Achieve the elder, set the younger free For our access, whose hap shall be to have her Will not so graceless be to be ingrate.Five tribunes to defend their vulgar wisdoms, Of their own choice: one's Junius Brutus, Sicinius Velutus, and I know not--'Sdeath!Never crave him; we are definitive.What, marry, may she!Shall I be tempted to infringe my vow In the same time 'tis made?I am one of those; his mother, wife, his child, And this brave fellow too, we are the grains: You are the musty chaff; and you are smelt Above the moon: we must be burnt for you.Nay, let us share thy thoughts, as thou dost ours.Why, what is it, my lord?Ay, marry, sir, now looks he like a king!How say you?Ah, know you not the city favours them, And they have troops of soldiers at their beck?But, soft!Look, here's a letter from him: the state hath another, his wife another; and, I think, there's one at home for you.But how out of this can she avail?Unhappy fortune!You have received many wounds for your country.They shall stand for seed: they had gone down too, but that a wise burgher put in for them.Come on, my fellows: He that retires I'll take him for a Volsce, And he shall feel mine edge.It was the lark, the herald of the morn, No nightingale: look, love, what envious streaks Do lace the severing clouds in yonder east: Night's candles are burnt out, and jocund day Stands tiptoe on the misty mountain tops.Let but your honour know, Whom I believe to be most strait in virtue, That, in the working of your own affections, Had time cohered with place or place with wishing, Or that the resolute acting of your blood Could have attain'd the effect of your own purpose, Whether you had not sometime in your life Err'd in this point which now you censure him, And pull'd the law upon you.Because that, like a Jack, thou keep'st the stroke Betwixt thy begging and my meditation.marry, God forbid!My lord, the mayor of London comes to greet you.I did but dream.Well, well, he was the covert'st shelter'd traitor That ever lived.Let's make the best of it.More health and happiness betide my liege Than can my care-tuned tongue deliver him!What his happier affairs may be, are to me unknown: but I have missingly noted, he is of late much retired from court and is less frequent to his princely exercises than formerly he hath appeared.I pray you, sir, is it your will To make a stale of me amongst these mates?Sir, here's the door, this is Lucentio's house: My father's bears more toward the market-place; Thither must I, and here I leave you, sir.O, he was gentle, mild, and virtuous!Gentlemen, God save you.They call for dates and quinces in the pastry.Good uncle, let this end where it begun; We'll calm the Duke of Norfolk, you your son.That may be, sir, when I may be a wife.Your brother's death, I know, sits at your heart; And you may marvel why I obscured myself, Labouring to save his life, and would not rather Make rash remonstrance of my hidden power Than let him so be lost.Methought I saw a thousand fearful wrecks; Ten thousand men that fishes gnaw'd upon; Wedges of gold, great anchors, heaps of pearl, Inestimable stones, unvalued jewels, All scatter'd in the bottom of the sea: Some lay in dead men's skulls; and, in those holes Where eyes did once inhabit, there were crept, As 'twere in scorn of eyes, reflecting gems, Which woo'd the slimy bottom of the deep, And mock'd the dead bones that lay scatter'd by.Ay, so we will.Aged sir, hands off.Howsoever you have been his liar, as you say you have, I am one that, telling true under him, must say, you cannot pass.Heavens bless my lord from fell Aufidius!Now, sir, how do you find the prisoner?Come, come, you're mocking: we will have no telling.I'll have you talked with anon.Blow, till thou burst thy wind, if room enough!Do not weep, good fools; There is no cause: when you shall know your mistress Has deserved prison, then abound in tears As I come out: this action I now go on Is for my better grace.Nay, but, fellow, fellow,-- What's the matter?Comfort, my liege; why looks your grace so pale?With love's light wings did I o'er-perch these walls; For stony limits cannot hold love out, And what love can do that dares love attempt; Therefore thy kinsmen are no let to me.Adieu, adieu!Here are the keys, there sits the duke asleep: I'll to the king; and signify to him That thus I have resign'd my charge to you.Were he not warm'd with ale, This were a bed but cold to sleep so soundly.I am not bestraught: here's-- O, this it is that makes your lady mourn!O, who can hold a fire in his hand By thinking on the frosty Caucasus?thy intention stabs the centre: Thou dost make possible things not so held, Communicatest with dreams;--how can this be?-- With what's unreal thou coactive art, And fellow'st nothing: then 'tis very credent Thou mayst co-join with something; and thou dost, And that beyond commission, and I find it, And that to the infection of my brains And hardening of my brows.whose rage doth rend Like interrupted waters and o'erbear What they are used to bear.Look I so pale, Lord Dorset, as the rest?Resume that spirit, when you were wont to say, If you had been the wife of Hercules, Six of his labours you'ld have done, and saved Your husband so much sweat.Think you so, sir?Worthy Cominius, speak.The glorious gods sit in hourly synod about thy particular prosperity, and love thee no worse than thy old father Menenius does!Who hath descried the number of the foe?methought, what pain it was to drown!On Wednesday next we solemnly set down Our coronation: lords, prepare yourselves.What, with my tongue in your tail?Sir, to satisfy you in what I have said, Stand by and mark the manner of his teaching.Stars, stars, And all eyes else dead coals!Show him our commission; talk no more.Do you persuade yourself that I respect you?Things have fall'n out, sir, so unluckily, That we have had no time to move our daughter: Look you, she loved her kinsman Tybalt dearly, And so did I:--Well, we were born to die.I fear it is too choleric a meat.O happy dagger!'Tis not his new-made bride shall succor him: And as for Clarence, as my letters tell me, He's very likely now to fall from him, For matching more for wanton lust than honour, Or than for strength and safety of our country.Then never man was true.as sweet repose and rest Come to thy heart as that within my breast!Wherefore?and, lords, bow low to him: Hold you his hands, whilst I do set it on.Thy garments are not spotted with our blood, Nor thou within the compass of my curse.I'll tell you what; I think it is our way, If we will keep in favour with the king, To be her men and wear her livery: The jealous o'erworn widow and herself, Since that our brother dubb'd them gentlewomen.O Harry's wife, triumph not in my woes!My daughter's mother thinks it with her soul.Sir, I know him, and I love him.Sound trumpets!I have sold all my trumpery; not a counterfeit stone, not a ribbon, glass, pomander, brooch, table-book, ballad, knife, tape, glove, shoe-tie, bracelet, horn-ring, to keep my pack from fasting: they throng who should buy first, as if my trinkets had been hallowed and brought a benediction to the buyer: by which means I saw whose purse was best in picture; and what I saw, to my good use I remembered.Most bounteous sir, Look, if it please you, on this man condemn'd, As if my brother lived: I partly think A due sincerity govern'd his deeds, Till he did look on me: since it is so, Let him not die.She may, yea, marry, may she-- What, marry, may she?But how long shall that title 'ever' last?Let this Barnardine be this morning executed, and his head born to Angelo.Farewell, good friar: I prithee, pray for me.Here pitch our tents, even here in Bosworth field.The good gods assuage thy wrath, and turn the dregs of it upon this varlet here,--this, who, like a block, hath denied my access to thee.I did but smile till now: Now, good my lord, give me the scope of justice My patience here is touch'd.But who comes here?'Fore me, this fellow speaks!Content.Of that fatal country, Sicilia, prithee speak no more; whose very naming punishes me with the remembrance of that penitent, as thou callest him, and reconciled king, my brother; whose loss of his most precious queen and children are even now to be afresh lamented.Twice treble shame on Angelo, To weed my vice and let his grow!Upon them!The heaven sets spies upon us, will not have Our contract celebrated.For that, being one o' the lowest, basest, poorest, Of this most wise rebellion, thou go'st foremost: Thou rascal, that art worst in blood to run, Lead'st first to win some vantage.Madam, have comfort: all of us have cause To wail the dimming of our shining star; But none can cure their harms by wailing them.And yet, between my soul's desire and me-- The lustful Edward's title buried-- Is Clarence, Henry, and his son young Edward, And all the unlook'd for issue of their bodies, To take their rooms, ere I can place myself: A cold premeditation for my purpose!Mercutio's kinsman, noble County Paris!Are gone to Bolingbroke, dispersed and fled.I have show'd too much The rashness of a woman: he is touch'd To the noble heart.Full well hath Clifford play'd the orator, Inferring arguments of mighty force.Bad men, you violate A twofold marriage, 'twixt my crown and me, And then betwixt me and my married wife.The Earl of Wiltshire hath the realm in farm.Dorset, embrace him; Hastings, love lord marquess.If you thrive well, bring them to Baynard's Castle; Where you shall find me well accompanied With reverend fathers and well-learned bishops.What, what, what!Go, take it to the fire; For thou set'st on thy wife.Will no man say amen?Before we proceed any further, hear me speak.Nay, then I see that Edward needs must down.Better it were they all came by the father, Or by the father there were none at all; For emulation now, who shall be nearest, Will touch us all too near, if God prevent not.Twelve year since, Miranda, twelve year since, Thy father was the Duke of Milan and A prince of power.come, let me have a bigger.Sir, have pity; I'll be his surety.While you, sweet dear, prove mistress of my heart!The door is open, sir; there lies your way; You may be jogging whiles your boots are green; For me, I'll not be gone till I please myself: 'Tis like you'll prove a jolly surly groom, That take it on you at the first so roundly.Mark your divorce, young sir, Whom son I dare not call; thou art too base To be acknowledged: thou a sceptre's heir, That thus affect'st a sheep-hook!On safe-guard he came to me; and did curse Against the Volsces, for they had so vilely Yielded the town: he is retired to Antium.More direful hap betide that hated wretch, That makes us wretched by the death of thee, Than I can wish to adders, spiders, toads, Or any creeping venom'd thing that lives!hold those justs and triumphs?What!Happy star, reign now!Infused with a fortitude from heaven, When I have deck'd the sea with drops full salt, Under my burthen groan'd; which raised in me An undergoing stomach, to bear up Against what should ensue.The lion dying thrusteth forth his paw, And wounds the earth, if nothing else, with rage To be o'erpower'd; and wilt thou, pupil-like, Take thy correction mildly, kiss the rod, And fawn on rage with base humility, Which art a lion and a king of beasts?A most courteous exposition.Here in your city; I now came from him: I speak amazedly; and it becomes My marvel and my message.O, that it were as like as it is true!Cousin of Hereford, what dost thou object Against the Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Mowbray?The next news is, I have to London sent The heads of Oxford, Salisbury, Blunt, and Kent: The manner of their taking may appear At large discoursed in this paper here.Romeo will answer it.That shall not be much amiss: Yet, as the matter now stands, he will avoid your accusation; he made trial of you only.The more my wrong, the more his spite appears: What, did he marry me to famish me?I brought high Hereford, if you call him so, But to the next highway, and there I left him.Nay, I will give thee a kiss: now pray thee, love, stay.Marry, sir, by my wife; who, if she had been a woman cardinally given, might have been accused in fornication, adultery, and all uncleanliness there.Come, masters, let's home.What's he approacheth boldly to our presence?I do constantly believe you.A bawd of eleven years' continuance, may it please your honour.no more!We might recover all our loss again; The queen from France hath brought a puissant power: Even now we heard the news: ah, could'st thou fly!What, shall we stab him as he sleeps?No matter, then, who see it; I will be satisfied; let me see the writing.Here, here, sir; here, sir.If I know how or which way to order these affairs Thus thrust disorderly into my hands, Never believe me.Do you intend to stay with me tonight?The Lord protect him from that kingly title!Then both, or one, or any thing thou wilt.There is the man of my soul's hate, Aufidius, Piercing our Romans: then, valiant Titus, take Convenient numbers to make good the city; Whilst I, with those that have the spirit, will haste To help Cominius.Say, has our general met the enemy?If Warwick knew in what estate he stands, 'Tis to be doubted he would waken him.Have I not told thee how I was cozened by the way and lost all my money?Where is the provost?Well ta'en, and like a buzzard.Anon, good nurse!Why will you mew her up, Signior Baptista, for this fiend of hell, And make her bear the penance of her tongue?Which of you, if you were a prince's son, Being pent from liberty, as I am now, if two such murderers as yourselves came to you, Would not entreat for life?Never was seen so black a day as this: O woful day, O woful day!To whom in all this presence speaks your grace?O, gentlemen, see, see!I see, as in a map, the end of all.What do you think?Truly, sir, I would desire you to clap into your prayers; for, look you, the warrant's come.How now, my masters!do you meddle with my master?Methinks I see Leontes opening his free arms and weeping His welcomes forth; asks thee the son forgiveness, As 'twere i' the father's person; kisses the hands Of your fresh princess; o'er and o'er divides him 'Twixt his unkindness and his kindness; the one He chides to hell and bids the other grow Faster than thought or time.Urge neither charity nor shame to me: Uncharitably with me have you dealt, And shamefully by you my hopes are butcher'd.Marrying a punk, my lord, is pressing to death, whipping, and hanging.I do it not in evil disposition, But from Lord Angelo by special charge.Dear Isabel, I have a motion much imports your good; Whereto if you'll a willing ear incline, What's mine is yours and what is yours is mine.To do what service am I sent for hither?Now Phaethon hath tumbled from his car, And made an evening at the noontide prick.Capulet!Indeed, madam?The heavens continue their loves!What means our cousin, that he stares and looks So wildly?Who shall hinder me?All tongues speak of him, and the bleared sights Are spectacled to see him: your prattling nurse Into a rapture lets her baby cry While she chats him: the kitchen malkin pins Her richest lockram 'bout her reechy neck, Clambering the walls to eye him: stalls, bulks, windows, Are smother'd up, leads fill'd, and ridges horsed With variable complexions, all agreeing In earnestness to see him: seld-shown flamens Do press among the popular throngs and puff To win a vulgar station: or veil'd dames Commit the war of white and damask in Their nicely-gawded cheeks to the wanton spoil Of Phoebus' burning kisses: such a pother As if that whatsoever god who leads him Were slily crept into his human powers And gave him graceful posture.Go with him, provost.Seize him, AEdiles!My father's death-- Thy life hath that dishonour'd.All's well; and might have been much better, if He could have temporized.What faults he made before the last, I think Might have found easy fines: but there to end Where he was to begin and give away The benefit of our levies, answering us With our own charge, making a treaty where There was a yielding,--this admits no excuse.Why linger we?In time I may believe, yet I mistrust.that Petruchio came?O, I cry you mercy; you are the singer: I will say for you.Yea, and much better blood than his or thine.You shall find me apt enough to that, sir, an you will give me occasion.Believe me, on mine honour, My words express my purpose.I have watch'd ere now All night for lesser cause, and ne'er been sick.Ay, but mildly.A fine spot, in good faith.Why then it sorts, brave warriors, let's away.The gods preserve you both!The Earl of Pembroke keeps his regiment: Good Captain Blunt, bear my good night to him And by the second hour in the morning Desire the earl to see me in my tent: Yet one thing more, good Blunt, before thou go'st, Where is Lord Stanley quarter'd, dost thou know?a prize!And who sits here that is not Richard's subject?O, if a virgin, And your affection not gone forth, I'll make you The queen of Naples.How now!am I king?Come, let us go: Our corn's to reap, for yet our tithe's to sow.And so it is: I wonder what it bodes.And was the duke a fleshmonger, a fool, and a coward, as you then reported him to be?A lie; you are rough and hairy.All things is ready.I know not, sir.Tush!my collop!who, in my rage, Kneel'd at my feet, and bade me be advised Who spake of brotherhood?I am a-weary, give me leave awhile: Fie, how my bones ache!Ay, by any means prove a tall fellow: if I do not wonder how thou darest venture to be drunk, not being a tall fellow, trust me not.Come on, Lord Hastings, will you go with me?Mistress, we have.Moreover, urge his hateful luxury And bestial appetite in change of lust; Which stretched to their servants, daughters, wives, Even where his lustful eye or savage heart, Without control, listed to make his prey.I would not be a Roman, of all nations; I had as lieve be a condemned man.An 'twere to give again,--but 'tis no matter.It then remains That you do speak to the people.Thou wilt revolt, and fly to him, I fear.What, drawn, and talk of peace!Mistress, what cheer?Good morrow, father.What, myself upon myself?Marry, that with no man here he is offended; For, were he, he had shown it in his looks.Your worship is deceived; the gown is made Just as my master had direction: Grumio gave order how it should be done.Switch and spurs, switch and spurs; or I'll cry a match.God-den to you all, god-den to you all.I am a Roman; and my services are, as you are, against 'em: know you me yet?Huntsman, what say'st thou?Right, you say true: as Hereford's love, so his; As theirs, so mine; and all be as it is.This outward-sainted deputy, Whose settled visage and deliberate word Nips youth i' the head and follies doth emmew As falcon doth the fowl, is yet a devil His filth within being cast, he would appear A pond as deep as hell.By heaven, brat, I'll plague ye for that word.Forbear to sleep the nights, and fast the days; Compare dead happiness with living woe; Think that thy babes were fairer than they were, And he that slew them fouler than he is: Bettering thy loss makes the bad causer worse: Revolving this will teach thee how to curse.My liege, the wound that bred this meeting here Cannot be cured by words; therefore be still.My loving lord, I take my leave of you; Of you, my noble cousin, Lord Aumerle; Not sick, although I have to do with death, But lusty, young, and cheerly drawing breath.Be satisfied; Your brother dies to-morrow; be content.If secret powers Suggest but truth to my divining thoughts, This pretty lad will prove our country's bliss.Let me entreat you.In brief, to set the needless process by, How I persuaded, how I pray'd, and kneel'd, How he refell'd me, and how I replied,-- For this was of much length,--the vile conclusion I now begin with grief and shame to utter: He would not, but by gift of my chaste body To his concupiscible intemperate lust, Release my brother; and, after much debatement, My sisterly remorse confutes mine honour, And I did yield to him: but the next morn betimes, His purpose surfeiting, he sends a warrant For my poor brother's head.Gracious my lord, You know your father's temper: at this time He will allow no speech, which I do guess You do not purpose to him; and as hardly Will he endure your sight as yet, I fear: Then, till the fury of his highness settle, Come not before him.Go, fellow, go, return unto thy lord; Bid him not fear the separated councils His honour and myself are at the one, And at the other is my servant Catesby Where nothing can proceed that toucheth us Whereof I shall not have intelligence.A piece of ice: if thou doubt it, thou mayst slide from my shoulder to my heel with no greater a run but my head and my neck.A bloody deed, and desperately dispatch'd!Think'st thou that I will leave my kingly throne, Wherein my grandsire and my father sat?How!As in a theatre, the eyes of men, After a well-graced actor leaves the stage, Are idly bent on him that enters next, Thinking his prattle to be tedious; Even so, or with much more contempt, men's eyes Did scowl on gentle Richard; no man cried 'God save him!'Now God in heaven bless thee!Well, sir; my mistress is the sweetest lady--Lord, Lord!Attend me, lords.sad hours seem long.Why dost not speak?It were impossible I should speed amiss.If I be waspish, best beware my sting.Then list to me: This follows, if you will not change your purpose But undergo this flight, make for Sicilia, And there present yourself and your fair princess, For so I see she must be, 'fore Leontes: She shall be habited as it becomes The partner of your bed.I prithee, Remember I have done thee worthy service; Told thee no lies, made thee no mistakings, served Without or grudge or grumblings: thou didst promise To bate me a full year.My Lord of Surrey, why look you so sad?Farewell.Go, Lovel, with all speed to Doctor Shaw; Go thou to Friar Penker; bid them both Meet me within this hour at Baynard's Castle.Fortunate mistress,--let my prophecy Come home to ye!--you must retire yourself Into some covert: take your sweetheart's hat And pluck it o'er your brows, muffle your face, Dismantle you, and, as you can, disliken The truth of your own seeming; that you may-- For I do fear eyes over--to shipboard Get undescried.Beshrew me, but his passion moves me so That hardly can I cheque my eyes from tears.To prison with her!So proud that Bolingbroke was on his back!When he that is my husband now Came to me, as I follow'd Henry's corse, When scarce the blood was well wash'd from his hands Which issued from my other angel husband And that dead saint which then I weeping follow'd; O, when, I say, I look'd on Richard's face, This was my wish: 'Be thou,' quoth I, ' accursed, For making me, so young, so old a widow!No more than from my soul I mourn for yours.thou whet'st a knife to kill thyself.I thank his grace, I know he loves me well; But, for his purpose in the coronation.I dreamt my lady came and found me dead-- Strange dream, that gives a dead man leave to think!-- And breathed such life with kisses in my lips, That I revived, and was an emperor.It boots thee not to be compassionate: After our sentence plaining comes too late.But for the rest, you tell a pedigree Of threescore and two years; a silly time To make prescription for a kingdom's worth.I would I were thy bird.How dost thou know that, constable?is it a lawful trade?His last offences to us Shall have judicious hearing.He had, before this last expedition, twenty-five wounds upon him.But the bottom of the news is that our general is cut i' the middle and but one half of what he was yesterday; for the other has half, by the entreaty and grant of the whole table.Where is she?Why, shall the people give One that speaks thus their voice?Sir, list to me: I am my father's heir and only son: If I may have your daughter to my wife, I'll leave her houses three or four as good, Within rich Pisa walls, as any one Old Signior Gremio has in Padua; Besides two thousand ducats by the year Of fruitful land, all which shall be her jointure.Go we to our tent: The blood upon your visage dries; 'tis time It should be look'd to: come.here comes two of the house of the Montagues.How now!threat you me with telling of the king?You cloudy princes and heart-sorrowing peers, That bear this mutual heavy load of moan, Now cheer each other in each other's love Though we have spent our harvest of this king, We are to reap the harvest of his son.So will I, Signior Gremio: but a word, I pray.But be it as it may: I here entail The crown to thee and to thine heirs for ever; Conditionally, that here thou take an oath To cease this civil war, and, whilst I live, To honour me as thy king and sovereign, And neither by treason nor hostility To seek to put me down and reign thyself.Now, Richard, I am with thee here alone: This is the hand that stabb'd thy father York; And this the hand that slew thy brother Rutland; And here's the heart that triumphs in their death And cheers these hands that slew thy sire and brother To execute the like upon thyself; And so, have at thee!How canst thou try them so?Come your ways, sir; come.Now by my soul, I would it were this hour.The grey-eyed morn smiles on the frowning night, Chequering the eastern clouds with streaks of light, And flecked darkness like a drunkard reels From forth day's path and Titan's fiery wheels: Now, ere the sun advance his burning eye, The day to cheer and night's dank dew to dry, I must up-fill this osier cage of ours With baleful weeds and precious-juiced flowers.Well, he in time may come to clear himself; But at this instant he is sick my lord, Of a strange fever.Of the king's ship The mariners say how thou hast disposed And all the rest o' the fleet.For my poor self, I am combined by a sacred vow And shall be absent.O, ay, what else?Away, away!I think I have done myself wrong, have I not?So, Green, thou art the midwife to my woe, And Bolingbroke my sorrow's dismal heir: Now hath my soul brought forth her prodigy, And I, a gasping new-deliver'd mother, Have woe to woe, sorrow to sorrow join'd.How!And is this all?Ay, or very falsely pocket up his report Methinks our garments are now as fresh as when we put them on first in Afric, at the marriage of the king's fair daughter Claribel to the King of Tunis.Hath been!That's my brave boy!Hermione, my dearest, thou never spokest To better purpose.Courageous Richmond, well hast thou acquit thee.O happy vantage of a kneeling knee!Gentle and fair, your brother kindly greets you: Not to be weary with you, he's in prison.It is war's prize to take all vantages; And ten to one is no impeach of valour.And so he vanish'd: then came wandering by A shadow like an angel, with bright hair Dabbled in blood; and he squeak'd out aloud, 'Clarence is come; false, fleeting, perjured Clarence, That stabb'd me in the field by Tewksbury; Seize on him, Furies, take him to your torments!'canst stand?Thus we debase The nature of our seats and make the rabble Call our cares fears; which will in time Break ope the locks o' the senate and bring in The crows to peck the eagles.Is not this true?Alas, I blame you not; for you are mortal, And mortal eyes cannot endure the devil.O, thou wilt speak again of banishment.We would as willingly give cure as know.Call me their traitor!Turn thee, Benvolio, look upon thy death.When, Caius, Rome is thine, Thou art poor'st of all; then shortly art thou mine.My business is a word or two with Claudio.Advocate's the court-word for a pheasant: say you have none.Go where you will, the king shall be commanded; And be you kings, command, and I'll obey.Know'st thou not any whom corrupting gold Would tempt unto a close exploit of death?The tyrannous and bloody deed is done.And there's for twitting me with perjury.all men call thee fickle: If thou art fickle, what dost thou with him.I, as I may--that which I would I cannot,-- With best advantage will deceive the time, And aid thee in this doubtful shock of arms: But on thy side I may not be too forward Lest, being seen, thy brother, tender George, Be executed in his father's sight.And grieve to hear't.'Zounds!Thou hast said enough.You smell this business with a sense as cold As is a dead man's nose: but I do see't and feel't As you feel doing thus; and see withal The instruments that feel.what news with you?And to that end we wish'd your lord-ship here, To avoid the carping censures of the world.Ah, sirrah, by my fay, it waxes late: I'll to my rest.And now, to soothe your forgery and his, Sends me a paper to persuade me patience?Had you such leisure in the time of death To gaze upon the secrets of the deep?Out of my sight!Here comes your father: never make denial; I must and will have Katharina to my wife.God save your grace!Sirrah, if thy captain knew I were here, he would use me with estimation.Fool, fool!why, then, I thank you all I thank you, honest gentlemen; good night.Signior Petruchio, fie!Go, bid thy master rise and come to me And we will both together to the Tower, Where, he shall see, the boar will use us kindly.Has spoken like a traitor, and shall answer As traitors do.I will go along; An if you leave me so, you do me wrong.Where is thy husband now?Had he none else to make a stale but me?What hast thou there?and if she be froward, Then hast thou taught Hortensio to be untoward.What say you to't?Piteous predicament!An if I live until I be a man, I'll win our ancient right in France again, Or die a soldier, as I lived a king.Caliban!Surrey, thou liest.Since arm from arm that voice doth us affray, Hunting thee hence with hunt's-up to the day, O, now be gone; more light and light it grows.My falcon now is sharp and passing empty; And till she stoop she must not be full-gorged, For then she never looks upon her lure.Marry, would the word 'farewell' have lengthen'd hours And added years to his short banishment, He should have had a volume of farewells; But since it would not, he had none of me.Mark and perform it, see'st thou!Far be the thought of this from Henry's heart, To make a shambles of the parliament-house!look thee here; take up, take up, boy; open't.Under what title shall I woo for thee, That God, the law, my honour and her love, Can make seem pleasing to her tender years?Welcome my lord; I dance attendance here; I think the duke will not be spoke withal.March on, and mark King Richard how he looks.Lead forth and bring you back in happiness!I do beseech your grace to pardon me: It is a matter of small consequence, Which for some reasons I would not have seen.Forgive him, Angelo, that brought you home The head of Ragozine for Claudio's: The offence pardons itself.Perjury, perjury, in the high'st degree Murder, stem murder, in the direst degree; All several sins, all used in each degree, Throng to the bar, crying all, Guilty!I have so; because it is an open room and good for winter.Make me, that nothing have, with nothing grieved, And thou with all pleased, that hast all achieved!When you are hearing a matter between party and party, if you chance to be pinched with the colic, you make faces like mummers; set up the bloody flag against all patience; and, in roaring for a chamber-pot, dismiss the controversy bleeding the more entangled by your hearing: all the peace you make in their cause is, calling both the parties knaves.Ay, an it like your good worship.Ay me!O my most sacred lady!We are the queen's abjects, and must obey.Didst perceive it?Thanks, dear Isabel.And I could sing, would weeping do me good, And never borrow any tear of thee.He hath promised you more than that, or there be liars.A gross hag And, lozel, thou art worthy to be hang'd, That wilt not stay her tongue.He means, my lord, that we are too remiss; Whilst Bolingbroke, through our security, Grows strong and great in substance and in power.The storm begins; poor wretch, That for thy mother's fault art thus exposed To loss and what may follow!What king so strong Can tie the gall up in the slanderous tongue?Lucentio, you shall supply the bridegroom's place: And let Bianca take her sister's room.That Julius Caesar was a famous man; With what his valour did enrich his wit, His wit set down to make his valour live Death makes no conquest of this conqueror; For now he lives in fame, though not in life.O Romeo, Romeo!Well, let it strike.Ay, now begins a second storm to rise; For this is he that moves both wind and tide.I'll fight with none but thee; for I do hate thee Worse than a promise-breaker.Wife, thou art a fool.Thy lips are warm.Faith, he is gone unto the taming-school.What's he that follows there, that would not dance?Awake, thou coward majesty!Help Heaven!Leave your prating: since these good men are pleased, let them come in; but quickly now.Your good voice, sir; what say you?And you are well met, Signior Hortensio.Hortensio, peace!They're busy within; you were best knock louder.Whence comest thou?And, in good time, here the lieutenant comes.I thought she had some great matter there in hand; for she hath privately twice or thrice a day, ever since the death of Hermione, visited that removed house.No, no, he's gone.Fairly offer'd.If thou delight to view thy heinous deeds, Behold this pattern of thy butcheries.Speak suddenly, my lords, are we all friends?Good Paulina, Lead us from hence, where we may leisurely Each one demand an answer to his part Perform'd in this wide gap of time since first We were dissever'd: hastily lead away.Thou poisonous slave, got by the devil himself Upon thy wicked dam, come forth!Beseech you, sir, were you present at this relation?And what shall become of those in the city?Say my request's unjust, And spurn me back: but if it be not so, Thou art not honest; and the gods will plague thee, That thou restrain'st from me the duty which To a mother's part belongs.What is your crest?Marry, sir, I think, if you handled her privately, she would sooner confess: perchance, publicly, she'll be ashamed.Will I live?Hark ye, your Romeo will be here at night: I'll to him; he is hid at Laurence' cell.If word nor oath Prevail not, go and see: if you can bring Tincture or lustre in her lip, her eye, Heat outwardly or breath within, I'll serve you As I would do the gods.Yet your good will must have that thanks from Rome, after the measure As you intended well.What ugly sights of death within mine eyes!you men, you beasts, That quench the fire of your pernicious rage With purple fountains issuing from your veins, On pain of torture, from those bloody hands Throw your mistemper'd weapons to the ground, And hear the sentence of your moved prince.What is't thou canst demand?Cousin of Buckingham, and you sage, grave men, Since you will buckle fortune on my back, To bear her burthen, whether I will or no, I must have patience to endure the load: But if black scandal or foul-faced reproach Attend the sequel of your imposition, Your mere enforcement shall acquittance me From all the impure blots and stains thereof; For God he knows, and you may partly see, How far I am from the desire thereof.Where is the duke?Come, cousin, I'll Dispose of you.This is true that I say: an I had thee in place where, thou shouldst know it.Pray, have you not a daughter Call'd Katharina, fair and virtuous?O me, the gods!Would you imagine, or almost believe, Were't not that, by great preservation, We live to tell it you, the subtle traitor This day had plotted, in the council-house To murder me and my good Lord of Gloucester?Withhold revenge, dear God!I pay thy poverty, and not thy will.Come, gentle night, come, loving, black-brow'd night, Give me my Romeo; and, when he shall die, Take him and cut him out in little stars, And he will make the face of heaven so fine That all the world will be in love with night And pay no worship to the garish sun.My lord, here comes the rascal I spoke of; here with the provost.Silence!Convenient is it.How came't, Camillo, That he did stay?But say, is Warwick friends with Margaret?whither shall we fly?Welcome, good Clarence; this is brotherlike.Even thou, that hast A heart so tender o'er it, take it hence And see it instantly consumed with fire; Even thou and none but thou.Ay, hand from hand, my love, and heart from heart.Excepting one, I would he were the best In all this presence that hath moved me so.The air hath got into my deadly wounds, And much effuse of blood doth make me faint.We must both give and take, my gracious lord.Now, in good time, here comes the Duke of York.Di faciant laudis summa sit ista tuae!Either heaven with lightning strike the murderer dead, Or earth, gape open wide and eat him quick, As thou dost swallow up this good king's blood Which his hell-govern'd arm hath butchered!I can, Petruchio, help thee to a wife With wealth enough and young and beauteous, Brought up as best becomes a gentlewoman: Her only fault, and that is faults enough, Is that she is intolerable curst And shrewd and froward, so beyond all measure That, were my state far worser than it is, I would not wed her for a mine of gold.To prison, eyes, ne'er look on liberty!Heard ye not what an humble suppliant Lord hastings was to her for his delivery?Warwick is chancellor and the lord of Calais; Stern Falconbridge commands the narrow seas; The duke is made protector of the realm; And yet shalt thou be safe?Proceed: No foot shall stir.Thou toad, thou toad, where is thy brother Clarence?Masters o' the people, We do request your kindest ears, and after, Your loving motion toward the common body, To yield what passes here.what flaying?Go not home.so I think you are.Grumio, Draw forth thy weapon, we are beset with thieves; Rescue thy mistress, if thou be a man.Come, sir: did you set these women on to slander Lord Angelo?how is't with aged Gaunt?My husband lives, that Tybalt would have slain; And Tybalt's dead, that would have slain my husband: All this is comfort; wherefore weep I then?Come, gentlemen, let's all go visit him: Pray God we may make haste, and come too late!Faith, sir, few of any wit in such matters: as they are chosen, they are glad to choose me for them; I do it for some piece of money, and go through with all.miserable England!Forgive me, cousin!On me, that halt and am unshapen thus?I brought my master news of Juliet's death; And then in post he came from Mantua To this same place, to this same monument.In an ungracious mouth is but profane.thy seat is up on high; Whilst my gross flesh sinks downward, here to die.When holy Harry died, and my sweet son.Farewell, old Gaunt.These times of woe afford no time to woo.marry with a king, A bachelor, a handsome stripling too: I wis your grandam had a worser match.What's he that knocks as he would beat down the gate?Fare ye well.for the fail Of any point in't shall not only be Death to thyself but to thy lewd-tongued wife, Whom for this time we pardon.welcome, Bolingbroke!'Gone already!Why dost thou say King Richard is deposed?what!In few, they hurried us aboard a bark, Bore us some leagues to sea; where they prepared A rotten carcass of a boat, not rigg'd, Nor tackle, sail, nor mast; the very rats Instinctively had quit it: there they hoist us, To cry to the sea that roar'd to us, to sigh To the winds whose pity, sighing back again, Did us but loving wrong.I would you had been by the ship side, to have helped her: there your charity would have lacked footing.The king my uncle is to blame for this: God will revenge it; whom I will importune With daily prayers all to that effect.And though you think that all, as you have done, Have torn their souls by turning them from us, And we are barren and bereft of friends; Yet know, my master, God omnipotent, Is mustering in his clouds on our behalf Armies of pestilence; and they shall strike Your children yet unborn and unbegot, That lift your vassal hands against my head And threat the glory of my precious crown.We recommend to you, tribunes of the people, Our purpose to them: and to our noble consul Wish we all joy and honour.I wasted time, and now doth time waste me; For now hath time made me his numbering clock: My thoughts are minutes; and with sighs they jar Their watches on unto mine eyes, the outward watch, Whereto my finger, like a dial's point, Is pointing still, in cleansing them from tears.Never, but once.Well, well, I see I talk but idly, and you laugh at me.was ever man so rayed?Tullus Aufidius, The second name of men, obeys his points As if he were his officer: desperation Is all the policy, strength and defence, That Rome can make against them.They that stand high have many blasts to shake them; And if they fall, they dash themselves to pieces.Why, masters, my good friends, mine honest neighbours, Will you undo yourselves?Madam, an hour before the worshipp'd sun Peer'd forth the golden window of the east, A troubled mind drave me to walk abroad; Where, underneath the grove of sycamore That westward rooteth from the city's side, So early walking did I see your son: Towards him I made, but he was ware of me And stole into the covert of the wood: I, measuring his affections by my own, That most are busied when they're most alone, Pursued my humour not pursuing his, And gladly shunn'd who gladly fled from me.the empire unpossess'd?All places that the eye of heaven visits Are to a wise man ports and happy havens.I prate, And the most noble mother of the world Leave unsaluted: sink, my knee, i' the earth; Of thy deep duty more impression show Than that of common sons.I will proclaim thee, Angelo; look for't: Sign me a present pardon for my brother, Or with an outstretch'd throat I'll tell the world aloud What man thou art.Pale ashes of the house of Lancaster!give me a cup of wine.I cannot weep; for all my body's moisture Scarce serves to quench my furnace-burning heart: Nor can my tongue unload my heart's great burthen; For selfsame wind that I should speak withal Is kindling coals that fires all my breast, And burns me up with flames that tears would quench.I know this man well: he hath been since an ape-bearer;
