Here comes his grace in person.Find them out whose names are written here!Ah, boy, if any life be left in thee, Throw up thine eye!For a worthy lady And one whom much I honour.Away, I say; I charge ye, bear her hence.Against them both my true joints bended be.Five times, Marcius, I have fought with thee: so often hast thou beat me, And wouldst do so, I think, should we encounter As often as we eat.Have I thought long to see this morning's face, And doth it give me such a sight as this?'Fair cousin'?Come away, servant, come.Beshrew thee, cousin, which didst lead me forth Of that sweet way I was in to despair!noon, midnight?Sweet sister, let me live: What sin you do to save a brother's life, Nature dispenses with the deed so far That it becomes a virtue.O God, O God!So stands this squire Officed with me: we two will walk, my lord, And leave you to your graver steps.Now, by my maidenhead, at twelve year old, I bade her come.These violent delights have violent ends And in their triumph die, like fire and powder, Which as they kiss consume: the sweetest honey Is loathsome in his own deliciousness And in the taste confounds the appetite: Therefore love moderately; long love doth so; Too swift arrives as tardy as too slow.He is our cousin, cousin; but 'tis doubt, When time shall call him home from banishment, Whether our kinsman come to see his friends.I swear.He took good rest to-night; 'Tis hoped his sickness is discharged.Fie, doff this habit, shame to your estate, An eye-sore to our solemn festival!'tis well they are whispering: clamour your tongues, and not a word more.Tut, you saw her fair, none else being by, Herself poised with herself in either eye: But in that crystal scales let there be weigh'd Your lady's love against some other maid That I will show you shining at this feast, And she shall scant show well that now shows best.This is the truth, or let Benvolio die.From London by the king was I press'd forth; My father, being the Earl of Warwick's man, Came on the part of York, press'd by his master; And I, who at his hands received my life, him Have by my hands of life bereaved him.young men's love then lies Not truly in their hearts, but in their eyes.Ready to fight; therefore be resolute.What is't?Good night, good Captain Blunt.Death, that hath suck'd the honey of thy breath, Hath had no power yet upon thy beauty: Thou art not conquer'd; beauty's ensign yet Is crimson in thy lips and in thy cheeks, And death's pale flag is not advanced there.Sir, those cold ways, That seem like prudent helps, are very poisonous Where the disease is violent.Now blessed be the great Apollo!That is no slander, sir, which is a truth; And what I spake, I spake it to my face.I neither care for the world nor your general: for such things as you, I can scarce think there's any, ye're so slight.See you these clothes?Why, that is spoken like a toward prince.'Farewell:' And, for my heart disdained that my tongue Should so profane the word, that taught me craft To counterfeit oppression of such grief That words seem'd buried in my sorrow's grave.Stand, Aufidius, And trouble not the peace.What!It shall be possible.the wrongs I have done thee stir Afresh within me, and these thy offices, So rarely kind, are as interpreters Of my behind-hand slackness.I would dissemble with my nature where My fortunes and my friends at stake required I should do so in honour: I am in this, Your wife, your son, these senators, the nobles; And you will rather show our general louts How you can frown than spend a fawn upon 'em, For the inheritance of their loves and safeguard Of what that want might ruin.My general cares not for you.Close by, my master.the sweet birds, O, how they sing!But repetition of what thou hast marr'd; That will I make before I let thee go.We do here pronounce, Upon the part o' the people, in whose power We were elected theirs, Marcius is worthy Of present death.These letters will resolve him of my mind.If to either, thou dost ill.I will dry-beat you with an iron wit, and put up my iron dagger.Thy face is mine, and thou hast slander'd it.Then make your garden rich in gillyvors, And do not call them bastards.If that I could for weeping, you should hear,-- Nay, and you shall hear some.O, my heart bleeds To think o' the teen that I have turn'd you to, Which is from my remembrance!God save your honour!Warwick and Clarence give me both your hands: Now join your hands, and with your hands your hearts, That no dissension hinder government: I make you both protectors of this land, While I myself will lead a private life And in devotion spend my latter days, To sin's rebuke and my Creator's praise.Take it up straight: Within this hour bring me word 'tis done, And by good testimony, or I'll seize thy life, With what thou else call'st thine.By the consent of all, we were establish'd The people's magistrates.Knock at the gate!And buried, gentle Tyrrel?She I kill'd!My lord, some two days since I saw the prince, And told him of those triumphs held at Oxford.All this from my remembrance brutish wrath Sinfully pluck'd, and not a man of you Had so much grace to put it in my mind.'tis a match.Husband, let's follow, to see the end of this ado.The sun not yet thy sighs from heaven clears, Thy old groans ring yet in my ancient ears; Lo, here upon thy cheek the stain doth sit Of an old tear that is not wash'd off yet: If e'er thou wast thyself and these woes thine, Thou and these woes were all for Rosaline: And art thou changed?This done, he took the bride about the neck And kiss'd her lips with such a clamorous smack That at the parting all the church did echo: And I seeing this came thence for very shame; And after me, I know, the rout is coming.O sir, the loathsomeness of them offends me more than the stripes I have received, which are mighty ones and millions.Be patient, they are friends, Ratcliff and Lovel.The nature of our people, Our city's institutions, and the terms For common justice, you're as pregnant in As art and practise hath enriched any That we remember.O my dread lord, I should be guiltier than my guiltiness, To think I can be undiscernible, When I perceive your grace, like power divine, Hath look'd upon my passes.Romeo shall thank thee, daughter, for us both.Ye are a baggage: the Slys are no rogues; look in the chronicles; we came in with Richard Conqueror.'Shall'!This is clean kam.which that it shall, Is all as monstrous to our human reason As my Antigonus to break his grave And come again to me; who, on my life, Did perish with the infant.Will't please your mightiness to wash your hands?Not for because Your brows are blacker; yet black brows, they say, Become some women best, so that there be not Too much hair there, but in a semicircle Or a half-moon made with a pen.I am a gentleman of Verona, sir, That, hearing of her beauty and her wit, Her affability and bashful modesty, Her wondrous qualities and mild behavior, Am bold to show myself a forward guest Within your house, to make mine eye the witness Of that report which I so oft have heard.Ay, sir.There shall not at your father's house these seven years Be born another such.Not she: nor doth she tempt: but it is I That, lying by the violet in the sun, Do as the carrion does, not as the flower, Corrupt with virtuous season.Ay; or else 'twere hard luck, being in so preposterous estate as we are.Yes, truly; I speak not as desiring more; But rather wishing a more strict restraint Upon the sisterhood, the votarists of Saint Clare.Tell me, gentle friend, How went he under him?What, is there a maid with child by him?The sullen passage of thy weary steps Esteem as foil wherein thou art to set The precious jewel of thy home return.Good queen!Go, tread the path that thou shalt ne'er return.No such jade as you, if me you mean.Well, forward, forward!My royal father, cheer these noble lords And hearten those that fight in your defence: Unsheathe your sword, good father; cry 'Saint George!''tis so: but Edward lives.a drum.To this I am most constant, Though destiny say no.I had a brother, then.and again does nothing But what he did being childish?Well, sir; what did this gentleman to her?Sir, we have all Great cause to give great thanks.How now!Up, cousin, up; your heart is up, I know, Thus high at least, although your knee be low.I do fear, too dreadful: Sith 'twas my fault to give the people scope, 'Twould be my tyranny to strike and gall them For what I bid them do: for we bid this be done, When evil deeds have their permissive pass And not the punishment.But leave it all to God.Who brought it?Arise, fair sun, and kill the envious moon, Who is already sick and pale with grief, That thou her maid art far more fair than she: Be not her maid, since she is envious; Her vestal livery is but sick and green And none but fools do wear it; cast it off.Kissing with inside lip?Injurious world!No quarrel, but a slight contention.Good even.To-morrow morning are to die Claudio and Barnardine.Speak, speak.No, my lord.I know her father, though I know not her; And he knew my deceased father well.That thou betray'dst Polixenes,'twas nothing; That did but show thee, of a fool, inconstant And damnable ingrateful: nor was't much, Thou wouldst have poison'd good Camillo's honour, To have him kill a king: poor trespasses, More monstrous standing by: whereof I reckon The casting forth to crows thy baby-daughter To be or none or little; though a devil Would have shed water out of fire ere done't: Nor is't directly laid to thee, the death Of the young prince, whose honourable thoughts, Thoughts high for one so tender, cleft the heart That could conceive a gross and foolish sire Blemish'd his gracious dam: this is not, no, Laid to thy answer: but the last,--O lords, When I have said, cry 'woe!'must we not?This sessions, to our great grief we pronounce, Even pushes 'gainst our heart: the party tried The daughter of a king, our wife, and one Of us too much beloved.Help, ye citizens!If tinkers may have leave to live, And bear the sow-skin budget, Then my account I well may, give, And in the stocks avouch it.Yes; keep you warm.How doth my lady?Cover your heads and mock not flesh and blood With solemn reverence: throw away respect, Tradition, form and ceremonious duty, For you have but mistook me all this while: I live with bread like you, feel want, Taste grief, need friends: subjected thus, How can you say to me, I am a king?Well; what has he done?Hath yet the deputy sent my brother's pardon?Lo, as at English feasts, so I regreet The daintiest last, to make the end most sweet: O thou, the earthly author of my blood, Whose youthful spirit, in me regenerate, Doth with a twofold vigour lift me up To reach at victory above my head, Add proof unto mine armour with thy prayers; And with thy blessings steel my lance's point, That it may enter Mowbray's waxen coat, And furbish new the name of John a Gaunt, Even in the lusty havior of his son.Men judge by the complexion of the sky The state and inclination of the day: So may you by my dull and heavy eye, My tongue hath but a heavier tale to say.But stay thee, 'tis the fruits of love I mean.This nor hurts him nor profits you a jot; Forbear it therefore; give your cause to heaven.Harry of Hereford, Lancaster and Derby, Receive thy lance; and God defend the right!Old Montague is come, And flourishes his blade in spite of me.Doth he so seek his life?Therefore commend me; let him not come there, To seek out sorrow that dwells every where.Will the king come, that I may breathe my last In wholesome counsel to his unstaid youth?Great Apollo Turn all to the best!Curse not thyself, fair creature thou art both.What dogs are these!I know not, mighty sovereign, but by guess.Bear with me; I am hungry for revenge, And now I cloy me with beholding it.I went To this pernicious caitiff deputy,-- That's somewhat madly spoken.I tore it from the traitor's bosom, king; Fear, and not love, begets his penitence: Forget to pity him, lest thy pity prove A serpent that will sting thee to the heart.This is a strange repose, to be asleep With eyes wide open; standing, speaking, moving, And yet so fast asleep.Down, down I come; like glistering Phaethon, Wanting the manage of unruly jades.Ay, to devour him; as the hungry plebeians would the noble Marcius.Ay, ay.I must be answer'd.What, talking with a priest, lord chamberlain?What is it?Of any thing the image tell me that Hath kept with thy remembrance.One day too late, I fear me, noble lord, Hath clouded all thy happy days on earth: O, call back yesterday, bid time return, And thou shalt have twelve thousand fighting men!Give me those flowers.Wherefore, gentle maiden, Do you neglect them?Why, very well, then; I hope here be truths.The more that Henry was unfortunate.Unfit to live or die: O gravel heart!do I not breathe a man?The king's grown bankrupt, like a broken man.No, Harry, Harry, 'tis no land of thine; Thy place is fill'd, thy sceptre wrung from thee, Thy balm wash'd off wherewith thou wast anointed: No bending knee will call thee Caesar now, No humble suitors press to speak for right, No, not a man comes for redress of thee; For how can I help them, and not myself?o' God's name, let it go: I'll give my jewels for a set of beads, My gorgeous palace for a hermitage, My gay apparel for an almsman's gown, My figured goblets for a dish of wood, My sceptre for a palmer's walking staff, My subjects for a pair of carved saints And my large kingdom for a little grave, A little little grave, an obscure grave; Or I'll be buried in the king's highway, Some way of common trade, where subjects' feet May hourly trample on their sovereign's head; For on my heart they tread now whilst I live; And buried once, why not upon my head?Say, what's thy name?By heaven, I will not do thee so much ease.God ye good den, fair gentlewoman.They'll sit by the fire, and presume to know What's done i' the Capitol; who's like to rise, Who thrives and who declines; side factions and give out Conjectural marriages; making parties strong And feebling such as stand not in their liking Below their cobbled shoes.When you speak best unto the purpose, it is not worth the wagging of your beards; and your beards deserve not so honourable a grave as to stuff a botcher's cushion, or to be entombed in an ass's pack- saddle.More torches here!The duke yet would have dark deeds darkly answered; he would never bring them to light: would he were returned!Worse and worse; she will not come!O, ay, Curtis, ay: and therefore fire, fire; cast on no water.I do well believe your highness; and did it to minister occasion to these gentlemen, who are of such sensible and nimble lungs that they always use to laugh at nothing.Why, she comes to borrow nothing of them.No, by the holy rood, thou know'st it well, Thou camest on earth to make the earth my hell.O here's a wit of cheveril, that stretches from an inch narrow to an ell broad!say thou but 'I,' And that bare vowel 'I' shall poison more Than the death-darting eye of cockatrice: I am not I, if there be such an I; Or those eyes shut, that make thee answer 'I.'Alla stoccata carries it away.She dances featly.I wot your love pursues A banish'd traitor: all my treasury Is yet but unfelt thanks, which more enrich'd Shall be your love and labour's recompense.The king, of his own royal disposition, And not provoked by any suitor else; Aiming, belike, at your interior hatred, Which in your outward actions shows itself Against my kindred, brothers, and myself, Makes him to send; that thereby he may gather The ground of your ill-will, and so remove it.Is this the witness, friar?Gentlemen, good den: a word with one of you.To save your life in this extremity, This favour will I do you for his sake; And think it not the worst of an your fortunes That you are like to Sir Vincentio.Now, as I live, I will.Romeo, that she were, O, that she were An open et caetera, thou a poperin pear!O fortune, fortune!Who knocks so hard?Else let my brother die, If not a feodary, but only he Owe and succeed thy weakness.These differences shall all rest under gage Till Norfolk be repeal'd: repeal'd he shall be, And, though mine enemy, restored again To all his lands and signories: when he's return'd, Against Aumerle we will enforce his trial.Lovel and Ratcliff, look that it be done: The rest, that love me, rise and follow me.King Lewis, I here protest, in sight of heaven, And by the hope I have of heavenly bliss, That I am clear from this misdeed of Edward's, No more my king, for he dishonours me, But most himself, if he could see his shame.Which way ran he that kill'd Mercutio?You will!I know't too well.How hath your lordship brook'd imprisonment?From your own mouth, my lord, did I this deed.What, are you busy, ho?But new struck nine.What say you, James Soundpost?Alas, my liege, my wife is dead to-night; Grief of my son's exile hath stopp'd her breath: What further woe conspires against mine age?Part of your cares you give me with your crown.Think you a little din can daunt mine ears?Away!Marry, my child, early next Thursday morn, The gallant, young and noble gentleman, The County Paris, at Saint Peter's Church, Shall happily make thee there a joyful bride.They said they were an-hungry; sigh'd forth proverbs, That hunger broke stone walls, that dogs must eat, That meat was made for mouths, that the gods sent not Corn for the rich men only: with these shreds They vented their complainings; which being answer'd, And a petition granted them, a strange one-- To break the heart of generosity, And make bold power look pale--they threw their caps As they would hang them on the horns o' the moon, Shouting their emulation.I do not like the Tower, of any place.what of that?When the sea is.Give way there, and go on!I shall, my lord.Ere my tongue Shall wound my honour with such feeble wrong, Or sound so base a parle, my teeth shall tear The slavish motive of recanting fear, And spit it bleeding in his high disgrace, Where shame doth harbour, even in Mowbray's face.Which in his greatest need will shrink from him.What, will he not to bed?He consul!You have misled a prince, a royal king, A happy gentleman in blood and lineaments, By you unhappied and disfigured clean: You have in manner with your sinful hours Made a divorce betwixt his queen and him, Broke the possession of a royal bed And stain'd the beauty of a fair queen's cheeks With tears drawn from her eyes by your foul wrongs.Thou lovest me not; for, brother, if thou didst, Thy tears would wash this cold congealed blood That glues my lips and will not let me speak.My noble uncle!Tranio, you jest: but have you both forsworn me?For the benefit of silence, would thou wert so too!Come, my gracious lord, Shall I be your playfellow?Come, stir, stir, stir!But let me see: is this our foeman's face?But the safer when 'tis back'd with France.be merciful, say 'death;' For exile hath more terror in his look, Much more than death: do not say 'banishment.'I know, sir, we weary you.So, the good horse is mine.You kiss by the book.I would do more than that, if more were needful.The lord protector lost it, and not I: When I was crown'd I was but nine months old.A woman moved is like a fountain troubled, Muddy, ill-seeming, thick, bereft of beauty; And while it is so, none so dry or thirsty Will deign to sip or touch one drop of it.Give me my sin again.Very well: Could he say less?In haste whereof, most heartily I pray Your highness to assign our trial day.O God!I will bite my thumb at them; which is a disgrace to them, if they bear it.Uninhabitable and almost inaccessible,-- Yet,-- Yet,-- He could not miss't.I'll have no bigger: this doth fit the time, And gentlewomen wear such caps as these When you are gentle, you shall have one too, And not till then.The violent carriage of it Will clear or end the business: when the oracle, Thus by Apollo's great divine seal'd up, Shall the contents discover, something rare Even then will rush to knowledge.Go, trumpet, to the walls, and sound a parle.Catesby!'Citizens!'Therefore, most absolute sir, if thou wilt have The leading of thine own revenges, take The one half of my commission; and set down-- As best thou art experienced, since thou know'st Thy country's strength and weakness,--thine own ways; Whether to knock against the gates of Rome, Or rudely visit them in parts remote, To fright them, ere destroy.Silence!And now what rests but that we spend the time With stately triumphs, mirthful comic shows, Such as befits the pleasure of the court?I thank you, sir.Happy be you!And, in this rage, with some great kinsman's bone, As with a club, dash out my desperate brains?Light to my chamber, ho!Know, I pray you,-- I know no further: Let them pronounce the steep Tarpeian death, Vagabond exile, raying, pent to linger But with a grain a day, I would not buy Their mercy at the price of one fair word; Nor cheque my courage for what they can give, To have't with saying 'Good morrow.'No, no, no, no, no.Your Coriolanus Is not much miss'd, but with his friends: The commonwealth doth stand, and so would do, Were he more angry at it.What?Now Jove afford you cause!What's o'clock, think you?Great reason why: Lest I revenge.No cause!That's as York thrives to beat back Bolingbroke.But, if thou be a king, where is thy crown?Prove it before these varlets here, thou honourable man; prove it.What, I prithee, might be the cause?Why?O sir, it is better to be brief than tedious.Cousin Aumerle, How far brought you high Hereford on his way?But, beseech your grace, Be plainer with me; let me know my trespass By its own visage: if I then deny it, 'Tis none of mine.And you shall understand from me her mind.My gracious sovereign, on the western coast Rideth a puissant navy; to the shore Throng many doubtful hollow-hearted friends, Unarm'd, and unresolved to beat them back: 'Tis thought that Richmond is their admiral; And there they hull, expecting but the aid Of Buckingham to welcome them ashore.I know it well.I'll undertake 't: I think he'll hear me.Not with fond shekels of the tested gold, Or stones whose rates are either rich or poor As fancy values them; but with true prayers That shall be up at heaven and enter there Ere sun-rise, prayers from preserved souls, From fasting maids whose minds are dedicate To nothing temporal.O Clifford, boisterous Clifford!But indeed I can do you little harm; you'll forswear this again.Be calm, be calm.My lord!As well as Lewis of France, or the Earl of Warwick, Which are so weak of courage and in judgment That they'll take no offence at our abuse.What was your dream?Romeo, doff thy name, And for that name which is no part of thee Take all myself.No, in good earnest.Carry this mad knave to the gaol.To Lynn, my lord, And ship from thence to Flanders.No, madam, no; I may not leave it so: I am bound by oath, and therefore pardon me.See that Claudio Be executed by nine to-morrow morning: Bring him his confessor, let him be prepared; For that's the utmost of his pilgrimage.What more fearful?it is best Put finger in the eye, an she knew why.Boy, this shall not excuse the injuries That thou hast done me; therefore turn and draw.the time has yet to come that she was ever respected with man, woman, or child.Ah, simple men, you know not what you swear!We have ever your good word.You, Titus Lartius, Must to Corioli back: send us to Rome The best, with whom we may articulate, For their own good and ours.Ay, but the case is alter'd: When you disgraced me in my embassade, Then I degraded you from being king, And come now to create you Duke of York.The moon!Where did you dwell when I was King of England?This was my speech, and I will speak't again-- Not now, not now.No, it begins again.O child!Upon the stroke of four.If she deny, Lord Hastings, go with him, And from her jealous arms pluck him perforce.poor bankrupt, break at once!Ay, sir, very well.the treble jars.I will not rise, unless your highness grant.My lord; I do confess I ne'er was married; And I confess besides I am no maid: I have known my husband; yet my husband Knows not that ever he knew me.Therefore proceed.My noble queen, let former grudges pass, And henceforth I am thy true servitor: I will revenge his wrong to Lady Bona, And replant Henry in his former state.we loved him but, like beasts And cowardly nobles, gave way unto your clusters, Who did hoot him out o' the city.See, see!Let deeds express What's like to be their words: 'we did request it; We are the greater poll, and in true fear They gave us our demands.'Ay, if the fool could find it where it lies, Who knows not where a wasp does wear his sting?He's sentenced; 'tis too late.So it is.Thou wilt fall backward when thou hast more wit; Wilt thou not, Jule?'Most dearly welcome!Thy death-bed is no lesser than thy land Wherein thou liest in reputation sick; And thou, too careless patient as thou art, Commit'st thy anointed body to the cure Of those physicians that first wounded thee: A thousand flatterers sit within thy crown, Whose compass is no bigger than thy head; And yet, incaged in so small a verge, The waste is no whit lesser than thy land.You thus employ'd, I will go root away The noisome weeds, which without profit suck The soil's fertility from wholesome flowers.Come to the pedlar; Money's a medler.Pardon, my lord; I will not show my face Until my husband bid me.Master Barnardine!What stays had I but they?But stay a while: what company is this?I beseech your graces both to pardon me; His majesty hath straitly given in charge That no man shall have private conference, Of what degree soever, with his brother.Do they still fly to the Roman?You would be another Penelope: yet, they say, all the yarn she spun in Ulysses' absence did but fill Ithaca full of moths.Care for us!Wars have not wasted it, for warr'd he hath not, But basely yielded upon compromise That which his noble ancestors achieved with blows: More hath he spent in peace than they in wars.O simple!The entreaties of your mistress!And all my armour laid into my tent?Hence with her, out o' door: A most intelligencing bawd!in your dumps?An if they live, I hope I need not fear.I am a woeful suitor to your honour, Please but your honour hear me.Ay, now methinks I hear great Warwick speak: Ne'er may he live to see a sunshine day, That cries 'Retire,' if Warwick bid him stay.Do not deny to him that you love me.Well, sir, as you guess, as you guess?Adieu, good neighbour.But thou didst kill my children.Why then, by God-- God's wrong is most of all.I'll ha' thee burnt.Ha!How fares my Kate?Say to me, when sawest thou the Prince Florizel, my son?It is a quarrel just and reasonable, To be revenged on him that slew my husband.When he lies along, After your way his tale pronounced shall bury His reasons with his body.And pardon, father, for I knew not thee!Where is thy conscience now?If God prevent not, I purpose so.You're very welcome.O, not by much.Who's here?Let's from this place.It likes me well.Now, by my troth, if I had been remember'd, I could have given my uncle's grace a flout, To touch his growth nearer than he touch'd mine.or my guest?The king shall be contented: must he lose The name of king?A combless cock, so Kate will be my hen.Go with me to the vault.Ay, but give me worship and quietness; I like it better than a dangerous honour.Sir, my gracious lord, To chide at your extremes it not becomes me: O, pardon, that I name them!I did not kill your husband.his choler?Where is the enemy?As thou lovest me, Camillo, wipe not out the rest of thy services by leaving me now: the need I have of thee thine own goodness hath made; better not to have had thee than thus to want thee: thou, having made me businesses which none without thee can sufficiently manage, must either stay to execute them thyself or take away with thee the very services thou hast done; which if I have not enough considered, as too much I cannot, to be more thankful to thee shall be my study, and my profit therein the heaping friendships.no more!mark you His absolute 'shall'?Go, bind thou up yon dangling apricocks, Which, like unruly children, make their sire Stoop with oppression of their prodigal weight: Give some supportance to the bending twigs.I could not send it,--here it is again,-- Nor get a messenger to bring it thee, So fearful were they of infection.I say, if he would incline to the people, there was never a worthier man.my lady!Either forbear, Quit presently the chapel, or resolve you For more amazement.If they have done this thing, my gracious lord-- If I thou protector of this damned strumpet-- Tellest thou me of 'ifs'?She embraces him.We have not yet been seen in any house, Nor can we lie distinguish'd by our faces For man or master; then it follows thus; Thou shalt be master, Tranio, in my stead, Keep house and port and servants as I should: I will some other be, some Florentine, Some Neapolitan, or meaner man of Pisa.for shame, if not for charity.Sound, trumpets; and set forward, combatants.Would he do so, I'ld beg your precious mistress, Which he counts but a trifle.Flower of warriors, How is it with Titus Lartius?Alas!how goes the world with thee?Wilt thou, O God, fly from such gentle lambs, And throw them in the entrails of the wolf?Hold, daughter: I do spy a kind of hope, Which craves as desperate an execution.Go, take it up unto thy master's use.And say'st thou yet that exile is not death?Fear not, my lord, we will not stand to prate; Talkers are no good doers: be assured We come to use our hands and not our tongues.What's gone and what's past help Should be past grief: do not receive affliction At my petition; I beseech you, rather Let me be punish'd, that have minded you Of what you should forget.O, but, sir, Your resolution cannot hold, when 'tis Opposed, as it must be, by the power of the king: One of these two must be necessities, Which then will speak, that you must change this purpose, Or I my life.Now, Warwick, wilt thou ope the city gates, Speak gentle words and humbly bend thy knee, Call Edward king and at his hands beg mercy?why, no.We follow thee.So.We charge you, that you have contrived to take From Rome all season'd office and to wind Yourself into a power tyrannical; For which you are a traitor to the people.Who knows the lord protector's mind herein?Away, begone; the sport is at the best.The Emperor of Russia was my father: O that he were alive, and here beholding His daughter's trial!I know none.Friend, Art thou certain this is true?Go, sirrah, take them to the buttery, And give them friendly welcome every one: Let them want nothing that my house affords.In truth, fair Montague, I am too fond, And therefore thou mayst think my 'havior light: But trust me, gentleman, I'll prove more true Than those that have more cunning to be strange.Welcome, then.You urged me as a judge; but I had rather You would have bid me argue like a father.To fear the foe, since fear oppresseth strength, Gives in your weakness strength unto your foe, And so your follies fight against yourself.'Though all at once cannot See what I do deliver out to each, Yet I can make my audit up, that all From me do back receive the flour of all, And leave me but the bran.'So, farewell.And, honest company, I thank you all, That have beheld me give away myself To this most patient, sweet and virtuous wife: Dine with my father, drink a health to me; For I must hence; and farewell to you all.Pray you, sit down; For now we sit to chat as well as eat.'Tis not possible.O, let her brother live!Unbuckle, unbuckle.He breathes, my lord.Hail, noble Marcius!Here is a friar, and slaughter'd Romeo's man; With instruments upon them, fit to open These dead men's tombs.What cheer?Why, then mine honesty shall be my dower; For by that loss I will not purchase them.Very true, sir; he, sir, he; that's the rogue that put me into this apparel.Shall I draw the curtain?Oxford, how haps it, in this smooth discourse, You told not how Henry the Sixth hath lost All that which Henry Fifth had gotten?I cry thee mercy then, for I had thought That thou hadst call'd me all these bitter names.Why, 'Jack, boy!No, by my life.And therefore is he idle?You have told me too many of him already, sir, if they be true; if not true, none were enough.I, by attorney, bless thee from thy mother Who prays continually for Richmond's good: So much for that.mount thee upon his horse; Spur post, and get before him to the king, And beg thy pardon ere he do accuse thee.I warrant your honour.Thanks.Noble Menenius, Be you then as the people's officer.My cousin Juliet?God bless your grace!good Mercutio!Marry, and did; but if you be remember'd, I did not bid you mar it to the time.O slaves, I can tell you news,-- news, you rascals!Besides, he hates me for my father Warwick; And will, no doubt, shortly be rid of me.But how is it That this lives in thy mind?And I, as I love Hastings with my heart!This is the point.Or shall we on the helmets of our foes Tell our devotion with revengeful arms?'Tis torture, and not mercy: heaven is here, Where Juliet lives; and every cat and dog And little mouse, every unworthy thing, Live here in heaven and may look on her; But Romeo may not: more validity, More honourable state, more courtship lives In carrion-flies than Romeo: they my seize On the white wonder of dear Juliet's hand And steal immortal blessing from her lips, Who even in pure and vestal modesty, Still blush, as thinking their own kisses sin; But Romeo may not; he is banished: Flies may do this, but I from this must fly: They are free men, but I am banished.How now!Let it go; there's few or none will entertain it.Neighbour, well met: whither away so fast?There's some among you have beheld me fighting: Come, try upon yourselves what you have seen me.O, I cannot speak!O the heavens!Come, I'll dispose of thee Among a sisterhood of holy nuns: Stay not to question, for the watch is coming; Come, go, good Juliet, I dare no longer stay.Well, well, put up your sword.Sir, she came in great with child; and longing, saving your honour's reverence, for stewed prunes; sir, we had but two in the house, which at that very distant time stood, as it were, in a fruit-dish, a dish of some three-pence; your honours have seen such dishes; they are not China dishes, but very good dishes,-- Go to, go to: no matter for the dish, sir.No, to the dignity and height of honour The high imperial type of this earth's glory.I am content.will you let it fall?May call it back again.Thus have we swept suspicion from our seat And made our footstool of security.By heaven, fond wretch, thou knowist not what thou speak'st, Or else thou art suborn'd against his honour In hateful practise.Therefore, no more but this: Henry, your sovereign, Is prisoner to the foe; his state usurp'd, His realm a slaughter-house, his subjects slain, His statutes cancell'd and his treasure spent; And yonder is the wolf that makes this spoil.Now I'll tell you without asking: my master is the great rich Capulet; and if you be not of the house of Montagues, I pray, come and crush a cup of wine.O, forfend it, God, That in a Christian climate souls refined Should show so heinous, black, obscene a deed!I say 'silver sound,' because musicians sound for silver.'Zounds, consort!These arms of mine shall be thy winding-sheet; My heart, sweet boy, shall be thy sepulchre, For from my heart thine image ne'er shall go; My sighing breast shall be thy funeral bell; And so obsequious will thy father be, Even for the loss of thee, having no more, As Priam was for all his valiant sons.My grave is like to be my wedding bed.Farewell, my blood; which if to-day thou shed, Lament we may, but not revenge thee dead.Good Lord, how you take it!I am courtier cap-a-pe; and one that will either push on or pluck back thy business there: whereupon I command thee to open thy affair.I pray you home to dinner with me.Prince, as thou art true, For blood of ours, shed blood of Montague.Who is't that calls Hail, virgin, if you be, as those cheek-roses Proclaim you are no less!O that ever I was born!Can curses pierce the clouds and enter heaven?The duty that I owe unto your majesty I seal upon the lips of this sweet babe.This comes off well; here's a wise officer.you say your husband.Give me thy hand.O fie!She is the fairies' midwife, and she comes In shape no bigger than an agate-stone On the fore-finger of an alderman, Drawn with a team of little atomies Athwart men's noses as they lie asleep; Her wagon-spokes made of long spiders' legs, The cover of the wings of grasshoppers, The traces of the smallest spider's web, The collars of the moonshine's watery beams, Her whip of cricket's bone, the lash of film, Her wagoner a small grey-coated gnat, Not so big as a round little worm Prick'd from the lazy finger of a maid; Her chariot is an empty hazel-nut Made by the joiner squirrel or old grub, Time out o' mind the fairies' coachmakers.None, since the curfew rung.Sirs, let't alone: I will not go to-day; and ere I do, It shall be what o'clock I say it is.when was't before?Why, then, the champions are prepared, and stay For nothing but his majesty's approach.Hang up philosophy!Thou didst smile.Our spoils he kick'd at, And look'd upon things precious as they were The common muck of the world: he covets less Than misery itself would give; rewards His deeds with doing them, and is content To spend the time to end it.'Twas my inheritance, as the earldom was.O tiger's heart wrapt in a woman's hide!O God!As I intend to thrive in this new world, Aumerle is guilty of my true appeal: Besides, I heard the banish'd Norfolk say That thou, Aumerle, didst send two of thy men To execute the noble duke at Calais.This is no witness for Lord Angelo.Your friends, sir; the hangman.In what enormity is Marcius poor in, that you two have not in abundance?I would to heaven I had your potency, And you were Isabel!That's he indeed.She-wolf of France, but worse than wolves of France, Whose tongue more poisons than the adder's tooth!He's a disease that must be cut away.Here is the cap your worship did bespeak.God bless thee; and put meekness in thy mind, Love, charity, obedience, and true duty!Edward for Edward pays a dying debt.I am too sore enpierced with his shaft To soar with his light feathers, and so bound, I cannot bound a pitch above dull woe: Under love's heavy burden do I sink.Nay, by Saint Jamy, I hold you a penny, A horse and a man Is more than one, And yet not many.Our prayers do out-pray his; then let them have That mercy which true prayer ought to have.You mistake, sir, you mistake, sir.Rise up, good aunt.Romeo slew him, he slew Mercutio; Who now the price of his dear blood doth owe?Calmly, I do beseech you.Skulking in corners?Sir, by your leave: having come to Padua To gather in some debts, my son Lucentio Made me acquainted with a weighty cause Of love between your daughter and himself: And, for the good report I hear of you And for the love he beareth to your daughter And she to him, to stay him not too long, I am content, in a good father's care, To have him match'd; and if you please to like No worse than I, upon some agreement Me shall you find ready and willing With one consent to have her so bestow'd; For curious I cannot be with you, Signior Baptista, of whom I hear so well.Come hither, sirrah.Lords, I protest, my soul is full of woe, That blood should sprinkle me to make me grow: Come, mourn with me for that I do lament, And put on sullen black incontinent: I'll make a voyage to the Holy Land, To wash this blood off from my guilty hand: March sadly after; grace my mournings here; In weeping after this untimely bier.Art thou so bare and full of wretchedness, And fear'st to die?I pray thee, good Camillo, be no more importunate: 'tis a sickness denying thee any thing; a death to grant this.Titus Lartius, thou Shalt see me once more strike at Tullus' face.The gods be good unto us!Thou, Richard, shalt to the Duke of Norfolk, And tell him privily of our intent.More light, you knaves; and turn the tables up, And quench the fire, the room is grown too hot.Butchers and villains!What doth our cousin lay to Mowbray's charge?What raiment will your honour wear to-day?What dost thou, or what art thou, Angelo?I'll say yon grey is not the morning's eye, 'Tis but the pale reflex of Cynthia's brow; Nor that is not the lark, whose notes do beat The vaulty heaven so high above our heads: I have more care to stay than will to go: Come, death, and welcome!So shalt thou show me friendship.Richard, I will create thee Duke of Gloucester, And George, of Clarence: Warwick, as ourself, Shall do and undo as him pleaseth best.O loyal father of a treacherous son!Then have my lips the sin that they have took.Most dangerous Is that temptation that doth goad us on To sin in loving virtue: never could the strumpet, With all her double vigour, art and nature, Once stir my temper; but this virtuous maid Subdues me quite.However God or fortune cast my lot, There lives or dies, true to King Richard's throne, A loyal, just and upright gentleman: Never did captive with a freer heart Cast off his chains of bondage and embrace His golden uncontroll'd enfranchisement, More than my dancing soul doth celebrate This feast of battle with mine adversary.Why then, the mustard without the beef.I shall attend your leisure: but make haste; The vaporous night approaches.Thou best know'st What torment I did find thee in; thy groans Did make wolves howl and penetrate the breasts Of ever angry bears: it was a torment To lay upon the damn'd, which Sycorax Could not again undo: it was mine art, When I arrived and heard thee, that made gape The pine and let thee out.Verily, You shall not go: a lady's 'Verily' 's As potent as a lord's.Is it not yours?If that be jest, then all the rest was so.I thank you for this comfort.He swore consent to your succession, His oath enrolled in the parliament; And now to London all the crew are gone, To frustrate both his oath and what beside May make against the house of Lancaster.Alack, poor Richard!The weary sun hath made a golden set, And by the bright track of his fiery car, Gives signal, of a goodly day to-morrow.Lay on our royal sword your banish'd hands; Swear by the duty that you owe to God-- Our part therein we banish with yourselves-- To keep the oath that we administer: You never shall, so help you truth and God!shall a buzzard take thee?Not shine to-day!It is a reeling world, indeed, my lord; And I believe twill never stand upright Tim Richard wear the garland of the realm.Amen, say we: we will be witnesses.Heaven cease this idle humour in your honour!God-den to your worships: more of your conversation would infect my brain, being the herdsmen of the beastly plebeians: I will be bold to take my leave of you.This fellow I remember, Since once he play'd a farmer's eldest son: 'Twas where you woo'd the gentlewoman so well: I have forgot your name; but, sure, that part Was aptly fitted and naturally perform'd.No shame but mine: I must, forsooth, be forced To give my hand opposed against my heart Unto a mad-brain rudesby full of spleen; Who woo'd in haste and means to wed at leisure.Aumerle, thou liest; his honour is as true In this appeal as thou art all unjust; And that thou art so, there I throw my gage, To prove it on thee to the extremest point Of mortal breathing: seize it, if thou darest.But I shall laugh at this a twelve-month hence, That they who brought me in my master's hate I live to look upon their tragedy.what's your will?I must hear from thee every day in the hour, For in a minute there are many days: O, by this count I shall be much in years Ere I again behold my Romeo!You, sirrah, provide your block and your axe to-morrow four o'clock.Now, for my life, she's wandering to the Tower, On pure heart's love to greet the tender princes.What!And you, good brother father.a south-west blow on ye And blister you all o'er!Noble Sebastian, Thou let'st thy fortune sleep--die, rather; wink'stLook, sir, your mother!when done thee wrong?I cannot rest Until the white rose that I wear be dyed Even in the lukewarm blood of Henry's heart.racks?So part we sadly in this troublous world, To meet with joy in sweet Jerusalem.O excellent motion!His answer was, he would unto the stews, And from the common'st creature pluck a glove, And wear it as a favour; and with that He would unhorse the lustiest challenger.Bianca's love Made me exchange my state with Tranio, While he did bear my countenance in the town; And happily I have arrived at the last Unto the wished haven of my bliss.Go, be gone.My remedy is then, to pluck it out.as if I knew not his name: I have brought him up ever since he was three years old, and his name is Tranio.Have with you.What say you now?Who's there?O, true, good Catesby: bid him levy straight The greatest strength and power he can make, And meet me presently at Salisbury.You speak too bitterly.what's the news with you?Petruchio, patience; I am Grumio's pledge: Why, this's a heavy chance 'twixt him and you, Your ancient, trusty, pleasant servant Grumio.But here she comes; and now, Petruchio, speak.A crown for York!Ay, my lord: and fear We have landed in ill time: the skies look grimly And threaten present blusters.My ears have not yet drunk a hundred words Of that tongue's utterance, yet I know the sound: Art thou not Romeo and a Montague?Thou injurious tribune!O' my word, an she knew him as well as I do, she would think scolding would do little good upon him: she may perhaps call him half a score knaves or so: why, that's nothing; an he begin once, he'll rail in his rope-tricks.By my troth, Isabel, I loved thy brother: if the old fantastical duke of dark corners had been at home, he had lived.How, Camillo, May this, almost a miracle, be done?Your suit's unprofitable; stand up, I say.Be intelligent to me: 'tis thereabouts; For, to yourself, what you do know, you must.Say how he died, for I will hear it all.That in the captain's but a choleric word, Which in the soldier is flat blasphemy.That's but a cavil: he is old, I young.Ah, my young princes!Yet I wish, sir,-- I mean for your particular,--you had not Join'd in commission with him; but either Had borne the action of yourself, or else To him had left it solely.Now, lords, take leave until we meet again, Where'er it be, in heaven or in earth.Here comes my son Aumerle.now art thou sociable, now art thou Romeo; now art thou what thou art, by art as well as by nature: for this drivelling love is like a great natural, that runs lolling up and down to hide his bauble in a hole.My lord, 'tis but begun.If I must die, I will encounter darkness as a bride, And hug it in mine arms.Lord, Lord!the apprehension of the good Gives but the greater feeling to the worse: Fell sorrow's tooth doth never rankle more Than when he bites, but lanceth not the sore.Do not bid me Dismiss my soldiers, or capitulate Again with Rome's mechanics: tell me not Wherein I seem unnatural: desire not To ally my rages and revenges with Your colder reasons.How could that be?Then, Pompey, nor now.I take thee at thy word: Call me but love, and I'll be new baptized; Henceforth I never will be Romeo.forswear it, sight!Who ever would have thought it?Though I could wish You were conducted to a gentle bath And balms applied to, you, yet dare I never Deny your asking: take your choice of those That best can aid your action.then, even now, I might have look'd upon my queen's full eyes, Have taken treasure from her lips-- And left them More rich for what they yielded.I have done.Of this make no conclusion, lest you say Your queen and I are devils: yet go on; The offences we have made you do we'll answer, If you first sinn'd with us and that with us You did continue fault and that you slipp'd not With any but with us.Well, on to the market-place.God for his mercy!But I'll be hanged, sir, if he wear your livery: Marry, go before to field, he'll be your follower; Your worship in that sense may call him 'man.'Katharina, you may stay; For I have more to commune with Bianca.How not your own desire?I will not bandy with thee word for word, But buckle with thee blows, twice two for one.There wanteth now our brother Gloucester here, To make the perfect period of this peace.but that I hate thee deadly, I should lament thy miserable state.Thou sheer, immaculate and silver fountain, From when this stream through muddy passages Hath held his current and defiled himself!This is the indictment of the good Lord Hastings; Which in a set hand fairly is engross'd, That it may be this day read over in Paul's.I fear you not.There is no tongue that moves, none, none i' the world, So soon as yours could win me: so it should now, Were there necessity in your request, although 'Twere needful I denied it.He thinks, nay, with all confidence he swears, As he had seen't or been an instrument To vice you to't, that you have touch'd his queen Forbiddenly.O, that a mighty man of such descent, Of such possessions and so high esteem, Should be infused with so foul a spirit!Give me the glass, and therein will I read.Not his that spoils her young before her face.Stay awhile!'Cucullus non facit monachum:' honest in nothing but in his clothes; and one that hath spoke most villanous speeches of the duke.I think he will carry this island home in his pocket and give it his son for an apple.Our spoils we have brought home Do more than counterpoise a full third part The charges of the action.But, peace be with him!If you will live, lament; if die, be brief, That our swift-winged souls may catch the king's; Or, like obedient subjects, follow him To his new kingdom of perpetual rest.I am your sorrow's nurse, And I will pamper it with lamentations.Pardon, dear father.He is.What stratagems, how fell, how butcherly, Erroneous, mutinous and unnatural, This deadly quarrel daily doth beget!By my troth, I'll go with thee to the lane's end: if bawdy talk offend you, we'll have very little of it.I am so sorry for my trespass made That, to deserve well at my brother's hands, I here proclaim myself thy mortal foe, With resolution, wheresoe'er I meet thee-- As I will meet thee, if thou stir abroad-- To plague thee for thy foul misleading me.Thou frantic woman, what dost thou make here?O honey nurse, what news?Why comest thou in such post?Thou factious Duke of York, descend my throne, and kneel for grace and mercy at my feet; I am thy sovereign.We would so, and then go a bat-fowling.Have the power still To banish your defenders; till at length Your ignorance, which finds not till it feels, Making not reservation of yourselves, Still your own foes, deliver you as most Abated captives to some nation That won you without blows!no, sir: I could not forget you, for I never saw you before in all my life.Amongst much other talk, that very time, I heard you say that you had rather refuse The offer of an hundred thousand crowns Than Bolingbroke's return to England; Adding withal how blest this land would be In this your cousin's death.Oh, who shall hinder me to wail and weep, To chide my fortune, and torment myself?Is the king dead?And still is friend to him and Margaret: But if your title to the crown be weak, As may appear by Edward's good success, Then 'tis but reason that I be released From giving aid which late I promised.What is thy name?What, not an oath?Indeed, brother-in-law was the farthest off you could have been to him and then your blood had been the dearer by I know how much an ounce.Why, sir, I pray, are not the streets as free For me as for you?I prithee, hear me speak.My lord!Your grace, we think, should soonest know his mind.No, so God help me, they spake not a word; But, like dumb statues or breathing stones, Gazed each on other, and look'd deadly pale.Well, I do so.Look, how this ring encompasseth finger.Oh, that deceit should steal such gentle shapes, And with a virtuous vizard hide foul guile!I bless the time When my good falcon made her flight across Thy father's ground.I appeal To your own conscience, sir, before Polixenes Came to your court, how I was in your grace, How merited to be so; since he came, With what encounter so uncurrent I Have strain'd to appear thus: if one jot beyond The bound of honour, or in act or will That way inclining, harden'd be the hearts Of all that hear me, and my near'st of kin Cry fie upon my grave!I had rather have one scratch my head i' the sun When the alarum were struck than idly sit To hear my nothings monster'd.Thou hast spoke too much already: get thee gone.Down with the topmast!Provost, a word with you.Why, lo you now, I have spoke to the purpose twice: The one for ever earn'd a royal husband; The other for some while a friend.Each substance of a grief hath twenty shadows, Which shows like grief itself, but is not so; For sorrow's eye, glazed with blinding tears, Divides one thing entire to many objects; Like perspectives, which rightly gazed upon Show nothing but confusion, eyed awry Distinguish form: so your sweet majesty, Looking awry upon your lord's departure, Find shapes of grief, more than himself, to wail; Which, look'd on as it is, is nought but shadows Of what it is not.We were as twinn'd lambs that did frisk i' the sun, And bleat the one at the other: what we changed Was innocence for innocence; we knew not The doctrine of ill-doing, nor dream'd That any did.it is my father's face, Whom in this conflict I unwares have kill'd.I'll plant Plantagenet, root him up who dares: Resolve thee, Richard; claim the English crown.Nay, you shall have no hat.I told you, I, he was a frantic fool, Hiding his bitter jests in blunt behavior: And, to be noted for a merry man, He'll woo a thousand, 'point the day of marriage, Make feasts, invite friends, and proclaim the banns; Yet never means to wed where he hath woo'd.Break off the parley; for scarce I can refrain The execution of my big-swoln heart Upon that Clifford, that cruel child-killer.Play the men.Well; what's your suit?how seems he to be touched?Doth this news hold of good King Edward's death?the smiles of knaves Tent in my cheeks, and schoolboys' tears take up The glasses of my sight!We make woe wanton with this fond delay: Once more, adieu; the rest let sorrow say.Things sweet to taste prove in digestion sour.What wert thou, if the King of Naples heard thee?Biondello, hie you home, And bid Bianca make her ready straight; And, if you will, tell what hath happened, Lucentio's father is arrived in Padua, And how she's like to be Lucentio's wife.Thou foolish friar, and thou pernicious woman, Compact with her that's gone, think'st thou thy oaths, Though they would swear down each particular saint, Were testimonies against his worth and credit That's seal'd in approbation?Gentle Northumberland, If thy offences were upon record, Would it not shame thee in so fair a troop To read a lecture of them?They are worn, lord consul, so, That we shall hardly in our ages see Their banners wave again.Very well: you being then, if you be remembered, cracking the stones of the foresaid prunes,-- Ay, so I did indeed.And here he comes.my soul, and not my child!I hear some noise.I pray you do.What says your highness to my just demand?let's pluck him down: My heart for anger burns; I cannot brook it.Only make trial what your love can do For Rome, towards Marcius.Tell me, for you seem to be honest plain men, what you have to the king: being something gently considered, I'll bring you where he is aboard, tender your persons to his presence, whisper him in your behalfs; and if it be in man besides the king to effect your suits, here is man shall do it.sport?And, that I love the tree from whence thou sprang'st, Witness the loving kiss I give the fruit.Why, Petruchio is coming in a new hat and an old jerkin, a pair of old breeches thrice turned, a pair of boots that have been candle-cases, one buckled, another laced, an old rusty sword ta'en out of the town-armory, with a broken hilt, and chapeless; with two broken points: his horse hipped with an old mothy saddle and stirrups of no kindred; besides, possessed with the glanders and like to mose in the chine; troubled with the lampass, infected with the fashions, full of wingdalls, sped with spavins, rayed with yellows, past cure of the fives, stark spoiled with the staggers, begnawn with the bots, swayed in the back and shoulder-shotten; near-legged before and with, a half-chequed bit and a head-stall of sheeps leather which, being restrained to keep him from stumbling, hath been often burst and now repaired with knots; one girth six time pieced and a woman's crupper of velure, which hath two letters for her name fairly set down in studs, and here and there pieced with packthread.madman!Fouler than heart can think thee, thou canst make No excuse current, but to hang thyself.Look, signior, here's your sister.he will do't; for, look you, sir, he has as many friends as enemies; which friends, sir, as it were, durst not, look you, sir, show themselves, as we term it, his friends whilst he's in directitude.To your worship's house, sir?So dear I loved the man, that I must weep.A woman.This is strange now: do you two know how you are censured here in the city, I mean of us o' the right-hand file?Best of my flesh, Forgive my tyranny; but do not say For that 'Forgive our Romans.'Proclaim it, provost, round about the city.I think most understand Bohemia stays here longer.I was not much afeard; for once or twice I was about to speak and tell him plainly, The selfsame sun that shines upon his court Hides not his visage from our cottage but Looks on alike.And is Aufidius with him?So shall you bind me to your highness' service.Should by the cormorant belly be restrain'd, Who is the sink o' the body,-- Well, what then?where have you been gadding?Sir, at the farthest for a week or two: But then up farther, and as for as Rome; And so to Tripoli, if God lend me life.why, she was dead ere thou wert born.Good my lord,-- It is for you we speak, not for ourselves: You are abused and by some putter-on That will be damn'd for't; would I knew the villain, I would land-damn him.O master, master, I have watch'd so long That I am dog-weary: but at last I spied An ancient angel coming down the hill, Will serve the turn.This kind of service Did not deserve corn gratis.Their latest refuge Was to send him; for whose old love I have, Though I show'd sourly to him, once more offer'd The first conditions, which they did refuse And cannot now accept; to grace him only That thought he could do more, a very little I have yielded to: fresh embassies and suits, Nor from the state nor private friends, hereafter Will I lend ear to.You have often Begun to tell me what I am, but stopp'd And left me to a bootless inquisition, Concluding 'Stay: not yet.'lady, such a man As all the world--why, he's a man of wax.Mount, mount, my soul!Being so great, I have no need to beg.If for the last, say ay, and to it, lords.Who sues to thee and cries 'God save the queen'?I doubt not but his friends will fly to us.Could you not take some occasion without giving?Ladies, you deserve To have a temple built you: all the swords In Italy, and her confederate arms, Could not have made this peace.Therefore lay hold of him; Bear him to the rock Tarpeian, and from thence Into destruction cast him.I tell thee, Kate, 'twas burnt and dried away; And I expressly am forbid to touch it, For it engenders choler, planteth anger; And better 'twere that both of us did fast, Since, of ourselves, ourselves are choleric, Than feed it with such over-roasted flesh.and more than so, my father, Even in the downfall of his mellow'd years, When nature brought him to the door of death?I tell thee, man, 'tis better with me now Than when I met thee last where now we meet: Then was I going prisoner to the Tower, By the suggestion of the queen's allies; But now, I tell thee--keep it to thyself-- This day those enemies are put to death, And I in better state than e'er I was.O, sir, Lucentio slipp'd me like his greyhound, Which runs himself and catches for his master.And live you yet?Ay, sir, by Mistress Overdone's means: but as she spit in his face, so she defied him.Romeo!mark'd you not how her sister Began to scold and raise up such a storm That mortal ears might hardly endure the din?Indeed, it does stink in some sort, sir; but yet, sir, I would prove-- Nay, if the devil have given thee proofs for sin, Thou wilt prove his.What think'st thou, then, of Stanley?Brother, I'll go and bring it thee.Tut, I can counterfeit the deep tragedian; Speak and look back, and pry on every side, Tremble and start at wagging of a straw, Intending deep suspicion: ghastly looks Are at my service, like enforced smiles; And both are ready in their offices, At any time, to grace my stratagems.Father, what news?the friar is come.Your native town you enter'd like a post, And had no welcomes home: but he returns, Splitting the air with noise.Lords, you that here are under our arrest, Procure your sureties for your days of answer.Isabel, Sweet Isabel, do yet but kneel by me; Hold up your hands, say nothing; I'll speak all.know you on which side They have placed their men of trust?He that has the two fair daughters: is't he you mean?If he did not care whether he had their love or no, he waved indifferently 'twixt doing them neither good nor harm: but he seeks their hate with greater devotion than can render it him; and leaves nothing undone that may fully discover him their opposite.I shall, between this and supper, tell you most strange things from Rome; all tending to the good of their adversaries.fear not, man, but yield me up the keys; For Edward will defend the town and thee, And all those friends that deign to follow me.you make me study of that: she was of Carthage, not of Tunis.But what thou art, God, thou, and I do know; And all too soon, I fear, the king shall rue.You had much ado to make his anchor hold: When you cast out, it still came home.Why, what of that?I told him that your father was at Venice, And that you look'd for him this day in Padua.Feeling so the loss, Cannot choose but ever weep the friend.O, what more favour can I do to thee, Than with that hand that cut thy youth in twain To sunder his that was thine enemy?Dear gentlewoman, How fares our gracious lady?I slew thy father, call'st thou him a child?And leave you to the hearing of the cause; Hoping you'll find good cause to whip them all.O boy, thy father gave thee life too soon, And hath bereft thee of thy life too late!To justify this worthy nobleman, So vulgarly and personally accused, Her shall you hear disproved to her eyes, Till she herself confess it.I wonder how the king escaped our hands.'Twere well We let the people know't.I say unto you, what he hath done famously, he did it to that end: though soft-conscienced men can be content to say it was for his country he did it to please his mother and to be partly proud; which he is, even till the altitude of his virtue.Hold, hold, hold, hold!Darest thou, thou little better thing than earth, Divine his downfall?Be fickle, fortune; For then, I hope, thou wilt not keep him long, But send him back.Nay, mother, Where is your ancient courage?My mind hath been as big as one of yours, My heart as great, my reason haply more, To bandy word for word and frown for frown; But now I see our lances are but straws, Our strength as weak, our weakness past compare, That seeming to be most which we indeed least are.Once more, adieu: be valiant, and speed well!O, the cry did knock Against my very heart.How do you both?I am inform'd that he comes towards London, To set the crown once more on Henry's head: Guess thou the rest; King Edward's friends must down, But, to prevent the tyrant's violence,-- For trust not him that hath once broken faith,-- I'll hence forthwith unto the sanctuary, To save at least the heir of Edward's right: There shall I rest secure from force and fraud.O cousin, cousin!But, come, let's home.My lord?The ship, sir, the slip; can you not conceive?Go hence; good night; and here stands all your state: Either be gone before the watch be set, Or by the break of day disguised from hence: Sojourn in Mantua; I'll find out your man, And he shall signify from time to time Every good hap to you that chances here: Give me thy hand; 'tis late: farewell; good night.What shall I do?Thou pratest, and pratest; serve with thy trencher, hence!Sirrah Biondello, go and entreat my wife To come to me forthwith.Who made thee, then, a bloody minister, When gallant-springing brave Plantagenet, That princely novice, was struck dead by thee?As this is true, Let me in safety raise me from my knees Or else for ever be confixed here, A marble monument!Even so As with a man by his own alms empoison'd, And with his charity slain.that bed, that womb, That metal, that self-mould, that fashion'd thee Made him a man; and though thou livest and breathest, Yet art thou slain in him: thou dost consent In some large measure to thy father's death, In that thou seest thy wretched brother die, Who was the model of thy father's life.But where is Kate?speak suddenly; be brief.I have stood by, my lord, and I have heard Your royal ear abused.Do right unto this princely Duke of York, Or I will fill the house with armed men, And over the chair of state, where now he sits, Write up his title with usurping blood.who comes here?God give your graces both A happy and a joyful time of day!I am confessor to Angelo, and I know this to be true; therefore prepare yourself to death: do not satisfy your resolution with hopes that are fallible: tomorrow you must die; go to your knees and make ready.Nurse, where's my daughter?I hope, sir, your good worship will be my bail.which their keepers call A lightning before death: O, how may I Call this a lightning?Therefore, to speak, and to avoid the first, And then, in speaking, not to incur the last, Definitively thus I answer you.O, what might?--No more:-- And yet me thinks I see it in thy face, What thou shouldst be: the occasion speaks thee, and My strong imagination sees a crown Dropping upon thy head.Ancient damnation!she weeps.I thank my good father, I am able to maintain it.I learnt it out of women's faces.And am I guerdon'd at the last with shame?O prince, I conjure thee, as thou believest There is another comfort than this world, That thou neglect me not, with that opinion That I am touch'd with madness!Why, then he will say we stabbed him sleeping.so ho!O, 'tis the cunning livery of hell, The damned'st body to invest and cover In prenzie guards!Or docks, or mallows.O mother!I would I were as sure of a good dinner.I do remember an apothecary,-- And hereabouts he dwells,--which late I noted In tatter'd weeds, with overwhelming brows, Culling of simples; meagre were his looks, Sharp misery had worn him to the bones: And in his needy shop a tortoise hung, An alligator stuff'd, and other skins Of ill-shaped fishes; and about his shelves A beggarly account of empty boxes, Green earthen pots, bladders and musty seeds, Remnants of packthread and old cakes of roses, Were thinly scatter'd, to make up a show.So: Lie there, my art.what, mistress!How prettily the young swain seems to wash The hand was fair before!I beseech your grace to pardon me, and withal Forbear your conference with the noble duke.Hast thou that holy feeling in thy soul, To counsel me to make my peace with God, And art thou yet to thy own soul so blind, That thou wilt war with God by murdering me?Hark!But now, Baptists, to your younger daughter: Now is the day we long have looked for: I am your neighbour, and was suitor first.Return to the tribunes.Whipt first, sir, and hanged after.Who meets us here?He says so, Tranio.O, that your young nobility could judge What 'twere to lose it, and be miserable!Richmond is on the seas.No; I would tell what 'twere to be a judge, And what a prisoner.My haste may not admit it; Nor need you, on mine honour, have to do With any scruple; your scope is as mine own So to enforce or qualify the laws As to your soul seems good.My brother, Are you so fond of your young prince as we Do seem to be of ours?Even till now, When men were fond, I smiled and wonder'd how.Marcius, We have at disadvantage fought and did Retire to win our purpose.Then, Bolingbroke, as low as to thy heart, Through the false passage of thy throat, thou liest.Go sleep, and hear us.Servants, leave me and her alone.Do you hear?I got them in my country's service, when Some certain of your brethren roar'd and ran From the noise of our own drums.'Adieu, my lord: I never wish'd to see you sorry; now I trust I shall.On him I lay what you would lay on me, The right and fortune of his happy stars; Which God defend that I should wring from him!Now will he sit under a medlar tree, And wish his mistress were that kind of fruit As maids call medlars, when they laugh alone.Now, good sir, You know me, do you not?These fifteen years!My friend, I spy some pity in thy looks: O, if thine eye be not a flatterer, Come thou on my side, and entreat for me, As you would beg, were you in my distress A begging prince what beggar pities not?it is the rival of my love.A letter for me!Juliet, on Thursday early will I rouse ye: Till then, adieu; and keep this holy kiss.Nay, he will answer the letter's master, how he dares, being dared.Despair not, madam.Ay, there's the villany.My lord: he doth entreat your grace; To visit him to-morrow or next day: He is within, with two right reverend fathers, Divinely bent to meditation; And no worldly suit would he be moved, To draw him from his holy exercise.'Tis a villain, sir, I do not love to look on.What then?When, Harry, when?The air breathes upon us here most sweetly.Ah, thou, the model where old Troy did stand, Thou map of honour, thou King Richard's tomb, And not King Richard; thou most beauteous inn, Why should hard-favour'd grief be lodged in thee, When triumph is become an alehouse guest?But who comes here?Peace have they made with him indeed, my lord.Come, let us go: This fellow had a Volscian to his mother; His wife is in Corioli and his child Like him by chance.None, man; all idle: whores and knaves.His face thou hast, for even so look'd he, Accomplish'd with the number of thy hours; But when he frown'd, it was against the French And not against his friends; his noble hand Did will what he did spend and spent not that Which his triumphant father's hand had won; His hands were guilty of no kindred blood, But bloody with the enemies of his kin.Now, sir, her father counts it dangerous That she doth give her sorrow so much sway, And in his wisdom hastes our marriage, To stop the inundation of her tears; Which, too much minded by herself alone, May be put from her by society: Now do you know the reason of this haste.Come on; We'll visit Caliban my slave, who never Yields us kind answer.You pay a great deal too dear for what's given freely.You do the nobler.My lord, I dare not: Sir Pierce of Exton, who lately came from the king, commands the contrary.There might you have beheld one joy crown another, so and in such manner that it seemed sorrow wept to take leave of them, for their joy waded in tears.O, you are novices!it cannot be.You blame Marcius for being proud?I would to God that the inclusive verge Of golden metal that must round my brow Were red-hot steel, to sear me to the brain!Which for some reasons, sir, I mean to see.If thou art rich, thou'rt poor; For, like an ass whose back with ingots bows, Thou bear's thy heavy riches but a journey, And death unloads thee.Wondrous heavy.For Polixenes, With whom I am accused, I do confess I loved him as in honour he required, With such a kind of love as might become A lady like me, with a love even such, So and no other, as yourself commanded: Which not to have done I think had been in me Both disobedience and ingratitude To you and toward your friend, whose love had spoke, Even since it could speak, from an infant, freely That it was yours.God's will, What simpleness is this!There is a sickness Which puts some of us in distemper, but I cannot name the disease; and it is caught Of you that yet are well.They're here with me already, whispering, rounding 'Sicilia is a so-forth:' 'tis far gone, When I shall gust it last.God join'd my heart and Romeo's, thou our hands; And ere this hand, by thee to Romeo seal'd, Shall be the label to another deed, Or my true heart with treacherous revolt Turn to another, this shall slay them both: Therefore, out of thy long-experienced time, Give me some present counsel, or, behold, 'Twixt my extremes and me this bloody knife Shall play the umpire, arbitrating that Which the commission of thy years and art Could to no issue of true honour bring.If ever he return and I can speak to him, I will open my lips in vain, or discover his government.This is no mortal business, nor no sound That the earth owes.his name is Lucentio and he is mine only son, and heir to the lands of me, Signior Vincentio.How now, fair shepherd!But who comes here?Before the time be out?One of the prettiest touches of all and that which angled for mine eyes, caught the water though not the fish, was when, at the relation of the queen's death, with the manner how she came to't bravely confessed and lamented by the king, how attentiveness wounded his daughter; till, from one sign of dolour to another, she did, with an 'Alas,' I would fain say, bleed tears, for I am sure my heart wept blood.mine old master Vincentio!How now, my friend!Now he's coming; And not a hair upon a soldier's head Which will not prove a whip: as many coxcombs As you threw caps up will he tumble down, And pay you for your voices.He must, and will Prithee now, say you will, and go about it.Your mistress' name?You promised knighthood to our forward son: Unsheathe your sword, and dub him presently.I did not, sir: These lords, my noble fellows, if they please, Can clear me in't.'Twas told me you were rough and coy and sullen, And now I find report a very liar; For thou are pleasant, gamesome, passing courteous, But slow in speech, yet sweet as spring-time flowers: Thou canst not frown, thou canst not look askance, Nor bite the lip, as angry wenches will, Nor hast thou pleasure to be cross in talk, But thou with mildness entertain'st thy wooers, With gentle conference, soft and affable.Come forth, I say!Pray now, sit down.Give me no help in lamentation; I am not barren to bring forth complaints All springs reduce their currents to mine eyes, That I, being govern'd by the watery moon, May send forth plenteous tears to drown the world!Why brother Rivers, are you yet to learn What late misfortune is befall'n King Edward?I was a poor groom of thy stable, king, When thou wert king; who, travelling towards York, With much ado at length have gotten leave To look upon my sometimes royal master's face.to prayers, to prayers!Farewell till soon.They thus directed, we will follow In the main battle, whose puissance on either side Shall be well winged with our chiefest horse.out, you baggage!and did they so?Widow, we will consider of your suit; And come some other time to know our mind.Mark a little while.I'll be sworn they are true.Here comes the Lady Paulina's steward: he can deliver you more.When I return with victory from the field I'll see your grace: till then I'll follow her.From worthy Edward, King of Albion, My lord and sovereign, and thy vowed friend, I come, in kindness and unfeigned love, First, to do greetings to thy royal person; And then to crave a league of amity; And lastly, to confirm that amity With a nuptial knot, if thou vouchsafe to grant That virtuous Lady Bona, thy fair sister, To England's king in lawful marriage.Marry, and will, my lord, with all my heart.I swear I will not die to-day for any man's persuasion.Strike up the drum; cry 'Courage!'No, no; no man saw 'em.A creature unprepared, unmeet for death; And to transport him in the mind he is Were damnable.He, sir, sitting, as I say, in a lower chair, sir; 'twas in the Bunch of Grapes, where indeed you have a delight to sit, have you not?I tell you, he does sit in gold, his eye Red as 'twould burn Rome; and his injury The gaoler to his pity.No sleep close up that deadly eye of thine, Unless it be whilst some tormenting dream Affrights thee with a hell of ugly devils!Then, gentle Clarence, welcome unto Warwick; And welcome, Somerset: I hold it cowardice To rest mistrustful where a noble heart Hath pawn'd an open hand in sign of love; Else might I think that Clarence, Edward's brother, Were but a feigned friend to our proceedings: But welcome, sweet Clarence; my daughter shall be thine.But she, your subject, loathes such sovereignty.Well, say.I have done As you have done; that's what I can; induced As you have been; that's for my country: He that has but effected his good will Hath overta'en mine act.What service is here!Who sets me else?Now the gods keep you!If I may trust the flattering truth of sleep, My dreams presage some joyful news at hand: My bosom's lord sits lightly in his throne; And all this day an unaccustom'd spirit Lifts me above the ground with cheerful thoughts.Shave the head, and tie the beard; and say it was the desire of the penitent to be so bared before his death: you know the course is common.Harp not on that string, madam; that is past.You are one of those Would have him wed again.Yea, at all points; and longs to enter in.a beggar's tongue Make motion through my lips, and my arm'd knees, Who bow'd but in my stirrup, bend like his That hath received an alms!I saw him run after a gilded butterfly: and when he caught it, he let it go again; and after it again; and over and over he comes, and again; catched it again; or whether his fall enraged him, or how 'twas, he did so set his teeth and tear it; O, I warrant it, how he mammocked it!Neighbours and friends, though bride and bridegroom wants For to supply the places at the table, You know there wants no junkets at the feast.Let no man mock me, For I will kiss her.and but I be deceived Signior Baptista may remember me, Near twenty years ago, in Genoa, Where we were lodgers at the Pegasus.'Tis one thing to be tempted, Escalus, Another thing to fall.Therefore, be gone.He does me double wrong That wounds me with the flatteries of his tongue.And fearless minds climb soonest unto crowns.Here love; thou see'st how diligent I am To dress thy meat myself and bring it thee: I am sure, sweet Kate, this kindness merits thanks.I know not where to turn: O, welcome home: And welcome, general: and ye're welcome all.I'll tell him what you say, my lord.Say as he says, or we shall never go.And, to sink in it, should you burden love; Too great oppression for a tender thing.If you are learn'd, Be not as common fools; if you are not, Let them have cushions by you.A prize!Now you are heir, therefore enjoy it now: By giving the house of Lancaster leave to breathe, It will outrun you, father, in the end.comfort me, counsel me.Who in this kind of merry fooling am nothing to you: so you may continue and laugh at nothing still.Call hither, I say, bid come before us Angelo.For what reason, I beseech you?Beshrew your heart for sending me about, To catch my death with jaunting up and down!And do you tell me of a woman's tongue, That gives not half so great a blow to hear As will a chestnut in a farmer's fire?The gods give you joy, sir, heartily!You will set cock-a-hoop!Thus, like the formal vice, Iniquity, I moralize two meanings in one word.Why, so: you have made good work!My brother and thy uncle, call'd Antonio-- I pray thee, mark me--that a brother should Be so perfidious!--he whom next thyself Of all the world I loved and to him put The manage of my state;
