as at that time Through all the signories it was the first And Prospero the prime duke, being so reputed In dignity, and for the liberal arts Without a parallel; those being all my study, The government I cast upon my brother And to my state grew stranger, being transported And rapt in secret studies.I'll beg one boon, And then be gone and trouble you no more.I thought no less: it is his policy To haste thus fast, to find us unprovided.humours!Madam.What, is my beaver easier than it was?Thou wrong'st it, more than tears, with that report.She being none of your flesh and blood, your flesh and blood has not offended the king; and so your flesh and blood is not to be punished by him.Bid me farewell.Three glorious suns, each one a perfect sun; Not separated with the racking clouds, But sever'd in a pale clear-shining sky.Romeo, hist!Sirrah, get you hence, And bid my cousin Ferdinand come hither: One, Kate, that you must kiss, and be acquainted with.Villain, I say, knock me at this gate And rap me well, or I'll knock your knave's pate.the day is spent.We have made peace With no less honour to the Antiates Than shame to the Romans: and we here deliver, Subscribed by the consuls and patricians, Together with the seal o' the senate, what We have compounded on.Have you a mind to sink?Assist.Nine!No, my good lord, my friends are in the north.O world, thy slippery turns!Go, Bushy, to the Earl of Wiltshire straight: Bid him repair to us to Ely House To see this business.What is the matter, Aumerle.Ah, froward Clarence!Alas poor Romeo!Send thy man away.What comfort is for Claudio?Good night, good night!Fetch hither Richard, that in common view He may surrender; so we shall proceed Without suspicion.O, teach me how I should forget to think.With signs of war about his aged neck: O, full of careful business are his looks!Yea, and much more: but I was born so high, Our aery buildeth in the cedar's top, And dallies with the wind and scorns the sun.Are you a maid?He is your husband on a pre-contract: To bring you thus together, 'tis no sin, Sith that the justice of your title to him Doth flourish the deceit.I'll enter: if he slay me, He does fair justice; if he give me way, I'll do his country service.such safety finds The trembling lamb environed with wolves.We are, my lord; and come to have the warrant That we may be admitted where he is.Stand fast, good Fate, to his hanging: make the rope of his destiny our cable, for our own doth little advantage.A noble fellow, I warrant him.Knock you here, sir!I think, or in any religion.News from Verona!--How now, Balthasar!Are you there, butcher?But come; our dance, I pray: Your hand, my Perdita: so turtles pair, That never mean to part.Will you give thanks, sweet Kate; or else shall I?Ay, spare us not.Eleven, sir.and how comest thou hither, Where no man never comes but that sad dog That brings me food to make misfortune live?How fain, like Pilate, would I wash my hands Of this most grievous guilty murder done!He hath released him, Isabel, from the world: His head is off and sent to Angelo.Come, follow us; We are to speak in public; for this business Will raise us all.Go take her hence, and marry her instantly.Well, somewhat we must do.I am but sorry, not afeard; delay'd, But nothing alter'd: what I was, I am; More straining on for plucking back, not following My leash unwillingly.Thus doth he force the swords of wicked men To turn their own points on their masters' bosoms: Now Margaret's curse is fallen upon my head; 'When he,' quoth she, 'shall split thy heart with sorrow, Remember Margaret was a prophetess.'Most welcome!Sea-nymphs hourly ring his knell Hark!Hold, take this letter; early in the morning See thou deliver it to my lord and father.If I must not, I need not be barren of accusations; he hath faults, with surplus, to tire in repetition.Then have you lost a sight, which was to be seen, cannot be spoken of.Why I desire thee To give me secret harbour, hath a purpose More grave and wrinkled than the aims and ends Of burning youth.Go, get thee to thy love, as was decreed, Ascend her chamber, hence and comfort her: But look thou stay not till the watch be set, For then thou canst not pass to Mantua; Where thou shalt live, till we can find a time To blaze your marriage, reconcile your friends, Beg pardon of the prince, and call thee back With twenty hundred thousand times more joy Than thou went'st forth in lamentation.I should so.And, for an entrance to my entertainment, I do present you with a man of mine, Cunning in music and the mathematics, To instruct her fully in those sciences, Whereof I know she is not ignorant: Accept of him, or else you do me wrong: His name is Licio, born in Mantua.The town is ta'en!Then strike up drums: God and Saint George for us!who's there?My lord, whoever journeys to the Prince, For God's sake, let not us two be behind; For, by the way, I'll sort occasion, As index to the story we late talk'd of, To part the queen's proud kindred from the king.Feed not thy sovereign's foe, my gentle earth, Nor with thy sweets comfort his ravenous sense; But let thy spiders, that suck up thy venom, And heavy-gaited toads lie in their way, Doing annoyance to the treacherous feet Which with usurping steps do trample thee: Yield stinging nettles to mine enemies; And when they from thy bosom pluck a flower, Guard it, I pray thee, with a lurking adder Whose double tongue may with a mortal touch Throw death upon thy sovereign's enemies.That would I learn of you, As one that are best acquainted with her humour.He must be told on't, and he shall: the office Becomes a woman best; I'll take't upon me: If I prove honey-mouth'd let my tongue blister And never to my red-look'd anger be The trumpet any more.Most miserable hour that e'er time saw In lasting labour of his pilgrimage!3 KING HENRY VI Now here a period of tumultuous broils.He shall not, Isabel, if you give me love.I say, he shall: go to; Am I the master here, or you?Be ruled by me, forget to think of her.First, mighty sovereign, let me know your mind, What from your grace I shall deliver to him.by whom?He has no equal.It cannot be.You have made fair work!Well, there went but a pair of shears between us.O, be some other name!Carlisle, this is your doom: Choose out some secret place, some reverend room, More than thou hast, and with it joy thy life; So as thou livest in peace, die free from strife: For though mine enemy thou hast ever been, High sparks of honour in thee have I seen.Nay, take away this scolding crookback rather.I say; commend me to thy master.We bodged again; as I have seen a swan With bootless labour swim against the tide And spend her strength with over-matching waves.I shall desire you, sir, to give me leave To have free speech with you; and it concerns me To look into the bottom of my place: A power I have, but of what strength and nature I am not yet instructed.prig, for my life, prig: he haunts wakes, fairs and bear-baitings.The appellant in all duty greets your highness, And craves to kiss your hand and take his leave.The law hath not been dead, though it hath slept: Those many had not dared to do that evil, If the first that did the edict infringe Had answer'd for his deed: now 'tis awake Takes note of what is done; and, like a prophet, Looks in a glass, that shows what future evils, Either new, or by remissness new-conceived, And so in progress to be hatch'd and born, Are now to have no successive degrees, But, ere they live, to end.Hear me, people; peace!For life, I prize it As I weigh grief, which I would spare: for honour, 'Tis a derivative from me to mine, And only that I stand for.while I play the good husband at home, my son and my servant spend all at the university.we'll have thee to a couch Softer and sweeter than the lustful bed On purpose trimm'd up for Semiramis.Escalus.What is the matter, my lord?Pink for flower.Ah, Warwick, why hast thou withdrawn thyself?Good morrow to your lordship.I'll after him, and see the event of this.O Isabel, will you not lend a knee?Ah, no, no, no, it is mine only son!He's right noble: Let him be call'd for.Despiteful tidings!The broken rancour of your high-swoln hearts, But lately splinter'd, knit, and join'd together, Must gently be preserved, cherish'd, and kept: Me seemeth good, that, with some little train, Forthwith from Ludlow the young prince be fetch'd Hither to London, to be crown'd our king.Of that there's none, or little.A jealous hood, a jealous hood!Believe me, I speak as my understanding instructs me and as mine honesty puts it to utterance.Are you so formal, sir?Uncle, you say the queen is at your house; For God's sake, fairly let her be entreated: Tell her I send to her my kind commends; Take special care my greetings be deliver'd.Not out of doors!How youngly he began to serve his country, How long continued, and what stock he springs of, The noble house o' the Marcians, from whence came That Ancus Marcius, Numa's daughter's son, Who, after great Hostilius, here was king; Of the same house Publius and Quintus were, That our beat water brought by conduits hither; And   Twice being   Was his great ancestor.What said the wench when he rose again?Hilloa, loa!Faith, none for me; except the north-east wind, Which then blew bitterly against our faces, Awaked the sleeping rheum, and so by chance Did grace our hollow parting with a tear.Ay, and a kind one too: Pray God, sir, your wife send you not a worse.Ne'er through an arch so hurried the blown tide, As the recomforted through the gates.My legs can keep no measure in delight, When my poor heart no measure keeps in grief: Therefore, no dancing, girl; some other sport.Is it upon record, or else reported Successively from age to age, he built it?Death, that hath ta'en her hence to make me wail, Ties up my tongue, and will not let me speak.It is, and wants but nomination.Let me entreat you.His nature is too noble for the world: He would not flatter Neptune for his trident, Or Jove for's power to thunder.Sirrah, go hire me twenty cunning cooks.Go you the next way with your findings.And, by thy guess, how nigh is Clarence now?Let him that makes but trifles of his eyes First hand me: on mine own accord I'll off; But first I'll do my errand.Under the canopy.God save King Harry, unking'd Richard says, And send him many years of sunshine days!Ay, as an ostler, that for the poorest piece Will bear the knave by the volume.It becomes thy oath full well, Thou to me thy secrets tell.Good mother, be content; it is no more Than my poor life must answer.Then, no, my lord.Tybalt, that murderer, which way ran he?True!Why, that was he.At that sad stop, my lord, Where rude misgovern'd hands from windows' tops Threw dust and rubbish on King Richard's head.Which of you trembles not that looks on me?In such a one as, you consenting to't, Would bark your honour from that trunk you bear, And leave you naked.To-morrow, then, I judge a happy day.That lie shall lie so heavy on my sword, That it shall render vengeance and revenge Till thou the lie-giver and that lie do lie In earth as quiet as thy father's skull: In proof whereof, there is my honour's pawn; Engage it to the trial, if thou darest.Apprehend Nothing but jollity.Here's another ballad of a fish, that appeared upon the coast on Wednesday the four-score of April, forty thousand fathom above water, and sung this ballad against the hard hearts of maids: it was thought she was a woman and was turned into a cold fish for she would not exchange flesh with one that loved her: the ballad is very pitiful and as true.Here, sir, a ring she bid me give you, sir: Hie you, make haste, for it grows very late.Not so: I am as ignorant in that as you In so entitling me, and no less honest Than you are mad; which is enough, I'll warrant, As this world goes, to pass for honest.and so falls it out With Rivers, Vaughan, Grey: and so 'twill do With some men else, who think themselves as safe As thou and I; who, as thou know'st, are dear To princely Richard and to Buckingham.I am glad to see your ladyship.Basta; content thee, for I have it full.Why, sir, what's your conceit in that?Then bid me kill myself, and I will do it.witless else her son.Give me your hand, And let the subject see, to make them know That outward courtesies would fain proclaim Favours that keep within.On fair ground I could beat forty of them.I assure you, Carthage.In thy foul throat thou liest: Queen Margaret saw Thy murderous falchion smoking in his blood; The which thou once didst bend against her breast, But that thy brothers beat aside the point.Now Warwick, tell me, even upon thy conscience, Is Edward your true king?Now is your time: speak loud and kneel before him.My Lord Northumberland, see them dispatch'd.Give me leave, I'll go to him, and undertake to bring him Where he shall answer, by a lawful form, In peace, to his utmost peril.And that's the wavering commons: for their love Lies in their purses, and whoso empties them By so much fills their hearts with deadly hate.I would thou hadst done so by Claudio.Ay me!You?He rose against him, being his sovereign, And made him to resign his crown perforce.can you not stay awhile?We are but plain fellows, sir.Welcome, sweet prince, to London, to your chamber.So deal with him as I prove true to you.Your patience this allowing, I turn my glass and give my scene such growing As you had slept between: Leontes leaving, The effects of his fond jealousies so grieving That he shuts up himself, imagine me, Gentle spectators, that I now may be In fair Bohemia, and remember well, I mentioned a son o' the king's, which Florizel I now name to you; and with speed so pace To speak of Perdita, now grown in grace Equal with wondering: what of her ensues I list not prophecy; but let Time's news Be known when 'tis brought forth.I swear I'll cuff you, if you strike again.What if her eyes were there, they in her head?Nay, I hear nothing: his mother and his wife Hear nothing from him.Good aunt, stand up.But I hear, no; they say my son of York Hath almost overta'en him in his growth.Away, sir!No cock of mine; you crow too like a craven.Heaven doth with us as we with torches do, Not light them for themselves; for if our virtues Did not go forth of us, 'twere all alike As if we had them not.If it were damnable, he being so wise, Why would he for the momentary trick Be perdurably fined?Good, yet remember whom thou hast aboard.At that place call upon me; and dispatch with Angelo, that it may be quickly.If the event o' the journey Prove as successful to the queen,--O be't so!-- As it hath been to us rare, pleasant, speedy, The time is worth the use on't.My sword, I say!Good Master Froth, look upon his honour; 'tis for a good purpose.Ay, with five hundred, father, for a need: A woman's general; what should we fear?Your partner, as I hear, must die to-morrow, And I am going with instruction to him.You have been a scourge to her enemies, you have been a rod to her friends; you have not indeed loved the common people.Withdraw, my lord; I'll help you to a horse.So may you lose your arms: If you strike me, you are no gentleman; And if no gentleman, why then no arms.and go along with us.What 'unjust'!Who sensibly outdares his senseless sword, And, when it bows, stands up.Nay, but it is not so.What will your grace have done with Margaret?Ah!Fellow, why dost thou show me thus to the world?why, bride!Mount you, my lord; towards Berwick post amain: Edward and Richard, like a brace of greyhounds Having the fearful flying hare in sight, With fiery eyes sparkling for very wrath, And bloody steel grasp'd in their ireful hands, Are at our backs; and therefore hence amain.The queen this day here holds her parliament, But little thinks we shall be of her council: By words or blows here let us win our right.And soothe the devil that I warn thee from?Holy Saint Francis, what a change is here!by being a bawd?Indeed, la, 'tis a noble child.No, he must not.But, as 'tis, We cannot miss him: he does make our fire, Fetch in our wood and serves in offices That profit us.I will, my lord.And far surmounts our labour to attain it.For then I'll marry Warwick's youngest daughter.A glooming peace this morning with it brings; The sun, for sorrow, will not show his head: Go hence, to have more talk of these sad things; Some shall be pardon'd, and some punished: For never was a story of more woe Than this of Juliet and her Romeo.Put not yourself into amazement how these things should be: all difficulties are but easy when they are known.I have no tongue but one: gentle my lord, Let me entreat you speak the former language.Stand fast; We have as many friends as enemies.I'll lay fourteen of my teeth,-- And yet, to my teeth be it spoken, I have but four-- She is not fourteen.I am content: Richard Plantagenet, Enjoy the kingdom after my decease.He hath some meaning in his mad attire: We will persuade him, be it possible, To put on better ere he go to church.So they are; My spirits, as in a dream, are all bound up.Some one hath set you on: Confess the truth, and say by whose advice Thou camest here to complain.Every man's conscience is a thousand swords, To fight against that bloody homicide.which of you all Will now deny to dance?what barm can your bisson conspectuities glean out of this character, if I be known well enough too?A pair of stocks, you rogue!Fie!I think not so.Good aunt, stand up.we will fetch thee straight Adonis painted by a running brook, And Cytherea all in sedges hid, Which seem to move and wanton with her breath, Even as the waving sedges play with wind.This is a gentle provost: seldom when The steeled gaoler is the friend of men.There's many have committed it.My suit is at an end.Sir, to your pleasure humbly I subscribe: My books and instruments shall be my company, On them to took and practise by myself.Away with the dotard!God grant him health!Even so.Mistress, your father prays you leave your books And help to dress your sister's chamber up: You know to-morrow is the wedding-day.Your enemies and his find something in him.Yes.Clarence and Somerset both gone to Warwick!I would your duty were as foolish too: The wisdom of your duty, fair Bianca, Hath cost me an hundred crowns since supper-time.Woe to the land that's govern'd by a child!Why, then 'tis time to arm and give direction.But the rarity of it is,--which is indeed almost beyond credit,-- As many vouched rarities are.For this one speech Lord Hastings well deserves To have the heir of the Lord Hungerford.Fear you the boar, and go so unprovided?Fame, at the which he aims, In whom already he's well graced, can not Better be held nor more attain'd than by A place below the first: for what miscarries Shall be the general's fault, though he perform To the utmost of a man, and giddy censure Will then cry out of Marcius 'O if he Had borne the business!'My old friend Grumio!Cominius, Droop not; adieu.You have taken it wiselier than I meant you should.Clarence, whom I, indeed, have laid in darkness, I do beweep to many simple gulls Namely, to Hastings, Derby, Buckingham; And say it is the queen and her allies That stir the king against the duke my brother.Here's Romeo's man; we found him in the churchyard.'Zounds, he dies: I had forgot the reward.They will, then, ere't be long.I pray you, sir, let him go while the humour lasts.Sweet Montague, be true.This Volumnia Is worth of consuls, senators, patricians, A city full; of tribunes, such as you, A sea and land full.When we banished him, we respected not them; and, he returning to break our necks, they respect not us.I understand thee well; and be thou sure, when he shall come to his account, he knows not What I can urge against him.The people in the street cry Romeo, Some Juliet, and some Paris; and all run, With open outcry toward our monument.We will ourself in person to this war: And, for our coffers, with too great a court And liberal largess, are grown somewhat light, We are inforced to farm our royal realm; The revenue whereof shall furnish us For our affairs in hand: if that come short, Our substitutes at home shall have blank charters; Whereto, when they shall know what men are rich, They shall subscribe them for large sums of gold And send them after to supply our wants; For we will make for Ireland presently.Go make thyself like a nymph o' the sea: be subject To no sight but thine and mine, invisible To every eyeball else.Looking on the lines Of my boy's face, methoughts I did recoil Twenty-three years, and saw myself unbreech'd, In my green velvet coat, my dagger muzzled, Lest it should bite its master, and so prove, As ornaments oft do, too dangerous: How like, methought, I then was to this kernel, This squash, this gentleman.It is extempore, from my mother-wit.Revoke that doom of mercy, for 'tis Clifford; Who not contented that he lopp'd the branch In hewing Rutland when his leaves put forth, But set his murdering knife unto the root From whence that tender spray did sweetly spring, I mean our princely father, Duke of York.I beseech you, Grant me this boon.Not I; unless the breath of heartsick groans, Mist-like, infold me from the search of eyes.Faith, gentlemen, now I play a merchant's part, And venture madly on a desperate mart.Lend thy hand, And pluck my magic garment from me.The duke!What you do Still betters what is done.thou know'st not gold's effect: Tell me her father's name and 'tis enough; For I will board her, though she chide as loud As thunder when the clouds in autumn crack.Alas, it hath been great pains to you.Here, sir: I'ld have beaten him like a dog, but for disturbing the lords within.Thou want'st a rough pash and the shoots that I have, To be full like me: yet they say we are Almost as like as eggs; women say so, That will say anything but were they false As o'er-dyed blacks, as wind, as waters, false As dice are to be wish'd by one that fixes No bourn 'twixt his and mine, yet were it true To say this boy were like me.Richmond and victory!Consider you what services he has done for his country?Do you hear how we are shent for keeping your greatness back?Here is a gentleman whom by chance I met, Upon agreement from us to his liking, Will undertake to woo curst Katharina, Yea, and to marry her, if her dowry please.Help him, Lucio.This night's the time That I should do what I abhor to name, Or else thou diest to-morrow.Sin from thy lips?I took an oath that he should quietly reign.'Patricians!'Your friends at Pomfret, they do need the priest; Your honour hath no shriving work in hand.Faith, I know not what to say.Let me have war, say I; it exceeds peace as far as day does night; it's spritely, waking, audible, and full of vent.Welcome, you;--how now, you;-- what, you;--fellow, you;--and thus much for greeting.We shall be much unfurnished for this time.Then you should hate Rome, as he does.As dissolute as desperate; yet through both I see some sparks of better hope, which elder years May happily bring forth.A greater gift!I have seen the day That I have worn a visor and could tell A whispering tale in a fair lady's ear, Such as would please: 'tis gone, 'tis gone, 'tis gone: You are welcome, gentlemen!A proper stripling and an amorous!Unless for that he comes to be your liege, You cannot guess wherefore the Welshman comes.No, gracious lord, except I cannot do it.No more talking on't; let it be done: away, away!But Warwick's king is Edward's prisoner: And, gallant Warwick, do but answer this: What is the body when the head is off?belike he thinks me Henry.Well, gentlemen, I am thus resolved: on Sunday next you know My daughter Katharina is to be married: Now, on the Sunday following, shall Bianca Be bride to you, if you this assurance; If not, Signior Gremio: And so, I take my leave, and thank you both.Brother of Gloucester, you mistake the matter.My business in this state Made me a looker on here in Vienna, Where I have seen corruption boil and bubble Till it o'er-run the stew; laws for all faults, But faults so countenanced, that the strong statutes Stand like the forfeits in a barber's shop, As much in mock as mark.But, wrangling pedant, this is The patroness of heavenly harmony: Then give me leave to have prerogative; And when in music we have spent an hour, Your lecture shall have leisure for as much.Daughter, speak you: He cares not for your weeping.Have I had children's voices?It is a mind That shall remain a poison where it is, Not poison any further.Who's there?I am appointed him to murder you.Good counsel, marry: learn it, learn it, marquess.Like an old tale still, which will have matter to rehearse, though credit be asleep and not an ear open.Can heaven be so envious?Ay, the heads of the maids, or their maidenheads; take it in what sense thou wilt.Romeo, will you come to your father's?So, now I have mine own again, be gone, That I might strive to kill it with a groan.Fie, fie!little honour to be much believed, And most pernicious purpose!You cavil, widow: I did mean, my queen.Once more, the more to aggravate the note, With a foul traitor's name stuff I thy throat; And wish, so please my sovereign, ere I move, What my tongue speaks my right drawn sword may prove.Brother, I go; I'll win them, fear it not: And thus most humbly I do take my leave.No remedy.Insisting on the old prerogative And power i' the truth o' the cause.What, in my sight?O passing traitor, perjured and unjust!for I would not speak with him till after dinner.I tell you, friends, most charitable care Have the patricians of you.What, have you dined at home?Dwelt by a churchyard: I will tell it softly; Yond crickets shall not hear it.I know it is the sun that shines so bright.Go, get thee gone, I say.Good Lord, how bright and goodly shines the moon!Vices, I would say, sir.Look, York: I stain'd this napkin with the blood That valiant Clifford, with his rapier's point, Made issue from the bosom of the boy; And if thine eyes can water for his death, I give thee this to dry thy cheeks withal.Has he dined, canst thou tell?I have deserved no better entertainment, In being Coriolanus.Good sister, wrong me not, nor wrong yourself, To make a bondmaid and a slave of me; That I disdain: but for these other gawds, Unbind my hands, I'll pull them off myself, Yea, all my raiment, to my petticoat; Or what you will command me will I do, So well I know my duty to my elders.Who bare my letter, then, to Romeo?Defy them then, or else hold close thy lips.Where did I leave?Look behind you, my lord.Adoptedly; as school-maids change their names By vain though apt affection.This oath I willingly take and will perform.'He that is giddy thinks the world turns round:' I pray you, tell me what you meant by that.Thou liest, thou thread, thou thimble, Thou yard, three-quarters, half-yard, quarter, nail!Oh, poor Clarence!Go to Flint castle: there I'll pine away; A king, woe's slave, shall kingly woe obey.For had I cursed now, I had cursed myself.Hear me, you wrangling pirates, that fall out In sharing that which you have pill'd from me!Ay, but not frighted me; therefore I'll sleep again.Pray, be counsell'd: I have a heart as little apt as yours, But yet a brain that leads my use of anger To better vantage.But, Clifford, tell me, didst thou never hear That things ill-got had ever bad success?Ho!What cause, do you think, I have to swoon?Alas, poor man!My guilt be on my head, and there an end.Why, then, O brawling love!It is written, that the shoemaker should meddle with his yard, and the tailor with his last, the fisher with his pencil, and the painter with his nets; but I am sent to find those persons whose names are here writ, and can never find what names the writing person hath here writ.Scurvy knave!Where is my lord protector?But what talk we of these traitorly rascals, whose miseries are to be smiled at, their offences being so capital?Help, help, help!I cannot say 'tis pity She lacks instructions, for she seems a mistress To most that teach.Why, how now, Juliet!Well said, noble woman?My Lord of Oxford, you, Sir William Brandon, And you, Sir Walter Herbert, stay with me.Up with my tent there!Offended us you have not, but the king.God keep the prince from all the pack of you!Why, then, thy husband's lands I freely give thee.is it my lady mother?Make us thy ministers of chastisement, That we may praise thee in the victory!Your husband, he is gone to save far off, Whilst others come to make him lose at home: Here am I left to underprop his land, Who, weak with age, cannot support myself: Now comes the sick hour that his surfeit made; Now shall he try his friends that flatter'd him.or how?And his well-chosen bride.You have made fair hands, You and your crafts!Yon light is not day-light, I know it, I: It is some meteor that the sun exhales, To be to thee this night a torch-bearer, And light thee on thy way to Mantua: Therefore stay yet; thou need'st not to be gone.God keep all vows unbroke that swear to thee!But did I never speak of all that time?I heard him swear, Were he to stand for consul, never would he Appear i' the market-place nor on him put The napless vesture of humility; Nor showing, as the manner is, his wounds To the people, beg their stinking breaths.This night you shall behold him at our feast; Read o'er the volume of young Paris' face, And find delight writ there with beauty's pen; Examine every married lineament, And see how one another lends content And what obscured in this fair volume lies Find written in the margent of his eyes.Nay, hear me, Isabel.No, in such a case the gods will not be good unto us.Be merry, Kate.How high a pitch his resolution soars!The news, Rogero?But what said Lady Bona to my marriage?You may, sir.Unless another, As like Hermione as is her picture, Affront his eye.Look, look!Women will love her, that she is a woman More worth than any man; men, that she is The rarest of all women.Banish us both and send the king with me.Do not believe it.Thou bloodless remnant of that royal blood!When you have vow'd, you must not speak with men But in the presence of the prioress: Then, if you speak, you must not show your face, Or, if you show your face, you must not speak.How if it be false, son?yare!Stand we in good array; for they no doubt Will issue out again and bid us battle: If not, the city being but of small defence, We'll quickly rouse the traitors in the same.Withdraw you hence, my lord, I'll follow you.Not having that, which, having, makes them short.They fell together all, as by consent; They dropp'd, as by a thunder-stroke.you villains, when?Stay thy revengeful hand; thou hast no cause to fear.For an end, We must suggest the people in what hatred He still hath held them; that to's power he would Have made them mules, silenced their pleaders and Dispropertied their freedoms, holding them, In human action and capacity, Of no more soul nor fitness for the world Than camels in the war, who have their provand Only for bearing burdens, and sore blows For sinking under them.But now, my lord, what say you to my suit?Wonder not, Nor be grieved: she is of good esteem, Her dowery wealthy, and of worthy birth; Beside, so qualified as may beseem The spouse of any noble gentleman.Ay, my dear, Such eyes the widows in Corioli wear, And mothers that lack sons.Ay, with such gifts that heaven shall share with you.Lord Hastings, you and he are near in love.I have drunk, and seen the spider.Silence that fellow: I would he had some cause To prattle for himself.Good morning to you, fair and gracious daughter.What's that to thee?Varlet, thou liest; thou liest, wicked varlet!Nay, rather, good my lords, be second to me: Fear you his tyrannous passion more, alas, Than the queen's life?That we were all, as some would seem to be, From our faults, as faults from seeming, free!Courage!what manners is in this?Say then, who dost thou mean shall be her king?O ho, O ho!What am I, sir!If we and Caius Marcius chance to meet, 'Tis sworn between us we shall ever strike Till one can do no more.Tell me not, friar, that thou hear'st of this, Unless thou tell me how I may prevent it: If, in thy wisdom, thou canst give no help, Do thou but call my resolution wise, And with this knife I'll help it presently.see, how beastly she doth court him!A wise stout captain, and soon persuaded!I have forgot why I did call thee back.Meantime, but think how I may do thee good, And be inheritor of thy desire.Whom thou wert sworn to cherish and defend.Out of her favour, where I am in love.Curster than she?Are all things fitting for that royal time?What!would not they speak?None, sir; I have no pheasant, cock nor hen.How came we ashore?Padua affords nothing but what is kind.While we devise fell tortures for thy faults.Come, Montague; for thou art early up, To see thy son and heir more early down.Take him over the costard with the hilts of thy sword, and then we will chop him in the malmsey-butt in the next room.And to conclude, the shepherd's homely curds, His cold thin drink out of his leather bottle.Whom should he follow but his natural king?I'll go see if the bear be gone from the gentleman and how much he hath eaten: they are never curst but when they are hungry: if there be any of him left, I'll bury it.Thou deceivest thyself: 'Tis he that sent us hither now to slaughter thee.If he be credulous and trust my tale, I'll make him glad to seem Vincentio, And give assurance to Baptista Minola, As if he were the right Vincentio Take in your love, and then let me alone.Catesby!So will it, madam till I lie with you.This is a way to kill a wife with kindness; And thus I'll curb her mad and headstrong humour.Cambio!He lives that loves thee better than he could.I hear some noise within; dear love, adieu!But what likelihood is in that?There is a lord will hear you play to-night: But I am doubtful of your modesties; Lest over-eyeing of his odd behavior,-- For yet his honour never heard a play-- You break into some merry passion And so offend him; for I tell you, sirs, If you should smile he grows impatient.You are welcome all.How now, my lord, what say the citizens?Nay, faith, I'll see the church o' your back; and then come back to my master's as soon as I can.'Tis much.This is to feel a tale, not to hear a tale.are you all afraid?Why should you sigh, my lord?Say that she rail; why then I'll tell her plain She sings as sweetly as a nightingale: Say that she frown, I'll say she looks as clear As morning roses newly wash'd with dew: Say she be mute and will not speak a word; Then I'll commend her volubility, And say she uttereth piercing eloquence: If she do bid me pack, I'll give her thanks, As though she bid me stay by her a week: If she deny to wed, I'll crave the day When I shall ask the banns and when be married.Stay but a little, I will come again.dispute his own estate?You have mistook, my lady, Polixenes for Leontes: O thou thing!My crown I am; but still my griefs are mine: You may my glories and my state depose, But not my griefs; still am I king of those.My lord, stand back, and let the coffin pass.Thou and thy brother both shall buy this treason Even with the dearest blood your bodies bear.'Tis well, sir, that you hunted for yourself: 'Tis thought your deer does hold you at a bay.Now is the sun upon the highmost hill Of this day's journey, and from nine till twelve Is three long hours, yet she is not come.Will it not be?The chaplain of the Tower hath buried them; But how or in what place I do not know.there was nothing done to her once.He loved his mother dearly.Well, mildly be it then.'Have I no friend?'Then, in God's name, march: True hope is swift, and flies with swallow's wings: Kings it makes gods, and meaner creatures kings.What think'st thou, Norfolk?I the great toe!And Warwick shall disprove it.Sweet widow, by my state I swear to thee I speak no more than what my soul intends; And that is, to enjoy thee for my love.Unsavoury news!I'faith, sir, you shall never need to fear: I wis it is not half way to her heart; But if it were, doubt not her care should be To comb your noddle with a three-legg'd stool And paint your face and use you like a fool.ay, I warrant you, and not without his true purchasing.But I have reasons strong and forcible.From such a cause as fills mine eyes with tears And stops my tongue, while heart is drown'd in cares.A book of prayers on their pillow lay; Which once,' quoth Forrest, 'almost changed my mind; But O!My Lord, I have consider'd in my mind The late demand that you did sound me in.I cannot tell; but I had as lief take her dowry with this condition, to be whipped at the high cross every morning.I do beseech your majesty, impute his words To wayward sickliness and age in him: He loves you, on my life, and holds you dear As Harry Duke of Hereford, were he here.What Clarence but a quicksand of deceit?We charge you, in God's name, and the king's, To go with us unto the officers.But, after all this fooling, I would not have it so.couple it with something; make it a word and a blow.Why, what should you fear?Were it not that my fellow-school-master Doth watch Bianca's steps so narrowly, 'Twere good, methinks, to steal our marriage; Which once perform'd, let all the world say no, I'll keep mine own, despite of all the world.But who comes here?How do you now?Bring forth these men.What, shall we toward the Tower?You say, seven years together?then I shall pose you quickly.Bear The addition nobly ever!Villain, thou know'st no law of God nor man: No beast so fierce but knows some touch of pity.Saw you Aufidius?And in this state she gallops night by night Through lovers' brains, and then they dream of love; O'er courtiers' knees, that dream on court'sies straight, O'er lawyers' fingers, who straight dream on fees, O'er ladies ' lips, who straight on kisses dream, Which oft the angry Mab with blisters plagues, Because their breaths with sweetmeats tainted are: Sometime she gallops o'er a courtier's nose, And then dreams he of smelling out a suit; And sometime comes she with a tithe-pig's tail Tickling a parson's nose as a' lies asleep, Then dreams, he of another benefice: Sometime she driveth o'er a soldier's neck, And then dreams he of cutting foreign throats, Of breaches, ambuscadoes, Spanish blades, Of healths five-fathom deep; and then anon Drums in his ear, at which he starts and wakes, And being thus frighted swears a prayer or two And sleeps again.Our enemy is banish'd!O, their bones, their bones!Sound trumpet; Edward shall be here proclaim'd: Come, fellow-soldier, make thou proclamation.Shall sweet Bianca practise how to bride it?Then let the pebbles on the hungry beach Fillip the stars; then let the mutinous winds Strike the proud cedars 'gainst the fiery sun; Murdering impossibility, to make What cannot be, slight work.Why, that was when Three crabbed months had sour'd themselves to death, Ere I could make thee open thy white hand And clap thyself my love: then didst thou utter 'I am yours for ever.'Good night.wretched Isabel!I thought, by your readiness in the office, you had continued in it some time.Give me some ink and paper in my tent I'll draw the form and model of our battle, Limit each leader to his several charge, And part in just proportion our small strength.But to her love concerneth us to add Her father's liking: which to bring to pass, As I before unparted to your worship, I am to get a man,--whate'er he be, It skills not much.I'll give thee armour to keep off that word: Adversity's sweet milk, philosophy, To comfort thee, though thou art banished.Dost thou love me?Wilt thou be gone?Ah, sirs, consider, he that set you on To do this deed will hate you for the deed.I was provoked by her slanderous tongue, which laid their guilt upon my guiltless shoulders.You have holp to ravish your own daughters and To melt the city leads upon your pates, To see your wives dishonour'd to your noses,-- What's the news?Will he woo her?Faith, I can tell her age unto an hour.So he did, my lord: The army marvell'd at it, and, in the last, When he had carried Rome and that we look'd For no less spoil than glory,-- There was it: For which my sinews shall be stretch'd upon him.Could man so blench?Go you to the city; Learn how 'tis held; and what they are that must Be hostages for Rome.ah sir!Towards Ludlow then, for we'll not stay behind.Here, sir!come in: the wish deserves a welcome.Plantagenet, for all the claim thou lay'st, Think not that Henry shall be so deposed.I see that thou art poor: Hold, there is forty ducats: let me have A dram of poison, such soon-speeding gear As will disperse itself through all the veins That the life-weary taker may fall dead And that the trunk may be discharged of breath As violently as hasty powder fired Doth hurry from the fatal cannon's womb.What fates impose, that men must needs abide; It boots not to resist both wind and tide.Yes, thou must die: Thou art too noble to conserve a life In base appliances.What, in metre?Here's flowers for you; Hot lavender, mints, savoury, marjoram; The marigold, that goes to bed wi' the sun And with him rises weeping: these are flowers Of middle summer, and I think they are given To men of middle age.We are lucky, boy; and to be so still requires nothing but secrecy.What's he?I task the earth to the like, forsworn Aumerle; And spur thee on with full as many lies As may be holloa'd in thy treacherous ear From sun to sun: there is my honour's pawn; Engage it to the trial, if thou darest.Were not you then as cruel as the sentence That you have slander'd so?Beseech you, give me leave to retire myself.Ay, traitor, Marcius!Well, jest on, brothers: I can tell you both Her suit is granted for her husband's lands.Romeo, the hate I bear thee can afford No better term than this,--thou art a villain.He does hear me; And that he does I weep: myself am Naples, Who with mine eyes, never since at ebb, beheld The king my father wreck'd.But it chances The stealth of our most mutual entertainment With character too gross is writ on Juliet.Let them go on; This mutiny were better put in hazard, Than stay, past doubt, for greater: If, as his nature is, he fall in rage With their refusal, both observe and answer The vantage of his anger.Why, I am past my gamut long ago.Utter your gravity o'er a gossip's bowl; For here we need it not.O, the better, sir; for he that drinks all night, and is hanged betimes in the morning, may sleep the sounder all the next day.Dive, thoughts, down to my soul: here Clarence comes.Not possible.receives not thy nose court-odor from me?And you.And to make us no better thought of, a little help will serve; for once we stood up about the corn, he himself stuck not to call us the many-headed multitude.I lost a couple, that 'twixt heaven and earth Might thus have stood begetting wonder as You, gracious couple, do: and then I lost-- All mine own folly--the society, Amity too, of your brave father, whom, Though bearing misery, I desire my life Once more to look on him.His wonted sleep under a fresh tree's shade, All which secure and sweetly he enjoys, Is far beyond a prince's delicates, His viands sparkling in a golden cup, His body couched in a curious bed, When care, mistrust, and treason waits on him.Once a day I'll visit The chapel where they lie, and tears shed there Shall be my recreation: so long as nature Will bear up with this exercise, so long I daily vow to use it.I see the play so lies That I must bear a part.Rise, Grumio, rise: we will compound this quarrel.What, Camillo there?My Lord of Somerset, what youth is that, Of whom you seem to have so tender care?So, sir, heartily well met, and most glad of your company.Good gentle youth, tempt not a desperate man; Fly hence, and leave me: think upon these gone; Let them affright thee.I pitied thee, Took pains to make thee speak, taught thee each hour One thing or other: when thou didst not, savage, Know thine own meaning, but wouldst gabble like A thing most brutish, I endow'd thy purposes With words that made them known.Well, madam, and in health.The king shall do it: must he be deposed?Comest thou because the anointed king is hence?Rest you well.Wherein, my friends, have I offended you?'Tis set down so in heaven, but not in earth.Shall we go throw away our coats of steel, And wrap our bodies in black mourning gowns, Numbering our Ave-Maries with our beads?Come unto these yellow sands, And then take hands: Courtsied when you have and kiss'd The wild waves whist, Foot it featly here and there; And, sweet sprites, the burthen bear.She will not stay the siege of loving terms, Nor bide the encounter of assailing eyes, Nor ope her lap to saint-seducing gold: O, she is rich in beauty, only poor, That when she dies with beauty dies her store.These soldiers shall be levied, And thou, Lord Bourbon, our high admiral, Shalt waft them over with our royal fleet.Farewell: the leisure and the fearful time Cuts off the ceremonious vows of love And ample interchange of sweet discourse, Which so long sunder'd friends should dwell upon: God give us leisure for these rites of love!Why, is not Oxford here another anchor?Come, sir, come, we know you well enough.and as much news as will thaw.Anointed let me be with deadly venom, And die, ere men can say, God save the queen!Dear, look up: Though Fortune, visible an enemy, Should chase us with my father, power no jot Hath she to change our loves.But in your daughter's womb I bury them: Where in that nest of spicery they shall breed Selves of themselves, to your recomforture.Within two hours.What black magician conjures up this fiend, To stop devoted charitable deeds?fast, I warrant her, she: Why, lamb!And long live thou and these thy forward sons!Would he not stumble?What with a torch!love's heralds should be thoughts, Which ten times faster glide than the sun's beams, Driving back shadows over louring hills: Therefore do nimble-pinion'd doves draw love, And therefore hath the wind-swift Cupid wings.As I was banish'd, I was banish'd Hereford; But as I come, I come for Lancaster.Be she honour-flaw'd, I have three daughters; the eldest is eleven The second and the third, nine, and some five; If this prove true, they'll pay for't: by mine honour, I'll geld 'em all; fourteen they shall not see, To bring false generations: they are co-heirs; And I had rather glib myself than they Should not produce fair issue.She hath, and in that sparing makes huge waste, For beauty starved with her severity Cuts beauty off from all posterity.O, 'tis an accident that heaven provides!Say you?Daughter, well met.by any other house or person?How now, boy!What is't your highness' pleasure I shall do at Salisbury?Fear not, my lord: we can contain ourselves, Were he the veriest antic in the world.True, I talk of dreams, Which are the children of an idle brain, Begot of nothing but vain fantasy, Which is as thin of substance as the air And more inconstant than the wind, who wooes Even now the frozen bosom of the north, And, being anger'd, puffs away from thence, Turning his face to the dew-dropping south.Do so, it is a point of wisdom: fare you well.My husband bids me; now I will unmask.Stand not amazed: the prince will doom thee death, If thou art taken: hence, be gone, away!it was my will and grant; And for this once my will shall stand for law.Ah, Juliet, if the measure of thy joy Be heap'd like mine and that thy skill be more To blazon it, then sweeten with thy breath This neighbour air, and let rich music's tongue Unfold the imagined happiness that both Receive in either by this dear encounter.Foul weather?I am for you.at a strife?I am glad on 't: then we shall ha' means to vent Our musty superfluity.You are a princox; go: Be quiet, or--More light, more light!Sorrow breaks seasons and reposing hours, Makes the night morning, and the noon-tide night.If you have writ your annals true, 'tis there, That, like an eagle in a dove-cote, I Flutter'd your Volscians in Corioli: Alone I did it.Come, Clarence, come; thou wilt, if Warwick call.Madam, with all my heart.La you now, you hear: When she will take the rein I let her run; But she'll not stumble.Sir,-- One: tell.The king of heaven forbid our lord the king Should so with civil and uncivil arms Be rush'd upon!Why, I am glad on't; this is well: stand up: This is as't should be.This is the rascal; this is he I spoke of.Ho, by your leave!By and by.Forward; away!If thou do pardon, whosoever pray, More sins for this forgiveness prosper may.But is he gracious in the people's eye?Who, I, my lord I we know each other's faces, But for our hearts, he knows no more of mine, Than I of yours; Nor I no more of his, than you of mine.Assemble presently the people hither; And when they bear me say 'It shall be so I' the right and strength o' the commons,' be it either For death, for fine, or banishment, then let them If I say fine, cry 'Fine;' if death, cry 'Death.'Let me be ignorant, and in nothing good, But graciously to know I am no better.As well as one so great and so forlorn May hold together: on her frights and griefs, Which never tender lady hath born greater, She is something before her time deliver'd.Thou hast faced many things.Good thou, save me a piece of marchpane; and, as thou lovest me, let the porter let in Susan Grindstone and Nell.You would have thought the very windows spake, So many greedy looks of young and old Through casements darted their desiring eyes Upon his visage, and that all the walls With painted imagery had said at once 'Jesu preserve thee!Your eyes do menace me: why look you pale?Dispatch, my lord; the duke would be at dinner: Make a short shrift; he longs to see your head.What mean these masterless and gory swords To lie discolour'd by this place of peace?O momentary grace of mortal men, Which we more hunt for than the grace of God!He hath ribbons of an the colours i' the rainbow; points more than all the lawyers in Bohemia can learnedly handle, though they come to him by the gross: inkles, caddisses, cambrics, lawns: why, he sings 'em over as they were gods or goddesses; you would think a smock were a she-angel, he so chants to the sleeve-hand and the work about the square on't.But youth in ladies' eyes that flourisheth.What would you have me do?Who's that, I pray thee?It cannot be The Volsces dare break with us.Well hast thou spoken, cousin: be it so.Have I not in my time heard lions roar?Ay, sir, they be ready: the oats have eaten the horses.She shall, she shall.A hundred then.And stay, good nurse, behind the abbey wall: Within this hour my man shall be with thee And bring thee cords made like a tackled stair; Which to the high top-gallant of my joy Must be my convoy in the secret night.Here, take away this dish.Mistake me not; I speak but as I find.Out, you green-sickness carrion!I think he'll be to Rome As is the osprey to the fish, who takes it By sovereignty of nature.and then to glance from him To the duke himself, to tax him with injustice?Hark, how they joy!What fare?My best Camillo!I'll not seek far-- For him, I partly know his mind--to find thee An honourable husband.True; save means to live.and that succession be determined.My eye's too quick, my heart o'erweens too much, Unless my hand and strength could equal them.Good news or bad, that thou comest in so bluntly?Was it we?O, I have suffered With those that I saw suffer: a brave vessel, Who had, no doubt, some noble creature in her, Dash'd all to pieces.Had I plantation of this isle, my lord,-- He'ld sow't with nettle-seed.What news from Oxford?Love give me strength!But follow me, and Edward shall be ours.But a harsh hearing when women are froward.Who deserves greatness Deserves your hate; and your affections are A sick man's appetite, who desires most that Which would increase his evil.Yet, to bite his lip And hum at good Cominius, much unhearts me.O slave!See where she comes from shrift with merry look.Is he come?You are old enough now, and yet, methinks, you lose.O slow-wing'd turtle!It doth so, holy sir; and there's my master, One that you love.Well, you'll answer this one day.That were some love but little policy.what's that?Pray, sir, in what?Is not the king's name twenty thousand names?Thou know'st my daughter's of a pretty age.What news?What impossible matter will he make easy next?I am not in the giving vein to-day.Beloved of me; and that my deeds shall prove.Friar John, go hence; Get me an iron crow, and bring it straight Unto my cell.Then all stand still; On: those that think it is unlawful business I am about, let them depart.Alack, alack, that heaven should practise stratagems Upon so soft a subject as myself!Where'er I wander, boast of this I can, Though banish'd, yet a trueborn Englishman.Beseech your highness, call the queen again.'Tis in my head to do my master good: I see no reason but supposed Lucentio Must get a father, call'd 'supposed Vincentio;' And that's a wonder: fathers commonly Do get their children; but in this case of wooing, A child shall get a sire, if I fail not of my cunning.But now I know thy mind; thou dost suspect That I have been disloyal to thy bed, And that he is a bastard, not thy son: Sweet York, sweet husband, be not of that mind: He is as like thee as a man may be, Not like to me, or any of my kin, And yet I love him.God save your good worships!Now, good sweet nurse,--O Lord, why look'st thou sad?An oath is of no moment, being not took Before a true and lawful magistrate, That hath authority over him that swears: Henry had none, but did usurp the place; Then, seeing 'twas he that made you to depose, Your oath, my lord, is vain and frivolous.Ah, poor my lord, what tongue shall smooth thy name, When I, thy three-hours wife, have mangled it?Sirrah Biondello, Now do your duty throughly, I advise you: Imagine 'twere the right Vincentio.Be York the next that must be bankrupt so!Warwick, these words have turn'd my hate to love; And I forgive and quite forget old faults, And joy that thou becomest King Henry's friend.Thou art my warrior; I holp to frame thee.Yield, Marcius, yield!Thou hast amazed me: by my holy order, I thought thy disposition better temper'd.I shall report, For most it caught me, the celestial habits, Methinks I so should term them, and the reverence Of the grave wearers.A name unmusical to the Volscians' ears, And harsh in sound to thine.And he that hath commanded is the king.Look, and thou shalt see.I do protest, I never injured thee, But love thee better than thou canst devise, Till thou shalt know the reason of my love: And so, good Capulet,--which name I tender As dearly as my own,--be satisfied.All but mariners Plunged in the foaming brine and quit the vessel, Then all afire with me: the king's son, Ferdinand, With hair up-staring,--then like reeds, not hair,-- Was the first man that leap'd; cried, 'Hell is empty And all the devils are here.'Poor Clifford!O, let him marry her.Then learn to know him now; this is the duke.Haste you speedily to Angelo: if for this night he entreat you to his bed, give him promise of satisfaction.And then he sends you word He dreamt to-night the boar had razed his helm: Besides, he says there are two councils held; And that may be determined at the one which may make you and him to rue at the other.Come, knock and enter; and no sooner in, But every man betake him to his legs.And I shall.3 KING HENRY VI Ah, whither shall I fly to 'scape their hands?First, madam, I entreat true peace of you, Which I will purchase with my duteous service; Of you, my noble cousin Buckingham, If ever any grudge were lodged between us; Of you, Lord Rivers, and, Lord Grey, of you; That without desert have frown'd on me; Dukes, earls, lords, gentlemen; indeed, of all.I see you do not mean to part with her, Or else you like not of my company.O dishonest wretch!At the hour of nine.Katharina, I charge thee, tell these headstrong women What duty they do owe their lords and husbands.'Tis thought That Marcius shall be consul: I have seen the dumb men throng to see him and The blind to bear him speak: matrons flung gloves, Ladies and maids their scarfs and handkerchers, Upon him as he pass'd: the nobles bended, As to Jove's statue, and the commons made A shower and thunder with their caps and shouts: I never saw the like.Send after the duke and appeal to him.Not better than he, by her own report.would he not fall down, Since pride must have a fall, and break the neck Of that proud man that did usurp his back?Direct me, if it be your will, Where great Aufidius lies: is he in Antium?It is a purposed thing, and grows by plot, To curb the will of the nobility: Suffer't, and live with such as cannot rule Nor ever will be ruled.Villain!Never?The duke is very strangely gone from hence; Bore many gentlemen, myself being one, In hand and hope of action: but we do learn By those that know the very nerves of state, His givings-out were of an infinite distance From his true-meant design.I am not.No; it is stopp'd with other flattering sounds, As praises, of whose taste the wise are fond, Lascivious metres, to whose venom sound The open ear of youth doth always listen; Report of fashions in proud Italy, Whose manners still our tardy apish nation Limps after in base imitation.Not one amongst us, save yourself, but says He used us scornfully: he should have show'd us His marks of merit, wounds received for's country.What, is there none of Pygmalion's images, newly made woman, to be had now, for putting the hand in the pocket and extracting it clutch'd?It is too general a vice, and severity must cure it.for what?Marry, I fare well for here is cheer enough.Can Oxford, that did ever fence the right, Now buckler falsehood with a pedigree?This may prove worse than hanging.Reason; because they then less need one another.I never look'd for better at his hands, After he once fell in with Mistress Shore.O, doubt not that; I speak from certainties.Now, Licio, to you: Good masters, take it not unkindly, pray, That I have been thus pleasant with you both.it has an elder sister, Or I mistake you: O, would her name were Grace!So long could I Stand by, a looker on.That, had he twenty heads to tender down On twenty bloody blocks, he'ld yield them up, Before his sister should her body stoop To such abhorr'd pollution.Thou desperate pilot, now at once run on The dashing rocks thy sea-sick weary bark!Hard-hearted Clifford, take me from the world: My soul to heaven, my blood upon your heads!O Kate, content thee; prithee, be not angry.What is't?What, have you forgot me?Make not impossible That which but seems unlike: 'tis not impossible But one, the wicked'st caitiff on the ground, May seem as shy, as grave, as just, as absolute As Angelo; even so may Angelo, In all his dressings, characts, titles, forms, Be an arch-villain; believe it, royal prince: If he be less, he's nothing; but he's more, Had I more name for badness.How long a time lies in one little word!Well, well, I see the issue of these arms: I cannot mend it, I must needs confess, Because my power is weak and all ill left: But if I could, by Him that gave me life, I would attach you all and make you stoop Unto the sovereign mercy of the king; But since I cannot, be it known to you I do remain as neuter.Are not these large enough?Ah, who is nigh?why is he so sad?Thou know'st my lodging: get me ink and paper, And hire post-horses; I will hence to-night.Fare you well.Why do we finger thus?The love of wicked men converts to fear; That fear to hate, and hate turns one or both To worthy danger and deserved death.Wife, we scarce thought us blest That God had lent us but this only child; But now I see this one is one too much, And that we have a curse in having her: Out on her, hilding!A cold world, Curtis, in every office but thine; and therefore fire: do thy duty, and have thy duty; for my master and mistress are almost frozen to death.And this my neighbour too?Madam, I have a touch of your condition, Which cannot brook the accent of reproof.And very welcome.What stay had I but Edward?say, whither?All bond and privilege of nature, break!Work you then.If thou wilt outstrip death, go cross the seas, And live with Richmond, from the reach of hell Go, hie thee, hie thee from this slaughter-house, Lest thou increase the number of the dead; And make me die the thrall of Margaret's curse, Nor mother, wife, nor England's counted queen.See that he be convey'd unto the Tower: And go we, brothers, to the man that took him, To question of his apprehension.That's true enough; Through 'tis a saying, sir, not due to me.And I this.Rebellious subjects, enemies to peace, Profaners of this neighbour-stained steel,-- Will they not hear?Nay, but hear me.Have thy desire.O sir!Thou art left, Marcius: A carbuncle entire, as big as thou art, Were not so rich a jewel.O' my troth, I looked upon him o' Wednesday half an hour together: has such a confirmed countenance.Were it not pity that this goodly boy Should lose his birthright by his father's fault, And long hereafter say unto his child, 'What my great-grandfather and his grandsire got My careless father fondly gave away'?O worthy prince, dishonour not your eye By throwing it on any other object Till you have heard me in my true complaint And given me justice, justice, justice, justice!My good Camillo, She is as forward of her breeding as She is i' the rear our birth.Here: what's the matter?Now put your shields before your hearts, and fight With hearts more proof than shields.Let's have that, good sir.Myself am struck in years, I must confess; And if I die to-morrow, this is hers, If whilst I live she will be only mine.Noble lady!Most manifest, and not denied by himself.Nay, rather, wilt thou draw thy forces hence, Confess who set thee up and pluck'd thee own, Call Warwick patron and be penitent?The higher powers forbid!Mowbray, impartial are our eyes and ears: Were he my brother, nay, my kingdom's heir, As he is but my father's brother's son, Now, by my sceptre's awe, I make a vow, Such neighbour nearness to our sacred blood Should nothing privilege him, nor partialize The unstooping firmness of my upright soul: He is our subject, Mowbray; so art thou: Free speech and fearless I to thee allow.Our army's in the field We never yet made doubt but Rome was ready To answer us.Neighbours, God speed!Thou attend'st not.Now, by my seat's right royal majesty, Wert thou not brother to great Edward's son, This tongue that runs so roundly in thy head Should run thy head from thy unreverent shoulders.Mistress Kate Keepdown was with child by him in the duke's time; he promised her marriage: his child is a year and a quarter old, come Philip and Jacob: I have kept it myself; and see how he goes about to abuse me!I would your highness would depart the field: The queen hath best success when you are absent.The rabble should have first unroof'd the city, Ere so prevail'd with me: it will in time Win upon power and throw forth greater themes For insurrection's arguing.Shall remain!And you.We are convented Upon a pleasing treaty, and have hearts Inclinable to honour and advance The theme of our assembly.What, shall I be appointed hours; as though, belike, I knew not what to take and what to leave, ha?would you have me False to my nature?O gracious duke, Harp not on that, nor do not banish reason For inequality; but let your reason serve To make the truth appear where it seems hid, And hide the false seems true.Why, there thou hast it: two deep enemies, Foes to my rest and my sweet sleep's disturbers Are they that I would have thee deal upon: Tyrrel, I mean those bastards in the Tower.Camillo with him?How goes it now, sir?Erroneous vassal!not a whit for me; For I, too fond, might have prevented this.Madam, in happy time, what day is that?We have not yet set down this day of triumph.The queen is valued thirty thousand strong, And Somerset, with Oxford fled to her: If she have time to breathe be well assured Her faction will be full as strong as ours.Go, do our bidding; hence!I hear it now above me.Poor queen!We are undone, lady, we are undone!Chide me, dear stone, that I may say indeed Thou art Hermione; or rather, thou art she In thy not chiding, for she was as tender As infancy and grace.It shall not neither.Nor near nor farther off, my gracious lord, Than this weak arm: discomfort guides my tongue And bids me speak of nothing but despair.a tapster, sir; parcel-bawd; one that serves a bad woman; whose house, sir, was, as they say, plucked down in the suburbs; and now she professes a hot-house, which, I think, is a very ill house too.Tell me, good my friend, What torch is yond, that vainly lends his light To grubs and eyeless skulls?Methinks I am a prophet new inspired And thus expiring do foretell of him: His rash fierce blaze of riot cannot last, For violent fires soon burn out themselves; Small showers last long, but sudden storms are short; He tires betimes that spurs too fast betimes; With eager feeding food doth choke the feeder: Light vanity, insatiate cormorant, Consuming means, soon preys upon itself.and by the operation of the second cup draws it on the drawer, when indeed there is no need.The loss you have is but a son being king, And by that loss your daughter is made queen.Marry, we were sent for to the justices.Madam, I am here.For Margaret my queen, and Clifford too, Have chid me from the battle; swearing both They prosper best of all when I am thence.What shall be done, sir, with the groaning Juliet?The tempter or the tempted, who sins most?You perceive she stirs: Start not; her actions shall be holy as You hear my spell is lawful: do not shun her Until you see her die again; for then You kill her double.Can you tell me of any?Mend and charge home, Or, by the fires of heaven, I'll leave the foe And make my wars on you: look to't: come on; If you'll stand fast, we'll beat them to their wives, As they us to our trenches followed.Who told me, when we both lay in the field Frozen almost to death, how he did lap me Even in his own garments, and gave himself, All thin and naked, to the numb cold night?To God, the widow's champion and defence.What, is't murder?The matter?Northumberland, I hold thee reverently.I gave thee mine before thou didst request it: And yet I would it were to give again.I will then give it you soundly.Or else his head's assurance is but frail.Come between us, good Benvolio; my wits faint.Would all the world but he had quite forsworn!Think with thyself How more unfortunate than all living women Are we come hither: since that thy sight, which should Make our eyes flow with joy, hearts dance with comforts, Constrains them weep and shake with fear and sorrow; Making the mother, wife and child to see The son, the husband and the father tearing His country's bowels out.What?This brat is none of mine; It is the issue of Polixenes: Hence with it, and together with the dam Commit them to the fire!Doth set my pugging tooth on edge; For a quart of ale is a dish for a king.And this shall free thee from this present shame; If no inconstant toy, nor womanish fear, Abate thy valour in the acting it.Does Bridget paint still, Pompey, ha?where are you?As that is desperate which we would prevent.Fear not, man; here's no harm intended to thee.speak to thy mother, boy!Alack, alack, what blood is this, which stains The stony entrance of this sepulchre?But thou art not quickly moved to strike.God ye good morrow, gentlemen.O sweet Paulina, Make me to think so twenty years together!Well, we may meet again.But hast thou done thy errand to Baptista?Sir Walter Herbert, a renowned soldier; Sir Gilbert Talbot, Sir William Stanley; Oxford, redoubted Pembroke, Sir James Blunt, And Rice ap Thomas with a valiant crew; And many more of noble fame and worth: And towards London they do bend their course, If by the way they be not fought withal.If that my cousin king be King of England, It must be granted I am Duke of Lancaster.Should all despair That have revolted wives, the tenth of mankind Would hang themselves.If I thought that, I tell thee, homicide, These nails should rend that beauty from my cheeks.Where be the bending peers that flatter'd thee?Abhorred slave, Which any print of goodness wilt not take, Being capable of all ill!No, sir, I say his horse comes, with him on his back.This, by his voice, should be a Montague.Ay, ay, a scratch, a scratch; marry, 'tis enough.Is ink and paper ready?Camillo, this great sir will yet stay longer.Old John of Gaunt, time-honour'd Lancaster, Hast thou, according to thy oath and band, Brought hither Henry Hereford thy bold son, Here to make good the boisterous late appeal, Which then our leisure would not let us hear, Against the Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Mowbray?where Madam Mitigation comes!Why, then the maid is mine from all the world, By your firm promise: Gremio is out-vied.If yet your gentle souls fly in the air And be not fix'd in doom perpetual, Hover about me with your airy wings And hear your mother's lamentation!I have a note from the Volscian state, to find you out there: you have well saved me a day's journey.But this is something odd.I do defy thy conjurations, And apprehend thee for a felon here.Give me mine own again; 'twere no good part To take on me to keep and kill thy heart.Down with him!O thou well skill'd in curses, stay awhile, And teach me how to curse mine enemies!See, see; what a man you are now!From Rome.An you re us and fa us, you note us.But let us hence, my sovereign, to provide A salve for any sore that may betide.Each word thou hast spoke hath weeded from my heart A root of ancient envy.Go to; no more words.My liege, in Kent the Guildfords are in arms; And every hour more competitors Flock to their aid, and still their power increaseth.'Twill make me think the world is full of rubs, And that my fortune rubs against the bias.'Tis well; and hold your own, in any case, With such austerity as 'longeth to a father.Exeter, thou art a traitor to the crown In following this usurping Henry.O, I have pass'd a miserable night, So full of ugly sights, of ghastly dreams, That, as I am a Christian faithful man, I would not spend another such a night, Though 'twere to buy a world of happy days, So full of dismal terror was the time!I think, Camillo?If the duke with the other dukes come not to composition with the King of Hungary, why then all the dukes fall upon the king.Where's Barnardine?Now, perjured Henry!What's thy offence, Claudio?Our aediles smote?Go home to bed, and like the owl by day, If he arise, be mock'd and wonder'd at.My sovereign liege, I do beseech your majesty To take our brother Clarence to your grace.Strike, drum.Norfolk, so far as to mine enemy:-- By this time, had the king permitted us, One of our souls had wander'd in the air.Your presence makes us rich, most noble lord.one mess is like to be your cheer: Come, sir; we will better it in Pisa.Sir, there lies such secrets in this fardel and box, which none must know but the king; and which he shall know within this hour, if I may come to the speech of him.Prove me, my gracious sovereign.I will be gone, sir, and not trouble you.I dream'd a dream to-night.Signior Lucentio, Here is my hand, and here I firmly vow Never to woo her no more, but do forswear her, As one unworthy all the former favours That I have fondly flatter'd her withal.O valiant lord, the Duke of York is slain!brother, revenge my death!'a very tall man!We'll have this song out anon by ourselves: my father and the gentlemen are in sad talk, and we'll not trouble them.The lady stirs.O holy friar, O, tell me, holy friar, Where is my lady's lord, where's Romeo?I inform them!I told her so, my lord, On your displeasure's peril and on mine, She should not visit you.Thyself and thy belongings Are not thine own so proper as to waste Thyself upon thy virtues, they on thee.Ay, full as dearly as I love myself.I know not whether to depart in silence, Or bitterly to speak in your reproof.O perilous mouths, That bear in them one and the self-same tongue, Either of condemnation or approof; Bidding the law make court'sy to their will: Hooking both right and wrong to the appetite, To follow as it draws!Thou'ldst thank me but a little for my counsel: And yet I'll promise thee she shall be rich And very rich: but thou'rt too much my friend, And I'll not wish thee to her.Hear a little further And then I'll bring thee to the present business Which now's upon's; without the which this story Were most impertinent.It was, villain, ere thy hand did set it down.This wind, you talk of, blows us from ourselves; Supper is done, and we shall come too late.dare you speak?What shall I say?A single thing, as I am now, that wonders To hear thee speak of Naples.Whom would to God I had well knock'd at first, Then had not Grumio come by the worst.Welcome, gentlemen!Should I do so, I should belie my thoughts: Comfort's in heaven; and we are on the earth, Where nothing lives but crosses, cares and grief.And is it not well served in to a sweet goose?Look you bring me in the names of some six or seven, the most sufficient of your parish.Why, is not this a lamentable thing, grandsire, that we should be thus afflicted with these strange flies, these fashion-mongers, these perdona-mi's, who stand so much on the new form, that they cannot at ease on the old bench?What do you think of the trade, Pompey?If it be so, out with it boldly, man; Quick is mine ear to hear of good towards him.Here's much to do with hate, but more with love.There is no truth at all i' the oracle: The sessions shall proceed: this is mere falsehood.Take heed; for he holds vengeance in his hands, To hurl upon their heads that break his law.The consul Coriolanus.Well mayst thou woo, and happy be thy speed!O monstrous beast!The king is not himself, but basely led By flatterers; and what they will inform, Merely in hate, 'gainst any of us all, That will the king severely prosecute 'Gainst us, our lives, our children, and our heirs.Alas, you know, 'tis far from hence to France; How could he stay till Warwick made return?So triumph thieves upon their conquer'd booty; So true men yield, with robbers so o'ermatch'd.We will so: almost all Repent in their election.Come, lords, away.Come away; it is almost clear dawn.Till then fair hope must hinder life's decay.No more of him; he is a worthy man: make way, they are coming.Yes, brother, you may live: There is a devilish mercy in the judge, If you'll implore it, that will free your life, But fetter you till death.I dare be sworn you were: And, sir, it is no little thing to make Mine eyes to sweat compassion.Hoo!Norfolk, we must have knocks; ha!and what stir Keeps good old York there with his men of war?They fear us not, but issue forth their city.Sir, are not you my father?Doubt not The commoners, for whom we stand, but they Upon their ancient malice will forget With the least cause these his new honours, which That he will give them make I as little question As he is proud to do't.What though I kill'd her husband and her father?When didst thou sleep when such a deed was done?What shrill-voiced suppliant makes this eager cry?You have no cause.Since birth, and heaven, and earth, all three do meet In thee at once; which thou at once wouldst lose.Away, away, to meet the queen's great power!where is Bagot?O, but they say the tongues of dying men Enforce attention like deep harmony: Where words are scarce, they are seldom spent in vain, For they breathe truth that breathe their words in pain.Here's to my love!A cause more promising Than a wild dedication of yourselves To unpath'd waters, undream'd shores, most certain To miseries enough; no hope to help you, But as you shake off one to take another; Nothing so certain as your anchors, who Do their best office, if they can but stay you Where you'll be loath to be: besides you know Prosperity's the very bond of love, Whose fresh complexion and whose heart together Affliction alters.I'll stay above the hill, so both may shoot.You are passing welcome, And so I pray you all to think yourselves.And he that will not fight for such a hope.Sir, my name is Lucio; well known to the duke.I will go wash; And when my face is fair, you shall perceive Whether I blush or no: howbeit, I thank you.What!What is thy name?A husband and a son thou owest to me; And thou a kingdom; all of you allegiance: The sorrow that I have, by right is yours, And all the pleasures you usurp are mine.Thou churl, for this time, Though full of our displeasure, yet we free thee From the dead blow of it.Accursed be he that seeks to make them foes!I know not, an't like you.Hath he set bounds betwixt their love and me?thou dost infect my eyes.We'll keep no great ado,--a friend or two; For, hark you, Tybalt being slain so late, It may be thought we held him carelessly, Being our kinsman, if we revel much: Therefore we'll have some half a dozen friends, And there an end.Madam, we will attend your grace.Our hint of woe Is common; every day some sailor's wife, The masters of some merchant and the merchant Have just our theme of woe; but for the miracle, I mean our preservation, few in millions Can speak like us: then wisely, good sir, weigh Our sorrow with our comfort.Nay, I knew by his face that there was something in him: he had, sir, a kind of face, methought,--I cannot tell how to term it.Under yond yew-trees lay thee all along, Holding thine ear close to the hollow ground; So shall no foot upon the churchyard tread, Being loose, unfirm, with digging up of graves, But thou shalt hear it: whistle then to me, As signal that thou hear'st something approach.O, I am slain!What answers Clarence to his sovereign's will?The ground is bloody; search about the churchyard: Go, some of you, whoe'er you find attach.Put this in any liquid thing you will, And drink it off; and, if you had the strength Of twenty men, it would dispatch you straight.Much is your sorrow; mine ten times so much.I will, my lord: God give your grace good rest!Go, go, poor soul, I envy not thy glory To feed my humour, wish thyself no harm.Some six miles off the duke is with the soldiers; And for your brother, he was lately sent From your kind aunt, Duchess of Burgundy, With aid of soldiers to this needful war.My men should call me 'lord:' I am your goodman.I have lived To see inherited my very wishes And the buildings of my fancy: only There's one thing wanting, which I doubt not but Our Rome will cast upon thee.I think there is not in the world either malice or matter to alter it.Fare ye well: Thou hast years upon thee; and thou art too full Of the wars' surfeits, to go rove with one That's yet unbruised: bring me but out at gate.Because that now it lies you on to speak To the people; not by your own instruction, Nor by the matter which your heart prompts you, But with such words that are but rooted in Your tongue, though but bastards and syllables Of no allowance to your bosom's truth.Good Paulina, Who hast the memory of Hermione, I know, in honour, O, that ever I Had squared me to thy counsel!Well, here he comes.Sir, what are you that offer to beat my servant?First will I see the coronation; And then to Brittany I'll cross the sea, To effect this marriage, so it please my lord.And here comes Claudio's pardon.Our state thinks not so: they are in a most warlike preparation, and hope to come upon them in the heat of their division.Pray you, do.Setting aside his high blood's royalty, And let him be no kinsman to my liege, I do defy him, and I spit at him; Call him a slanderous coward and a villain: Which to maintain I would allow him odds, And meet him, were I tied to run afoot Even to the frozen ridges of the Alps, Or any other ground inhabitable, Where ever Englishman durst set his foot.I shall tell you A pretty tale: it may be you have heard it;
