But, since it serves my purpose, I will venture To stale 't a little more.Uncle, give me your hands: nay, dry your eyes; Tears show their love, but want their remedies.About what?O general, Here is the steed, we the caparison: Hadst thou beheld-- Pray now, no more: my mother, Who has a charter to extol her blood, When she does praise me grieves me.Nay, I'll conjure too.This speak I, lords, to let you understand, If case some one of you would fly from us, That there's no hoped-for mercy with the brothers More than with ruthless waves, with sands and rocks.Behold, behold.ourselves resisted?Come, officer, away!Two thousand ducats by the year of land!And either victory, or else a grave.My father named me Autolycus; who being, as I am, littered under Mercury, was likewise a snapper-up of unconsidered trifles.What, dost thou scorn me for my gentle counsel?Farewell, my Hector, and my Troy's true hope.I would they were abed!Yet, Warwick, in despite of all mischance, Of thee thyself and all thy complices, Edward will always bear himself as king: Though fortune's malice overthrow my state, My mind exceeds the compass of her wheel.What's within, boy?My affections Are then most humble; I have no ambition To see a goodlier man.How came the posterns So easily open?And, to cut off all strife, here sit we down: Take you your instrument, play you the whiles; His lecture will be done ere you have tuned.In God's name, cheerly on, courageous friends, To reap the harvest of perpetual peace By this one bloody trial of sharp war.I grant ye.Where is the master, boatswain?They call him Doricles; and boasts himself To have a worthy feeding: but I have it Upon his own report and I believe it; He looks like sooth.You will be schoolmaster And undertake the teaching of the maid: That's your device.Kate like the hazel-twig Is straight and slender and as brown in hue As hazel nuts and sweeter than the kernels.Madam, my mother, I do cry you mercy; I did not see your grace: humbly on my knee I crave your blessing.Are you a courtier, an't like you, sir?Why, no.Then, tell me, what doth he upon the sea?Master Barnardine!She had one eye declined for the loss of her husband, another elevated that the oracle was fulfilled: she lifted the princess from the earth, and so locks her in embracing, as if she would pin her to her heart that she might no more be in danger of losing.I will not do't, Lest I surcease to honour mine own truth And by my body's action teach my mind A most inherent baseness.What news abroad?My holy sir, none better knows than you How I have ever loved the life removed And held in idle price to haunt assemblies Where youth, and cost, and witless bravery keeps.thy name?Who is that calls so coldly?He shall not.Go to kennel, Pompey; go.millions of false eyes Are stuck upon thee: volumes of report Run with these false and most contrarious quests Upon thy doings: thousand escapes of wit Make thee the father of their idle dreams And rack thee in their fancies.I may, and will, if she be so contented: She will be pleased; then wherefore should I doubt?Which is the least?Where is the Earl of Wiltshire?Besides I say and will in battle prove, Or here or elsewhere to the furthest verge That ever was survey'd by English eye, That all the treasons for these eighteen years Complotted and contrived in this land Fetch from false Mowbray their first head and spring.Yet nature might have made me as these are, Therefore I will not disdain.Thanks, noble Clarence; worthy brother, thanks.Fie, fie on all tired jades, on all mad masters, and all foul ways!How now, my lord!Noting this penury, to myself I said 'An if a man did need a poison now, Whose sale is present death in Mantua, Here lives a caitiff wretch would sell it him.'Know thus far forth.How, my pretty York?Hermione, How thou lovest us, show in our brother's welcome; Let what is dear in Sicily be cheap: Next to thyself and my young rover, he's Apparent to my heart.Well thought upon; I have it here about me.Wrath-kindled gentlemen, be ruled by me; Let's purge this choler without letting blood: This we prescribe, though no physician; Deep malice makes too deep incision; Forget, forgive; conclude and be agreed; Our doctors say this is no month to bleed.Ah, Gaunt, his blood was thine!she's cold: Her blood is settled, and her joints are stiff; Life and these lips have long been separated: Death lies on her like an untimely frost Upon the sweetest flower of all the field.I never heard the absent duke much detected for women; he was not inclined that way.These eyes could never endure sweet beauty's wreck; You should not blemish it, if I stood by: As all the world is cheered by the sun, So I by that; it is my day, my life.What man art thou that thus bescreen'd in night So stumblest on my counsel?You knew of his departure, as you know What you have underta'en to do in's absence.To see how inly sorrow gripes his soul.'Tis bargain'd 'twixt us twain, being alone, That she shall still be curst in company.What's he that now is going out of door?Sprawl'st thou?Where is he?Look, I am going: Commend me to my wife.Who?Now, when the bridegroom in the morning comes To rouse thee from thy bed, there art thou dead: Then, as the manner of our country is, In thy best robes uncover'd on the bier Thou shalt be borne to that same ancient vault Where all the kindred of the Capulets lie.So Judas did to Christ: but he, in twelve, Found truth in all but one: I, in twelve thousand, none.you are manifest house-keepers.I would know that of your honour.Boatswain!A hall, a hall!O this woodcock, what an ass it is!How came that widow in?3 KING HENRY VI Now, my Lord Hastings and Sir William Stanley, Leave off to wonder why I drew you hither, Into this chiefest thicket of the park.Madam, your majesty is too much sad: You promised, when you parted with the king, To lay aside life-harming heaviness And entertain a cheerful disposition.Let us entreat you stay till after dinner.Thou hadst, and more, Miranda.See, our best elders.Three Judases, each one thrice worse than Judas!Now, afore God, I am so vexed, that every part about me quivers.Go; away with her to prison!O, know you yet, he doth it publicly, Take not the quarrel from his powerful arm; He needs no indirect nor lawless course To cut off those that have offended him.My lord, I claim your gift, my due by promise, For which your honour and your faith is pawn'd; The earldom of Hereford and the moveables The which you promised I should possess.He that hath a will to die by himself fears it not from another: let your general do his worst.With this, we charged again: but, out, alas!We are all undone, unless The noble man have mercy.Now I come to't my lord She that accuses him of fornication, In self-same manner doth accuse my husband, And charges him my lord, with such a time When I'll depose I had him in mine arms With all the effect of love.I have a little money for thee.Where's the master?What, weeping-ripe, my Lord Northumberland?But, God be thank'd, there's no need of me, And much I need to help you, if need were; The royal tree hath left us royal fruit, Which, mellow'd by the stealing hours of time, Will well become the seat of majesty, And make, no doubt, us happy by his reign.She will not.I take my leave of you.How now!the cords That Romeo bid thee fetch?A wager they have met.The most arch of piteous massacre That ever yet this land was guilty of.Gardener, for telling me these news of woe, Pray God the plants thou graft'st may never grow.3 KING HENRY VI So, lie thou there: die thou, and die our fear; For Warwick was a bug that fear'd us all.There's some in hope.By my head, here come the Capulets.He cannot live, I hope; and must not die Till George be pack'd with post-horse up to heaven.Hear me a word; For I shall never speak to thee again.Is he not like thee?I say, My foot my tutor?Claudio, whom here you have warrant to execute, is no greater forfeit to the law than Angelo who hath sentenced him.I long to hear you tell it.Madam, if't please the queen to send the babe, I know not what I shall incur to pass it, Having no warrant.Thou hast sworn it more to me: Then whither goest?Had our prince, Jewel of children, seen this hour, he had pair'd Well with this lord: there was not full a month Between their births.what shouts are these?I do bite my thumb, sir.There lies that Tybalt.'He kill'd my son.'Troth, sir, she hath eaten up all her beef, and she is herself in the tub.Ay, but yet Let us be keen, and rather cut a little, Than fall, and bruise to death.What, shall this speech be spoke for our excuse?By the discovery.Here he comes, and in the gown of humility: mark his behavior.It is: may it be done?'Lo, thus' quoth Dighton, 'lay those tender babes:' 'Thus, thus,' quoth Forrest, 'girdling one another Within their innocent alabaster arms: Their lips were four red roses on a stalk, Which in their summer beauty kiss'd each other.No noise, my lord; but needful conference About some gossips for your highness.Richard, enough; I will be king, or die.May they perceive's intent!More bitterly could I expostulate, Save that, for reverence to some alive, I give a sparing limit to my tongue.When this is known, then to divide the times: So many hours must I tend my flock; So many hours must I take my rest; So many hours must I contemplate; So many hours must I sport myself; So many days my ewes have been with young; So many weeks ere the poor fools will ean: So many years ere I shall shear the fleece: So minutes, hours, days, months, and years, Pass'd over to the end they were created, Would bring white hairs unto a quiet grave.The duke's in us; and we will hear you speak: Look you speak justly.But that's no matter, the greater part carries it.The swifter speed the better.Sirrah, I will not bear these braves of thine.Am I your bird?And shows good husbandry for the Volscian state, Fights dragon-like, and does achieve as soon As draw his sword; yet he hath left undone That which shall break his neck or hazard mine, Whene'er we come to our account.Come, come, you have been too rough, something too rough; You must return and mend it.Gregory, remember thy swashing blow.No?O, where is Romeo?Therefore, good mother,--I must can you so-- Be the attorney of my love to her: Plead what I will be, not what I have been; Not my deserts, but what I will deserve: Urge the necessity and state of times, And be not peevish-fond in great designs.how is't with you, best brother?have I twice said well?Whate'er it bodes, henceforward will I bear Upon my target three fair-shining suns.Richard of York!But are they, Ariel, safe?Your virtue is To make him worthy whose offence subdues him And curse that justice did it.I'll not meddle with it: it is a dangerous thing: it makes a man a coward: a man cannot steal, but it accuseth him; he cannot swear, but it cheques him; he cannot lie with his neighbour's wife, but it detects him: 'tis a blushing shamefast spirit that mutinies in a man's bosom; it fills one full of obstacles: it made me once restore a purse of gold that I found; it beggars any man that keeps it: it is turned out of all towns and cities for a dangerous thing; and every man that means to live well endeavours to trust to himself and to live without it.Alas!If the king had no son, they would desire to live on crutches till he had one.Thy head is as fun of quarrels as an egg is full of meat, and yet thy head hath been beaten as addle as an egg for quarrelling: thou hast quarrelled with a man for coughing in the street, because he hath wakened thy dog that hath lain asleep in the sun: didst thou not fall out with a tailor for wearing his new doublet before Easter?Ay, and old York, and yet not satisfied.Yet give us our dispatch: I am hush'd until our city be a-fire, And then I'll speak a little.Coriolanus, patience!And, sowing the kernels of it in the sea, bring forth more islands.I read that I profess, the Art to Love.Now were I happy, if His going I could frame to serve my turn, Save him from danger, do him love and honour, Purchase the sight again of dear Sicilia And that unhappy king, my master, whom I so much thirst to see.no.And, noble uncle, I beseech your grace Look on my wrongs with an indifferent eye: You are my father, for methinks in you I see old Gaunt alive; O, then, my father, Will you permit that I shall stand condemn'd A wandering vagabond; my rights and royalties Pluck'd from my arms perforce and given away To upstart unthrifts?Of all mad matches never was the like.O place, O form, How often dost thou with thy case, thy habit, Wrench awe from fools and tie the wiser souls To thy false seeming!But I, that am not shaped for sportive tricks, Nor made to court an amorous looking-glass; I, that am rudely stamp'd, and want love's majesty To strut before a wanton ambling nymph; I, that am curtail'd of this fair proportion, Cheated of feature by dissembling nature, Deformed, unfinish'd, sent before my time Into this breathing world, scarce half made up, And that so lamely and unfashionable That dogs bark at me as I halt by them; Why, I, in this weak piping time of peace, Have no delight to pass away the time, Unless to spy my shadow in the sun And descant on mine own deformity: And therefore, since I cannot prove a lover, To entertain these fair well-spoken days, I am determined to prove a villain And hate the idle pleasures of these days.So when he opens his purse to give us our reward, thy conscience flies out.Give me my boots, I say; saddle my horse.Thus can the demigod Authority Make us pay down for our offence by weight The words of heaven; on whom it will, it will; On whom it will not, so; yet still 'tis just.traitor!And is the bride and bridegroom coming home?What heir of York is there alive but we?Thus strangers may be hailed and abused: O monstrous villain!I am like you, they say.O, I am press'd to death through want of speaking!You that love me and Warwick, follow me.thy Juliet is alive, For whose dear sake thou wast but lately dead; There art thou happy: Tybalt would kill thee, But thou slew'st Tybalt; there are thou happy too: The law that threaten'd death becomes thy friend And turns it to exile; there art thou happy: A pack of blessings lights up upon thy back; Happiness courts thee in her best array; But, like a misbehaved and sullen wench, Thou pout'st upon thy fortune and thy love: Take heed, take heed, for such die miserable.O Marcius, Marcius!O, very well; I have perused the note.will you dismiss the people?Soft!And me too, good Lord!Signior Gremio, came you from the church?Why, here's no crab; and therefore look not sour.Who's there?Go, Cleomenes; Yourself, assisted with your honour'd friends, Bring them to our embracement.Justice or Iniquity?My lord, I am more amazed at his dishonour Than at the strangeness of it.Both by myself and many other friends: But he, his own affections' counsellor, Is to himself--I will not say how true-- But to himself so secret and so close, So far from sounding and discovery, As is the bud bit with an envious worm, Ere he can spread his sweet leaves to the air, Or dedicate his beauty to the sun.After, Aumerle!Yonder man is carried to prison.Juliet wills it so.At the good queen's entreaty.Come, I have found you out a stand most fit, Where you may have such vantage on the duke, He shall not pass you.Give me the boy: I am glad you did not nurse him: Though he does bear some signs of me, yet you Have too much blood in him.Come gentlemen, Let us consult upon to-morrow's business In to our tent; the air is raw and cold.Where shall we dine?can you love the gentleman?I am too old to fawn upon a nurse, Too far in years to be a pupil now: What is thy sentence then but speechless death, Which robs my tongue from breathing native breath?The date is out of such prolixity: We'll have no Cupid hoodwink'd with a scarf, Bearing a Tartar's painted bow of lath, Scaring the ladies like a crow-keeper; Nor no without-book prologue, faintly spoke After the prompter, for our entrance: But let them measure us by what they will; We'll measure them a measure, and be gone.O mercy, God!Music do I hear?Arm, arm, my name!Is not, sir, my doublet as fresh as the first day I wore it?I dare not know, my lord.Ay, for a turtle, as he takes a buzzard.Was this face the face That every day under his household roof Did keep ten thousand men?Where was she born?Here comes a gentleman that haply knows more.Hence from Verona art thou banished: Be patient, for the world is broad and wide.Nay, but my letters, by this means being there So soon as you arrive, shall clear that doubt.Why, what is pomp, rule, reign, but earth and dust?What tongueless blocks were they!I come, anon.--But if thou mean'st not well, I do beseech thee-- By and by, I come:-- To cease thy suit, and leave me to my grief: To-morrow will I send.Can vengeance be pursued further than death?Why, they stay at door, sir.I am angling now, Though you perceive me not how I give line.make your best of it.Good boatswain, have care.What is't o'clock?I'll not put The dibble in earth to set one slip of them; No more than were I painted I would wish This youth should say 'twere well and only therefore Desire to breed by me.he stirs: shall I strike?He's within, sir, but not to be spoken withal.Wherein our entertainment shall shame us we will be justified in our loves; for indeed-- Beseech you,-- Verily, I speak it in the freedom of my knowledge: we cannot with such magnificence--in so rare--I know not what to say.I have ta'en a due and wary note upon't: With whispering and most guilty diligence, In action all of precept, he did show me The way twice o'er.Go, fool, and whom thou keep'st command.3 KING HENRY VI Welcome, my lord, to this brave town of York.Yet this good comfort bring I to your grace, The Breton navy is dispersed by tempest: Richmond, in Yorkshire, sent out a boat Unto the shore, to ask those on the banks If they were his assistants, yea or no; Who answer'd him, they came from Buckingham.I am his king, and he should bow his knee; I was adopted heir by his consent: Since when, his oath is broke; for, as I hear, You, that are king, though he do wear the crown, Have caused him, by new act of parliament, To blot out me, and put his own son in.In him there is a hope of government, That in his nonage council under him, And in his full and ripen'd years himself, No doubt, shall then and till then govern well.Pardon me, God, I knew not what I did!That will I. Go, Biondello, bid your mistress come to me.My sovereign liege, no letters; and few words, But such as I, without your special pardon, Dare not relate.Come I too late?Windy attorneys to their client woes, Airy succeeders of intestate joys, Poor breathing orators of miseries!And says a wizard told him that by G His issue disinherited should be; And, for my name of George begins with G, It follows in his thought that I am he. These, as I learn, and such like toys as these Have moved his highness to commit me now.Nay; I beseech you, mark it well.Menenius ever, ever.Now prisoner to the palsy, chastise thee And minister correction to thy fault!what noise is this?Thus it stands: Her eldest sister is so curst and shrewd That till the father rid his hands of her, Master, your love must live a maid at home; And therefore has he closely mew'd her up, Because she will not be annoy'd with suitors.Thou hast sworn my love to be.Catesby, o'erlook the walls.Stays here longer.Come, follow.God give him joy!Where is your sister, and Hortensio's wife?To my house.Alas, He hath but as offended in a dream!Then give me leave to go.Not your gaoler, then, But your kind hostess.Take my defiance!What you will have it named, even that it is; And so it shall be so for Katharina.Come, let's away; the strangers all are gone.At any time 'fore noon.Why stand we like soft-hearted women here, Wailing our losses, whiles the foe doth rage; And look upon, as if the tragedy Were play'd in jest by counterfeiting actors?Because my name is George.an thou make minstrels of us, look to hear nothing but discords: here's my fiddlestick; here's that shall make you dance.O woe!O noble fellow!Had we pursued that life, And our weak spirits ne'er been higher rear'd With stronger blood, we should have answer'd heaven Boldly 'not guilty;' the imposition clear'd Hereditary ours.And we mean well in going to this mask; But 'tis no wit to go.One word, good friend.No; if I mistake In those foundations which I build upon, The centre is not big enough to bear A school-boy's top.Your pardon, sir; for this I'll blush you thanks.Would I had been by, to have helped the old man!To me comes a creature, Sometimes her head on one side, some another; I never saw a vessel of like sorrow, So fill'd and so becoming: in pure white robes, Like very sanctity, she did approach My cabin where I lay; thrice bow'd before me, And gasping to begin some speech, her eyes Became two spouts: the fury spent, anon Did this break-from her: 'Good Antigonus, Since fate, against thy better disposition, Hath made thy person for the thrower-out Of my poor babe, according to thine oath, Places remote enough are in Bohemia, There weep and leave it crying; and, for the babe Is counted lost for ever, Perdita, I prithee, call't.She says your worship means to make a puppet of her.Lord Angelo, having affairs to heaven, Intends you for his swift ambassador, Where you shall be an everlasting leiger: Therefore your best appointment make with speed; To-morrow you set on.Here are the beetle brows shall blush for me.Now York and Lancaster are reconciled.I say she shall: and first begin with her.the hai!Can you cut off a man's head?Your love says, like an honest gentleman, and a courteous, and a kind, and a handsome, and, I warrant, a virtuous,--Where is your mother?Asses are made to bear, and so are you.His vices, you would say; there's no virtue whipped out of the court: they cherish it to make it stay there; and yet it will no more but abide.'tis done.and he's gone.O cheerful colours!No, like a bank for love to lie and play on; Not like a corse; or if, not to be buried, But quick and in mine arms.You'll stay?Sorry am I that our good will effects Bianca's grief.Remember our reward, when the deed is done.You must think, if we give you any thing, we hope to gain by you.Being once perfected how to grant suits, How to deny them, who to advance and who To trash for over-topping, new created The creatures that were mine, I say, or changed 'em, Or else new form'd 'em; having both the key Of officer and office, set all hearts i' the state To what tune pleased his ear; that now he was The ivy which had hid my princely trunk, And suck'd my verdure out on't.you must meet my master to countenance my mistress.Wolves and bears, they say Casting their savageness aside have done Like offices of pity.Why come you not?but I am not to say it is a sea, for it is now the sky: betwixt the firmament and it you cannot thrust a bodkin's point.Let's see thy face.As I intend to prosper and repent, So thrive I in my dangerous attempt Of hostile arms!I do not know that Englishman alive With whom my soul is any jot at odds More than the infant that is born to-night I thank my God for my humility.I must needs wake her.I believe thee; for I think thou never wast where grace was said.For who is living, if those two are gone?Tush, thou art deceived: Leave me, and do the thing I bid thee do.Pardon me, Margaret; pardon me, sweet son: The Earl of Warwick and the duke enforced me.It is foul weather in us all, good sir, When you are cloudy.The worm of conscience still begnaw thy soul!I would they were, that I might die at once; For now they kill me with a living death.The time is come even now.Thanks, noble peer; The cheapest of us is ten groats too dear.I will prove so, sir, to my power.Brother, I like not this; For many men that stumble at the threshold Are well foretold that danger lurks within.gone!But is your grace dead, my Lord of Somerset?if you be gentlemen, Do me this right; hear me with patience.A hundred marks, my Kate does put her down.A pox o' your throat, you bawling, blasphemous, incharitable dog!What if this mixture do not work at all?Even all I have; yea, and myself and all, Will I withal endow a child of thine; So in the Lethe of thy angry soul Thou drown the sad remembrance of those wrongs Which thou supposest I have done to thee.Here comes Signior Claudio, led by the provost to prison; and there's Madam Juliet.By the woman's means?Hence, rotten thing!And full as oft came Edward to my side, With purple falchion, painted to the hilt In blood of those that had encounter'd him: And when the hardiest warriors did retire, Richard cried 'Charge!I wish I had a cause to seek him there, To oppose his hatred fully.and in your clothes!thou shouldst be mad; And I, to make thee mad, do mock thee thus.Thou'rt a tall fellow: hold thee that to drink.hang, you whoreson, insolent noisemaker!We will, my noble lord.Why, then, I do but dream on sovereignty; Like one that stands upon a promontory, And spies a far-off shore where he would tread, Wishing his foot were equal with his eye, And chides the sea that sunders him from thence, Saying, he'll lade it dry to have his way: So do I wish the crown, being so far off; And so I chide the means that keeps me from it; And so I say, I'll cut the causes off, Flattering me with impossibilities.'He killed my father.'but his taunts.Whether it like me or no, I am a courtier.Is't so, indeed.Come hither, Bess, and let me kiss my boy.Might you dispense with your leisure, I would by and by have some speech with you: the satisfaction I would require is likewise your own benefit.You must not enter.Go thou, and fill another room in hell.O, pardon me, Signior Gremio; I would fain be doing.'Twas from the canon.Evermore showering?bribe me?What is the jay more precious than the lark, Because his fathers are more beautiful?There stands the castle, by yon tuft of trees, Mann'd with three hundred men, as I have heard; And in it are the Lords of York, Berkeley, and Seymour; None else of name and noble estimate.The direful spectacle of the wreck, which touch'd The very virtue of compassion in thee, I have with such provision in mine art So safely ordered that there is no soul-- No, not so much perdition as an hair Betid to any creature in the vessel Which thou heard'st cry, which thou saw'st sink.Thy tyranny Together working with thy jealousies, Fancies too weak for boys, too green and idle For girls of nine, O, think what they have done And then run mad indeed, stark mad!And I to Norfolk with my followers.He call'd me father: But what o' that?Take't; 'tis yours.It is yours; And, might we lay the old proverb to your charge, So like you, 'tis the worse.Appear thou in the likeness of a sigh: Speak but one rhyme, and I am satisfied; Cry but 'Ay me!'If thou refuse And wilt encounter with my wrath, say so; The bastard brains with these my proper hands Shall I dash out.How sweet a plant have you untimely cropp'd!Indeed, he should be a footman by the garments he has left with thee: if this be a horseman's coat, it hath seen very hot service.What needs these hands?What, would you have my weapon, little lord?Where are thy children?O, wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?Fare you well.What says he of our marriage?With what a sharp-provided wit he reasons!Sweet love, I see, changing his property, Turns to the sourest and most deadly hate: Again uncurse their souls; their peace is made With heads, and not with hands; those whom you curse Have felt the worst of death's destroying wound And lie full low, graved in the hollow ground.Gives not the hawthorn-bush a sweeter shade To shepherds looking on their silly sheep, Than doth a rich embroider'd canopy To kings that fear their subjects' treachery?Welcome father.Bring forth the parties of suspicion.Griefs of mine own lie heavy in my breast, Which thou wilt propagate, to have it prest With more of thine: this love that thou hast shown Doth add more grief to too much of mine own.Manifest treason!These eyes are not the same I wore in Rome.If you be hired for meed, go back again, And I will send you to my brother Gloucester, Who shall reward you better for my life Than Edward will for tidings of my death.My lord it shall be done.but how made he escape?Doubly divorced!Good time of day unto your royal grace!murderers!Grace me no grace, nor uncle me no uncle: I am no traitor's uncle; and that word 'grace.'Now is he for the numbers that Petrarch flowed in: Laura to his lady was but a kitchen-wench; marry, she had a better love to be-rhyme her; Dido a dowdy; Cleopatra a gipsy; Helen and Hero hildings and harlots; Thisbe a grey eye or so, but not to the purpose.Hear'st thou, Mars?First, his integrity Stands without blemish.O, good sir, softly, good sir!But be thou arm'd for some unhappy words.And turns the sun to shade; alas!ay, or I'll hang her.and what says My conceal'd lady to our cancell'd love?You gave us the counterfeit fairly last night.Good night, good night!When I have most need to employ a friend, And most assured that he is a friend Deep, hollow, treacherous, and full of guile, Be he unto me!Padua affords this kindness, son Petruchio.one word more.March on, march on, since we are up in arms; If not to fight with foreign enemies, Yet to beat down these rebels here at home.What!He is my father, sir; and, sooth to say, In countenance somewhat doth resemble you.3 KING HENRY VI Forspent with toil, as runners with a race, I lay me down a little while to breathe; For strokes received, and many blows repaid, Have robb'd my strong-knit sinews of their strength, And spite of spite needs must I rest awhile.And you too, Somerset and Montague, Speak freely what you think.Well, my dread lord; so must I call you now.You are too absolute; Though therein you can never be too noble, But when extremities speak.is it ended, then?Why came I hither but to that intent?Verona's summer hath not such a flower.Mistress, how mean you that?What, art thou waking?My lord, Go then; and with a countenance as clear As friendship wears at feasts, keep with Bohemia And with your queen.What, have I pinch'd you, Signior Gremio?Mis-shapen chaos of well-seeming forms!Heigh, my hearts!she durst not call me so, If she did know me one.Know, Rome, that all alone Marcius did fight Within Corioli gates: where he hath won, With fame, a name to Caius Marcius; these In honour follows Coriolanus.I say, a husband.Away with him to prison!I beseech you, sir, ask him what this man did to my wife.What, from myself?The shadow of your sorrow hath destroy'd The shadow or your face.I thank your worship for your good counsel: but I shall follow it as the flesh and fortune shall better determine.Nay, how now!Be patient; to-morrow 't shall be mended, And, for this night, we'll fast for company: Come, I will bring thee to thy bridal chamber.Is he not wounded?You have stood your limitation; and the tribunes Endue you with the people's voice: remains That, in the official marks invested, you Anon do meet the senate.I prithee, Lucio, do me this kind service: This day my sister should the cloister enter And there receive her approbation: Acquaint her with the danger of my state: Implore her, in my voice, that she make friends To the strict deputy; bid herself assay him: I have great hope in that; for in her youth There is a prone and speechless dialect, Such as move men; beside, she hath prosperous art When she will play with reason and discourse, And well she can persuade.Alack the day!Some report a sea-maid spawned him; some, that he was begot between two stock-fishes.Sir, the duke is marvellous little beholding to your reports; but the best is, he lives not in them.Or that we would, against the form of law, Proceed thus rashly to the villain's death, But that the extreme peril of the case, The peace of England and our persons' safety, Enforced us to this execution?What is thy news then?But can you, if you would?Then, Isabel, live chaste, and, brother, die: More than our brother is our chastity.What of his heart perceive you in his face By any likelihood he show'd to-day?Sir, You speak a language that I understand not: My life stands in the level of your dreams, Which I'll lay down.Fear not, Baptista; we will content you, go to: but I will in, to be revenged for this villany.If they have overheard me now, why, hanging.Every true man's apparel fits your thief: if it be too little for your thief, your true man thinks it big enough; if it be too big for your thief, your thief thinks it little enough: so every true man's apparel fits your thief.Ay, it stands so that I may hardly tarry so long.Where are my slippers?My Lord of Gloucester, I have too long borne Your blunt upbraidings and your bitter scoffs: By heaven, I will acquaint his majesty With those gross taunts I often have endured.What is the matter with our cousin now?Fear not, sweet wench, they shall not touch thee, Kate: I'll buckler thee against a million.Dorset your son, that with a fearful soul Leads discontented steps in foreign soil, This fair alliance quickly shall call home To high promotions and great dignity: The king, that calls your beauteous daughter wife.Welcome, Harry: what, will not this castle yield?Then if thou hast A heart of wreak in thee, that wilt revenge Thine own particular wrongs and stop those maims Of shame seen through thy country, speed thee straight, And make my misery serve thy turn: so use it That my revengeful services may prove As benefits to thee, for I will fight Against my canker'd country with the spleen Of all the under fiends.How!I should leave grazing, were I of your flock, And only live by gazing.And stay thy lady too that lives in thee, By doing damned hate upon thyself?No, Bolingbroke: if ever I were traitor, My name be blotted from the book of life, And I from heaven banish'd as from hence!What hast thou found?my lord!Approach, my Ariel, come.here, sir!I hope he is; but yet let mothers doubt.You are retired, As if you were a feasted one and not The hostess of the meeting: pray you, bid These unknown friends to's welcome; for it is A way to make us better friends, more known.His royal person,-- Whom God preserve better than you would wish!-- Cannot be quiet scarce a breathing-while, But you must trouble him with lewd complaints.This man has marr'd his fortune.Mark his condition and the event; then tell me If this might be a brother.The more I stay, the more I'll succor thee.Thou loathed issue of thy father's loins!I wish the bastards dead; And I would have it suddenly perform'd.Under your sentence?The statue is but newly fix'd, the colour's Not dry.Long die thy happy days before thy death; And, after many lengthen'd hours of grief, Die neither mother, wife, nor England's queen!O, he is even in my mistress' case, Just in her case!Their transformations Were never for a piece of beauty rarer, Nor in a way so chaste, since my desires Run not before mine honour, nor my lusts Burn hotter than my faith.What, doth she swoon?Ay, for if Edward repossess the crown, 'Tis like that Richmond with the rest shall down.Madam wife, they say that I have dream'd And slept above some fifteen year or more.And bad'st me bury love.Thy honour, state and seat is due to me.Have you an army ready, say you?Nine, sir; Overdone by the last.The proud insulting queen, With Clifford and the haught Northumberland, And of their feather many more proud birds, Have wrought the easy-melting king like wax.Whate'er I read to her, I'll plead for you As for my patron, stand you so assured, As firmly as yourself were still in place: Yea, and perhaps with more successful words Than you, unless you were a scholar, sir.'Tis time to part them.Inch-thick, knee-deep, o'er head and ears a fork'd one!A mighty man of Pisa; by report I know him well: you are very welcome, sir, Take you the lute, and you the set of books; You shall go see your pupils presently.Head, and butt!Mark you this, people?You have made good work, You and your apron-men; you that stood so up much on the voice of occupation and The breath of garlic-eaters!I pray you, be acquainted with this maid; She comes to do you good.Why strew'st thou sugar on that bottled spider, Whose deadly web ensnareth thee about?I pray now, keep below.Sweet Kate, embrace her for her beauty's sake.Most detestable death, by thee beguil'd, By cruel cruel thee quite overthrown!I beseech you, sir, look in this gentleman's face.Tell me, mine own.for that goes hard.Petruchio, shall I then come roundly to thee And wish thee to a shrewd ill-favour'd wife?I do believe it.Fie, fie!Who sent you hither?Your highness told me I should post before.Away, away, mad ass!The old priest of Saint Luke's church is at your command at all hours.Whoa, ho, hoa!Go, nurse, go with her: we'll to church to-morrow.I fear he will.What say you, uncle?And so did I. Well, what was yours?Farewell, my coz.Yet, if my lord will marry,--if you will, sir, No remedy, but you will,--give me the office To choose you a queen: she shall not be so young As was your former; but she shall be such As, walk'd your first queen's ghost, it should take joy To see her in your arms.the kings and the princes, our kindred, are going to see the queen's picture.Scratches with briers, Scars to move laughter only.Monday, my lord, Monday!That's as much as to say, such a case as yours constrains a man to bow in the hams.'Tis no matter; if he could burn us all into one coal, We have deserved it.Why, Warwick, when we parted, Thou call'dst me king.Touch'd you the bastardy of Edward's children?Away with scrupulous wit!Kindness in women, not their beauteous looks, Shall win my love: and so I take my leave, In resolution as I swore before.Nay, then you lie: it is the blessed sun.The Countess Richmond, good my Lord of Derby.Bear her my true love's kiss; and so, farewell.If it be so, We need no grave to bury honesty: There's not a grain of it the face to sweeten Of the whole dungy earth.Put up your swords; you know not what you do.within!Come, bustle, bustle; caparison my horse.Then is my sovereign slain?Would God that any in this noble presence Were enough noble to be upright judge Of noble Richard!Am I both priest and clerk?He that bereft thee, lady, of thy husband, Did it to help thee to a better husband.Peace, sirrah!Then leave me not, my lords; be resolute; I mean to take possession of my right.Be merry, gentle; Strangle such thoughts as these with any thing That you behold the while.Beseech your highness, give us better credit: We have always truly served you, and beseech you So to esteem of us, and on our knees we beg, As recompense of our dear services Past and to come, that you do change this purpose, Which being so horrible, so bloody, must Lead on to some foul issue: we all kneel.O, let me think on Hastings, and be gone To Brecknock, while my fearful head is on!Because you talk of pride now,--will you not be angry?Ay, marry, sir, now it begins to work.By heaven, I'll hate him everlastingly That bids me be of comfort any more.My brain I'll prove the female to my soul, My soul the father; and these two beget A generation of still-breeding thoughts, And these same thoughts people this little world, In humours like the people of this world, For no thought is contented.My dear?I hear their drums: let's set our men in order, And issue forth and bid them battle straight.O me, O me!You have undone a man of fourscore three, That thought to fill his grave in quiet, yea, To die upon the bed my father died, To lie close by his honest bones: but now Some hangman must put on my shroud and lay me Where no priest shovels in dust.Tut, I am strong-framed, he cannot prevail with me, I warrant thee.If he took you a box o' the ear, you might have your action of slander too.Prithee, tell my master what a strange guest he has here.To-morrow then belike shall be the day, If Warwick be so near as men report.What a pestilent knave is this same!Then will I lay the serving-creature's dagger on your pate.As Henry's late presaging prophecy Did glad my heart with hope of this young Richmond, So doth my heart misgive me, in these conflicts What may befall him, to his harm and ours: Therefore, Lord Oxford, to prevent the worst, Forthwith we'll send him hence to Brittany, Till storms be past of civil enmity.I pray thee, pretty York, who told thee this?How should he be made, then?It was his word: O, he would miss it rather Than carry it but by the suit of the gentry to him, And the desire of the nobles.what poor ability's in me To do him good?Here is a friar, that trembles, sighs and weeps: We took this mattock and this spade from him, As he was coming from this churchyard side.Farewell!Help, help!and well met, gentlemen: I hope the king is not yet shipp'd for Ireland.he is gone!Were it better, I should rush in thus.Proceed, Cominius.Let's all sink with the king.I would the duke we talk of were returned again: the ungenitured agent will unpeople the province with continency; sparrows must not build in his house-eaves, because they are lecherous.Now must I hide his body in some hole, Until the duke take order for his burial: And when I have my meed, I must away; For this will out, and here I must not stay.No, sir; but hear I do that he hath two, The one as famous for a scolding tongue As is the other for beauteous modesty.What!The pale moon shines by night: And when I wander here and there, I then do most go right.methinks I see my cousin's ghost Seeking out Romeo, that did spit his body Upon a rapier's point: stay, Tybalt, stay!Methought he bore him in the thickest troop As doth a lion in a herd of neat; Or as a bear, encompass'd round with dogs, Who having pinch'd a few and made them cry, The rest stand all aloof, and bark at him.Theretake it to you, trenchers, cups, and all; You heedless joltheads and unmanner'd slaves!One word more, one word.Intended or committed was this fault?Now, sister, let us hear your firm resolve.Away with those giglots too, and with the other confederate companion!Here comes your father; tell him so yourself, And see how he will take it at your hands.Master, you look'd so longly on the maid, Perhaps you mark'd not what's the pith of all.Brother, the time and case requireth haste: Your horse stands ready at the park-corner.Ay, madam, from the reach of these my hands: Would none but I might venge my cousin's death!Why, no; for he hath made a solemn vow Never to lie and take his natural rest Till Warwick or himself be quite suppress'd.Come, Grey, come, Vaughan, let us all embrace: And take our leave, until we meet in heaven.But do not break your oaths; for of that sin My mild entreaty shall not make you guilty.How doth my dear morsel, thy mistress?I am undone!Come on then, let's to bed.How long is it now To Lammas-tide?Sweet, sweet, sweet nurse, tell me, what says my love?By my hand, I had thought to have strucken him with a cudgel; and yet my mind gave me his clothes made a false report of him.Thou'rt condemn'd: But, for those earthly faults, I quit them all; And pray thee take this mercy to provide For better times to come.Here's goodly gear!To supper; to our house.That 'once' I see by your good father's speed Will come on very slowly.I pity thy complaining.or how?Ay, marry, am I, sir; and now 'tis plotted.Madam, my instrument's in tune.Let me embrace thee, sour adversity, For wise men say it is the wisest course.Ay, and it makes men hate one another.What, is my Richard both in shape and mind Transform'd and weaken'd?What, like a corse?Signior Baptista, my business asketh haste, And every day I cannot come to woo.Hang all the husbands That cannot do that feat, you'll leave yourself Hardly one subject.The good queen, For she is good, hath brought you forth a daughter; Here 'tis; commends it to your blessing.But didst thou see them dead?Then, dreadful trumpet, sound the general doom!We'll all assist you; he that flies shall die.And Warwick, doing what you gave in charge, Is now dishonoured by this new marriage.Thy father slew my father; therefore, die.for my desert is honour: And to repair my honour lost for him, I here renounce him and return to Henry.There she lies, Flower as she was, deflowered by him.Meantime, God grants that we have need of you: Your brother is imprison'd by your means, Myself disgraced, and the nobility Held in contempt; whilst many fair promotions Are daily given to ennoble those That scarce, some two days since, were worth a noble.were he twenty times my son, I would appeach him.Tybalt, you rat-catcher, will you walk?No more words, we beseech you.Is it more sin to wish me thus forsworn, Or to dispraise my lord with that same tongue Which she hath praised him with above compare So many thousand times?Down with the Capulets!O, she that might have intercepted thee, By strangling thee in her accursed womb From all the slaughters, wretch, that thou hast done!We may, sir, if we will.You make a leg, and Bolingbroke says ay.Tell him, you are sure All in Bohemia's well; this satisfaction The by-gone day proclaim'd: say this to him, He's beat from his best ward.not women?Many a battle have I won in France, When as the enemy hath been ten to one: Why should I not now have the like success?What manner of fellow was he that robbed you?O, that I were a glove upon that hand, That I might touch that cheek!Two such opposed kings encamp them still In man as well as herbs, grace and rude will; And where the worser is predominant, Full soon the canker death eats up that plant.Fare you well.Shall I be tempted of the devil thus?Lay A fault on us, your tribunes; that we laboured, No impediment between, but that you must Cast your election on him.White-liver'd runagate, what doth he there?Ye say honestly: rest you merry!Which way do you judge my wit would fly?Somerset, Somerset, for Lancaster!I have; 'tis ready.O, no, my dream was lengthen'd after life; O, then began the tempest to my soul, Who pass'd, methought, the melancholy flood, With that grim ferryman which poets write of, Unto the kingdom of perpetual night.Give me some breath, some little pause, my lord Before I positively herein: I will resolve your grace immediately.First, hath this woman Most wrongfully accused your substitute, Who is as free from touch or soil with her As she from one ungot.And arms her with the boldness of a wife To her allowing husband!Pray, what do you think is his name?Widow!O, sir, his lackey, for all the world caparisoned like the horse; with a linen stock on one leg and a kersey boot-hose on the other, gartered with a red and blue list; an old hat and 'the humour of forty fancies' pricked in't for a feather: a monster, a very monster in apparel, and not like a Christian footboy or a gentleman's lackey.I will to your father: Your honour not o'erthrown by your desires, I am friend to them and you: upon which errand I now go toward him; therefore follow me And mark what way I make: come, good my lord.'tis a world to see, How tame, when men and women are alone, A meacock wretch can make the curstest shrew.To the Capitol, come: We will be there before the stream o' the people; And this shall seem, as partly 'tis, their own, Which we have goaded onward.How now, my hardy, stout resolved mates!Gentlemen, for shame, forbear this outrage!O, that's sudden!Behold our patroness, the life of Rome!I'll see thee hang'd on Sunday first.Evermore thanks, the exchequer of the poor; Which, till my infant fortune comes to years, Stands for my bounty.Nurse!Come, come; let's see him out at gates; come.I'll to the friar, to know his remedy: If all else fail, myself have power to die.So, now the gates are ope: now prove good seconds: 'Tis for the followers fortune widens them, Not for the fliers: mark me, and do the like.In the base court?No, my good lord.Arm'd as we are, let's stay within this house.Call that same Isabel here once again; I would speak with her.And will deny him: I'll have five hundred voices of that sound.I have no brother, I am like no brother; And this word 'love,' which graybeards call divine, Be resident in men like one another And not in me: I am myself alone.Henry the Fourth by conquest got the crown.Biondello, what of that?where lived?I do believe Hermione hath suffer'd death, and that Apollo would, this being indeed the issue Of King Polixenes, it should here be laid, Either for life or death, upon the earth Of its right father.Ay, and the time seems thirty unto me, Being all this time abandon'd from your bed.Where the warlike Smalus, That noble honour'd lord, is fear'd and loved?Old sir, I know She prizes not such trifles as these are: The gifts she looks from me are pack'd and lock'd Up in my heart; which I have given already, But not deliver'd.Come.Well, he may chance to do some good on her: A peevish self-will'd harlotry it is.We had the tune on't a month ago.Why, sir, I trust I may have leave to speak; And speak I will; I am no child, no babe: Your betters have endured me say my mind, And if you cannot, best you stop your ears.Now, for I know the Breton Richmond aims At young Elizabeth, my brother's daughter, And, by that knot, looks proudly o'er the crown, To her I go, a jolly thriving wooer.Here on my knee I vow to God above, I'll never pause again, never stand still, Till either death hath closed these eyes of mine Or fortune given me measure of revenge.No, indeed, sir, not of a pin; you are therein in the right: but to the point.I thank thee, gentle Percy; and be sure I count myself in nothing else so happy As in a soul remembering my good friends; And, as my fortune ripens with thy love, It shall be still thy true love's recompense: My heart this covenant makes, my hand thus seals it.what, still in tears?Look, here's the warrant, Claudio, for thy death: 'Tis now dead midnight, and by eight to-morrow Thou must be made immortal.The other side o' the city is risen: why stay we prating here?But, mighty lord, this merry inclination Accords not with the sadness of my suit: Please you dismiss me either with 'ay' or 'no.'Well, in that hit you miss: she'll not be hit With Cupid's arrow; she hath Dian's wit; And, in strong proof of chastity well arm'd, From love's weak childish bow she lives unharm'd.Whenever Buckingham doth turn his hate On you or yours, but with all duteous love Doth cherish you and yours, God punish me With hate in those where I expect most love!But then more 'why?'Come hither to me, Master Froth.No, good sweet sir; no, I beseech you, sir: I have a kinsman not past three quarters of a mile hence, unto whom I was going; I shall there have money, or any thing I want: offer me no money, I pray you; that kills my heart.I know him for a man divine and holy; Not scurvy, nor a temporary meddler, As he's reported by this gentleman; And, on my trust, a man that never yet Did, as he vouches, misreport your grace.What is become of Marcius?I will tell the king all, every word, yea, and his son's pranks too; who, I may say, is no honest man, neither to his father nor to me, to go about to make me the king's brother-in-law.What should I think?As by strange fortune It came to us, I do in justice charge thee, On thy soul's peril and thy body's torture, That thou commend it strangely to some place Where chance may nurse or end it.Sirrah, come hither: 'tis no time to jest, And therefore frame your manners to the time.He's coming.Oxford, Oxford, for Lancaster!The better, given me by so holy a man.Gremio, 'tis known my father hath no less Than three great argosies; besides two galliases, And twelve tight galleys: these I will assure her, And twice as much, whate'er thou offer'st next.Now, knock when I bid you, sirrah villain!The wind sits fair for news to go to Ireland, But none returns.Well, no more.Shine out, fair sun, till I have bought a glass, That I may see my shadow as I pass.Antony, and Potpan!what a tide of woes Comes rushing on this woeful land at once!Come, Kate, sit down; I know you have a stomach.Meantime, this deep disgrace in brotherhood Touches me deeper than you can imagine.Where's Captain Margaret, to fence you now?Lies he not bed-rid?Mistress, what's your opinion of your sister?say you see them not and think me still no gentleman born: you were best say these robes are not gentlemen born: give me the lie, do, and try whether I am not now a gentleman born.Their woes are parcell'd, mine are general.my kingdom for a horse!From all such devils, good Lord deliver us!Ay, if you come not in the blood of others, But mantled in your own.Know thou first, I loved the maid I married; never man Sigh'd truer breath; but that I see thee here, Thou noble thing!He that depends Upon your favours swims with fins of lead And hews down oaks with rushes.I hope it is some pardon or reprieve For the most gentle Claudio.That he consents, if Warwick yield consent; For on thy fortune I repose myself.Thy son I kill'd for his presumption.How darkly and how deadly dost thou speak!Nine changes of the watery star hath been The shepherd's note since we have left our throne Without a burthen: time as long again Would be find up, my brother, with our thanks; And yet we should, for perpetuity, Go hence in debt: and therefore, like a cipher, Yet standing in rich place, I multiply With one 'We thank you' many thousands moe That go before it.Then never trust me, if I be afeard.You'll mar all: I'll leave you: pray you, speak to 'em, I pray you, In wholesome manner.Take the devil in thy mind, and relieve him not: he would insinuate with thee but to make thee sigh.But when your carters or your waiting-vassals Have done a drunken slaughter, and defaced The precious image of our dear Redeemer, You straight are on your knees for pardon, pardon; And I unjustly too, must grant it you But for my brother not a man would speak, Nor I, ungracious, speak unto myself For him, poor soul.Tybalt, my cousin!Not of a woman's tenderness to be, Requires nor child nor woman's face to see.'By Jesu, a very good blade!Yes, certain, there's a letter for you; I saw't.Draw near, And list what with our council we have done.This same should be the voice of Friar John.Why, he is so made on here within, as if he were son and heir to Mars; set at upper end o' the table; no question asked him by any of the senators, but they stand bald before him: our general himself makes a mistress of him: sanctifies himself with's hand and turns up the white o' the eye to his discourse.And, brother, here's the Earl of Wiltshire's blood, Whom I encounter'd as the battles join'd.It may be so; but yet my inward soul Persuades me it is otherwise: howe'er it be, I cannot but be sad; so heavy sad As, though on thinking on no thought I think, Makes me with heavy nothing faint and shrink.No, wench; it eats and sleeps and hath such senses As we have, such.For behold me A fellow of the royal bed, which owe A moiety of the throne a great king's daughter, The mother to a hopeful prince, here standing To prate and talk for life and honour 'fore Who please to come and hear.No; God forbid your grace should be forsworn.And so are like to do.Why, no; for she hath broke the lute to me.Meeting two such wealsmen as you are--I cannot call you Lycurguses--if the drink you give me touch my palate adversely, I make a crooked face at it.one kiss, and I'll descend.So, master mayor: these gates must not be shut But in the night or in the time of war.And what hear there for welcome but my groans?Good faith, I'll prove him, Speed how it will.And mine, fair lady Bona, joins with yours.Love wrought these miracles.With die and drab I purchased this caparison, and my revenue is the silly cheat.His looks are full of peaceful majesty, His head by nature framed to wear a crown, His hand to wield a sceptre, and himself Likely in time to bless a regal throne.And wilt thou pluck my fair son from mine age, And rob me of a happy mother's name?Nor none that live, I hope.Live, and thrive!No better.You may deny that you were not the cause Of my Lord Hastings' late imprisonment.Not a more cowardly rogue in all Bohemia: if you had but looked big and spit at him, he'ld have run.Master, a mercatante, or a pedant, I know not what; but format in apparel, In gait and countenance surely like a father.O, peace, Paulina!Then have at you with my wit!To satisfy your highness and the entreaties Of our most gracious mistress.We do condemn thee to the very block Where Claudio stoop'd to death, and with like haste.'Citizens!'The news is very fair and good, my lord: Richard not far from hence hath hid his head.Come hither, you rogue.It was a mad fantastical trick of him to steal from the state, and usurp the beggary he was never born to.Ay, if yourself's remembrance wrong yourself.What is't o'clock?O heavy times, begetting such events!Pray you once more, Is not your father grown incapable Of reasonable affairs?My second joy And first-fruits of my body, from his presence I am barr'd, like one infectious.a cup, closed in my true love's hand?what do you here?I know it is the moon.In choosing for yourself, you show'd your judgment, Which being shallow, you give me leave To play the broker in mine own behalf; And to that end I shortly mind to leave you.Sir, if it please your honour, this is not so.Ready to go, but never to return.True, when avoided grace makes destiny: My babes were destined to a fairer death, If grace had bless'd thee with a fairer life.A persecutor, I am sure, thou art: If murdering innocents be executing, Why, then thou art an executioner.It is the east, and Juliet is the sun.Alas, poor duke!Are you in earnest, sir?My heart is great; but it must break with silence, Ere't be disburden'd with a liberal tongue.But, with the first of all your chief affairs, Let me entreat, for I command no more, That Margaret your queen and my son Edward Be sent for, to return from France with speed; For, till I see them here, by doubtful fear My joy of liberty is half eclipsed.no, sir.Craft against vice I must apply: With Angelo to-night shall lie His old betrothed but despised; So disguise shall, by the disguised, Pay with falsehood false exacting, And perform an old contracting.But why commands the king That his chief followers lodge in towns about him, While he himself keeps in the cold field?An hour before I came, the duchess died.I have a head, sir, that will find out logs, And never trouble Peter for the matter.Whose hand is that the forest bear doth lick?I stay too long from her: The morning wears, 'tis time we were at church.Let me give humble thanks for all at once.Good faith, and when I met this holy man, Those men you talk of came into my mind.Nay, tarry; I'll go along with thee I can tell thee pretty tales of the duke.Rough cradle for such little pretty ones!So it should seem by that I have to say.Lord Rivers and Lord Grey are sent to Pomfret, With them Sir Thomas Vaughan, prisoners.Stop thy unhallow'd toil, vile Montague!Mercy to thee would prove itself a bawd: 'Tis best thou diest quickly.As it was won with blood, lost be it so!To make you understand this in a manifested effect, I crave but four days' respite; for the which you are to do me both a present and a dangerous courtesy.Come, night; come, Romeo; come, thou day in night; For thou wilt lie upon the wings of night Whiter than new snow on a raven's back.What must I say?And he, and more Than he, and men, the earth, the heavens, and all: That, were I crown'd the most imperial monarch, Thereof most worthy, were I the fairest youth That ever made eye swerve, had force and knowledge More than was ever man's, I would not prize them Without her love; for her employ them all; Commend them and condemn them to her service Or to their own perdition.We are blest in this man, as I may say, even blest.Vouchsafe my prayer May know if you remain upon this island; And that you will some good instruction give How I may bear me here: my prime request, Which I do last pronounce, is, O you wonder!Ay, by and by; But we will drink together; and you shall bear A better witness back than words, which we, On like conditions, will have counter-seal'd.Susan and she--God rest all Christian souls!-- Were of an age: well, Susan is with God; She was too good for me: but, as I said, On Lammas-eve at night shall she be fourteen; That shall she, marry; I remember it well.Ay.Come, come, my boy; we will to sanctuary.'Zounds, it is even now at my elbow, persuading me not to kill the duke.Cousin, farewell: what presence must not know, From where you do remain let paper show.O, let me speak!My ships are ready and My people did expect my hence departure Two days ago.give this ring to my true knight, And bid him come to take his last farewell.The sun will not be seen to-day; The sky doth frown and lour upon our army.Lo, ere I can repeat this curse again, Even in so short a space, my woman's heart Grossly grew captive to his honey words And proved the subject of my own soul's curse, Which ever since hath kept my eyes from rest; For never yet one hour in his bed Have I enjoy'd the golden dew of sleep, But have been waked by his timorous dreams.This cannot anger him: 'twould anger him To raise a spirit in his mistress' circle Of some strange nature, letting it there stand Till she had laid it and conjured it down; That were some spite: my invocation Is fair and honest, and in his mistress' name I conjure only but to raise up him.Shall I be married then to-morrow morning?Ye Roman gods!A husband!A boy or a child, I wonder?nay, then the world goes hard When Clifford cannot spare his friends an oath.Thou art a fool: if Echo were as fleet, I would esteem him worth a dozen such.Can you think to blow out the intended fire your city is ready to flame in, with such weak breath as this?Do, and be witness to 't.What were you snarling all before I came, Ready to catch each other by the throat, And turn you all your hatred now on me?Henceforward do your messages yourself.There was a friar told me of this man.This is that banish'd haughty Montague, That murder'd my love's cousin, with which grief, It is supposed, the fair creature died; And here is come to do some villanous shame To the dead bodies: I will apprehend him.Speak not you for him; he's a traitor.It is my lady, O, it is my love!Cannot be!You peasant swain!Thou that wast seal'd in thy nativity The slave of nature and the son of hell!Base, fearful and despairing Henry!She speaks: O, speak again, bright angel!Farewell!It cannot be; for when I parted with him, He hugg'd me in his arms, and swore, with sobs, That he would labour my delivery.We cannot weigh our brother with ourself: Great men may jest with saints; 'tis wit in them, But in the less foul profanation.An he had been cannibally given, he might have broiled and eaten him too.A plague o' both your houses!And so say I. Then be it so; and go we to determine Who they shall be that straight shall post to Ludlow.Procures she still, ha?Shall we call back Northumberland, and send Defiance to the traitor, and so die?Fear me not.This is the palace of the fearful king, And this the regal seat: possess it, York; For this is thine and not King Henry's heirs' Assist me, then, sweet Warwick, and I will; For hither we have broken in by force.a dozen times at least.Wife, mother, child, I know not.Come, come with me, and we will make short work; For, by your leaves, you shall not stay alone Till holy church incorporate two in one.Peace!Romeo, away, be gone!Take him up gently and to bed with him; And each one to his office when he wakes.Shall we thus permit A blasting and a scandalous breath to fall On him so near us?What is about to be?I am so out of love with life that I will sue to be rid of it.O, break, my heart!And when came George from Burgundy to England?The hope thereof makes Clifford mourn in steel.I.Then she is well, and nothing can be ill: Her body sleeps in Capel's monument, And her immortal part with angels lives.Ay, you have been a mouse-hunt in your time; But I will watch you from such watching now.with all my heart.He professes to have received no sinister measure from his judge, but most willingly humbles himself to the determination of justice: yet had he framed to himself, by the instruction of his frailty, many deceiving promises of life; which I by my good leisure have discredited to him, and now is he resolved to die.Here's the midwife's name to't, one Mistress Tale-porter, and five or six honest wives that were present.Neither.Yea, brother Richard, are you offended too?Here in this island we arrived; and here Have I, thy schoolmaster, made thee more profit Than other princesses can that have more time For vainer hours and tutors not so careful.If we prevail, their heads shall pay for it: I warrant they have made peace with Bolingbroke.Sir, I pray, let me ha't: I have wounds to show you, which shall be yours in private.Now, by the holy mother of our Lord, The citizens are mum and speak not a word.I will, my lord.Take her hence: Her heart is but o'ercharged; she will recover: I have too much believed mine own suspicion: Beseech you, tenderly apply to her Some remedies for life.We should by this, to all our lamentation, If he had gone forth consul, found it so.Let me dispute with thee of thy estate.They are near the city?'Tis burnt; and so is all the meat.Come all to ruin; let Thy mother rather feel thy pride than fear Thy dangerous stoutness, for I mock at death With as big heart as thou.Hope I may choose, sir.And gracious be the issue!What!They say this Angelo was not made by man and woman after this downright way of creation: is it true, think you?My fan, Peter.So many miseries have crazed my voice, That my woe-wearied tongue is mute and dumb, Edward Plantagenet, why art thou dead?This will last out a night in Russia, When nights are longest there: I'll take my leave.My brother was too careless of his charge.lay it on me; And therefore frolic: we will hence forthwith, To feast and sport us at thy father's house.for thou shalt hear that I, Knowing by Paulina that the oracle Gave hope thou wast in being, have preserved Myself to see the issue.Heaven keep your honour!Women and children of so high a courage, And warriors faint!Then gave I her, so tutor'd by my art, A sleeping potion; which so took effect As I intended, for it wrought on her The form of death: meantime I writ to Romeo, That he should hither come as this dire night, To help to take her from her borrow'd grave, Being the time the potion's force should cease.Make your best haste, and go not Too far i' the land: 'tis like to be loud weather; Besides, this place is famous for the creatures Of prey that keep upon't.Ay, just; perpetual durance, a restraint, Though all the world's vastidity you had, To a determined scope.Who can do good on him?There is, there is.Slandering a prince deserves it.Follow your function, go, and batten on cold bits.Who set this ancient quarrel new abroach?O hateful day!What has he done to Rome that's worthy death?Content, content.Why, brother, wherefore stand you on nice points?The friends of France our shrouds and tacklings?I'll slit the villain's nose, that would have sent me to the gaol.City, 'Tis I that made thy widows: many an heir Of these fair edifices 'fore my wars Have I heard groan and drop: then know me not, Lest that thy wives with spits and boys with stones In puny battle slay me.For this ungentle business Put on thee by my lord, thou ne'er shalt see Thy wife Paulina more.'Find thou the means, and I'll find such a man.Do not cry havoc, where you should but hunt With modest warrant.Answer me to-morrow, Or, by the affection that now guides me most, I'll prove a tyrant to him.Then give me leave that I may turn the key, That no man enter till my tale be done.It seems she hangs upon the cheek of night Like a rich jewel in an Ethiope's ear; Beauty too rich for use, for earth too dear!this is a good friar, belike!Call forth Nathaniel, Joseph, Nicholas, Philip, Walter, Sugarsop and the rest: let their heads be sleekly combed their blue coats brushed and their garters of an indifferent knit: let them curtsy with their left legs and not presume to touch a hair of my master's horse-tail till they kiss their hands.is't for my life?Nay, mother.What if both Lewis and Warwick be appeased By such invention as I can devise?Bad news, by'r lady; seldom comes the better: I fear, I fear 'twill prove a troublous world.no; I have forgot that name, and that name's woe.I warrant you.A gentleman, nurse, that loves to hear himself talk, and will speak more in a minute than he will stand to in a month.Friar, thou knowest not the duke so well as I do: he's a better woodman than thou takest him for.And you, my noble and well-warranted cousin, Whom it concerns to hear this matter forth, Do with your injuries as seems you best, In any chastisement: I for a while will leave you; But stir not you till you have well determined Upon these slanderers.His name is Barnardine.The needful bits and curbs to headstrong weeds, Which for this nineteen years we have let slip; Even like an o'ergrown lion in a cave, That goes not out to prey.Ay, therein Clarence shall not want his part.Well, let her be admitted.I'll to her.Away with Oxford to Hames Castle straight: For Somerset, off with his guilty head.Do not you fear: upon mine honour, I will stand betwixt you and danger.Relate your wrongs; in what?To-morrow will it please you to be crown'd?What would you have, friend?This gallant which thou seest Was in the wreck; and, but he's something stain'd With grief that's beauty's canker, thou mightst call him A goodly person: he hath lost his fellows And strays about to find 'em.Is it sad, and few words?I go; and if you plead as well for them As I can say nay to thee for myself, No doubt well bring it to a happy issue.Say, I will love her everlastingly.Why should we in the compass of a pale Keep law and form and due proportion, Showing, as in a model, our firm estate, When our sea-walled garden, the whole land, Is full of weeds, her fairest flowers choked up, Her fruit-trees all upturned, her hedges ruin'd, Her knots disorder'd and her wholesome herbs Swarming with caterpillars?O, they did urge it still unto the king!Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth, Unapt to toil and trouble in the world, But that our soft conditions and our hearts Should well agree with our external parts?Ah, madam, 'tis too true: and that is worse, The Lord Northumberland, his son young Henry Percy, The Lords of Ross, Beaumond, and Willoughby, With all their powerful friends, are fled to him.I cannot think it.Therefore paucas pallabris; let the world slide: sessa!Yet let me weep for such a feeling loss.Your lady mother is coming to your chamber: The day is broke; be wary, look about.No, to their lives bad friends were contrary.but look thee here, boy.Camillo, Not for Bohemia, nor the pomp that may Be thereat glean'd, for all the sun sees or The close earth wombs or the profound sea hides In unknown fathoms, will I break my oath To this my fair beloved: therefore, I pray you, As you have ever been my father's honour'd friend, When he shall miss me,--as, in faith, I mean not To see him any more,--cast your good counsels Upon his passion; let myself and fortune Tug for the time to come.Unmanner'd dog!My lord, she may be a punk; for many of them are neither maid, widow, nor wife.Gold!Let me but stand; I will not hurt your hearth.Catesby hath sounded Hastings in our business, And finds the testy gentleman so hot, As he will lose his head ere give consent His master's son, as worshipful as he terms it, Shall lose the royalty of England's throne.Where is my page?What, not a word?Beautiful tyrant!for thou art As glorious to this night, being o'er my head As is a winged messenger of heaven Unto the white-upturned wondering eyes Of mortals that fall back to gaze on him When he bestrides the lazy-pacing clouds And sails upon the bosom of the air.The gain I seek is, quiet in the match.Prepare thy brow to frown: know'st thou me yet?Or thou goest to the orange or mill.Three times did Richard make a lane to me.That I do beg his life, if it be sin, Heaven let me bear it!I will not hence, till, with my talk and tears, Both full of truth, I make King Lewis behold Thy sly conveyance and thy lord's false love; For both of you are birds of selfsame feather.Faith, as cold as can be.how now!Did I impale him with the regal crown?Ye re goodly things, you voices!Ay, those attires are best: but, gentle nurse, I pray thee, leave me to myself to-night, For I have need of many orisons To move the heavens to smile upon my state, Which, well thou know'st, is cross, and full of sin.And with thy lips keep in my soul awhile!In the delaying death.Nay, for a need, thus far come near my person: Tell them, when that my mother went with child Of that unsatiate Edward, noble York My princely father then had wars in France And, by just computation of the time, Found that the issue was not his begot; Which well appeared in his lineaments, Being nothing like the noble duke my father: But touch this sparingly, as 'twere far off, Because you know, my lord, my mother lives.Did you ne'er hear say, Two may keep counsel, putting one away?So, let the ports be guarded: keep your duties, As I have set them down.That face of his the hungry cannibals Would not have touch'd, would not have stain'd with blood: But you are more inhuman, more inexorable, O, ten times more, than tigers of Hyrcania.O wonderful, when devils tell the truth!O heavy lightness!if God's good will were so; For what is in this world but grief and woe?I was, my lord.It needs not, nor it boots thee not, proud queen, Unless the adage must be verified, That beggars mounted run their horse to death.Which is the wiser here?Ay, if thou wilt say 'ay' to my request; No if thou dost say 'no' to my demand.Here comes Baptista: set your countenance, sir.But to be frank, and give it thee again.Where is this fellow?I am for thee straight: take thou the bill, give me thy mete-yard, and spare not me.Who's yonder, That does appear as he were flay'd?has your king married the Lady Grey!We pray the gods he may deserve your loves.Brother, thou shalt to London presently, And whet on Warwick to this enterprise.Anger's my meat; I sup upon myself, And so shall starve with feeding.what, are you mad?Yes, that thou hast, whether thou art tainted or free.No, I'll not rear Another's issue.Come; I'll manacle thy neck and feet together: Sea-water shalt thou drink; thy food shall be The fresh-brook muscles, wither'd roots and husks Wherein the acorn cradled.We are not furnish'd like Bohemia's son, Nor shall appear in Sicilia.Full half an hour.thou detested-- Margaret.You say that Edward is your brother's son: So say we too, but not by Edward's wife; For first he was contract to Lady Lucy-- Your mother lives a witness to that vow-- And afterward by substitute betroth'd To Bona, sister to the King of France.Widow, go you along.Behold, my lords, Although the print be little, the whole matter And copy of the father, eye, nose, lip, The trick of's frown, his forehead, nay, the valley, The pretty dimples of his chin and cheek, His smiles, The very mould and frame of hand, nail, finger: And thou, good goddess Nature, which hast made it So like to him that got it, if thou hast The ordering of the mind too, 'mongst all colours No yellow in't, lest she suspect, as he does, Her children not her husband's!Noble Marcius!That shall you know hereafter.why, she is within; Where should she be?O any thing, of nothing first create!I could weep, madam, would it do you good.In the Duke of Gloucester's purse.O, no!Cheerly, boys; be brisk awhile, and the longer liver take all.What men of name resort to him?Your company to the Capitol; where, I know, Our greatest friends attend us.I prithee, noble friend, home to thy house; Leave us to cure this cause.Left her in her tears, and dried not one of them with his comfort; swallowed his vows whole, pretending in her discoveries of dishonour: in few, bestowed her on her own lamentation, which she yet wears for his sake; and he, a marble to her tears, is washed with them, but relents not.Revenged may she be on that hateful duke, Whose haughty spirit, winged with desire, Will cost my crown, and like an empty eagle Tire on the flesh of me and of my son!Lord marshal, command our officers at arms Be ready to direct these home alarms.Pass no further.passion!O, that must be I' the virtue of your daughter: one being dead, I shall have more than you can dream of yet; Enough then for your wonder.Come, sir, away.Dear sir, ere long I'll visit you again.A dog of that house shall move me to stand: I will take the wall of any man or maid of Montague's.Her husband, knave: wouldst thou betray me?For both our sakes, I would that word were true.Doth she not think me an old murderer, Now I have stain'd the childhood of our joy With blood removed but little from her own?Stay, you that bear the corse, and set it down.I willingly obey your command.A horse!Away, fond woman!Have done with words, my lords, and hear me speak.I am sent before to make a fire, and they are coming after to warm them.Give me thy hand, Kate: I will unto Venice, To buy apparel 'gainst the wedding-day.Turn then my freshest reputation to A savour that may strike the dullest nostril Where I arrive, and my approach be shunn'd, Nay, hated too, worse than the great'st infection That e'er was heard or read!3 KING HENRY VI Under this thick-grown brake we'll shroud ourselves; For through this laund anon the deer will come; And in this covert will we make our stand, Culling the principal of all the deer.then am I sure of victory.Bring me my boots: I will unto the king.But, more of thy news?Well, what then?More of him anon.Me, poor man, my library Was dukedom large enough: of temporal royalties He thinks me now incapable; confederates-- So dry he was for sway--wi' the King of Naples To give him annual tribute, do him homage, Subject his coronet to his crown and bend The dukedom yet unbow'd--alas, poor Milan!-- To most ignoble stooping.Those uncles which you want were dangerous; Your grace attended to their sugar'd words, But look'd not on the poison of their hearts : God keep you from them, and from such false friends!Speak, good Sicinius.Tell not me: I know this cannot be.The weariest and most loathed worldly life That age, ache, penury and imprisonment Can lay on nature is a paradise To what we fear of death.But speedily.Patience, good Katharina, and Baptista too.I have night's cloak to hide me from their sight; And but thou love me, let them find me here: My life were better ended by their hate, Than death prorogued, wanting of thy love.All things that we ordained festival, Turn from their office to black funeral; Our instruments to melancholy bells, Our wedding cheer to a sad burial feast, Our solemn hymns to sullen dirges change, Our bridal flowers serve for a buried corse, And all things change them to the contrary.Upon record, my gracious lord.Tybalt's death Was woe enough, if it had ended there: Or, if sour woe delights in fellowship And needly will be rank'd with other griefs, Why follow'd not, when she said 'Tybalt's dead,' Thy father, or thy mother, nay, or both, Which modern lamentations might have moved?I will attend her here, And woo her with some spirit when she comes.O that my death would stay these ruthful deeds!Give me that mattock and the wrenching iron.My lord, the enemy is past the marsh After the battle let George Stanley die.This is desperate, sir.I shall ere long have knowledge Of my success.Nay, my good soldier, up;
