My gentle Marcius, worthy Caius, and By deed-achieving honour newly named,-- What is it?--Coriolanus must I call thee?-- But O, thy wife!Why, you are nothing then: neither maid, widow, nor wife?Relent!Now we have shown our power, Let us seem humbler after it is done Than when it was a-doing.A sceptre, or an earthly sepulchre!'I pray, sir, tell me, is it possible That love should of a sudden take such hold?Fewness and truth, 'tis thus: Your brother and his lover have embraced: As those that feed grow full, as blossoming time That from the seedness the bare fallow brings To teeming foison, even so her plenteous womb Expresseth his full tilth and husbandry.Madam, yourself are not exempt in this, Nor your son Dorset, Buckingham, nor you; You have been factious one against the other, Wife, love Lord Hastings, let him kiss your hand; And what you do, do it unfeignedly.Say on, my loving lord.They are dissolved: hang 'em!An if thou couldst, thou couldst not make him live; Therefore, have done: some grief shows much of love; But much of grief shows still some want of wit.Just opposite to what thou justly seem'st, A damned saint, an honourable villain!If love be blind, love cannot hit the mark.Hadst thou groan'd for him As I have done, thou wouldst be more pitiful.Poor heart, adieu!well, I must wait, And watch withal; for, but I be deceived, Our fine musician groweth amorous.Take leave and part; for you must part forthwith.Saw you no more?Most sure, the goddess On whom these airs attend!You talk of pride: O that you could turn your eyes toward the napes of your necks, and make but an interior survey of your good selves!Once more, fare you well.Had you a special warrant for the deed?Abhorson!What if we do omit This reprobate till he were well inclined; And satisfy the deputy with the visage Of Ragozine, more like to Claudio?You have not heard of the proclamation, have you?Therein thou wrong'st thy children mightily.Thy son is banish'd upon good advice, Whereto thy tongue a party-verdict gave: Why at our justice seem'st thou then to lour?Truly, officer, because he hath some offences in him that thou wouldst discover if thou couldst, let him continue in his courses till thou knowest what they are.Sirrah Grumio, go to your mistress; Say, I command her to come to me.O earth, which this blood drink'st revenge his death!O lamentable day!No more evasion: We have with a leaven'd and prepared choice Proceeded to you; therefore take your honours.Methinks I see thee, now thou art below, As one dead in the bottom of a tomb: Either my eyesight fails, or thou look'st pale.Tread not upon him.Here standeth Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk, On pain to be found false and recreant, Both to defend himself and to approve Henry of Hereford, Lancaster, and Derby, To God, his sovereign and to him disloyal; Courageously and with a free desire Attending but the signal to begin.Say it be, 'tis true.Tush, Gremio, though it pass your patience and mine to endure her loud alarums, why, man, there be good fellows in the world, an a man could light on them, would take her with all faults, and money enough.Accursed and unquiet wrangling days, How many of you have mine eyes beheld!How have you slept, my lord?And so, with shrieks She melted into air.I humbly thank you.I'll warrant him for drowning; though the ship were no stronger than a nutshell and as leaky as an unstanched wench.I'll send to one in Mantua, Where that same banish'd runagate doth live, Shall give him such an unaccustom'd dram, That he shall soon keep Tybalt company: And then, I hope, thou wilt be satisfied.Sweet, good night!It shall be seven ere I go to horse: Look, what I speak, or do, or think to do, You are still crossing it.An old Italian fox is not so kind, my boy.Here's he that would take from you all your power.Clifford, repent in bootless penitence.doth she not count her blest, Unworthy as she is, that we have wrought So worthy a gentleman to be her bridegroom?See not your bride in these unreverent robes: Go to my chamber; Put on clothes of mine.The heavens have bless'd you with a goodly son, To be your comforter when he is gone.Conceit, more rich in matter than in words, Brags of his substance, not of ornament: They are but beggars that can count their worth; But my true love is grown to such excess I cannot sum up sum of half my wealth.What's to do here, Thomas tapster?there will be pity taken on you: you that have worn your eyes almost out in the service, you will be considered.Must die to-morrow!I have heard you say, Honour and policy, like unsever'd friends, I' the war do grow together: grant that, and tell me, In peace what each of them by the other lose, That they combine not there.We shall write to you, As time and our concernings shall importune, How it goes with us, and do look to know What doth befall you here.Foul shame upon you!Is my father well?I melt, and am not Of stronger earth than others.Tut, were it farther off, I'll pluck it down.They shall go forward, Kate, at thy command.This is most likely!Now I begin: Imprimis, we came down a foul hill, my master riding behind my mistress,-- Both of one horse?The people's enemy is gone, is gone!How say you?I long with all my heart to see the prince: I hope he is much grown since last I saw him.famine is in thy cheeks, Need and oppression starveth in thine eyes, Contempt and beggary hangs upon thy back; The world is not thy friend nor the world's law; The world affords no law to make thee rich; Then be not poor, but break it, and take this.Madam, we'll play at bowls.Trow you whither I am going?But will you woo this wild-cat?How many children hast thou, widow?This bud of love, by summer's ripening breath, May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet.Now, sir, is your name Menenius?what hope of good?Ah, Clifford, murder not this innocent child, Lest thou be hated both of God and man!In sign of truth, I kiss your highness' hand.My dear-loved cousin, and my dearer lord?'Twas not your valour, Clifford, drove me thence.What said our cousin when you parted with him?Thanks, good Montgomery; but we now forget Our title to the crown and only claim Our dukedom till God please to send the rest.You'll think it strange if I should marry her.My lord, he doth deny to come.My lord, your sorrow was too sore laid on, Which sixteen winters cannot blow away, So many summers dry; scarce any joy Did ever so long live; no sorrow But kill'd itself much sooner.or have I dream'd till now?Nothing but sit and sit, and eat and eat!Signior Baptista, shall I lead the way?I have sat too long.Why, Clarence, to myself.Ere he would have hanged a man for the getting a hundred bastards, he would have paid for the nursing a thousand: he had some feeling of the sport: he knew the service, and that instructed him to mercy.for all Thy by-gone fooleries were but spices of it.Yes, faith, and all his lords; the Duke of Milan And his brave son being twain.Where's this girl?So call it: but it does fulfil my vow; I needs must think it honesty.Vouchsafe a word, young sister, but one word.Who else?Ay, nurse; what of that?I brought the old man and his son aboard the prince: told him I heard them talk of a fardel and I know not what: but he at that time, overfond of the shepherd's daughter, so he then took her to be, who began to be much sea-sick, and himself little better, extremity of weather continuing, this mystery remained undiscovered.By this reckoning he is more shrew than she.Neither, my lord.I am fain to dine and sup with water and bran; I dare not for my head fill my belly; one fruitful meal would set me to 't.speak; Recover breath; tell us how near is danger, That we may arm us to encounter it.To fight on Edward's party for the crown; And for his meed, poor lord, he is mew'd up.Within thine eyes sat twenty thousand deaths, In thy hand clutch'd as many millions, in Thy lying tongue both numbers, I would say 'Thou liest' unto thee with a voice as free As I do pray the gods.I have bewept a worthy husband's death, And lived by looking on his images: But now two mirrors of his princely semblance Are crack'd in pieces by malignant death, And I for comfort have but one false glass, Which grieves me when I see my shame in him.Double and treble admonition, and still forfeit in the same kind!Gentlemen, can any of you tell me where I may find the young Romeo?Ay, and for an assault too.Your noble Tullus Aufidius will appear well in these wars, his great opposer, Coriolanus, being now in no request of his country.Our scouts have found the adventure very easy: That as Ulysses and stout Diomede With sleight and manhood stole to Rhesus' tents, And brought from thence the Thracian fatal steeds, So we, well cover'd with the night's black mantle, At unawares may beat down Edward's guard And seize himself; I say not, slaughter him, For I intend but only to surprise him.Who is't that goes with me?Insolent villain!So would you be again to Henry, If he were seated as King Edward is.O Clifford, but bethink thee once again, And in thy thought o'er-run my former time; And, if though canst for blushing, view this face, And bite thy tongue, that slanders him with cowardice Whose frown hath made thee faint and fly ere this!Physic for't there is none; It is a bawdy planet, that will strike Where 'tis predominant; and 'tis powerful, think it, From east, west, north and south: be it concluded, No barricado for a belly; know't; It will let in and out the enemy With bag and baggage: many thousand on's Have the disease, and feel't not.I have been i' the market-place; and, sir,'tis fit You make strong party, or defend yourself By calmness or by absence: all's in anger.A hundred thousand welcomes.Which is that Barnardine?Why, trow'st thou, Warwick, That Clarence is so harsh, so blunt, unnatural, To bend the fatal instruments of war Against his brother and his lawful king?Sir, this is the house: please it you that I call?If I were not in love with Mopsa, thou shouldst take no money of me; but being enthralled as I am, it will also be the bondage of certain ribbons and gloves.So had you need.Have you Ere now denied the asker?Well, go, prepare yourself.Or, if misfortune miss the first career, Be Mowbray's sins so heavy in his bosom, They may break his foaming courser's back, And throw the rider headlong in the lists, A caitiff recreant to my cousin Hereford!Ay, my lord; even so As it is here set down.When we grow stronger, then we'll make our claim: Till then, 'tis wisdom to conceal our meaning.Now is the winter of our discontent Made glorious summer by this sun of York; And all the clouds that lour'd upon our house In the deep bosom of the ocean buried.Why, As all comforts are; most good, most good indeed.My traffic is sheets; when the kite builds, look to lesser linen.No, madam; we have cull'd such necessaries As are behoveful for our state to-morrow: So please you, let me now be left alone, And let the nurse this night sit up with you; For, I am sure, you have your hands full all, In this so sudden business.Your grace hath still been famed for virtuous; And now may seem as wise as virtuous, By spying and avoiding fortune's malice, For few men rightly temper with the stars: Yet in this one thing let me blame your grace, For choosing me when Clarence is in place.'Tis grace indeed.Make them be strong and ready for this hint, When we shall hap to give 't them.If ever he have wife, let her he made A miserable by the death of him As I am made by my poor lord and thee!O, hear me breathe my life Before this ancient sir, who, it should seem, Hath sometime loved!for vengeance comes along with them: Nay, stay not to expostulate, make speed; Or else come after: I'll away before.A little joy enjoys the queen thereof; For I am she, and altogether joyless.I am out of breath; Confusion's near; I cannot speak.Yet ask.My lord, He wonders to what end you have assembled Such troops of citizens to speak with him, His grace not being warn'd thereof before: My lord, he fears you mean no good to him.Advance, brave Titus: They do disdain us much beyond our thoughts, Which makes me sweat with wrath.Nurse, commend me to thy lady and mistress.Pleased you to do't at peril of your soul, Were equal poise of sin and charity.Go, fellow, get thee home, provide some carts And bring away the armour that is there.The tears have got small victory by that; For it was bad enough before their spite.Now, Mars, I prithee, make us quick in work, That we with smoking swords may march from hence, To help our fielded friends!What doth she say, my Lord of Buckingham?do you?My master is grown quarrelsome.Why, this it is, when men are ruled by women: 'Tis not the king that sends you to the Tower: My Lady Grey his wife, Clarence, 'tis she That tempers him to this extremity.Two props of virtue for a Christian prince, To stay him from the fall of vanity: And, see, a book of prayer in his hand, True ornaments to know a holy man.Be patient, gentlemen; I choose her for myself: If she and I be pleased, what's that to you?Well aim'd of such a young one.The time will come when thou shalt wish for me To help thee curse that poisonous bunchback'd toad.who knows he is?Dost thou teach pardon pardon to destroy?They ne'er cared for us yet: suffer us to famish, and their store-houses crammed with grain; make edicts for usury, to support usurers; repeal daily any wholesome act established against the rich, and provide more piercing statutes daily, to chain up and restrain the poor.What says my brother?Swear, if thou darest.When will he be here?O my liege, Pardon me, if you please; if not, I, pleased Not to be pardon'd, am content withal.my kingdom for a horse!Grace go with you, Benedicite!Upon my life, my lord, I'll under-take it; And so, God give you quiet rest to-night!how found Thy father's court?His daughter is to be brought by you to the supper.Come, sirs, convey me to the block of shame; Wrong hath but wrong, and blame the due of blame.It rested in your grace To unloose this tied-up justice when you pleased: And it in you more dreadful would have seem'd Than in Lord Angelo.Was not your husband In Margaret's battle at Saint Alban's slain?Stay yet another day, thou trusty Welshman: The king reposeth all his confidence in thee.Hence!But was not this nigh shore?Let the first budger die the other's slave, And the gods doom him after!O, fie, fie, fie!show your sheep-biting face, and be hanged an hour!Away with him to death!You bid me make it orderly and well, According to the fashion and the time.Such wind as scatters young men through the world, To seek their fortunes farther than at home Where small experience grows.You know the very road into his kindness, And cannot lose your way.3 KING HENRY VI Where is the post that came from valiant Oxford?The loss of such a lord includes all harm.where be thy brothers?My dangerous cousin, let your mother in: I know she is come to pray for your foul sin.though the odds be great, I doubt not, uncle, of our victory.I prithee now, my son, Go to them, with this bonnet in thy hand; And thus far having stretch'd it--here be with them-- Thy knee bussing the stones--for in such business Action is eloquence, and the eyes of the ignorant More learned than the ears--waving thy head, Which often, thus, correcting thy stout heart, Now humble as the ripest mulberry That will not hold the handling: or say to them, Thou art their soldier, and being bred in broils Hast not the soft way which, thou dost confess, Were fit for thee to use as they to claim, In asking their good loves, but thou wilt frame Thyself, forsooth, hereafter theirs, so far As thou hast power and person.My lord, we must entreat the time alone.Joy to you, Mariana!Please you, great sir, Bohemia greets you from himself by me; Desires you to attach his son, who has-- His dignity and duty both cast off-- Fled from his father, from his hopes, and with A shepherd's daughter.Alack the day, she's dead, she's dead, she's dead!Thou know'st, great son, The end of war's uncertain, but this certain, That, if thou conquer Rome, the benefit Which thou shalt thereby reap is such a name, Whose repetition will be dogg'd with curses; Whose chronicle thus writ: 'The man was noble, But with his last attempt he wiped it out; Destroy'd his country, and his name remains To the ensuing age abhorr'd.'What if it be a poison, which the friar Subtly hath minister'd to have me dead, Lest in this marriage he should be dishonour'd, Because he married me before to Romeo?'tis better hope he is; For his designs crave haste, his haste good hope: Then wherefore dost thou hope he is not shipp'd?honour now or never!Fear not that, my lord.Then call them to our presence; face to face, And frowning brow to brow, ourselves will hear The accuser and the accused freely speak: High-stomach'd are they both, and full of ire, In rage deaf as the sea, hasty as fire.Not a dump we; 'tis no time to play now.This, as you say, suggested At some time when his soaring insolence Shall touch the people--which time shall not want, If he be put upon 't; and that's as easy As to set dogs on sheep--will be his fire To kindle their dry stubble; and their blaze Shall darken him for ever.What art thou?what news abroad?Not Isabel?You, my lords, Look on her, mark her well; be but about To say 'she is a goodly lady,' and The justice of your bearts will thereto add 'Tis pity she's not honest, honourable:' Praise her but for this her without-door form, Which on my faith deserves high speech, and straight The shrug, the hum or ha, these petty brands That calumny doth use--O, I am out-- That mercy does, for calumny will sear Virtue itself: these shrugs, these hums and ha's, When you have said 'she's goodly,' come between Ere you can say 'she's honest:' but be 't known, From him that has most cause to grieve it should be, She's an adulteress.A' shall not tread on me; I'll run away till I am bigger, but then I'll fight.Well said, master; mum!Thou liest: his father is come from Padua and here looking out at the window.The sum of all I can, I have disclosed; Why or for what these nobles were committed Is all unknown to me, my gracious lady.So play the foolish throngs with one that swoons; Come all to help him, and so stop the air By which he should revive: and even so The general, subject to a well-wish'd king, Quit their own part, and in obsequious fondness Crowd to his presence, where their untaught love Must needs appear offence.Whiles lions war and battle for their dens, Poor harmless lambs abide their enmity.Whilst I remember Her and her virtues, I cannot forget My blemishes in them, and so still think of The wrong I did myself; which was so much, That heirless it hath made my kingdom and Destroy'd the sweet'st companion that e'er man Bred his hopes out of.Her silence flouts me, and I'll be revenged.I will carry no crotchets: I'll re you, I'll fa you; do you note me?Comfort, my lord; and so I take my leave.It must and shall be so: content thyself.who's here?This cannot be but a great courtier.Would Katharina had never seen him though!You gods!Thou wast provoked by thy bloody mind.Emilia?Why, uncle, 'tis a shame.You are never without your tricks: you may, you may.Welcome home.I charge you, as you hope to have redemption By Christ's dear blood shed for our grievous sins, That you depart and lay no hands on me The deed you undertake is damnable.And thou unfit for any place but hell.O Warwick, Warwick!Am not I Christopher Sly, old Sly's son of Burtonheath, by birth a pedlar, by education a cardmaker, by transmutation a bear-herd, and now by present profession a tinker?Ah, sirrah, this unlook'd-for sport comes well.Is proclamation made, that who finds Edward Shall have a high reward, and he his life?Signior Lucio, did not you say you knew that Friar Lodowick to be a dishonest person?I have.Now, fellows, you are welcome.Why, then, I will.I am going to visit the prisoner.Where is my mother!What shall become of me?Yet you are amazed; but this shall absolutely resolve you.Pray you, who does the wolf love?If you shall chance, Camillo, to visit Bohemia, on the like occasion whereon my services are now on foot, you shall see, as I have said, great difference betwixt our Bohemia and your Sicilia.And living too; for now his son is duke.Well have you heard, but something hard of hearing: They call me Katharina that do talk of me.My lords, when you shall know--as in this rage, Provoked by him, you cannot--the great danger Which this man's life did owe you, you'll rejoice That he is thus cut off.Marry, sir, because silver hath a sweet sound.You must, sir, change persons with me, ere you make that my report: you, indeed, spoke so of him; and much more, much worse.And steep'd in blood?Beseech you, sir, be merry; you have cause, So have we all, of joy; for our escape Is much beyond our loss.Here, cousin, seize the crown; Here cousin: On this side my hand, and on that side yours.Neighbour, this is a gift very grateful, I am sure of it.But do you hear, sir?O day!ho!Because I cannot flatter and speak fair, Smile in men's faces, smooth, deceive and cog, Duck with French nods and apish courtesy, I must be held a rancorous enemy.Your worship had like to have given us one, if you had not taken yourself with the manner.was this the face That, like the sun, did make beholders wink?Well, then, farewell.The northern lords that have forsworn thy colours Will follow mine, if once they see them spread; And spread they shall be, to thy foul disgrace And utter ruin of the house of York.Yet one time he did call me by my name: I urged our old acquaintance, and the drops That we have bled together.Ay, let the county take you in your bed; He'll fright you up, i' faith.Heaven grant us its peace, but not the King of Hungary's!The queen with all the northern earls and lords Intend here to besiege you in your castle: She is hard by with twenty thousand men; And therefore fortify your hold, my lord.Well, go with me and be not so discomfited: Proceed in practise with my younger daughter; She's apt to learn and thankful for good turns.Whose tongue?Farewell, my liege.Thy brother's love, our duty, and thy fault, Provoke us hither now to slaughter thee.A goodly house: the feast smells well; but I Appear not like a guest.What scene of death hath Roscius now to act?But I know none, and therefore am no beast.honest gentleman!Marry, so I mean, sweet Katharina, in thy bed: And therefore, setting all this chat aside, Thus in plain terms: your father hath consented That you shall be my wife; your dowry 'greed on; And, Will you, nill you, I will marry you.Hours, minutes?Post you to London, and you will find it so; I speak no more than every one doth know.Wot you what, my lord?Wilt thou not hide the trespass of thine own?Since what I am to say must be but that Which contradicts my accusation and The testimony on my part no other But what comes from myself, it shall scarce boot me To say 'not guilty:' mine integrity Being counted falsehood, shall, as I express it, Be so received.I would your spirit were easier for advice, Or stronger for your need.What, dress'd!Hearest thou, Biondello?My hair doth stand on end to hear her curses.I go.My lord, this argues conscience in your grace; But the respects thereof are nice and trivial, All circumstances well considered.I am content you shall entreat me stay; But yet not stay, entreat me how you can.Jesu, what haste?Your mother.Go, you that banish'd him; A mile before his tent fall down, and knee The way into his mercy: nay, if he coy'd To hear Cominius speak, I'll keep at home.O princely Buckingham I'll kiss thy hand, In sign of league and amity with thee: Now fair befal thee and thy noble house!This Tunis, sir, was Carthage.See you the fornicatress be removed: Let have needful, but not lavish, means; There shall be order for't.Faith, there had been many great men that have flattered the people, who ne'er loved them; and there be many that they have loved, they know not wherefore: so that, if they love they know not why, they hate upon no better a ground: therefore, for Coriolanus neither to care whether they love or hate him manifests the true knowledge he has in their disposition; and out of his noble carelessness lets them plainly see't.My love, forbear to fawn upon their frowns: What danger or what sorrow can befall thee, So long as Edward is thy constant friend, And their true sovereign, whom they must obey?Come, he hath hid himself among these trees, To be consorted with the humorous night: Blind is his love and best befits the dark.There's in all two worthy voices begged.See, doth he breathe?An advocate for an imposter!Now, by the jealous queen of heaven, that kiss I carried from thee, dear; and my true lip Hath virgin'd it e'er since.Hear me, O hear me, here!So I am, to let him live.Where have I been!I care not.The castle royally is mann'd, my lord, Against thy entrance.You rogue, I have been drinking all night; I am not fitted for 't.Decline all this, and see what now thou art: For happy wife, a most distressed widow; For joyful mother, one that wails the name; For queen, a very caitiff crown'd with care; For one being sued to, one that humbly sues; For one that scorn'd at me, now scorn'd of me; For one being fear'd of all, now fearing one; For one commanding all, obey'd of none.Respect to your great place!This is my fault: as for the rest appeall'd, It issues from the rancour of a villain, A recreant and most degenerate traitor Which in myself I boldly will defend; And interchangeably hurl down my gage Upon this overweening traitor's foot, To prove myself a loyal gentleman Even in the best blood chamber'd in his bosom.Now, by Saint Peter's Church and Peter too, He shall not make me there a joyful bride.O, you hope the duke will return no more; or you imagine me too unhurtful an opposite.Thou earth, thou!What noise is this?thou art woman-tired, unroosted By thy dame Partlet here.Let him be but testimonied in his own bringings-forth, and he shall appear to the envious a scholar, a statesman and a soldier.You are plebeians, If they be senators: and they are no less, When, both your voices blended, the great'st taste Most palates theirs.Now let me see if I can construe it: 'Hic ibat Simois,' I know you not, 'hic est Sigeia tellus,' I trust you not; 'Hic steterat Priami,' take heed he hear us not, 'regia,' presume not, 'celsa senis,' despair not.Nay.For ever may my knees grow to the earth, My tongue cleave to my roof within my mouth Unless a pardon ere I rise or speak.I do not think thou canst, for then thou wast not Out three years old.But art thou not advised, he took some care To get her cunning schoolmasters to instruct her?I have some wounds upon me, and they smart To hear themselves remember'd.What is your will?'Tis since the earthquake now eleven years; And she was wean'd,--I never shall forget it,-- Of all the days of the year, upon that day: For I had then laid wormwood to my dug, Sitting in the sun under the dove-house wall; My lord and you were then at Mantua:-- Nay, I do bear a brain:--but, as I said, When it did taste the wormwood on the nipple Of my dug and felt it bitter, pretty fool, To see it tetchy and fall out with the dug!Mistress Overdone.And most chirurgeonly.Now, sir, come on: what was done to Elbow's wife, once more?Where is my Romeo?go all which way it will!Your judgments, my grave lords, Must give this cur the lie: and his own notion-- Who wears my stripes impress'd upon him; that Must bear my beating to his grave--shall join To thrust the lie unto him.I will seem friendly, as thou hast advised me.She wakes; and I entreated her come forth, And bear this work of heaven with patience: But then a noise did scare me from the tomb; And she, too desperate, would not go with me, But, as it seems, did violence on herself.Heaven and fortune bar me happy hours!and foot it, girls.strike now, or else the iron cools.It would beseem the Lord Northumberland To say 'King Richard:' alack the heavy day When such a sacred king should hide his head.Here comes a man; let's stay till he be past.If you be maid or no?what care I What curious eye doth quote deformities?Your brother cannot live.O, tell me, friar, tell me, In what vile part of this anatomy Doth my name lodge?Belike she minds to play the Amazon.I am joyful to hear of their readiness, and am the man, I think, that shall set them in present action.how fares our loving brother?this news which is called true is so like an old tale, that the verity of it is in strong suspicion: has the king found his heir?Now, by Saint George, I am too young for you.My noble uncle, do you know the cause?Untutor'd lad, thou art too malapert.Noble Aufidius, Take your commission; hie you to your bands: Let us alone to guard Corioli: If they set down before 's, for the remove Bring your army; but, I think, you'll find They've not prepared for us.fear boys with bugs.Of neither, girl: For of joy, being altogether wanting, It doth remember me the more of sorrow; Or if of grief, being altogether had, It adds more sorrow to my want of joy: For what I have I need not to repeat; And what I want it boots not to complain.My parks, my walks, my manors that I had.Sorrow and grief of heart Makes him speak fondly, like a frantic man Yet he is come.What can you vouch against him, Signior Lucio?What though the mast be now blown overboard, The cable broke, the holding-anchor lost, And half our sailors swallow'd in the flood?Though death be poor, it ends a mortal woe.Take heed you dally not before your king; Lest he that is the supreme King of kings Confound your hidden falsehood, and award Either of you to be the other's end.I will bethink me: come again tomorrow.A most unworthy and unnatural lord Can do no more.Here come the Lords of Ross and Willoughby, Bloody with spurring, fiery-red with haste.You'll leave his lecture when I am in tune?First, here's young Master Rash; he's in for a commodity of brown paper and old ginger, ninescore and seventeen pounds; of which he made five marks, ready money: marry, then ginger was not much in request, for the old women were all dead.The wager thou hast won; and I will add Unto their losses twenty thousand crowns; Another dowry to another daughter, For she is changed, as she had never been.I pray you, sir, of what disposition was the duke?But if so be Thou darest not this and that to prove more fortunes Thou'rt tired, then, in a word, I also am Longer to live most weary, and present My throat to thee and to thy ancient malice; Which not to cut would show thee but a fool, Since I have ever follow'd thee with hate, Drawn tuns of blood out of thy country's breast, And cannot live but to thy shame, unless It be to do thee service.For this, consorted with the citizens, Your very worshipful and loving friends, And by their vehement instigation, In this just suit come I to move your grace.They smile at me that shortly shall be dead.why?What, have I choked you with an argosy?Go, call my men, and let us straight to him; And bring our horses unto Long-lane end; There will we mount, and thither walk on foot Let's see; I think 'tis now some seven o'clock, And well we may come there by dinner-time.Edward, kneel down.he is a sailmaker in Bergamo.This and much more, much more than twice all this, Condemns you to the death.Who sued to me for him?Lords, use her honourably.brother, ho!It may be so, for it is not mine own.Ay, if I know the letters and the language.Sir, sir,-- Peace!well, she shall be there.Tribunes, give way; he shall to the market-place.Is the senate possessed of this?Tut, dun's the mouse, the constable's own word: If thou art dun, we'll draw thee from the mire Of this sir-reverence love, wherein thou stick'st Up to the ears.Within the guilty closure of thy walls Richard the second here was hack'd to death; And, for more slander to thy dismal seat, We give thee up our guiltless blood to drink.Why, then, let's on our way in silent sort: For Warwick and his friends, God and Saint George!O!Charges she more than me?Dost thou forget From what a torment I did free thee?For shame!Coriolanus He would not answer to: forbad all names; He was a kind of nothing, titleless, Till he had forged himself a name o' the fire Of burning Rome.'Tis death for any one in Mantua To come to Padua.Right glad I am he was not at this fray.You may go walk, and give me leave a while: My lessons make no music in three parts.A ghostly father, belike.He hath not money for these Irish wars, His burthenous taxations notwithstanding, But by the robbing of the banish'd duke.Farewell, my wife, my mother: I'll do well yet.Hath he born himself penitently in prison?It is apart That I shall blush in acting, and might well Be taken from the people.'Tis your counsel My lord should to the heavens be contrary, Oppose against their wills.Come on, sit down: come on, and do your best To fright me with your sprites; you're powerful at it.Be ruled by him.Jesu Maria, what a deal of brine Hath wash'd thy sallow cheeks for Rosaline!Who is it?why shakest thou so?Now, by the world, it is a lusty wench; I love her ten times more than e'er I did: O, how I long to have some chat with her!come, what says Romeo?He had so; looking as it were--would I were hanged, but I thought there was more in him than I could think.hark!Ay, with my sword.Unhappy Claudio!Vile earth, to earth resign; end motion here; And thou and Romeo press one heavy bier!The red plague rid you For learning me your language!God forgive my sins, and pardon thee!So with me: My birth-place hate I, and my love's upon This enemy town.The mighty dukes Gloucester and Buckingham.here's some good pastime toward: That wench is stark mad or wonderful froward.Then, Clifford, were thy heart as hard as steel, As thou hast shown it flinty by thy deeds, I come to pierce it, or to give thee mine.A blessed labour, my most sovereign liege: Amongst this princely heap, if any here, By false intelligence, or wrong surmise, Hold me a foe; If I unwittingly, or in my rage, Have aught committed that is hardly borne By any in this presence, I desire To reconcile me to his friendly peace: 'Tis death to me to be at enmity; I hate it, and desire all good men's love.far off!Sail how thou canst, have wind and tide thy friend, This hand, fast wound about thy coal-black hair Shall, whiles thy head is warm and new cut off, Write in the dust this sentence with thy blood, 'Wind-changing Warwick now can change no more.'If your lass Interpretation should abuse and call this Your lack of love or bounty, you were straited For a reply, at least if you make a care Of happy holding her.There's no man in the world More bound to 's mother; yet here he lets me prate Like one i' the stocks.And yet methinks your grace hath not done well, To give the heir and daughter of Lord Scales Unto the brother of your loving bride; She better would have fitted me or Clarence: But in your bride you bury brotherhood.Behold, the heavens do ope, The gods look down, and this unnatural scene They laugh at.What wouldst thou have with me?Ay, as the glasses where they view themselves; Which are as easy broke as they make forms.You will not own it.God save you, sir!Nay, your wit will not so soon out as another man's will;'tis strongly wedged up in a block-head, but if it were at liberty, 'twould, sure, southward.What noise there, ho?All may be well; but, if God sort it so, 'Tis more than we deserve, or I expect.Where is my wife?I'll tell you what sir, an she stand him but a little, he will throw a figure in her face and so disfigure her with it that she shall have no more eyes to see withal than a cat.Lord Stafford's father, Duke of Buckingham, Is either slain or wounded dangerously; I cleft his beaver with a downright blow: That this is true, father, behold his blood.where is my lord?Ay, sir.Why, what is Tybalt?Get you hence instantly, and tell those friends, They have chose a consul that will from them take Their liberties; make them of no more voice Than dogs that are as often beat for barking As therefore kept to do so.Not to the beast that would usurp their den.I'll not be by the while: my liege, farewell: What will ensue hereof, there's none can tell; But by bad courses may be understood That their events can never fall out good.What misadventure is so early up, That calls our person from our morning's rest?I think no less.Well, I will for refuge straight to Bristol castle: The Earl of Wiltshire is already there.Blind sight, dead life, poor mortal living ghost, Woe's scene, world's shame, grave's due by life usurp'd, Brief abstract and record of tedious days, Rest thy unrest on England's lawful earth, Unlawfully made drunk with innocents' blood!'Tis no less, I tell you, for the bawdy hand of the dial is now upon the prick of noon.It is not his, my lord; here Southam lies: The drum your honour hears marcheth from Warwick.Wilt thou provoke me?They are come.Masterly done: The very life seems warm upon her lip.Draw, Benvolio; beat down their weapons.how is it with her?do not.Has the old man e'er a son, sir, do you hear.But, madam, where is Warwick then become?Our fatherless distress was left unmoan'd; Your widow-dolour likewise be unwept!Privy to none of this.The better for him: would I were so too!There is a vice that most I do abhor, And most desire should meet the blow of justice; For which I would not plead, but that I must; For which I must not plead, but that I am At war 'twixt will and will not.How now!Give me a torch: I am not for this ambling; Being but heavy, I will bear the light.I mean, an we be in choler, we'll draw.For the dearth, The gods, not the patricians, make it, and Your knees to them, not arms, must help.And, madam, there is order ta'en for you; With all swift speed you must away to France.There lie, and there thy character: there these; Which may, if fortune please, both breed thee, pretty, And still rest thine.O nature, what hadst thou to do in hell, When thou didst bower the spirit of a fiend In moral paradise of such sweet flesh?Helen of Greece was fairer far than thou, Although thy husband may be Menelaus; And ne'er was Agamemnon's brother wrong'd By that false woman, as this king by thee.why, ay: come, tailor, let us see't.Here comes his mother.The urging of that word 'judgment' hath bred a kind of remorse in me.Would any but these boiled brains of nineteen and two-and-twenty hunt this weather?What a merit were it in death to take this poor maid from the world!My words are dull; O, quicken them with thine!O me!Who knows not he is dead!O, patience!Come, Warwick, take the time; kneel down, kneel down: Nay, when?Farewell: our countrymen are gone and fled, As well assured Richard their king is dead.I very well agree with you in the hopes of him: it is a gallant child; one that indeed physics the subject, makes old hearts fresh: they that went on crutches ere he was born desire yet their life to see him a man.Sir, my lord, I could do this, and that with no rash potion, But with a lingering dram that should not work Maliciously like poison: but I cannot Believe this crack to be in my dread mistress, So sovereignly being honourable.Stay, Edward.Make way, unruly woman!What, art so near?Farewell: thou canst not teach me to forget.So, so: farewell; we are gone.What news?We thank your honour.Black night o'ershade thy day, and death thy life!Say Warwick was our anchor; what of that?Cursed be the heart that had the heart to do it!My quaint Ariel, Hark in thine ear.You are a Roman, are you?How now, fair lords!I am sorry, sir, I have thus far stirr'd you: but I could afflict you farther.Prithee, Virgilia, turn thy solemness out o' door.So much the more our carver's excellence; Which lets go by some sixteen years and makes her As she lived now.What's in a name?He hath, my lord.Farewell at once, for once, for all, and ever.if my brother wrought by my pity, it should not be so with him.The matter; proceed.Titus Lartius writes, they fought together, but Aufidius got off.Hath she forgot already that brave prince, Edward, her lord, whom I, some three months since, Stabb'd in my angry mood at Tewksbury?How!This shall assure my constant loyalty, That if our queen and this young prince agree, I'll join mine eldest daughter and my joy To him forthwith in holy wedlock bands.I would thou wert so happy by thy stay, To hear true shrift.O God, that seest it, do not suffer it!I humbly beseech you, sir, to pardon me all the faults I have committed to your worship and to give me your good report to the prince my master.In winter's tedious nights sit by the fire With good old folks and let them tell thee tales Of woeful ages long ago betid; And ere thou bid good night, to quit their griefs, Tell thou the lamentable tale of me And send the hearers weeping to their beds: For why, the senseless brands will sympathize The heavy accent of thy moving tongue And in compassion weep the fire out; And some will mourn in ashes, some coal-black, For the deposing of a rightful king.lower, lower!down with him!Well I will arm me, being thus forewarn'd: They shall have wars and pay for their presumption.His actions show much like to madness: pray heaven his wisdom be not tainted!My child?She's come to know If yet her brother's pardon be come hither: But I will keep her ignorant of her good, To make her heavenly comforts of despair, When it is least expected.Well, I will walk myself To County Paris, to prepare him up Against to-morrow: my heart is wondrous light, Since this same wayward girl is so reclaim'd.Say there be; Yet nature is made better by no mean But nature makes that mean: so, over that art Which you say adds to nature, is an art That nature makes.Come, I have heard that fearful commenting Is leaden servitor to dull delay; Delay leads impotent and snail-paced beggary Then fiery expedition be my wing, Jove's Mercury, and herald for a king!Lay hands upon him.'Twas you that kill'd young Rutland, was it not?And what is Edward but ruthless sea?But few, And those but mean.O yes, I saw sweet beauty in her face, Such as the daughter of Agenor had, That made great Jove to humble him to her hand.Very well; and could be content to give him good report fort, but that he pays himself with being proud.What, by a horseman, or a footman?But that thy face is, vizard-like, unchanging, Made impudent with use of evil deeds, I would assay, proud queen, to make thee blush.Nay, he is dead; and slain by Edward's hand.An a' speak any thing against me, I'll take him down, an a' were lustier than he is, and twenty such Jacks; and if I cannot, I'll find those that shall.I'll give thee scope to beat, Since foes have scope to beat both thee and me.I will not fail: 'tis twenty years till then.And so did I; and, to say the truth, so did very many of us: that we did, we did for the best; and though we willingly consented to his banishment, yet it was against our will.How far hence is thy lord, mine honest fellow?Ingratitude is monstrous, and for the multitude to be ingrateful, were to make a monster of the multitude: of the which we being members, should bring ourselves to be monstrous members.Come, follow us: we'll be thy good masters.And thrice cried 'Courage, father!Sirrah, be gone, or talk not, I advise you.Is the day so young?How!boy!'And happy always was it for that son Whose father for his hoarding went to hell?Thou art like one of those fellows that when he enters the confines of a tavern claps me his sword upon the table and says 'God send me no need of thee!'is it not an easy matter To make William Lord Hastings of our mind, For the instalment of this noble duke In the seat royal of this famous isle?At a few drops of women's rheum, which are As cheap as lies, he sold the blood and labour Of our great action: therefore shall he die, And I'll renew me in his fall.Bianca, stand aside.Thou wouldst else have made thy tale large.I am peppered, I warrant, for this world.that Plantagenet, Which held three dearly as his soul's redemption, Is by the stern Lord Clifford done to death.Well get you gone: o' Thursday be it, then.And so I was; which plainly signified That I should snarl and bite and play the dog.Well, and say that Marcius Return me, as Cominius is return'd, Unheard; what then?Mistress Bianca, bless you with such grace As 'longeth to a lover's blessed case!I do perceive These poor informal women are no more But instruments of some more mightier member That sets them on: let me have way, my lord, To find this practise out.Nay, mark how Lewis stamps, as he were nettled: I hope all's for the best.Look, here comes one: a gentlewoman of mine, Who, falling in the flaws of her own youth, Hath blister'd her report: she is with child; And he that got it, sentenced; a young man More fit to do another such offence Than die for this.Why, Buckingham, I say, I would be king, Why, so you are, my thrice renowned liege.God save his majesty!Belike the elder; Clarence will have the younger.O, yes, my lord, but very idle words: For though you lay here in this goodly chamber, Yet would you say ye were beaten out of door; And rail upon the hostess of the house; And say you would present her at the leet, Because she brought stone jugs and no seal'd quarts: Sometimes you would call out for Cicely Hacket.Out, alas!Three Dukes of Somerset, threefold renown'd For hardy and undoubted champions; Two Cliffords, as the father and the son, And two Northumberlands; two braver men Ne'er spurr'd their coursers at the trumpet's sound; With them, the two brave bears, Warwick and Montague, That in their chains fetter'd the kingly lion And made the forest tremble when they roar'd.Best fitteth my degree or your condition If not to answer, you might haply think Tongue-tied ambition, not replying, yielded To bear the golden yoke of sovereignty, Which fondly you would here impose on me; If to reprove you for this suit of yours, So season'd with your faithful love to me.Baptista is safe, talking with the deceiving father of a deceitful son.But the law will not allow it, Pompey; nor it shall not be allowed in Vienna.Aumerle that was; But that is lost for being Richard's friend, And, madam, you must call him Rutland now: I am in parliament pledge for his truth And lasting fealty to the new-made king.I doubt it not, sir; but you will curse your wooing.Please you to march; And four shall quickly draw out my command, Which men are best inclined.Teach her the way.I thank your worship.quoth she; 'I'll fume with them:' And, with that word, she struck me on the head, And through the instrument my pate made way; And there I stood amazed for a while, As on a pillory, looking through the lute; While she did call me rascal fiddler And twangling Jack; with twenty such vile terms, As had she studied to misuse me so.The strangeness of your story put Heaviness in me.say't be so?Why, how are we censured?Lest you mistake the heavens are o'er our heads.My lord Sebastian, The truth you speak doth lack some gentleness And time to speak it in: you rub the sore, When you should bring the plaster.But did you not request to have it cut?I was, I must confess, Great Albion's queen in former golden days: But now mischance hath trod my title down, And with dishonour laid me on the ground; Where I must take like seat unto my fortune, And to my humble seat conform myself.Well, go thy ways, old lad; for thou shalt ha't.What's your will, father That now you are come, you will be gone.I think he is: but a greater soldier than he you wot on.Tell him, in hope he'll prove a widower shortly, I'll wear the willow garland for his sake.Now be you blest for it!I will bring these two moles, these blind ones, aboard him: if he think it fit to shore them again and that the complaint they have to the king concerns him nothing, let him call me rogue for being so far officious; for I am proof against that title and what shame else belongs to't.Twenty-three days They have been absent: 'tis good speed; foretells The great Apollo suddenly will have The truth of this appear.Poor boy, thou art amazed.was it you that would be England's king?God shall mend my soul!That by degrees we mean to look into, And watch our vantage in this business: We'll over-reach the greybeard, Gremio, The narrow-prying father, Minola, The quaint musician, amorous Licio; All for my master's sake, Lucentio.Ah, kill me with thy weapon, not with words!I cannot tell: the world is grown so bad, That wrens make prey where eagles dare not perch: Since every Jack became a gentleman There's many a gentle person made a Jack.Now, brother of Clarence, how like you our choice, That you stand pensive, as half malcontent?What sadness lengthens Romeo's hours?are they not malefactors?O, good sir, I do.Anon, anon!Sir Richard Ratcliff, let me tell thee this: To-day shalt thou behold a subject die For truth, for duty, and for loyalty.what then?Tunis was never graced before with such a paragon to their queen.Take that, and that: if all this will not do, I'll drown you in the malmsey-butt within.Whither you will, so I were from your sights.What stay had we but Clarence?Bid them come near.The language I have learn'd these forty years, My native English, now I must forego: And now my tongue's use is to me no more Than an unstringed viol or a harp, Or like a cunning instrument cased up, Or, being open, put into his hands That knows no touch to tune the harmony: Within my mouth you have engaol'd my tongue, Doubly portcullis'd with my teeth and lips; And dull unfeeling barren ignorance Is made my gaoler to attend on me.speak.Blush, Blush, thou lump of foul deformity; For 'tis thy presence that exhales this blood From cold and empty veins, where no blood dwells; Thy deed, inhuman and unnatural, Provokes this deluge most unnatural.Father Baptista, I charge you see that he be forthcoming.An honest tale speeds best being plainly told.Will it not be?Ignomy in ransom and free pardon Are of two houses: lawful mercy Is nothing kin to foul redemption.Sir, your company is fairer than honest.A brittle glory shineth in this face: As brittle as the glory is the face; For there it is, crack'd in a hundred shivers.Now, afore God--God forbid I say true!-- If you do wrongfully seize Hereford's rights, Call in the letters patent that he hath By his attorneys-general to sue His livery, and deny his offer'd homage, You pluck a thousand dangers on your head, You lose a thousand well-disposed hearts And prick my tender patience, to those thoughts Which honour and allegiance cannot think.But where is Kate?I would he had continued to his country As he began, and not unknit himself The noble knot he made.Methinks the power that Edward hath in field Should not be able to encounter mine.Gregory, o' my word, we'll not carry coals.Come, madam, let's away.O, spare me not, my brother Edward's son, For that I was his father Edward's son; That blood already, like the pelican, Hast thou tapp'd out and drunkenly caroused: My brother Gloucester, plain well-meaning soul, Whom fair befal in heaven 'mongst happy souls!So it must fall out To him or our authorities.A right fair mark, fair coz, is soonest hit.The midwife wonder'd and the women cried 'O, Jesus bless us, he is born with teeth!'None, but such remedy as, to save a head, To cleave a heart in twain.I'll tell you, Sir Lucentio: when the priest Should ask, if Katharina should be his wife, 'Ay, by gogs-wouns,' quoth he; and swore so loud, That, all-amazed, the priest let fall the book; And, as he stoop'd again to take it up, The mad-brain'd bridegroom took him such a cuff That down fell priest and book and book and priest: 'Now take them up,' quoth he, 'if any list.'Now, mistress, profit you in what you read?I, then in London keeper of the king, Muster'd my soldiers, gather'd flocks of friends, And very well appointed, as I thought, March'd toward Saint Alban's to intercept the queen, Bearing the king in my behalf along; For by my scouts I was advertised That she was coming with a full intent To dash our late decree in parliament Touching King Henry's oath and your succession.Alack, You are transported by calamity Thither where more attends you, and you slander The helms o' the state, who care for you like fathers, When you curse them as enemies.You are too senseless--obstinate, my lord, Too ceremonious and traditional Weigh it but with the grossness of this age, You break not sanctuary in seizing him.I think our fellows are asleep.The fixture of her eye has motion in't, As we are mock'd with art.Return, good Catesby, to thy lord again; Tell him, myself, the mayor and citizens, In deep designs and matters of great moment, No less importing than our general good, Are come to have some conference with his grace.Harry, how fares your uncle?If I may counsel you, some day or two Your highness shall repose you at the Tower: Then where you please, and shall be thought most fit For your best health and recreation.Why, here's he that was wont to thwack our general, Caius Marcius.'Tis a very excellent piece of work, madam lady: would 'twere done!Mark, silent king, the moral of this sport, How soon my sorrow hath destroy'd my face.I love myself.And why should we proclaim it in an hour before his entering, that if any crave redress of injustice, they should exhibit their petitions in the street?Good Norfolk, hie thee to thy charge; Use careful watch, choose trusty sentinels.Nay, go not from us thus.Rather rejoicing to see another merry, than merry at any thing which professed to make him rejoice: a gentleman of all temperance.Why force you this?Look you, sir; here comes your ghostly father: do we jest now, think you?Here, if it like your honour.Thus from my lips, by yours, my sin is purged.My mind will never grant what I perceive Your highness aims at, if I aim aright.I talk not of your soul: our compell'd sins Stand more for number than for accompt.A man, young lady!If it be so, then both depart to him; I rather wish you foes than hollow friends: But if you mind to hold your true obedience, Give me assurance with some friendly vow, That I may never have you in suspect.My lords, we were forewarned of your coming, And shut the gates for safety of ourselves; For now we owe allegiance unto Henry.I fly, Biondello: but they may chance to need thee at home; therefore leave us.Is it true, think you?Now no way can I stray; Save back to England, all the world's my way.Angelo hath seen them both, and will discover the favour.And shamed life a hateful.A very superficial, ignorant, unweighing fellow.Bootless is flight, they follow us with wings; And weak we are and cannot shun pursuit.In any proportion or in any language.Never came poison from so sweet a place.terrible hell make war Upon their spotted souls for this offence!Yes, worthy sir, The slave's report is seconded; and more, More fearful, is deliver'd.You are very sensible, and yet you miss my sense: I mean, Hortensio is afeard of you.you must go.and they are gone.Why, so hath this, both by the father and mother.AEdiles, seize him!I am glad he's come, howsoe'er he comes.No, my good lord; Nor wish'd to hold my peace.How long have you been in this place of constable?Well, let us go together.Camillo's flight, Added to their familiarity, Which was as gross as ever touch'd conjecture, That lack'd sight only, nought for approbation But only seeing, all other circumstances Made up to the deed, doth push on this proceeding: Yet, for a greater confirmation, For in an act of this importance 'twere Most piteous to be wild, I have dispatch'd in post To sacred Delphos, to Apollo's temple, Cleomenes and Dion, whom you know Of stuff'd sufficiency: now from the oracle They will bring all; whose spiritual counsel had, Shall stop or spur me.And cried 'A crown, or else a glorious tomb!How!stand thou, when I command: Advance thy halbert higher than my breast, Or, by Saint Paul, I'll strike thee to my foot, And spurn upon thee, beggar, for thy boldness.Mine honest friend, Will you take eggs for money?Northumberland comes back from Bolingbroke.On both sides more respect.Shall we hear from thee, Tyrrel, ere we sleep?That villain cousin would have kill'd my husband: Back, foolish tears, back to your native spring; Your tributary drops belong to woe, Which you, mistaking, offer up to joy.is it for a wife That thou art malcontent?Go, play, boy, play: thy mother plays, and I Play too, but so disgraced a part, whose issue Will hiss me to my grave: contempt and clamour Will be my knell.Teeth hadst thou in thy head when thou wast born, To signify thou camest to bite the world: And, if the rest be true which I have heard, Thou camest-- I'll hear no more: die, prophet in thy speech: For this amongst the rest, was I ordain'd.I will frown as I pass by, and let them take it as they list.What is't your worship's pleasure I shall do with this wicked caitiff?No, good madam; I will not out of doors.What's the news?Hold your peaces.Away with him to prison!I follow you.you whoreson malt-horse drudge!But saying o'er what I have said before: My child is yet a stranger in the world; She hath not seen the change of fourteen years, Let two more summers wither in their pride, Ere we may think her ripe to be a bride.Nay, present your hand: When she was young you woo'd her; now in age Is she become the suitor?Get you gone.Ha!I do beseech your majesty, To have some conference with your grace alone.I had rather be a pedlar: Far be it from my heart, the thought of it!Such war of white and red within her cheeks!My horse to yours, no.Nay, sit, nay, sit, good cousin Capulet; For you and I are past our dancing days: How long is't now since last yourself and I Were in a mask?Take all the swift advantage of the hours; You shall have letters from me to my son To meet you on the way, and welcome you.Where I have learn'd me to repent the sin Of disobedient opposition To you and your behests, and am enjoin'd By holy Laurence to fall prostrate here, And beg your pardon: pardon, I beseech you!Think not the king did banish thee, But thou the king.I warrant, an I should live a thousand years, I never should forget it: 'Wilt thou not, Jule?'Cousins, indeed; and by their uncle cozen'd Of comfort, kingdom, kindred, freedom, life.You have won a happy victory to Rome; But, for your son,--believe it, O, believe it, Most dangerously you have with him prevail'd, If not most mortal to him.I strike quickly, being moved.Heaven shield my mother play'd my father fair!Pedlar, let's have the first choice.As much for my poor brother as myself: That is, were I under the terms of death, The impression of keen whips I'ld wear as rubies, And strip myself to death, as to a bed That longing have been sick for, ere I'ld yield My body up to shame.Not yet, I thee beseech: For ever will I walk upon my knees, And never see day that the happy sees, Till thou give joy; until thou bid me joy, By pardoning Rutland, my transgressing boy.How!What men of name are slain on either side?strike alarum, drums!My lord, your promise for the earldom,-- Richmond!It may not be.Go to, then.Tush, that was in thy rage: Speak it again, and, even with the word, That hand, which, for thy love, did kill thy love, Shall, for thy love, kill a far truer love; To both their deaths thou shalt be accessary.Within the infant rind of this small flower Poison hath residence and medicine power: For this, being smelt, with that part cheers each part; Being tasted, slays all senses with the heart.If I be so disgracious in your sight, Let me march on, and not offend your grace.With all my heart; and much it joys me too, To see you are become so penitent.For sleeping England long time have I watch'd; Watching breeds leanness, leanness is all gaunt: The pleasure that some fathers feed upon, Is my strict fast; I mean, my children's looks; And therein fasting, hast thou made me gaunt: Gaunt am I for the grave, gaunt as a grave, Whose hollow womb inherits nought but bones.Yet looks he like a king: behold, his eye, As bright as is the eagle's, lightens forth Controlling majesty: alack, alack, for woe, That any harm should stain so fair a show!Come hither, nurse.I will be satisfied; let me see it, I say.Sweet Oxford, and my loving Montague, And all at once, once more a happy farewell.What is he, Biondello?O, how my heart abhors To hear him named, and cannot come to him.Follow me close, for I will speak to them.As she lived peerless, So her dead likeness, I do well believe, Excels whatever yet you look'd upon Or hand of man hath done; therefore I keep it Lonely, apart.But did you never swear, and break an oath?Romeo, arise; Thou wilt be taken.Hark, Perdita I'll hear you by and by.If this be magic, let it be an art Lawful as eating.speak you.O life!Why, all the souls that were were forfeit once; And He that might the vantage best have took Found out the remedy.Now shall my friend Petruchio do me grace, And offer me disguised in sober robes To old Baptista as a schoolmaster Well seen in music, to instruct Bianca; That so I may, by this device, at least Have leave and leisure to make love to her And unsuspected court her by herself.Ay, so I fear; the more is my unrest.An offer, uncle, that we will accept: But we must win your grace to go with us To Bristol castle, which they say is held By Bushy, Bagot and their complices, The caterpillars of the commonwealth, Which I have sworn to weed and pluck away.I warrant him, Petruchio is Kated.Hath that poor monarch taught thee to insult?Farewell, old Gaunt: thy sometimes brother's wife With her companion grief must end her life.When the devout religion of mine eye Maintains such falsehood, then turn tears to fires; And these, who often drown'd could never die, Transparent heretics, be burnt for liars!Therefore, go back.I took this for silver.But, Warwick, after God, thou set'st me free, And chiefly therefore I thank God and thee; He was the author, thou the instrument.If it prove She's otherwise, I'll keep my stables where I lodge my wife; I'll go in couples with her; Than when I feel and see her no farther trust her; For every inch of woman in the world, Ay, every dram of woman's flesh is false, If she be.I would not lose the dog for twenty pound.Nay, let me have't; I long.Now, if you love me, stay.Have you forgot the Duke of Hereford, boy?My lord.I have great comfort from this fellow: methinks he hath no drowning mark upon him; his complexion is perfect gallows.Thy husband is thy lord, thy life, thy keeper, Thy head, thy sovereign; one that cares for thee, And for thy maintenance commits his body To painful labour both by sea and land, To watch the night in storms, the day in cold, Whilst thou liest warm at home, secure and safe; And craves no other tribute at thy hands But love, fair looks and true obedience; Too little payment for so great a debt.My lord, my answer is--to Lancaster; And I am come to seek that name in England; And I must find that title in your tongue, Before I make reply to aught you say.You are sent for to the senate: A fearful army, led by Caius Marcius Associated with Aufidius, rages Upon our territories; and have already O'erborne their way, consumed with fire, and took What lay before them.Who intercepts my expedition?This your sheep-shearing Is as a meeting of the petty gods, And you the queen on't.To a cruel war I sent him; from whence he returned, his brows bound with oak.Angelo, There is a kind of character in thy life, That to the observer doth thy history Fully unfold.Shall thy old dugs once more a traitor rear?O despiteful love!Ay, but to die, and go we know not where; To lie in cold obstruction and to rot; This sensible warm motion to become A kneaded clod; and the delighted spirit To bathe in fiery floods, or to reside In thrilling region of thick-ribbed ice; To be imprison'd in the viewless winds, And blown with restless violence round about The pendent world; or to be worse than worst Of those that lawless and incertain thought Imagine howling: 'tis too horrible!Hail, royal prince!he was not born to shame: Upon his brow shame is ashamed to sit; For 'tis a throne where honour may be crown'd Sole monarch of the universal earth.If that thy valour stand on sympathy, There is my gage, Aumerle, in gage to thine: By that fair sun which shows me where thou stand'st, I heard thee say, and vauntingly thou spakest it That thou wert cause of noble Gloucester's death.O, God ye god-den.The early village-cock Hath twice done salutation to the morn; Your friends are up, and buckle on their armour.What wisdom stirs amongst you?'True, noble prince!'I anger her sometimes and tell her that Paris is the properer man; but, I'll warrant you, when I say so, she looks as pale as any clout in the versal world.Who's there?On's brows: Menenius, he comes the third time home with the oaken garland.And for that offence Immediately we do exile him hence: I have an interest in your hate's proceeding, My blood for your rude brawls doth lie a-bleeding; But I'll amerce you with so strong a fine That you shall all repent the loss of mine: I will be deaf to pleading and excuses; Nor tears nor prayers shall purchase out abuses: Therefore use none: let Romeo hence in haste, Else, when he's found, that hour is his last.I am ready now.That she's the chosen of Signior Hortensio.Shame to him whose cruel striking Kills for faults of his own liking!How know you that?Suppose that I am now my father's mouth; Resign thy chair, and where I stand kneel thou, Whilst I propose the selfsame words to thee, Which traitor, thou wouldst have me answer to.Thy sun sets weeping in the lowly west, Witnessing storms to come, woe and unrest: Thy friends are fled to wait upon thy foes, And crossly to thy good all fortune goes.Why, master mayor, why stand you in a doubt?Thoughts tending to content flatter themselves That they are not the first of fortune's slaves, Nor shall not be the last; like silly beggars Who sitting in the stocks refuge their shame, That many have and others must sit there; And in this thought they find a kind of ease, Bearing their own misfortunes on the back Of such as have before endured the like.Who is't can blame him?know'st thou not That when the searching eye of heaven is hid, Behind the globe, that lights the lower world, Then thieves and robbers range abroad unseen In murders and in outrage, boldly here; But when from under this terrestrial ball He fires the proud tops of the eastern pines And darts his light through every guilty hole, Then murders, treasons and detested sins, The cloak of night being pluck'd from off their backs, Stand bare and naked, trembling at themselves?Yea, is the worst well?Come, come, in wooing sorrow let's be brief, Since, wedding it, there is such length in grief; One kiss shall stop our mouths, and dumbly part; Thus give I mine, and thus take I thy heart.Thou art not certain; For thy complexion shifts to strange effects, After the moon.And as for you yourself, our quondam queen, You have a father able to maintain you; And better 'twere you troubled him than France.Let AEsop fable in a winter's night; His currish riddles sort not with this place.If I could find example Of thousands that had struck anointed kings And flourish'd after, I'ld not do't; but since Nor brass nor stone nor parchment bears not one, Let villany itself forswear't.So 'tis said, sir; about his son, that should have married a shepherd's daughter.It is a bitter deputy.Yea, look'st thou pale?We'll show thee Io as she was a maid, And how she was beguiled and surprised, As lively painted as the deed was done.will they wear their plackets where they should bear their faces?Alas, why would you heap these cares on me?Henry now lives in Scotland at his ease, Where having nothing, nothing can he lose.Why, madam, so, no doubt, he is.Why, thou say'st true; it is a paltry cap, A custard-coffin, a bauble, a silken pie: I love thee well, in that thou likest it not.And, live we how we can, yet die we must.As any in Vienna, on my word.God knows when we shall meet again.And why not queen?You are to know That prosperously I have attempted and With bloody passage led your wars even to The gates of Rome.Shall I be heard?How will my wife for slaughter of my son Shed seas of tears and ne'er be satisfied!'Tis not to save labour, nor that I want love.Weeping and wailing over Tybalt's corse: Will you go to them?An't please your honour, players That offer service to your lordship.Do not repent these things, for they are heavier Than all thy woes can stir; therefore betake thee To nothing but despair.I'll follow thee a month, devise with thee Where thou shalt rest, that thou mayst hear of us And we of thee: so if the time thrust forth A cause for thy repeal, we shall not send O'er the vast world to seek a single man, And lose advantage, which doth ever cool I' the absence of the needer.You will not, then?what's the matter?The fruits of love I mean, my loving liege.Ha, ha!I will, and know her mind early to-morrow; To-night she is mew'd up to her heaviness.God save thee, noble consul!Sir, make me not your story.Was ever woman in this humour woo'd?Fare you well, good father.Mistrust it not: for, sure, AEacides Was Ajax, call'd so from his grandfather.Ah ha, my mistresses!no duty?The tartness of his face sours ripe grapes: when he walks, he moves like an engine, and the ground shrinks before his treading: he is able to pierce a corslet with his eye; talks like a knell, and his hum is a battery.I am a subject, And I challenge law: attorneys are denied me; And therefore, personally I lay my claim To my inheritance of free descent.Our old and faithful friend, we are glad to see you.Grumio, my horse.Be absolute for death; either death or life Shall thereby be the sweeter.Are you so brave?I swear-- By nothing; for this is no oath: The George, profaned, hath lost his holy honour; The garter, blemish'd, pawn'd his knightly virtue; The crown, usurp'd, disgraced his kingly glory.Thou canst not, son; it is impossible.by my brotherhood, The letter was not nice but full of charge Of dear import, and the neglecting it May do much danger.Very well mended.Pompey, you are partly a bawd, Pompey, howsoever you colour it in being a tapster, are you not?I know thou wilt say 'Ay,' And I will take thy word: yet if thou swear'st, Thou mayst prove false; at lovers' perjuries Then say, Jove laughs.And topping all others in boasting.Is it your will Claudio shall die tomorrow?Nay, I will win my wager better yet And show more sign of her obedience, Her new-built virtue and obedience.By a name I know not how to tell thee who I am: My name, dear saint, is hateful to myself, Because it is an enemy to thee; Had I it written, I would tear the word.O monstrous, monstrous!Follow me.But no more of this.You do him wrong, surely.My lord of Ely!Beguiled, divorced, wronged, spited, slain!We at time of year Do wound the bark, the skin of our fruit-trees, Lest, being over-proud in sap and blood, With too much riches it confound itself: Had he done so to great and growing men, They might have lived to bear and he to taste Their fruits of duty: superfluous branches We lop away, that bearing boughs may live: Had he done so, himself had borne the crown, Which waste of idle hours hath quite thrown down.What, do you grumble?For God's sake, take away this captive scold.Mean time let this defend my loyalty, By all my hopes, most falsely doth he lie.No, holy father; throw away that thought; Believe not that the dribbling dart of love Can pierce a complete bosom.Thou hadst but power over his mortal body, His soul thou canst not have; therefore be gone.Of all thy suitors, here I charge thee, tell Whom thou lovest best: see thou dissemble not.To tell, he longs to see his son, were strong: But let him say so then, and let him go; But let him swear so, and he shall not stay, We'll thwack him hence with distaffs.I would to God my heart were flint, like Edward's; Or Edward's soft and pitiful, like mine I am too childish-foolish for this world.Besides, our nearness to the king in love Is near the hate of those love not the king.whither away?But hear you.If any such be here-- As it were sin to doubt--that love this painting Wherein you see me smear'd; if any fear Lesser his person than an ill report; If any think brave death outweighs bad life And that his country's dearer than himself; Let him alone, or so many so minded, Wave thus, to express his disposition, And follow Marcius.In her consists my happiness and thine; Without her, follows to this land and me, To thee, herself, and many a Christian soul, Death, desolation, ruin and decay: It cannot be avoided but by this; It will not be avoided but by this.Like an unseasonable stormy day, Which makes the silver rivers drown their shores, As if the world were all dissolved to tears, So high above his limits swells the rage Of Bolingbroke, covering your fearful land With hard bright steel and hearts harder than steel.O my sweet lady, pardon.I will make much of your voices, and so trouble you no further.Amen.My mother, you wot well My hazards still have been your solace: and Believe't not lightly--though I go alone, Like to a lonely dragon, that his fen Makes fear'd and talk'd of more than seen--your son Will or exceed the common or be caught With cautelous baits and practise.Dost thou love hawking?Harry of Hereford, Lancaster and Derby, Stands here for God, his sovereign and himself, On pain to be found false and recreant, To prove the Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Mowbray, A traitor to his God, his king and him; And dares him to set forward to the fight.O think'st thou we shall ever meet again?'Coriolanus!'Believe me, sir, It carries a brave form.call him hither.I'll throw thy body in another room And triumph, Henry, in thy day of doom.Do't!Or that I could forget what I have been, Or not remember what I must be now!And, Henry, hadst thou sway'd as kings should do, Or as thy father and his father did, Giving no ground unto the house of York, They never then had sprung like summer flies; I and ten thousand in this luckless realm Had left no mourning widows for our death; And thou this day hadst kept thy chair in peace.Was it not so?Evermore cross'd and cross'd; nothing but cross'd!he's dead, he's dead, he's dead!How art thou out of breath, when thou hast breath To say to me that thou art out of breath?Away betimes, before his forces join, And take the great-grown traitor unawares: Brave warriors, march amain towards Coventry.guilty!No, no: but all this did I know before.Kiss him for that, good widow.God forbid!Therefore, beseech you,-- You that will be less fearful than discreet, That love the fundamental part of state More than you doubt the change on't, that prefer A noble life before a long, and wish To jump a body with a dangerous physic That's sure of death without it, at once pluck out The multitudinous tongue; let them not lick The sweet which is their poison: your dishonour Mangles true judgment and bereaves the state Of that integrity which should become't, Not having the power to do the good it would, For the in which doth control't.True, noble prince.And Somerset another goodly mast?In God's name what are you, and how came you hither?No, by my troth, I did not mean such love.No, my good lord; it was by private message.Farewell, kind neighbours: we wish'd Coriolanus Had loved you as we did.You are a pair of strange ones.Signior Hortensio, 'twixt such friends as we Few words suffice; and therefore, if thou know One rich enough to be Petruchio's wife, As wealth is burden of my wooing dance, Be she as foul as was Florentius' love, As old as Sibyl and as curst and shrewd As Socrates' Xanthippe, or a worse, She moves me not, or not removes, at least, Affection's edge in me, were she as rough As are the swelling Adriatic seas: I come to wive it wealthily in Padua; If wealthily, then happily in Padua.Gladly, my lord.I'll tell him yet of Angelo's request, And fit his mind to death, for his soul's rest.art thou king, and wilt be forced?You know neither me, yourselves nor any thing.That our garments, being, as they were, drenched in the sea, hold notwithstanding their freshness and glosses, being rather new-dyed than stained with salt water.Now will I write letters to Angelo,-- The provost, he shall bear them, whose contents Shall witness to him I am near at home, And that, by great injunctions, I am bound To enter publicly: him I'll desire To meet me at the consecrated fount A league below the city; and from thence, By cold gradation and well-balanced form, We shall proceed with Angelo.No man but prophesied revenge for it.Ay, but thou usest to forswear thyself: 'Twas sin before, but now 'tis charity.God hold it, to your honour's good content!Thy father bears the type of King of Naples, Of both the Sicils and Jerusalem, Yet not so wealthy as an English yeoman.how but well?Sir, sir, the first's for me; let her go by.He is a kinsman to the Montague; Affection makes him false; he speaks not true: Some twenty of them fought in this black strife, And all those twenty could but kill one life.You forget That we are those which chased you from the field And slew your fathers, and with colours spread March'd through the city to the palace gates.Good ladies, let's go.To every article.I like it well that our fair queen and mistress Smiles at her news, while Warwick frowns at his.is he not thine own?Obedience bids I should not bid again.his train?Alas, the part I had in Woodstock's blood Doth more solicit me than your exclaims, To stir against the butchers of his life!For being a bawd, for being a bawd.I was by at the opening of the fardel, heard the old shepherd deliver the manner how he found it: whereupon, after a little amazedness, we were all commanded out of the chamber; only this methought I heard the shepherd say, he found the child.If that shepherd be not in hand-fast, let him fly: the curses he shall have, the tortures he shall feel, will break the back of man, the heart of monster.O bloody times!Peace, thou!Nay, gentle Romeo, we must have you dance.Madam, if you could find out but a man To bear a poison, I would temper it; That Romeo should, upon receipt thereof, Soon sleep in quiet.They say there's grain enough!Most dear'st!Stay, then; I'll go alone.Troth, and your bum is the greatest thing about you; so that in the beastliest sense you are Pompey the Great.But how prevail'd you?Why, she hath a face of her own.Ha!Talk not of France, sith thou hast lost it all.How will the country for these woful chances Misthink the king and not be satisfied!Sir William Brandon, you shall bear my standard.Away!For this world frowns, and Edward's sun is clouded.use means for her recovery.His princess, say you, with him?And but one word with one of us?Now my soul's palace is become a prison: Ah, would she break from hence, that this my body Might in the ground be closed up in rest!A wisp of straw were worth a thousand crowns, To make this shameless callet know herself.Draw near, ye people.Not I, my lord.Nay, then thou lovest it not; And all my pains is sorted to no proof.Why, my young cousin, it is good to grow.Where's the cook?What should it be, that they so shriek abroad?O, had thy grandsire with a prophet's eye Seen how his son's son should destroy his sons, From forth thy reach he would have laid thy shame, Deposing thee before thou wert possess'd, Which art possess'd now to depose thyself.I promise you, I scarcely know myself: Hear you the news abroad?In God's name, what art thou?Worth six on him.Sir, you have done enough, and have perform'd A saint-like sorrow: no fault could you make, Which you have not redeem'd; indeed, paid down More penitence than done trespass: at the last, Do as the heavens have done, forget your evil; With them forgive yourself.Thou hast most kindly hit it.Tybalt, here slain, whom Romeo's hand did slay;
