Romeo that spoke him fair, bade him bethink How nice the quarrel was, and urged withal Your high displeasure: all this uttered With gentle breath, calm look, knees humbly bow'd, Could not take truce with the unruly spleen Of Tybalt deaf to peace, but that he tilts With piercing steel at bold Mercutio's breast, Who all as hot, turns deadly point to point, And, with a martial scorn, with one hand beats Cold death aside, and with the other sends It back to Tybalt, whose dexterity, Retorts it: Romeo he cries aloud, 'Hold, friends!Now, by mine honour, by my life, by my troth, I will appeach the villain.And daily new exactions are devised, As blanks, benevolences, and I wot not what: But what, o' God's name, doth become of this?I do but keep the peace: put up thy sword, Or manage it to part these men with me.I pray thee, moralize them.Then thou dwellest with daws too?Yet, to have join'd with France in such alliance Would more have strengthen'd this our commonwealth 'Gainst foreign storms than any home-bred marriage.If on the first, how heinous e'er it be, To win thy after-love I pardon thee.the task he undertakes Is numbering sands and drinking oceans dry: Where one on his side fights, thousands will fly.To speak so indirectly I am loath: I would say the truth; but to accuse him so, That is your part: yet I am advised to do it; He says, to veil full purpose.Good Camillo, Your changed complexions are to me a mirror Which shows me mine changed too; for I must be A party in this alteration, finding Myself thus alter'd with 't.You have of these pedlars, that have more in them than you'ld think, sister.Ah, my sour husband, my hard-hearted lord, That set'st the word itself against the word!Be not so hot; the duke Dare no more stretch this finger of mine than he Dare rack his own: his subject am I not, Nor here provincial.Glad am I that your highness is so arm'd To bear the tidings of calamity.Dishonourable boy!It shall be so; he shall to Brittany.We were, fair queen, Two lads that thought there was no more behind But such a day to-morrow as to-day, And to be boy eternal.O, then, I see, you will part but with light gifts; In weightier things you'll say a beggar nay.Ay, that's the first thing that we have to do; To free King Henry from imprisonment And see him seated in the regal throne.Are they returned to the court?Right gracious lord, I cannot brook delay: May it please your highness to resolve me now; And what your pleasure is, shall satisfy me.Woe the while!Help, help, help!It is not my consent, But my entreaty too.But, ere I go, Hastings and Montague, Resolve my doubt.But come, young waverer, come, go with me, In one respect I'll thy assistant be; For this alliance may so happy prove, To turn your households' rancour to pure love.O, were it but my life, I'ld throw it down for your deliverance As frankly as a pin.I have purchased as many diseases under her roof as come to-- To what, I pray?Sir, I think You have heard of my poor services, i' the love That I have borne your father?I love no chiders, sir.Speak like a subject, proud ambitious York!here come my executioners.Thou art no Atlas for so great a weight: And weakling, Warwick takes his gift again; And Henry is my king, Warwick his subject.Ha!Speak sweetly, man, although thy looks be sour.Amen.This double worship, Where one part does disdain with cause, the other Insult without all reason, where gentry, title, wisdom, Cannot conclude but by the yea and no Of general ignorance,--it must omit Real necessities, and give way the while To unstable slightness: purpose so barr'd, it follows, Nothing is done to purpose.Edward, what satisfaction canst thou make For bearing arms, for stirring up my subjects, And all the trouble thou hast turn'd me to?Fie, daughter!How now, Grumio!Then, good my lord, take to your royal self This proffer'd benefit of dignity; If non to bless us and the land withal, Yet to draw forth your noble ancestry From the corruption of abusing times, Unto a lineal true-derived course.Three parts of that receipt I had for Calais Disbursed I duly to his highness' soldiers; The other part reserved I by consent, For that my sovereign liege was in my debt Upon remainder of a dear account, Since last I went to France to fetch his queen: Now swallow down that lie.More than I seem, and less than I was born to: A man at least, for less I should not be; And men may talk of kings, and why not I?Pardon me, lords, 'tis the first time that ever I was forced to scold.What's the matter, That in these several places of the city You cry against the noble senate, who, Under the gods, keep you in awe, which else Would feed on one another?Why, sir, you know this is your wedding-day: First were we sad, fearing you would not come; Now sadder, that you come so unprovided.Their love is not so great, Hortensio, but we may blow our nails together, and fast it fairly out: our cakes dough on both sides.Think you my uncle did dissemble, grandam?Bushy and Green, I will not vex your souls-- Since presently your souls must part your bodies-- With too much urging your pernicious lives, For 'twere no charity; yet, to wash your blood From off my hands, here in the view of men I will unfold some causes of your deaths.Such pity as my rapier's point affords.My lord?To press before thy father to a grave?E'en at hand, alighted by this; and therefore be not--Cock's passion, silence!Ay, sir; so his mother says, if I may believe her.The advancement of your children, gentle lady.Bum, sir.Proceed.Say, Henry, shall I have my right, or no?Who should that be?There hath been in Rome strange insurrections; the people against the senators, patricians, and nobles.What is the news from this good deputy?Grace to boot!Barkloughly castle call they this at hand?Must these have voices, that can yield them now And straight disclaim their tongues?Bolder, though not so subtle.Grandam, we can; for my good uncle Gloucester Told me, the king, provoked by the queen, Devised impeachments to imprison him : And when my uncle told me so, he wept, And hugg'd me in his arm, and kindly kiss'd my cheek; Bade me rely on him as on my father, And he would love me dearly as his child.myself myself confound!Your will be done: this must my comfort be, Sun that warms you here shall shine on me; And those his golden beams to you here lent Shall point on me and gild my banishment.wherefore art thou Romeo?Lucentio is your name; of whence, I pray?But, lords, we hear this fearful tempest sing, Yet see no shelter to avoid the storm; We see the wind sit sore upon our sails, And yet we strike not, but securely perish.Can you, when you have pushed out your gates the very defender of them, and, in a violent popular ignorance, given your enemy your shield, think to front his revenges with the easy groans of old women, the virginal palms of your daughters, or with the palsied intercession of such a decayed dotant as you seem to be?Where are the vile beginners of this fray?The contents of this is the return of the duke: you shall anon over-read it at your pleasure; where you shall find, within these two days he will be here.No, my lord.Katharina the curst!A fellow, sir, that I have known to go about with troll-my-dames; I knew him once a servant of the prince: I cannot tell, good sir, for which of his virtues it was, but he was certainly whipped out of the court.'Tis well thou art not fish; if thou hadst, thou hadst been poor John.We have record that very well it can, And three examples of the like have been Within my age.'Tis hatch'd and shall be so: Tranio, at once Uncase thee; take my colour'd hat and cloak: When Biondello comes, he waits on thee; But I will charm him first to keep his tongue.Come, come, dispatch; 'tis bootless to exclaim.Tongue-tied, our queen?Impute it not a crime To me or my swift passage, that I slide O'er sixteen years and leave the growth untried Of that wide gap, since it is in my power To o'erthrow law and in one self-born hour To plant and o'erwhelm custom.He was in the right; and so indeed it is.should--buzz!Ay, gracious sovereign; they are so link'd in friendship That young Prince Edward marries Warwick's daughter.But what said Warwick to these injuries?Ay, thou wast born to be a plague to men.You say well.Hush, master!Come, sir, I know what I know.Well; the matter?Answer no more, for thou shalt be my queen.O coward conscience, how dost thou afflict me!Three civil brawls, bred of an airy word, By thee, old Capulet, and Montague, Have thrice disturb'd the quiet of our streets, And made Verona's ancient citizens Cast by their grave beseeming ornaments, To wield old partisans, in hands as old, Canker'd with peace, to part your canker'd hate: If ever you disturb our streets again, Your lives shall pay the forfeit of the peace.He shall be endured: What, goodman boy!resolved.No: the princess hearing of her mother's statue, which is in the keeping of Paulina,--a piece many years in doing and now newly performed by that rare Italian master, Julio Romano, who, had he himself eternity and could put breath into his work, would beguile Nature of her custom, so perfectly he is her ape: he so near to Hermione hath done Hermione that they say one would speak to her and stand in hope of answer: thither with all greediness of affection are they gone, and there they intend to sup.I cannot joy, until I be resolved Where our right valiant father is become.he scrape a trencher!Well; what benefactors are they?Who call'd here of late?Marry, God forbid his grace should say us nay!Then show it me.and, lips, O you The doors of breath, seal with a righteous kiss A dateless bargain to engrossing death!Grumio, mum!I'll bear thee hence, where I may weep my fill.Then patiently hear my impatience.I was; but I do find more pain in banishment Than death can yield me here by my abode.Go together, You precious winners all; your exultation Partake to every one.A fortnight and odd days.Where is the foolish knave I sent before?Brave warriors, Clifford and Northumberland, Come, make him stand upon this molehill here, That raught at mountains with outstretched arms, Yet parted but the shadow with his hand.Hast thou met with him?Ten days ago I drown'd these news in tears; And now, to add more measure to your woes, I come to tell you things sith then befall'n.For he fears none.He jests at scars that never felt a wound.Go thou away: I'll follow instantly.This is that very Mab That plats the manes of horses in the night, And bakes the elflocks in foul sluttish hairs, Which once untangled, much misfortune bodes: This is the hag, when maids lie on their backs, That presses them and learns them first to bear, Making them women of good carriage: This is she-- Peace, peace, Mercutio, peace!O immortal gods!My lord, you do me shameful injury, Falsely to draw me in these vile suspects.Lay her a-hold, a-hold!Love goes toward love, as schoolboys from their books, But love from love, toward school with heavy looks.O, I will to him and pluck out his eyes!Thou!Peace, Grumio!They say she's mad.Why, love forswore me in my mother's womb: And, for I should not deal in her soft laws, She did corrupt frail nature with some bribe, To shrink mine arm up like a wither'd shrub; To make an envious mountain on my back, Where sits deformity to mock my body; To shape my legs of an unequal size; To disproportion me in every part, Like to a chaos, or an unlick'd bear-whelp That carries no impression like the dam.Sirrah, fetch drier logs: Call Peter, he will show thee where they are.Say that the king, which may command, entreats.Bianca, get thee in.help, Signior Baptista!Why, that's all one.An old sheep-whistling rogue a ram-tender, to offer to have his daughter come into grace!He tells her something That makes her blood look out: good sooth, she is The queen of curds and cream.Come, come.Mine, such as fill my heart with unhoped joys.I gave him no order; I gave him the stuff.Tullus Aufidius then had made new head?Yea, my good lord.Where be the thronging troops that follow'd thee?There are pretty orders beginning, I can tell you: it is but heading and hanging.Sirrah, what made your master in this place?And, by despairing, shouldst thou stand excused; For doing worthy vengeance on thyself, Which didst unworthy slaughter upon others.Of this allow, If ever you have spent time worse ere now; If never, yet that Time himself doth say He wishes earnestly you never may.why, no question but he was.Is this the alliance that he seeks with France?If that thy bent of love be honourable, Thy purpose marriage, send me word to-morrow, By one that I'll procure to come to thee, Where and what time thou wilt perform the rite; And all my fortunes at thy foot I'll lay And follow thee my lord throughout the world.Hold thy desperate hand: Art thou a man?for I were loath To link with him that were not lawful chosen.Wilt thou be made a man out of my vice?Please it your honours To call me to your senate, I'll deliver Myself your loyal servant, or endure Your heaviest censure.I would they would forget me, like the virtues Which our divines lose by 'em.You shall.I will not do't.I am their mother; who should keep me from them?Little are we beholding to your love, And little look'd for at your helping hands.Vouchsafe, divine perfection of a woman, Of these supposed-evils, to give me leave, By circumstance, but to acquit myself.Ha!Mercutio, thou consort'st with Romeo,-- Consort!Sir, you may thank yourself for this great loss, That would not bless our Europe with your daughter, But rather lose her to an African; Where she at least is banish'd from your eye, Who hath cause to wet the grief on't.Father, 'tis thus: yourself and all the world, That talk'd of her, have talk'd amiss of her: If she be curst, it is for policy, For she's not froward, but modest as the dove; She is not hot, but temperate as the morn; For patience she will prove a second Grissel, And Roman Lucrece for her chastity: And to conclude, we have 'greed so well together, That upon Sunday is the wedding-day.I never did thee harm: why wilt thou slay me?sometimes to see 'em, and not to see 'em; now the ship boring the moon with her main-mast, and anon swallowed with yest and froth, as you'ld thrust a cork into a hogshead.O my dear lord, I crave no other, nor no better man.So shall you feel the loss, but not the friend Which you weep for.keep time: how sour sweet music is, When time is broke and no proportion kept!Give me thy hand: Come.Come, let's go: I am the king's friend, and will rid his foe.O God's lady dear!thy priesthood saves thy life.Bloody thou art, bloody will be thy end; Shame serves thy life and doth thy death attend.So could I, faith, boy, to have the next wish after, That Lucentio indeed had Baptista's youngest daughter.forgot.Speak like a true knight, so defend thee heaven!Woe doth the heavier sit, Where it perceives it is but faintly borne.O, then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do; They pray, grant thou, lest faith turn to despair.Art thou gone so?Ah, Warwick!Ay, if the devil tempt thee to do good.Marshal, demand of yonder champion The cause of his arrival here in arms: Ask him his name and orderly proceed To swear him in the justice of his cause.Young Ned, for thee, thine uncles and myself Have in our armours watch'd the winter's night, Went all afoot in summer's scalding heat, That thou mightst repossess the crown in peace; And of our labours thou shalt reap the gain.Ay, but not mine own desire.Pitiful sight!My noble masters, hear me speak.unconstant womankind!It is too heavy for your grace to wear.One word more; I charge thee That thou attend me: thou dost here usurp The name thou owest not; and hast put thyself Upon this island as a spy, to win it From me, the lord on't.Would they make peace?Nay then you jest, and now I well perceive You have but jested with me all this while: I prithee, sister Kate, untie my hands.I'll leave my son my virtuous deeds behind; And would my father had left me no more!make haste, lest mine be about your ears ere it be out.Full of wise care is this your counsel, madam.The augurer tells me we shall have news to-night.Royal commanders, be in readiness: For with a band of thirty thousand men Comes Warwick, backing of the Duke of York; And in the towns, as they do march along, Proclaims him king, and many fly to him: Darraign your battle, for they are at hand.Then I salute you with this kingly title: Long live Richard, England's royal king!Therefore he sends to know your lordship's pleasure, If presently you will take horse with him, And with all speed post with him toward the north, To shun the danger that his soul divines.Here comes the Duke of York.Ay me, I see the downfall of our house!Very ready, sir.I boarded the king's ship; now on the beak, Now in the waist, the deck, in every cabin, I flamed amazement: sometime I'ld divide, And burn in many places; on the topmast, The yards and bowsprit, would I flame distinctly, Then meet and join.Art thou sure of this?Not proud, you have; but thankful, that you have: Proud can I never be of what I hate; But thankful even for hate, that is meant love.As certain as I know the sun is fire: Where have you lurk'd, that you make doubt of it?Hortensio, hark: This gentleman is happily arrived, My mind presumes, for his own good and ours.what comfort have we now?I must confess your offer is the best; And, let your father make her the assurance, She is your own; else, you must pardon me, if you should die before him, where's her dower?Have mercy, Jesu!--Soft!Come you to make confession to this father?You should account me the more virtuous that I have not been common in my love.What, ho!Romeo!We stay here for the people.So just is God, to right the innocent.No more than when my daughters call thee mother.Why grow the branches now the root is wither'd?Good my lord, forbear: The ruddiness upon her lip is wet; You'll mar it if you kiss it, stain your own With oily painting.So you must be the first that gives this sentence, And he, that suffer's.Uncomfortable time, why camest thou now To murder, murder our solemnity?To brag unto them, thus I did, and thus; Show them the unaching scars which I should hide, As if I had received them for the hire Of their breath only!I am sorry, Most sorry, you have broken from his liking Where you were tied in duty, and as sorry Your choice is not so rich in worth as beauty, That you might well enjoy her.and he's gone.Father, be quiet; he shall stay my leisure.Cotus!The ditty does remember my drown'd father.The gods assist you!No, but there's a woman with maid by him.What you command, that rests in me to do.Nay then, I will not: you shall have the mustard, Or else you get no beef of Grumio.Let be, let be.He, more incensed against your majesty Than all the rest, discharged me with these words: 'Tell him from me that he hath done me wrong, And therefore I'll uncrown him ere't be long.'Now, my lord, what shall we do, if we perceive Lord Hastings will not yield to our complots?although I be not he; And yet, amen, if heaven do think him me.Is the duke gone?alas!Why the devil came you between us?With other muniments and petty helps In this our fabric, if that they-- What then?One thus descended, That hath beside well in his person wrought To be set high in place, we did commend To your remembrances: but you have found, Scaling his present bearing with his past, That he's your fixed enemy, and revoke Your sudden approbation.Ill mayst thou thrive, if thou grant any grace!Thou hast.Know you this woman?You guard like men; 'tis well: but, by your leave, I am an officer of state, and come To speak with Coriolanus.The aediles, ho!Methinks King Richard and myself should meet With no less terror than the elements Of fire and water, when their thundering shock At meeting tears the cloudy cheeks of heaven.how accursed In being so blest!what old or newer torture Must I receive, whose every word deserves To taste of thy most worst?The commons will not then be satisfied.This is that face, thou cruel Angelo, Which once thou sworest was worth the looking on; This is the hand which, with a vow'd contract, Was fast belock'd in thine; this is the body That took away the match from Isabel, And did supply thee at thy garden-house In her imagined person.where is my lovely bride?The news I have to tell your majesty Is, that by sudden floods and fall of waters, Buckingham's army is dispersed and scatter'd; And he himself wander'd away alone, No man knows whither.O friar, the damned use that word in hell; Howlings attend it: how hast thou the heart, Being a divine, a ghostly confessor, A sin-absolver, and my friend profess'd, To mangle me with that word 'banished'?You shall not choose but drink before you go: I think I shall command your welcome here, And, by all likelihood, some cheer is toward.Is there a murderer here?A little more lenity to lechery would do no harm in him: something too crabbed that way, friar.This dead king to the living king I'll bear Take hence the rest, and give them burial here.never more come in my sight.Welcome, dear cousin, my thoughts' sovereign The weary way hath made you melancholy.No; I will resist such entertainment till Mine enemy has more power.Boy!Fairer than tongue can name thee, let me have Some patient leisure to excuse myself.So is the dear'st o' the loss.As we paced along Upon the giddy footing of the hatches, Methought that Gloucester stumbled; and, in falling, Struck me, that thought to stay him, overboard, Into the tumbling billows of the main.We will meet them, And help the joy.Her father is Baptista Minola, An affable and courteous gentleman: Her name is Katharina Minola, Renown'd in Padua for her scolding tongue.The game was ne'er so fair, and I am done.Thou shouldst a husband take by my consent, As I by thine a wife: this is a match, And made between's by vows.No; if without more words you will get you hence.Worshipful mutiners, Your valour puts well forth: pray, follow.Even here undone!Gramercies, Tranio, well dost thou advise.'Tis well borne up.'Tis more, 'tis more, his son is elder, sir; His son is thirty.Of Mantua, sir?Still, 'tis strange He thus should steal upon us.Yes, I agree, and thank you for your motion.I'll tell you what, my cousin Buckingham,-- What, my gracious lord?If you do, sir, I am for you: I serve as good a man as you.Alack!More welcome is the stroke of death to me Than Bolingbroke to England.Take good Cominius With thee awhile: determine on some course, More than a wild exposture to each chance That starts i' the way before thee.It is the lark that sings so out of tune, Straining harsh discords and unpleasing sharps.I was too hot to do somebody good, That is too cold in thinking of it now.By accident most strange, bountiful Fortune, Now my dear lady, hath mine enemies Brought to this shore; and by my prescience I find my zenith doth depend upon A most auspicious star, whose influence If now I court not but omit, my fortunes Will ever after droop.But, O thou tyrant!truly, gentlemen, A bloody tyrant and a homicide; One raised in blood, and one in blood establish'd; One that made means to come by what he hath, And slaughter'd those that were the means to help him; Abase foul stone, made precious by the foil Of England's chair, where he is falsely set; One that hath ever been God's enemy: Then, if you fight against God's enemy, God will in justice ward you as his soldiers; If you do sweat to put a tyrant down, You sleep in peace, the tyrant being slain; If you do fight against your country's foes, Your country's fat shall pay your pains the hire; If you do fight in safeguard of your wives, Your wives shall welcome home the conquerors; If you do free your children from the sword, Your children's children quit it in your age.His garments are rich, but he wears them not handsomely.Banished, sir.Down: an end; This is the last: so we will home to Rome, And die among our neighbours.A hundred, if they'll do you any good.O, sir, you must: and therefore I beseech you Look forward on the journey you shall go.Pardon me, Edward, I will make amends: And, Richard, do not frown upon my faults, For I will henceforth be no more unconstant.We shall be shorten'd in our aim, which was To take in many towns ere almost Rome Should know we were afoot.no.That's my good son: but where hast thou been, then?So other foes may set upon our backs.That dreamers often lie.You will not pay for the glasses you have burst?When thou camest first, Thou strokedst me and madest much of me, wouldst give me Water with berries in't, and teach me how To name the bigger light, and how the less, That burn by day and night: and then I loved thee And show'd thee all the qualities o' the isle, The fresh springs, brine-pits, barren place and fertile: Cursed be I that did so!Witness my son, now in the shade of death; Whose bright out-shining beams thy cloudy wrath Hath in eternal darkness folded up.What is your quarrel?Whither?Wherein the king stands generally condemn'd.Bondage is hoarse, and may not speak aloud; Else would I tear the cave where Echo lies, And make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine, With repetition of my Romeo's name.Why, how now, Kate!If you affect him, sister, here I swear I'll plead for you myself, but you shall have him.Sir Christopher, tell Richmond this from me: That in the sty of this most bloody boar My son George Stanley is frank'd up in hold: If I revolt, off goes young George's head; The fear of that withholds my present aid.Prevent it, resist it, let it not be so, Lest child, child's children, cry against you woe!Be plain, good son, and homely in thy drift; Riddling confession finds but riddling shrift.Why should I carry lies abroad?Gentle Isabella, Turn you the key, and know his business of him; You may, I may not; you are yet unsworn.At what hour to-morrow Shall I attend your lordship?O Tranio, till I found it to be true, I never thought it possible or likely; But see, while idly I stood looking on, I found the effect of love in idleness: And now in plainness do confess to thee, That art to me as secret and as dear As Anna to the queen of Carthage was, Tranio, I burn, I pine, I perish, Tranio, If I achieve not this young modest girl.Thou that so stoutly hast resisted me, Give me thy gold, if thou hast any gold: For I have bought it with an hundred blows.Directitude!Look, the unfolding star calls up the shepherd.Your enigma?Why give you me this shame?Lest I might be too rash: Under your good correction, I have seen, When, after execution, judgment hath Repented o'er his doom.Comfort, my liege; remember who you are.What are you, sir?Say, then, my peace is made.And will you pale your head in Henry's glory, And rob his temples of the diadem, Now in his life, against your holy oath?Then thus: I have from Port le Blanc, a bay In Brittany, received intelligence That Harry Duke of Hereford, Rainold Lord Cobham, That late broke from the Duke of Exeter, His brother, Archbishop late of Canterbury, Sir Thomas Erpingham, Sir John Ramston, Sir John Norbery, Sir Robert Waterton and Francis Quoint, All these well furnish'd by the Duke of Bretagne With eight tall ships, three thousand men of war, Are making hither with all due expedience And shortly mean to touch our northern shore: Perhaps they had ere this, but that they stay The first departing of the king for Ireland.Thou hast hit it: come, sit on me.O heavens!If I would yield him my virginity, Thou mightst be freed.Thou old and true Menenius, Thy tears are salter than a younger man's, And venomous to thine eyes.Why, then resolve me whether you will or no.What an arm he has!Weep I cannot, But my heart bleeds; and most accursed am I To be by oath enjoin'd to this.O, he's a limb that has but a disease; Mortal, to cut it off; to cure it, easy.But say, my lord, it were not register'd, Methinks the truth should live from age to age, As 'twere retail'd to all posterity, Even to the general all-ending day.Now, good Camillo; I am so fraught with curious business that I leave out ceremony.To me can life be no commodity: The crown and comfort of my life, your favour, I do give lost; for I do feel it gone, But know not how it went.Yes, if you will, my lord.Can it be That modesty may more betray our sense Than woman's lightness?No, take more: What may be sworn by, both divine and human, Seal what I end withal!The service of the foot Being once gangrened, is not then respected For what before it was.Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.I think 'twill serve, if he Can thereto frame his spirit.My true Paulina, We shall not marry till thou bid'st us.He'll be hang'd yet, Though every drop of water swear against it And gape at widest to glut him.She's very near her hour.Let them puff all about mine ears, present me Death on the wheel or at wild horses' heels, Or pile ten hills on the Tarpeian rock, That the precipitation might down stretch Below the beam of sight, yet will I still Be thus to them.Now, Thomas Mowbray, do I turn to thee, And mark my greeting well; for what I speak My body shall make good upon this earth, Or my divine soul answer it in heaven.Peace, I have done.wherein dost thou, joy?My husband lost his life to get the crown; And often up and down my sons were toss'd, For me to joy and weep their gain and loss: And being seated, and domestic broils Clean over-blown, themselves, the conquerors.Take the boy to you: he so troubles me, 'Tis past enduring.Lay hands on the villain: I believe a' means to cozen somebody in this city under my countenance.'Alla nostra casa ben venuto, molto honorato signor mio Petruchio.'Always obedient to your grace's will, I come to know your pleasure.Lord, let me never have a cause to sigh, Till I be brought to such a silly pass!What, no man at door To hold my stirrup nor to take my horse!Clifford, devise excuses for thy faults.Yes, better, sir.Where is the post that came from Montague?I am greater than a king: For when I was a king, my flatterers Were then but subjects; being now a subject, I have a king here to my flatterer.Prove it, Henry, and thou shalt be king.speak, I pray you.Eyes, look your last!They, for their truth, might better wear their heads Than some that have accused them wear their hats.I muse my mother Does not approve me further, who was wont To call them woollen vassals, things created To buy and sell with groats, to show bare heads In congregations, to yawn, be still and wonder, When one but of my ordinance stood up To speak of peace or war.the fatal followers do pursue; And I am faint and cannot fly their fury: And were I strong, I would not shun their fury: The sands are number'd that make up my life; Here must I stay, and here my life must end.Ten the clock there.I would not be a stander-by to hear My sovereign mistress clouded so, without My present vengeance taken: 'shrew my heart, You never spoke what did become you less Than this; which to reiterate were sin As deep as that, though true.O, then my best blood turn To an infected jelly and my name Be yoked with his that did betray the Best!How well resembles it the prime of youth, Trimm'd like a younker prancing to his love!O thou bloody prison, Fatal and ominous to noble peers!Why have you not proclaim'd Northumberland And all the rest revolted faction traitors?I am, as thy general is.Within this mile and half.Not at all, good lady: You might have spoken a thousand things that would Have done the time more benefit and graced Your kindness better.Are you my wife and will not call me husband?On whom depending, their obedience fails To the greater bench: in a rebellion, When what's not meet, but what must be, was law, Then were they chosen: in a better hour, Let what is meet be said it must be meet, And throw their power i' the dust.The god of soldiers, With the consent of supreme Jove, inform Thy thoughts with nobleness; that thou mayst prove To shame unvulnerable, and stick i' the wars Like a great sea-mark, standing every flaw, And saving those that eye thee!O Paulina, We honour you with trouble: but we came To see the statue of our queen: your gallery Have we pass'd through, not without much content In many singularities; but we saw not That which my daughter came to look upon, The statue of her mother.Now therefore let us hence; and lose no hour, Till we meet Warwick with his foreign power.whence are you?My liege, one word.I speak not this as doubting any here For did I but suspect a fearful man He should have leave to go away betimes, Lest in our need he might infect another And make him of like spirit to himself.And speaking it, he wistly look'd on me, And who should say, 'I would thou wert the man' That would divorce this terror from my heart;' Meaning the king at Pomfret.Murder her brothers, and then marry her!Thank you.And that same vengeance doth he hurl on thee, For false forswearing and for murder too: Thou didst receive the holy sacrament, To fight in quarrel of the house of Lancaster.Why, then, though loath, yet must I be content: We'll yoke together, like a double shadow To Henry's body, and supply his place; I mean, in bearing weight of government, While he enjoys the honour and his ease.To the palace, an it like your worship.Thus hath the course of justice wheel'd about, And left thee but a very prey to time; Having no more but thought of what thou wert, To torture thee the more, being what thou art.Let not the heavens hear these tell-tale women Rail on the Lord's enointed: strike, I say!For God's sake, let us sit upon the ground And tell sad stories of the death of kings; How some have been deposed; some slain in war, Some haunted by the ghosts they have deposed; Some poison'd by their wives: some sleeping kill'd; All murder'd: for within the hollow crown That rounds the mortal temples of a king Keeps Death his court and there the antic sits, Scoffing his state and grinning at his pomp, Allowing him a breath, a little scene, To monarchize, be fear'd and kill with looks, Infusing him with self and vain conceit, As if this flesh which walls about our life, Were brass impregnable, and humour'd thus Comes at the last and with a little pin Bores through his castle wall, and farewell king!Plots have I laid, inductions dangerous, By drunken prophecies, libels and dreams, To set my brother Clarence and the king In deadly hate the one against the other: And if King Edward be as true and just As I am subtle, false and treacherous, This day should Clarence closely be mew'd up, About a prophecy, which says that 'G' Of Edward's heirs the murderer shall be.It did, it did; alas the day, it did!I'll have no halves; I'll bear it all myself.Where are your mess of sons to back you now?This but done, Even as she speaks, why, their hearts were yours; For they have pardons, being ask'd, as free As words to little purpose.Aufidius, and you Volsces, mark; for we'll Hear nought from Rome in private.What's here?Well, well see't.After my death the one half of my lands, And in possession twenty thousand crowns.Tribunes, withdraw awhile.Now, where's my wife?Away with her; go, bear her hence perforce.The smallest worm will turn being trodden on, And doves will peck in safeguard of their brood.Ay, but he's dead: off with the traitor's head, And rear it in the place your father's stands.Hang thee, young baggage!Well, say there is no kingdom then for Richard; What other pleasure can the world afford?In brief, sir, sith it your pleasure is, And I am tied to be obedient; For so your father charged me at our parting, 'Be serviceable to my son,' quoth he, Although I think 'twas in another sense; I am content to be Lucentio, Because so well I love Lucentio.Like a dull actor now, I have forgot my part, and I am out, Even to a full disgrace.Away!Farewell, York's wife, and queen of sad mischance: These English woes will make me smile in France.Ah, one that was a woful looker-on When as the noble Duke of York was slain, Your princely father and my loving lord!Press me not, beseech you, so.Base men by his endowments are made great.We are tougher, brother, Than you can put us to't.If the law would allow it, sir.What was done to Elbow's wife, that he hath cause to complain of?have you married my daughter without asking my good will?I cannot blame her: by God's holy mother, She hath had too much wrong; and I repent My part thereof that I have done to her.Well, give me the moiety.I would these dewy tears were from the ground.By the king.Sir, understand you this of me in sooth: The youngest daughter whom you hearken for Her father keeps from all access of suitors, And will not promise her to any man Until the elder sister first be wed: The younger then is free and not before.He did.Gentlemen, will you go muster men?I' the name of me-- O, help me, help me!What then?and yet thou wilt tutor me from quarrelling!You are three That Rome should dote on: yet, by the faith of men, We have some old crab-trees here at home that will not Be grafted to your relish.Go, see him out at gates, and follow him, As he hath followed you, with all despite; Give him deserved vexation.Now for the rebels which stand out in Ireland, Expedient manage must be made, my liege, Ere further leisure yield them further means For their advantage and your highness' loss.O, sir, sir, sir, I would have had you put your power well on, Before you had worn it out.One that I would were here, Friar Lodowick.Here's snip and nip and cut and slish and slash, Like to a censer in a barber's shop: Why, what, i' devil's name, tailor, call'st thou this?Bastards and all.Then, worthy Marcius, Attend upon Cominius to these wars.Shall I seem crest-fall'n in my father's sight?Sir, believe this, I had rather give my body than my soul.Ah, would the scandal vanish with my life, How happy then were my ensuing death!Turn, good lady; Our Perdita is found.Say you so?Hence, and shut your gates upon's.Hath Romeo slain himself?Throng our large temples with the shows of peace, And not our streets with war!Norfolk, for thee remains a heavier doom, Which I with some unwillingness pronounce: The sly slow hours shall not determinate The dateless limit of thy dear exile; The hopeless word of 'never to return' Breathe I against thee, upon pain of life.O villains, vipers, damn'd without redemption!No, to White-Friars; there attend my coining.To help King Edward in his time of storm, As every loyal subject ought to do.Or I'll be thine, my fair, Or not my father's.Yet, ere thou go, but answer me one doubt, What pledge have we of thy firm loyalty?Well, Juliet, I will lie with thee to-night.What a blow was there given!But for my daughter Katharina, this I know, She is not for your turn, the more my grief.So looks the pent-up lion o'er the wretch That trembles under his devouring paws; And so he walks, insulting o'er his prey, And so he comes, to rend his limbs asunder.By love, who first did prompt me to inquire; He lent me counsel and I lent him eyes.Dally not with the gods, but get thee gone.None good, my lord, to please you with the hearing; Nor none so bad, but it may well be told.Gentlemen and friends, I thank you for your pains: I know you think to dine with me to-day, And have prepared great store of wedding cheer; But so it is, my haste doth call me hence, And therefore here I mean to take my leave.Swinge me them soundly forth unto their husbands: Away, I say, and bring them hither straight.Are you a party in this business?Methought the souls of all that I had murder'd Came to my tent; and every one did threat To-morrow's vengeance on the head of Richard.Thou didst love York, and I am son to York.Love talks with better knowledge, and knowledge with dearer love.Know man from man?Shall I obtain it?Gramercy, fellow: there, drink that for me.If it be ne'er so false, a true gentleman may swear it in the behalf of his friend: and I'll swear to the prince thou art a tall fellow of thy hands and that thou wilt not be drunk; but I know thou art no tall fellow of thy hands and that thou wilt be drunk: but I'll swear it, and I would thou wouldst be a tall fellow of thy hands.He'll stay my lord.I, sir!Rivers and Dorset, you were standers by, And so wast thou, Lord Hastings, when my son Was stabb'd with bloody daggers: God, I pray him, That none of you may live your natural age, But by some unlook'd accident cut off!Ere you were queen, yea, or your husband king, I was a pack-horse in his great affairs; A weeder-out of his proud adversaries, A liberal rewarder of his friends: To royalize his blood I spilt mine own.For instance, sir, That you may know you shall not want, one word.While I remain above the ground, you shall Hear from me still, and never of me aught But what is like me formerly.Your followers I will whisper to the business, And will by twos and threes at several posterns Clear them o' the city.'Tis a good hearing when children are toward.O, you have made good work!My name is Caius Marcius, who hath done To thee particularly and to all the Volsces Great hurt and mischief; thereto witness may My surname, Coriolanus: the painful service, The extreme dangers and the drops of blood Shed for my thankless country are requited But with that surname; a good memory, And witness of the malice and displeasure Which thou shouldst bear me: only that name remains; The cruelty and envy of the people, Permitted by our dastard nobles, who Have all forsook me, hath devour'd the rest; And suffer'd me by the voice of slaves to be Whoop'd out of Rome.My power?Welcome, my lords.Noble tribunes, It is the humane way: the other course Will prove too bloody, and the end of it Unknown to the beginning.How far is it, my lord, to Berkeley now?A rhyme I learn'd even now Of one I danced withal.Or, if I live, is it not very like, The horrible conceit of death and night, Together with the terror of the place,-- As in a vault, an ancient receptacle, Where, for these many hundred years, the bones Of all my buried ancestors are packed: Where bloody Tybalt, yet but green in earth, Lies festering in his shroud; where, as they say, At some hours in the night spirits resort;-- Alack, alack, is it not like that I, So early waking, what with loathsome smells, And shrieks like mandrakes' torn out of the earth, That living mortals, hearing them, run mad:-- O, if I wake, shall I not be distraught, Environed with all these hideous fears?As much unto my good lord chamberlain!tribunes for them!-- The mouse ne'er shunn'd the cat as they did budge From rascals worse than they.There may be in the cup A spider steep'd, and one may drink, depart, And yet partake no venom, for his knowledge Is not infected: but if one present The abhorr'd ingredient to his eye, make known How he hath drunk, he cracks his gorge, his sides, With violent hefts.Here is for thy pains.Have you not heard speak of Mariana, the sister of Frederick the great soldier who miscarried at sea?Let us kill him, and we'll have corn at our own price.Be advised.O, that's the case of the shepherd's son: hang him, he'll be made an example.At Crosby Place, there shall you find us both.apothecary!hush!That thou hast wronged in the time o'erpast; For I myself have many tears to wash Hereafter time, for time past wrong'd by thee.Good even, good father.I am the best of them that speak this speech, Were I but where 'tis spoken.Where is the provost?Or shall we on without a apology?Every letter he hath writ hath disvouched other.Measureless liar, thou hast made my heart Too great for what contains it.Blossom, speed thee well!Their aunt I am in law, in love their mother: Then bring me to their sights; I'll bear thy blame And take thy office from thee, on my peril.While she lives My heart will be a burthen to me.My lord, dispatch; read o'er these articles.nay, what are you, sir?Then thou wert best say that I am not Lucentio.Sir, I shall tell you.And thus I seal my truth, and bid adieu.How fares our cousin, noble Lord of York?Then further, all dissembling set aside, Tell me for truth the measure of his love Unto our sister Bona.Stay, fellow; I can read.Simple, plain Clarence!give me some aqua vitae: These griefs, these woes, these sorrows make me old.I do, my lord.hath he been in thy heart?reflect I not on thy baseness court-contempt?My land amounts not to so much in all: That she shall have; besides an argosy That now is lying in Marseilles' road.Foul devil, for God's sake, hence, and trouble us not; For thou hast made the happy earth thy hell, Fill'd it with cursing cries and deep exclaims.O villain!Provide the feast, father, and bid the guests; I will be sure my Katharina shall be fine.What are you sewing here?Come, I'll fill your grave up: stir, nay, come away, Bequeath to death your numbness, for from him Dear life redeems you.We are amazed; and thus long have we stood To watch the fearful bending of thy knee, Because we thought ourself thy lawful king: And if we be, how dare thy joints forget To pay their awful duty to our presence?I told you what would come of this: beseech you, Of your own state take care: this dream of mine,-- Being now awake, I'll queen it no inch farther, But milk my ewes and weep.3 KING HENRY VI Good day, my lord.O Isabel!Thy husband in thy bosom there lies dead; And Paris too.We still have known thee for a holy man.Very well.O you beast!Whose soul is that which takes her heavy leave?Father, and wife, and gentlemen, adieu; I will to Venice; Sunday comes apace: We will have rings and things and fine array; And kiss me, Kate, we will be married o'Sunday.My lord protector needs will have it so.You make my bonds still greater.Grandam, one night, as we did sit at supper, My uncle Rivers talk'd how I did grow More than my brother: 'Ay,' quoth my uncle Gloucester, 'Small herbs have grace, great weeds do grow apace:' And since, methinks, I would not grow so fast, Because sweet flowers are slow and weeds make haste.Alack, my lord, that fault is none of yours; He should, for that, commit your godfathers: O, belike his majesty hath some intent That you shall be new-christen'd in the Tower.Why then should I be consul?But, sure, if you Would be your country's pleader, your good tongue, More than the instant army we can make, Might stop our countryman.We do not know How he may soften at the sight o' the child: The silence often of pure innocence Persuades when speaking fails.But to make an end of the ship, to see how the sea flap-dragoned it: but, first, how the poor souls roared, and the sea mocked them; and how the poor gentleman roared and the bear mocked him, both roaring louder than the sea or weather.You shall have wine enough, my lord, anon.And, Norfolk, throw down his.need you my help?Had thy brethren here, their lives and thine Were not revenge sufficient for me; No, if I digg'd up thy forefathers' graves And hung their rotten coffins up in chains, It could not slake mine ire, nor ease my heart.Well; come to me to-morrow.Ay, but, I fear me, in another sense.Thieves for their robbery have authority When judges steal themselves.Thou didst prevent me; I had peopled else This isle with Calibans.Now mark me, how I will undo myself; I give this heavy weight from off my head And this unwieldy sceptre from my hand, The pride of kingly sway from out my heart; With mine own tears I wash away my balm, With mine own hands I give away my crown, With mine own tongue deny my sacred state, With mine own breath release all duty's rites: All pomp and majesty I do forswear; My manors, rents, revenues I forego; My acts, decrees, and statutes I deny: God pardon all oaths that are broke to me!Remember 'stoned,' and 'flayed alive.'Why, here's a change indeed in the commonwealth!say what; what shall I do?Look not to the ground, Ye favourites of a king: are we not high?What lawful quest have given their verdict up Unto the frowning judge?ha!Why, so: now have I done a good day's work: You peers, continue this united league: I every day expect an embassage From my Redeemer to redeem me hence; And now in peace my soul shall part to heaven, Since I have set my friends at peace on earth.Lords, to the field; Saint George and victory!Pardon me, noble lord: I thought it was a fault, but knew it not; Yet did repent me, after more advice; For testimony whereof, one in the prison, That should by private order else have died, I have reserved alive.Why, how now, sons and brother!But be it; let it live.thou may'st hear Minerva speak.Good morrow, Richmond!Let me stand here till thou remember it.What if a man bring him a hundred pound or two, to make merry withal?Alas!Alack.Is this the promise that you made your mother?And must we be divided?Yield to our mercy, proud Plantagenet.O, mickle is the powerful grace that lies In herbs, plants, stones, and their true qualities: For nought so vile that on the earth doth live But to the earth some special good doth give, Nor aught so good but strain'd from that fair use Revolts from true birth, stumbling on abuse: Virtue itself turns vice, being misapplied; And vice sometimes by action dignified.He cannot temperately transport his honours From where he should begin and end, but will Lose those he hath won.Bushy, what news?You worthy tribunes,-- He shall be thrown down the Tarpeian rock With rigorous hands: he hath resisted law, And therefore law shall scorn him further trial Than the severity of the public power Which he so sets at nought.This afternoon, sir?Madam, before you touch the instrument, To learn the order of my fingering, I must begin with rudiments of art; To teach you gamut in a briefer sort, More pleasant, pithy and effectual, Than hath been taught by any of my trade: And there it is in writing, fairly drawn.My life thou shalt command, but not my shame: The one my duty owes; but my fair name, Despite of death that lives upon my grave, To dark dishonour's use thou shalt not have.Fare you well.But thus, I trust, you will not marry her.Then, good prince, No longer session hold upon my shame, But let my trial be mine own confession: Immediate sentence then and sequent death Is all the grace I beg.You will be there, I know.Thy drugs are quick.Say you can swim; alas, 'tis but a while!Indeed, I am no mourner for that news, Because they have been still mine enemies: But, that I'll give my voice on Richard's side, To bar my master's heirs in true descent, God knows I will not do it, to the death.To fight with Glendower and his complices: Awhile to work, and after holiday.She says you have some goodly jest in hand: She will not come: she bids you come to her.Dispatch, I prithee.What, think You we are Turks or infidels?You, Lord Escalus, Sit with my cousin; lend him your kind pains To find out this abuse, whence 'tis derived.Not of this country, though my chance is now To use it for my time: I am a brother Of gracious order, late come from the See In special business from his holiness.'Twas you incensed the rabble: Cats, that can judge as fitly of his worth As I can of those mysteries which heaven Will not have earth to know.I think 'twas Soto that your honour means.Let's hear.For me, that I may surely keep mine oath, I will be married to a wealthy widow, Ere three days pass, which hath as long loved me As I have loved this proud disdainful haggard.Good sometime queen, prepare thee hence for France: Think I am dead and that even here thou takest, As from my death-bed, thy last living leave.Poor girl!In brief,--for so the season bids us be,-- Prepare thy battle early in the morning, And put thy fortune to the arbitrement Of bloody strokes and mortal-staring war.But, as you will not wed, I'll pardon you: Graze where you will you shall not house with me: Look to't, think on't, I do not use to jest.Honest goodfellows, ah, put up, put up; For, well you know, this is a pitiful case.Tell him his fears are shallow, wanting instance: And for his dreams, I wonder he is so fond To trust the mockery of unquiet slumbers To fly the boar before the boar pursues, Were to incense the boar to follow us And make pursuit where he did mean no chase.Mistress!Pray you, my lord, give me leave to question; you shall see how I'll handle her.Farewell, my sovereign.Good uncle, help to order several powers To Oxford, or where'er these traitors are: They shall not live within this world, I swear, But I will have them, if I once know where.Romeo.But, good sir, What peace you'll make, advise me: for my part, I'll not to Rome, I'll back with you; and pray you, Stand to me in this cause.O Richard!A thousand welcomes!O loving hate!O, no!Help, masters, help!Hath he not pass'd the noble and the common?The nobility are vex'd, whom we see have sided In his behalf.His name and credit shall you undertake, And in my house you shall be friendly lodged: Look that you take upon you as you should; You understand me, sir: so shall you stay Till you have done your business in the city: If this be courtesy, sir, accept of it.I have stay'd for thee, God knows, in anguish, pain and agony.They do you wrong to put you so oft upon 't: are there not men in your ward sufficient to serve it?What, ho!O, death's a great disguiser; and you may add to it.Nay, it is ten times strange.I pray, sir, can you read?I'll draw the curtain: My lord's almost so far transported that He'll think anon it lives.Now this extremity Hath brought me to thy hearth; not out of hope-- Mistake me not--to save my life, for if I had fear'd death, of all the men i' the world I would have 'voided thee, but in mere spite, To be full quit of those my banishers, Stand I before thee here.my wife!She may do more, sir, than denying that: She may help you to many fair preferments, And then deny her aiding hand therein, And lay those honours on your high deserts.Pray heartily he be at palace.And who durst mine when Warwick bent his brow?What is your will, sir, that you send for me?and now again Of him that did not ask, but mock, bestow Your sued-for tongues?Was this the face that faced so many follies, And was at last out-faced by Bolingbroke?'Bless you, friar.By and by!Ah, Juliet, I already know thy grief; It strains me past the compass of my wits: I hear thou must, and nothing may prorogue it, On Thursday next be married to this county.let the Volsces Plough Rome and harrow Italy: I'll never Be such a gosling to obey instinct, but stand, As if a man were author of himself And knew no other kin.as I discern, It burneth in the Capel's monument.I tell thee, fellow, The general is my lover: I have been The book of his good acts, whence men have read His name unparallel'd, haply amplified; For I have ever verified my friends, Of whom he's chief, with all the size that verity Would without lapsing suffer: nay, sometimes, Like to a bowl upon a subtle ground, I have tumbled past the throw; and in his praise Have almost stamp'd the leasing: therefore, fellow, I must have leave to pass.I paint him in the character.Spread thy close curtain, love-performing night, That runaway's eyes may wink and Romeo Leap to these arms, untalk'd of and unseen.victory sits on our helms.No, uncle; but our crosses on the way Have made it tedious, wearisome, and heavy I want more uncles here to welcome me.A god on earth thou art.Shame come to Romeo!Dark cloudy death o'ershades his beams of life, And he nor sees nor hears us what we say.Some water, here; what, ho!You mean, to bear me, not to bear with me: Uncle, my brother mocks both you and me; Because that I am little, like an ape, He thinks that you should bear me on your shoulders.Go, get you home, you fragments!Didst thou not mark the king, what words he spake, 'Have I no friend will rid me of this living fear?'But mark me; To be received plain, I'll speak more gross: Your brother is to die.Come hither, England's hope.We were not born to sue, but to command; Which since we cannot do to make you friends, Be ready, as your lives shall answer it, At Coventry, upon Saint Lambert's day: There shall your swords and lances arbitrate The swelling difference of your settled hate: Since we can not atone you, we shall see Justice design the victor's chivalry.O, pity, God, this miserable age!Camillo?I tell thee, Licio, this is wonderful.Apollo plays, And twenty caged nightingales do sing: Or wilt thou sleep?A' will make the man mad, to make a woman of him.The time to come.But shall all our houses of resort in the suburbs be pulled down?Menenius, you are known well enough too.What reply, ha?In leads or oils?Not Gloucester's death, nor Hereford's banishment Not Gaunt's rebukes, nor England's private wrongs, Nor the prevention of poor Bolingbroke About his marriage, nor my own disgrace, Have ever made me sour my patient cheek, Or bend one wrinkle on my sovereign's face.O, let my sovereign turn away his face And bid his ears a little while be deaf, Till I have told this slander of his blood, How God and good men hate so foul a liar.I mean, thy general.I' the shoulder and i' the left arm there will be large cicatrices to show the people, when he shall stand for his place.Know, good mother, I had rather be their servant in my way, Than sway with them in theirs.Now breathe we, lords: good fortune bids us pause, And smooth the frowns of war with peaceful looks.I think it well: And from this testimony of your own sex,-- Since I suppose we are made to be no stronger Than faults may shake our frames,--let me be bold; I do arrest your words.'Tis true: If he were putting to my house the brand That should consume it, I have not the face To say 'Beseech you, cease.'My lord, Is this the daughter of a king?Heavens thank you for't!A herald, Kate?Sir, if you'ld save your life, fly to your house: The plebeians have got your fellow-tribune And hale him up and down, all swearing, if The Roman ladies bring not comfort home, They'll give him death by inches.Be collected: No more amazement: tell your piteous heart There's no harm done.Where are the evidence that do accuse me?We will descend and fold him in our arms.Yea, my lord.Peruse this writing here, and thou shalt know The treason that my haste forbids me show.Jove's lightnings, the precursors O' the dreadful thunder-claps, more momentary And sight-outrunning were not; the fire and cracks Of sulphurous roaring the most mighty Neptune Seem to besiege and make his bold waves tremble, Yea, his dread trident shake.Nature teaches beasts to know their friends.I must perforce.Show your knave's visage, with a pox to you!
